column2: LEAD: ''We knew we had to stay on the air. If television falls, the revolution falls. That's for certain.'' -Eugenia Bogdan, an employee of Free Rumanian Television. [ A1:4. ]

LEAD: ONE of the newest things in the world of roses is the rediscovery of old roses. Gallicas and Damasks and Centifolias with a European history going back in some cases to Bronze Age Crete are blooming anew. So are Bourbons and Noisettes and other classes of roses hybridized in the 19th century from European species and forms of Rosa chinensis collected in the

LEAD: State regulators, spurred by the collapse of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, intend to prohibit the sale of high-risk ''junk bonds'' from the offices of California's state-chartered savings institutions.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The recent success of a squad of American collegiate All-Stars playing an elite Soviet touring team was significant on two counts. The games met with enthusiastic responses in two Southern cities, Orlando, Fla., and Dallas, and the United States skaters were competitive on a world-class level.
LEAD: The Vatican appeared today to reject President Bush's argument that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega was a common criminal who should be handed over to the United States for trial.
LEAD: The investment group making a $10-a-share offer for the Dataproducts Corporation said it had changed its financial adviser, replacing the Chase Manhattan Bank with Paine Webber Inc.

LEAD: Gerald Perry, a starting tackle for the Denver Broncos, was sentenced yesterday in Aurora, Colo., to 15 days in jail, beginning Feb. 5, and was fined $610 after he was convicted of having solicited a prostitute.
LEAD: Bruce Coslet, coordinator of the Cincinnati Bengals' high-tech, no-huddle offense, will be interviewed for the Jets' vacant head-coaching job.

LEAD: Tom Chambers, a Phoenix Suns forward, fractured his left cheekbone slightly and suffered a cut requiring 14 stitches in Tuesday night's victory over Portland at Phoenix, X-rays taken yesterday by the team surgeon, Dr. Richard Emerson, showed. The injury occurred when Chambers dived for a rebound and was elbowed accidentally by the Blazers' Kevin Duckworth.(

LEAD: ''It was difficult to break myself down and become a primitive man: that was the challenge of this part,'' Denzel Washington was saying about his portrayal of Trip, a runaway slave who takes up arms against the Confederacy in the film ''Glory.'' ''He's a man who says words like onliest. Onliest!'' He shook his head.
LEAD: A hormone that promotes growth in children can also help adults lose fat, gain muscle and burn calories faster, a new study has found.
LEAD: A year spent wrangling with lawsuits and proxy battles is ending happily for Laurans A. Mendelson.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ''Drug abuse and the crime, violence and human suffering it engenders is the most urgent and intractable problem of our time,'' thundered Mario Cuomo back in January. President Bush and others have similarly raised their voices in a year of public outcry over the crack epidemic.

LEAD: Painting Wrought Iron Q.We have a wrought-iron fence around our patio that has been painted several times with a flat black rust-preventive paint. We scrape off all peeling paint and sand down rusty areas each time before repainting. We used a widely sold brand of rust-preventive paint one time, and another brand that contains epoxy the second time.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 Rumania's most repressive controls on individual freedoms, the legacy of Nicolae Ceausescu, were removed by the new Government. Among laws reversed were a ban on abortion and a law requiring registration of all typewriters. Page A1

LEAD: THE stacking chair is a rather lowly furniture form. But one of the most recent designs, by Donghia Furniture for the American Academy in Rome, is anything but.
LEAD: Jon A. Shirley, the president and chief operating officer of the Microsoft Corporation since 1983, will retire in June at the end of the company's fiscal year, Microsoft said yesterday.

LEAD: A man prosecutors called the biggest single broker of Southeast Asian marijuana pleaded guilty on Tuesday in Federal District Court to smuggling nearly 200 tons into the United States over four years.

LEAD: Tactics are changing on the police lines of America's drug war. Frustrated by the overwhelming numbers of drug offenders and an almost infinite supply of illicit drugs, more and more police officers are talking like social workers, arguing that the real solution lies in preventing young people from getting involved with drugs in the first place.

LEAD: The Baxter Healthcare Corporation announced that it had extended medical-supplies contracts with three companies that run more than 450 hospitals nationwide. The contracts are worth $2.5 billion.

LEAD: Many people dealing directly with the Campeau Corporation or trading in its securities express a growing conviction that the troubled company's two American retail subsidiaries will find it difficult to avoid filing for bankruptcy.
LEAD: ''WHEN I moved to New York,'' Leslie Cozart said, ''I realized that few people here knew what Mexican furniture was all about.''

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in SportsMonday this week about Bo Schembechler's final game as Michigan's football coach misstated the date of his first heart attack. It was 20 years ago this week, on Dec. 31, 1969.
LEAD: State housing officials said today that they plan to enter Connecticut's glutted condominium market and buy homes at bargain prices to rent or sell to moderate- and low-income families.

LEAD: Chris Nelson, a defenseman who plays for the University of Wisconsin Badgers, has three ambitious career goals: to be the first black player on the United States Olympic team, to be the first American-born black player in the National Hockey League and to follow his playing career with one in television.

LEAD: Elisabeth F. Gotbaum's resume bears the stamp of someone, who, her friends and former colleagues say, is comfortable in nearly any postition that draws on an ability to bring diverse parties together and to get projects off the ground. One translation: She knows how to raise money.

LEAD: It was almost exactly 15 years ago that the teen-age Stephanie Mills opened at the Majestic Theater on Broadway as Dorothy in ''The Wiz'' and introduced what has since become her signature song, Charlie Smalls' ballad ''Home.'' On Tuesday evening, Miss Mills, now 32 years old, returned to Broadway, this time to the Brooks Atkinson Theater (256 West 47th Street) for six nights in what has been billed as a triumphant coming-home-to

LEAD: At his best, Joe Morris was a Pro Bowl player, a darting cutback runner who made 1,000-yard rushing seasons routine and helped the Giants win Super Bowl XXI. From 1982 through 1988, he became their career rushing leader with 5,296 yards.
LEAD: Rumania's new Government asked the General Assembly today to make an international appeal for emergency aid to the country.
LEAD: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh announced today that he would proceed with plans to disband the Justice Department's organized crime strike forces despite some opposition in Congress.

LEAD: Once again, the network news departments are succumbing to the seasonal obligation to remind us of times past, without expending too much time present. On Tuesday evening ABC, abetted by Time magazine, offered ''Images of the 80's,'' Peter Jennings presiding. Last night, Tom Brokaw and Jane Pauley shared the burden of ''The 80's,'' on NBC.
LEAD: Panama faces the daunting task of rebuilding an economy ravaged not only by bullets and bombs but also by two years of economic war with the United States.
LEAD: Michael and Jessica held onto first place, but Brian and Danielle were set back severely.
LEAD: Douglas H. White, who was appointed by David N. Dinkins yesterday to head the city's Department of Personnel, is no stranger to the corridors of City Hall or government.
LEAD: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS ** *3* Halton Reinsurance Year to Sept 30 1989 1988 Net inc 1,228,162 918,925 Share earns .22 .15 Results are in Canadian dollars. The revenues were not available.
LEAD: Betty Garde, an actress who played roles in hundreds of radio dramas and portrayed Aunt Eller in the original Broadway production of ''Oklahoma!,'' died on Monday. She was 84 years old.
LEAD: AN exhibition of illustrations, including color plates, bookbindings, texts and lithographs illustrating the growth of Victorian style, has opened at the New York Public Library.

LEAD: In January 1938 a panhandler named Prudent drove a knife into an Irishman living in Paris, narrowly missing his victim's heart. Upon recovering, Samuel Beckett sought out his assailant in jail to ask what had prompted the attack. ''Je ne sais pas,'' replied Prudent. The same cryptic words turned up in ''Waiting for Godot,'' spoken by a character called Boy, who deflects Vladimir's thirst for answers with, ''I don't know, sir.

LEAD: Jack C. Smith, a planning specialist who headed the New York City Planning Department's Office of Master Planning from 1960 to 1965, died of cancer on Tuesday at the North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 66 years old and lived in Douglaston, Queens.
LEAD: When South Africa created its black homelands and pushed four of them into nominal independence, it did not anticipate that they would hatch a maverick like Maj. Gen. Bantu Holomisa.

LEAD: Florida's Attorney General said today that the state was investigating whether the Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company had underpaid commissions to governments in several Southeastern states for pay-telephone use. Attorney General Robert
LEAD: Some matters that were subjects of this column in the last year continued to unfold after they were first reported. Here's an update:

LEAD: A pension plan for police and firefighters in Detroit has acquired a 5.8 percent stake in RPS Realty Trust. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Policemen and Firemen Retirement System of the City of Detroit said it might seek control of the New York real estate trust.

LEAD: LARGE damaged areas of wooden strip flooring can sometimes be satisfactorily repaired by an experienced installer. But large repairs are almost always visible, and the results may not be permanent. Often, a more practical solution is to minimize the visibility of the repair by replacing damaged sections of floorboards with small patches, making as close a match as possible.

LEAD: In a surprisingly close contest, St. John's (10-2) defeated Howard University (2-7) by 77-65 before a standing-room-only crowd of 6,008 at Alumni Hall last night.

LEAD: Pointing to deep-rooted ethnic and racial antagonisms in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, a coalition of housing groups asserted yesterday that city housing officials are illegally using quotas there to favor Hasidic Jews in renting apartments. In legal papers filed yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan, the groups said that the New York City Housing Authority has violated a settlement agreed to in 1978 and approved by the court.

LEAD: Mickey L. Hooten, a television executive for the Hearst Corporation and a former chairman of the ABC Television Network Affiliates Board of Governors, died of a heart attack on Sunday at his home in Armonk, N.Y. He was 54 years old.
LEAD: As the Knicks went through what Coach Stu Jackson said was a much-needed practice today at the Miami Jewish Center, Patrick Ewing sat off to the side and watched.

LEAD: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported a 9.3 percent rise in open positions on short sales in actively traded securities in its national market system for the month that ended Dec. 15. The advance was sharply higher than the 2.8 percent increase in the previous period.

LEAD: Ten years ago, a politically troubled President Jimmy Carter asked Mark Green to become the White House's consumer affairs director. He declined. A decade later, Mr. Green not only accepted the job as New York City's commissioner of consumer affairs, but also actively sought the position. Why the change in attitude?
LEAD: Annette Reed and Oscar de la Renta, the fashion designer, were married Tuesday at his home in La Romana, the Dominican Republic. A local justice of the peace officiated.

LEAD: IN the era of leverage, its founders do not reside on Wall Street, public perceptions to the contrary. The boom in borrowing can, to a considerable extent, be laid at the doorstep of the Congressional tax law writers.

LEAD: American Jews concerned about the security of the 20,000 Jews living in Rumania have been reassured in recent days that the Jews were safe and had not been singled out in the revolution that toppled the Government of Nicolae Ceausescu.
LEAD: For the Rangers, the streak without a victory is now at nine games, the longest in more than two years. During the slide, their flair for creative self-destruction has been unbounded.
LEAD: While New York City has begun to dig out from decades of neglect, much rebuilding remains to be done.

LEAD: When the temperature plummeted into the low 20's over the weekend, making much of Florida colder than Anchorage, Ben Abbitt prayed for warmer weather to save the 7,000 acres of oranges owned by him and 250 other members of the Haines City Citrus Growers' Assocation.

LEAD: A 23-year-old man was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison yesterday after he admitted that he beat his parents to death with a baseball bat in order to steal money from them to buy crack and that he killed his nephew in the same way after the child woke up.

LEAD: The Daiwa Securities Company of Tokyo has been punished for compensating a customer for losses in stock transactions, a company official said Tuesday. The official said the company had not violated any laws, but he quoted Masahiro Dozen, Daiwa's president, as apologizing for unfairness to other investors.

LEAD: Will they or won't they? The somewhat prurient question, or gimmick, has bolstered the ratings of countless television series. ''Moonlighting'' and ''Beauty and the Beast'' are among the more recent examples, and in each instance the hero and heroine did. Now there is ABC's ''Anything but Love'' (Wednesdays at 9:30), the show that asks: Can carefree Hannah Miller, former schoolteacher and aspiring writer, be just good friends with angst-ridden Marty Gold, award-winning magazine reporter?

LEAD: Chuck Schmidt, who oversaw the books for the Detroit Lions as understudy to the general manager, Russ Thomas, was named yesterday to succeed Thomas as the team's chief operating officer. Occupying a new joint position, he will also be executive vice president. Schmidt was previously vice president of finance.

LEAD: The Hillsborough Holdings Corporation, the company formed by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company to acquire the Jim Walter Corporation last year for $2.4 billion, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection today after its bondholders rejected a plan to overhaul the company's finances.
LEAD: United Airlines, the nation's second-largest carrier, today followed the lead of a smaller crosstown rival, Midway Airlines, and said it would lower some fares up to 30 percent.
LEAD: United States textile imports rose by 13 percent and their value climbed to more than $32 billion in 1989, the American Textile Manufacturers Institute said today.
LEAD: Seeking to dismantle the legacy of Nicolae Ceausescu, the executed dictator, Rumania today lifted some of the controls that have made this country one of the most repressive in Europe.

LEAD: A first-time expert partnership can suffer a major bidding disaster on occasion, as witness the two men in a world championship who landed in a grand slam missing four aces after a slight Blackwood misunderstanding.

LEAD: rrIt's business as usual at Mohawk Mountain, Conn., this ski season. Of course, to people who skied there in the past, the area looks somewhat different. After all, any place that has been visited by a three-funnel super-cell tornado is bound to show some changes.

LEAD: Johnny Rodgers, a previous Heisman Trophy winner, yesterday denied having contacted the 1989 winner, Andre Ware, illegally. But Rodgers, who played at Nebraska, said in Omaha that he did buy Ware's mother a fur coat and other items.

LEAD: In the long cat-and-mouse game between drivers who flout speed limits and police officers who enforce them, the Canadian police are gaining the upper hand, for now, with a device invented last summer.
LEAD: THE decorative arts, long a popular subject for books, lectures and museum shows, are soon to be explored on television, too.

LEAD: Weeks after this city and more than 150 villages were devastated by some of India's worst Hindu-Muslim fighting, police officials are still uncovering graves from massacres that they say have left as many as 1,000 dead.
LEAD: Keith Waggoner, a manager for Jujamcyn Theaters, died on Saturday at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 42 years old.

LEAD: Japanese scientists have reported that small gyroscopes lose weight when spun under certain conditions, apparently in defiance of gravity. If proved correct, the finding would mark a stunning scientific advance, but experts said they doubted that it would survive intense scrutiny.

LEAD: A work crew of 23 was assigned to do nothing on Christmas weekend but flush the 503 toilets at the Gator Bowl to prevent a freeze-up at the stadium before the annual New Year's college football game. A freeze in 1983 caused about $400,000 damage in broken water pipes, so during last week's record cold, officials hired a brigade of flushers to keep water moving through the plumbing.

LEAD: WHEN the actress Ali MacGraw decided to be photographed with her son, Joshua Evans, they both wore white T-shirts, she wore black tights and he wore jeans. They were photographed in an Art Deco bathroom.
LEAD: In economics, as in other spheres, it is the simplest questions that are often the hardest to answer.

LEAD: Hiawatha Berry, a starting defensive tackle for the University of Georgia, was dismissed from the squad by Coach Ray Goff yesterday, three days before the Bulldogs are to meet Syracuse in the Peach Bowl. Goff said without elaboration that Berry, a senior, was dismissed for violating rules.

LEAD: THERE is no single pattern to the closeness of childhood best friends. They may show their affection and alliance through whispered confidences, shared favorite toys or swift punches to the arm. The relationship often reflects each child's stage of social development more than it does the goals, values and beliefs they hold in common.

LEAD: Two years ago, hoping to save its businesses and its school, this Farm Belt community put out an invitation for new residents, offering a free lot and $1,200 cash to anyone who builds a house worth $30,000.
LEAD: * American Pioneer Savings Bank, Orlando, Fla., said it had received regulatory approval for the sale of 13 central Florida branches to a unit of Southeast Banking Corp., Miami.

LEAD: A small film company that makes videocassettes of the nation's top tourist attractions said today that it had settled a breach-of-contract lawsuit against a division of the Eastman Kodak Company.

LEAD: ''Born on the Fourth of July,'' ''Glory'' and ''When Harry Met Sally . . .'' each received five Golden Globe Award nominations, which were announced today by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association.

LEAD: The Opera Orchestra of New York is to open its 20th-anniversary season at Carnegie Hall on Jan. 16 at 8 P.M. with a performance of ''I Vespri Siciliani.'' LEAD: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins named six more members to his administration yesterday, including the chief fund-raiser for his mayoral campaign, Elisabeth F. Gotbaum, and Mark Green, a senior campaign adviser and longtime consumer advocate.
LEAD: ''ALTHOUGH my garden is never quite what I want it to be,'' said Bernice Steinbaum, ''I've come to realize that gardens represent man's control over nature.''

LEAD: As the bicentennial year of the French Revolution draws to a close, France is making an all-out effort to send aid to Rumania, an effort aimed in part at showing, once again, France's leadership in the fight for liberty, equality and fraternity.

LEAD: Every day more than 500,000 elderly Americans in nursing homes and hospitals, most of them frail and demented, are tied to their beds or wheelchairs. But institutions across the country are re-examining their use of restraints.
LEAD: The Commerce Department ruled today that mechanical transfer presses from Japan were being sold in the United States at less than fair value.

LEAD: Stocks advanced yesterday and the pace of trading picked up as a result of bargain hunting and the usual year-end ''window dressing,'' in which investment managers seek to embellish their portfolios.

LEAD: Pamela Anne Taft Married To Mark S. Blackwell Pamela Anne Taft and Mark Strath Blackwell were married yesterday at the Plymouth Congregational Church of the Pilgrims in Brooklyn Heights. The Rev. Dr. Richard Stanger and the Rev. William J. Hammann, a retired Lutheran minister and the bride's great-uncle, officiated.

LEAD: The Pittston Company resumed negotiations with its coal miners today to end a brutal strike in Appalachia that is now nearly nine months old. The participants are working toward a deadline of this weekend, the Federal mediator said.

LEAD: >Question: After the convulsions in the Soviet Union, Eastern Europe, the Philippines and South Korea, what's the main difference between established foreign policy experts and 20-year-old college students? Well, students generally don't know about Prince Souphanouvong of Laos or Patrice Lumumba of the Congo.

LEAD: Joseph Evans, a 33-year-old Queens bricklayer, reached into his coat yesterday afternoon and pulled out an eight-inch hunting knife and a loaded clip for a .38-caliber automatic revolver. He was showing how he protects himself against the violence of South Jamaica.

LEAD: PEARLS seem synonymous with classic style, habitually draped around the necks of fashion editors and the current First Lady. But pearl necklaces need to be maintained, so what is the procedure when a strand breaks or needs routine restringing? How does one find a reliable restringer, especially in light of horror stories about jewelers who substitute cheap pearls for fine ones?

LEAD: The ruling Communists and an opposition coalition agreed today to hold wide-ranging talks on Bulgaria's future, and the Government dismissed the Interior Minister, who had been criticized over police violence against demonstrators in October.
LEAD: Heavy tropical rains have flooded much of northeastern Brazil, killing 35 people, leaving 200,000 homeless and ravaging some of the country's finest colonial-era architectural treasures.
LEAD: An article yesterday about the fatal shooting of a teen-ager and a pregnant woman in Queens misstated the site. It was the west side of 160th Street, between 107th and 108th Avenues.

LEAD: Jeff Harding, the World Boxing Council light heavyweight champion, is widely viewed as a very beatable boxer. And the prospect of fighting him has prompted two retired former champions - Bobby Czyz and Donny Lalonde - to go back into training.
LEAD: Coach John Cunniff of the Devils expected his team to be highly motivated for a game with plenty at stake, but he conceded later that he had misread the mood of his players.

LEAD: ON a Wednesday morning in London last September, Peter Palumbo, the chairman of the Arts Council in Britain, met with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher to lobby for more money for the council. Ten Downing Street is only one of the historic stops in Mr. Palumbo's life.
LEAD: Results of a blood test showed yesterday that the driver of the pickup truck in which Billy Martin was killed was legally drunk when the truck crashed near Martin's upstate New York home.

LEAD: The real history of the American musical theater in the 1980's began in 1981 with William Finn's ''March of the Falsettos,'' an exuberant show about the love between husbands and wives, parents and children, men and men, and everyone and psychiatrists. Though the story might now have to be revised to accommodate the virus that would later rewrite the lives of its characters, the score and lyrics of ''Falsettos'' remain as invigorating as ever.
LEAD: Grady Wacaster was a prison warden in Spooky Hollow, N.C.

LEAD: Israeli leaders warned today that Syria remains a powerful threat to Israel despite its reconciliation with Egypt this week. But they also said they hoped that Cairo could persuade Damascus to adopt a moderate line toward Israel.
LEAD: A man was killed here this week by a trap set up inside a house whose owner had complained of frequent break-ins.
LEAD: Eastern Airlines said yesterday that it was laying off 600 employees, mostly managers, and cutting wages by 10 percent or 20 percent for about half its work force.
LEAD: The three-day holiday break was wonderful.

LEAD: Last spring, Violet Ragland and some of her neighbors in the Baldwin Woods area of Roosevelt, a Nassau County community, compared their property-tax bills and saw that while their houses were virtually identical, their assessments were all different.

LEAD: When the Los Angeles Rams play the Eagles in Philadelphia on Sunday in the National Conference wild-card game, the difference between the teams may be in their health. The Rams have suffered so many recent injuries to their defense that they may be unable to stop Randall Cunningham, the Eagles' elusive quarterback.

LEAD: Ending a small mystery that had been growing around the Transit Authority's decision to raise the price of a subway and bus ride from $1 to $1.15 next Monday, a Transit Authority spokesman indicated last night that passengers will be able to use the same token they have been using until now.
LEAD: A state appeals court today upheld the conspiracy conviction of a Columbia County man for plotting to kill members of his family in 1986.

LEAD: Alex Bacall of Kew Gardens, Queens, said he watched the grisly scenes of mass graves in Rumania broadcast in recent days with only one thought in his mind: ''I pray my Robert is not among them.''

LEAD: The eldest brother of former President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania was found hanged in the cellar of his Vienna offices today, apparently after committing suicide, police officials said.

LEAD: NEW YEAR'S EVE festivities may seem like timeless traditions, but throughout most of history, Dec. 31 came and went with none of the hoopla that will envelop New York and elsewhere this weekend. In fact, until 1564 in France and 1752 in England, the new year began -much more logically - on March 25 with the first hopeful signs of spring.

LEAD: Philippine Government officials said today that they had evidence that a leader of the political opposition to President Corazon C. Aquino was involved in this month's coup attempt against her.

LEAD: In ranking the Mafia hierarchy, law-enforcement authorities put Vincent (the Chin) Gigante near the top - the undisputed boss of the Genovese family. He is now a target of a Federal investigation.

LEAD: Will Yugoslavia be the next Eastern European state to erupt - or can free elections help contain its explosive nationalist rivalries? Communists in Croatia and Slovenia, the most westward-looking of Yugoslavia's six republics, want to hold multiparty elections. In Serbia, largest of the six, the Communist Party objects.

LEAD: Karole Armitage has announced the temporary disbanding of the Armitage Ballet. The seven-member company was founded in 1985 to perform Ms. Armitage's dances, including her frequent collaborations with the artist David Salle.

LEAD: An Atlanta television station today made public a racially charged letter that took responsibility for the two recent fatal bombings in the South and threatened more violence against ''the black leadership'' and Federal judges.

LEAD: The main front-page article on Tuesday about Rumania misidentified Ana Ipatescu, for whom a street in Bucharest is named. She was a heroine of the 1848 uprising against the Turks and the Russians, not of the Communist takeover after World War II.

LEAD: An early marble portrait bust attributed to Gianlorenzo Bernini that was thought to be lost for more than a century is to be auctioned at Christie's in New York on Jan. 10.

LEAD: The Devils reduced their overcrowded roster yesterday by demoting Peter Sundstrom to their minor league affiliate, the Utica Devils, two days after the demotion of the defenseman Sergei Starikov.

LEAD: Fearful that a 10-year alliance with Syria may be coming to an end, Iran is increasing military and financial aid to its Muslim funamentalist surrogates in Lebanon to help them gain supremacy in Muslim areas.

LEAD: The geological conditions that produced yesterday's earthquake north of Sydney, Australia, are strikingly similar to those on the East Coast of the United States, according to specialists in earthquake hazards.

LEAD: Since April, when John T. Dorrance Jr., the head of the family that owns almost 59 percent of the Campbell Soup Company, died, Wall Street has buzzed with speculation that the Dorrances would sell the company. For eight months, the family issued unanimous denials.

LEAD: New laws and procedures intended to speed the courts' handling of criminal drug cases are now in many instances making matters worse. And both Federal and state judges say the nation's new drug policies are only going to compound the problem.

LEAD: A pickup truck slammed into an overturned tanker carrying 1,100 gallons of fuel Wednesday night, causing a huge explosion and the death of four people. The driver of the tanker was not in the vehicle and thus escaped injury in the crash, which occurred on Interstate 10. All those killed were inside the pickup truck.

LEAD: The American Express Company has reached an agreement to sell its Geneva-based private banking subsidiary to another Swiss banking institution for about $1 billion, American Express said yesterday.

LEAD: The Ensemble for Early Music is to perform ''Herod and the Innocents,'' a production based on two medieval Nativity plays, at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street, tonight at 7:30. The two works on which the production is based - ''The Representation of Herod'' and ''The Slaughter of the Innocents'' - come from the Fleury Play Book, a 12th-century French manuscript.

LEAD: The number of public-school districts in Suffolk County should be reduced by half through mergers to create a more efficient school system, a county task force said today. Much of the $55 million in annual savings would go to reduce property taxes, the task force said.

LEAD: Hundreds of police officers surrounded a Sikh temple today in the northern state of Punjab and battled militants inside, the police said. At least four policeman were reported killed. About 500 police officers surrounded the Darbar Sahib temple and exchanged fire with entrenched militants who hd tried to take over.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY Federal regulators and banking experts are concerned that mounting losses from troubled real estate loans could lead to a wave of bank failures, straining the Federal insurance program that protects depositors' funds. The danger, regulators and analysts say, is that when the country enters an economic downturn, as most economists say it eventually must, the losses at commercial banks may be so large that the Government might have to raise insurance fees on the banking industry or rescue some banks with taxpayers' money.

LEAD: The last senior leader of a Sinhalese extremist group has been captured and killed, and the dominant Tamil militants have ambushed and killed members of a rival Tamil organization, Sri Lankan officials said today.

LEAD: The Commissioner of Social Security has begun an effort to enroll many of the one million to two million poor people who are eligible for the Supplemental Security Income program.

LEAD: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins appointed three more people to his incoming city administration yesterday, naming department heads for aging, employment, and legislative affairs.

LEAD: Five members of Greenpeace, an anti-nuclear group, have been acquitted of mischief by a judge who ruled that the anchoring of a United States Navy vessel, capable of carrying nuclear weapons, off Vancouver was an invitation to protest. The provincial court judge, Wallace Craig, said on Thursday that they were right to protest and that Canadians had been too passive in the past.

LEAD: Two civil guards were shot and killed on Thursday in the northern city of Gijon in an attack that the police attribute to a shadowy leftist terrorist group known as the Oct. 1 Anti-Fascist Resistance.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY The index of leading indicators edged up 0.1 percent in November after modestly declining in October, the Commerce Department reported. That was in line with expectations and was seen as a further indication that the nation's sharply slower economic growth is unlikely to deteriorate into a recession.

LEAD: ''An occupying power cannot interfere with the work of a diplomatic mission nor demand that a person seeking asylum in that mission be handed over to it.'' -Joaquin Navarro-Valls, the Vatican spokesman. [ 7:2. ]
LEAD: Alexander Ellis 2d, the brother-in-law of President Bush and a prominent businessman here, died Friday of a stroke. He was 67 years old.

LEAD: The dance troupe Jamison Project will give a free performance at 6:30 P.M. on Jan. 16 at the World Financial Center Winter Garden, between Vesey and Liberty Streets. The troupe is led by Judith Jamison, who was recently appointed artistic director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.

LEAD: A Federal grand jury in Tucson has indicted 18 people to break what the United States Attorney calls a worldwide conspiracy that made and marketed millions of counterfeit name-brand athletic shoes.
LEAD: The death of a college student while in police custody outside a Grateful Dead concert here has been ruled a homicide.
LEAD: The Indian Parliament voted today to repeal a widely criticized constitutional amendment that allowed the suspension of civil rights in Punjab state.

LEAD: Shrimp are America's favorite shellfish. And they make wonderful hors d'oeuvres at parties on New Year's Eve or any other time. Caterers say guests consume twice as many shrimp as any other cocktail food. Virtually all shrimp in markets have been frozen and are sold thawed. They are graded according to size or number of pieces per pound.

LEAD: The contradictions between the profusely complimentary public posture that Lou Holtz, Notre Dame's football coach, often holds toward opponents and his private observations have become a focal point of the upcoming Orange Bowl meeting with top-ranked Colorado.

LEAD: Union workers at the Pimlico and Laurel race tracks voted today to accept the five-year contract they had rejected a week ago, averting a strike Monday. The contract covers about 660 parimutuel clerks, guards, parking-lot workers, admissions personnel, jockeys' room valets and the starting-gate crew.

LEAD: On the day after security forces fired the opening shots of Rumania's revolution, Lorin Fortuna, newly tapped as the head of the opposition, met secretly the head of the opposition, met secretly with the Communist Party leader of Timisoara.
LEAD: Doug Harvey, the defensive mainstay of the Montreal Canadiens in the late 1950's and a member of the Hockey Hall of Fame, was buried today with several of his former teammates in attendance.

LEAD: Robert Rosenthal, a curator at the Joseph Regenstein Library of the University of Chicago, died Wednesday in Scotland after suffering a heart attack. Mr. Rosenthal, 63 years old, lived in Chicago and had been visiting friends and booksellers in Scotland.
LEAD: To the usual urban New Year's hazards of drunken drivers and hangovers add another: bullets raining from the sky.
LEAD: The Polish Senate approved a landmark economic package yesterday that should place Poland far in front of other Eastern bloc nations in moving from Communism to capitalism.

LEAD: Federal investigators said today that evidence strongly indicates that the person or group whose bombs killed a Federal judge in Alabama and a lawyer in Georgia is also behind a subsequent series of letters claiming responsibility for the bombings and threatening further violence.
LEAD: A book review on Dec. 9 about a memoir by Zofia S. Kubar, a Holocaust survivor, misstated the title.

LEAD: How best to reduce the solid waste that is burying the nation? The windy debates have produced two choices: recycling and ''resource recovery,'' or incineration to produce electric power. A relatively new plant in Bridgeport, Conn., makes clear that resource recovery has a strong future.

LEAD: A fire that the authorities attributed to arson heavily damaged a Planned Parenthood clinic here early today. There were no injuries. The clinic does not provide abortions. Patty Brous, director of development for Planned Parenthood of Kansas City, said there had been several recent acts of vandalism against the clinic.

LEAD: A Greek freighter's 28 crew members struggled today to keep their 600-foot ship afloat about 800 miles northeast of Hawaii, but the vessel was not in immediate danger of sinking, said the captain of a tanker that came to the rescue.
LEAD: Spock on Spock A Memoir of Growing Up With the Century By Benjamin Spock, M.D., and Mary Morgan Illustrated. 282 pages. Pantheon Books. $19.95.

LEAD: A body exhumed from a common grave today has been tentatively identified as that of a longtime American resident of Panama who was abducted from his house by armed men the night of the United States invasion, American officials said.

LEAD: For the Devils, speed was at the top of their wish list during the off season, so Sylvain Turgeon was not a surprising acquisition. He had speed in his legs and wrists, a combination that can turn games around in a hurry.

LEAD: Some airlines, including Trans World and Continental, are seriously considering raising fares or adding a surcharge to tickets to offset a sharp increase in fuel prices, people in the industry said yesterday.
LEAD: In 1988, Damian Johnson, the Giants' starting right offensive guard, suffered back spasms while warming up for the seventh game of the season. He underwent surgery and was gone for the year.

LEAD: Another New Year's Eve without Guy Lombardo. It has been 13 years since the ''sweetest music this side of heaven'' rolled from a New York bandstand, then oozed elegantly across a nation's airwaves - an annual serenade to Americans' naive and conflicting notions that each year represents a new beginning, and that nothing changes.

LEAD: Stocks rose strongly yesterday in sharply higher trading, capping the Dow Jones industrial average's second best year of the decade in percentage terms.

LEAD: Japan has agreed to drop its demand for further information about the circumstances in which a hydrogen bomb fell overboard from an American aircraft carrier 24 years ago off the coast of Okinawa, Japanese and American officials said today.
LEAD: After its revolution and the collapse of its Communist Party, Rumania, which was once alone in the Eastern bloc in shunning Moscow's leadership, is now improving its ties to the Soviet Union.

LEAD: The On Stage column in Weekend yesterday gave an incorrect starting date for Eric Bogosian's ''Sex, Drugs, Rock & Roll'' at the Orpheum Theater. Performances begin Jan. 30 and continue for 12 weeks; the official opening is Feb. 8.

LEAD: Gregory R. McNab, who retired from General Motors in 1974 as director of distribution outside the United States, died of cancer on Tuesday at his home in Summit, N.J. He was 79 years old.

LEAD: Days before David N. Dinkins takes over as mayor, New Yorkers are eager to have his administration overhaul the city's schools and house and heal its poor. But more than anything else, they want him to treat its addicts and make its streets safe.

LEAD: Bobby Dodd, Georgia Tech football coach whose name adorns a football stadium and a street in this city, liked all the fuss and feathers about bowl games. In justifying them, he once said, ''There's never been a bad bowl game.''

Nov. 17: In the largest anti-Government rally since 1968, tens of thousands of demonstrators take to the streets of Prague.

LEAD: A woman has been jailed here at a prosecutor's request because she failed to appear to testify against the man accused of kidnapping and raping her last June.

LEAD: Abraham Worcel, a professor of biology at the University of Rochester, died on Wednesday at Genesee Hospital in Rochester. He was 51 years old and lived in Penfield, a suburb of Rochester.

LEAD: The Government is encouraging skilled East Germans to immigrate to South Africa, which has a shortage of skilled labor but has a surplus of unskilled labor.

The Queen carries out the investiture of the honors later.

New Link in Bomb Cases Officials said there was strong evidence that whoever mailed the bombs that killed a judge and a lawyer was responsible for subsequent letters threatening more violence.

LEAD: The Vatican blamed the American Government yesterday for the impasse over Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's fate, calling the United States an ''occupying power'' with no right to demand that the ousted dictator be handed over to its forces.

LEAD: A natural gas main in the South Bronx exploded in a tower of flames visible across the metropolitan area yesterday, killing two people and forcing a shutoff of power and subway service in large sections of the Bronx and Manhattan throughout the afternoon and early evening.

LEAD: Civil rights organizations and their major Congressional allies are putting finishing touches on legislation to reverse recent Supreme Court decisions that have made it harder to show job discrimination and easier to challenge affirmative action programs.

LEAD: Margaret Grein,A Law Student,Becomes a Bride The Cathedral of St. John the Divine was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Margaret Allene Grein, a daughter of Bishop and Mrs. Richard F. Grein of New York, and James Arthur Moore, a son of Mrs. James Thomas Rutherford of Denver and Willow Springs, Mo., and the late Robert Lee Moore.

LEAD: Unable to turn a profit despite emerging from Federal bankruptcy court protection, Heck's Inc. announced plans to sell its retail operations, consisting of 55 discount stores in six states, to New York-based Jordache Enterprises Inc.Heck's is essentially giving away its retailers to a subsidiary of Jordache, which will assume the chain's debts and long-term obligations, said Maartan Hemsley,
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Burmese forces backed by more than 800 rounds of mortar fire captured a major base of the Karen rebels on the Thai border today, the Thai police said. Dozens of people were reported killed. The border police said that as many as 3,000 Burmese soldiers fought hundreds of rebels for four days before overrunning the camp at Pa Loo, about 10 miles southwest of the Thai border town of Mae Sot.

LEAD: In some parts of the city, residents lined up to go into grocery stores one at a time beside employees who held flashlights and showed the way. Some paid $2 for a single candle. Others double-locked their doors at home, afraid of going out at all.

LEAD: The police raided a Vietnamese refugee camp today and clashed with stone-throwing boat people who reportedly feared that they would be forced to return to their homeland. Officials said 40 people were wounded.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Bulgarian Turks will be allowed to adopt the Muslim names that they were forced to change in an often violent campaign of assimilation that began in the early 1980's, a senior official announced today.

LEAD: Drug use inside prisons across the United States has become a major problem with a variety of consequences, including threats to prison order, violence among inmates and corruption of guards and other employees.
LEAD: ONE of the truisms of the financial services industry - that no good idea goes uncopied -may not be true much longer.

LEAD: Rod Langway, defenseman for Washington, will be lost to the Capitals for four to six weeks after surgery Thursday to repair damage to both knees, team officials said yesterday. Langway was injured in the second period of last Saturday's game against the Rangers.(AP)

LEAD: He is not yet sure when he will move in or how long it will take him to commute to work, but finally, after months of searching, Joseph A. Fernandez, the incoming Schools Chancellor for New York City, has selected a home.
LEAD: For the first time in his seven years in office, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has declined to grant clemency to any of the hundreds of state prison inmates who petitioned him for early release.

LEAD: After a long period of complacency during which American reliance on foreign oil fell sharply and the price dived to under $10 a barrel, the United States is now headed for permanent levels of dependence on imports that are higher than those that led to havoc in the 1970's, many specialists say.

LEAD: After the halftime buzzer sounded tonight in the championship game of the Bell Atlantic Holiday tournament, most of the members of the women's basketball teams from Rutgers and Virginia raced across the floor and into their locker rooms at the Louis Brown Athletic Center.

LEAD: Dr. Milton J. Grand, a member of the senior pediatrics staff at Montefiore Medical Center, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital after suffering a heart attack Monday night. He was 85 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.
LEAD: Charles F. Scott, a retired executive of the Mobil Oil Corporation, died Wednesday at Danbury (Conn.) Hospital after a brief illness. He was 75 years old and lived in Ridgefield, Conn.

LEAD: More than 6,500 people, ranging from former President Richard M. Nixon to a 9-year-old boy wearing a sweatshirt, jacket and cap with Yankee insignia, turned out for Billy Martin's funeral yesterday. More than 3,000 of them jammed St. Patrick's Cathedral for the 70-minute service, and approximately 3,500 stood outside in the cold, jamming the Fifth Avenue sidewalks in front of and across from the church.
LEAD: The rebellious Christian commander, Gen. Michel Aoun, said today that he was putting off elections for a Parliament to rival that of the Government of President Elias Hrawi.

LEAD: * Carlyle Group, Washington D.C., a merchant banking group, completed the previously announced purchase of the Ticketron Sports and Entertainment division from Control Data Corp., Minneapolis, a maker of computer systems. Terms were not disclosed.
LEAD: After coping with one last emergency, a fire and a blackout, Edward I. Koch walked out of City Hall for the last time as Mayor yesterday, his tenure virtually at an end. Page 27.
LEAD: The chairman of the Campbell Soup Company said yesterday that the board's first choice to fill the chief executive's job had been accepted but the person's name was not announced.

LEAD: When troops of the 82d Airborne Division under the command of Col. Renard Marable stormed up a hill to capture Fort Tinajitas on Dec. 20, the armed resistance to them was led by Capt. German Gonzalez Pitti. Within four days, however, Captain Gonzalez was back in the fort behind his own desk, on which his nameplate sits above a plaque reading, ''Blessed Be He Who Brings Peace.

LEAD: The police fired tear gas, pulled demonstrators by their hair and struck them with night sticks today to break up a peace march in Jerusalem by more than 3,000 Israeli, Palestinian and European women.
LEAD: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York today called for repeal of a scheduled increase in the Social Security payroll tax, terming it regressive and unfair.
LEAD: The Polish Senate today approved a package of economic changes that should place Poland far in front of other Eastern European nations in moving from Communism to capitalism.
LEAD: The Supreme Court has rejected an emergency request by the City of Pittsburgh for authority to bar a large menorah from the steps of the City-County Building.

LEAD: The Chiron Corporation and Ortho Diagnostic Systems Inc., a unit of Johnson & Johnson, said today that they expected to enter an agreement to purchase most of the AIDS and hepatitis blood-screening business of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company. Chiron said negotiations could be concluded over the weekend.
LEAD: Herman Short, a former Houston Police Chief, died of a heart attack in Houston on Thursday. He was 71 years old.
LEAD: As they set out for summer vacations these days, Brazilian drivers are likely to scan the sea lanes before they scan the highway lanes.

LEAD: Elizabeth Ann Howard, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Neil Howard of Hudson, N.Y., was married yesterday to Second Lieut. Mark Lincoln Stock, a son of Maj. and Mrs. Ronald Paul Stock of Baitesville, Ind. The Rev. Robert Drummond performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Chapel of the Most Holy Trinity at the United States Military Academy at West Point, N

LEAD: Treasury note and bond prices were mostly lower and bill rates mixed yesterday in a shortened pre-holiday session that ended a year characterized by gradually rising prices of Treasury and many investment-grade corporate debt issues and by declining values of many high-yielding ''junk bonds.''

LEAD: The last time the Nationals seemed so superior to the Americans, the Baltimore Colts were 18-point favorites to beat the Jets in Super Bowl III. But that was before the rival leagues merged and the Colts switched conferences, and before Joe Namath proved that the American Football League was at least equal to the National Football
LEAD: Presiding Bishop J. O. Patterson Sr. of the Church of God in Christ, who retired this year in failing health, died at William F. Bowld Hospital here today. He was 77 years old.

LEAD: Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, today scrapped conflict-of-interest guidelines proposed by the National Institutes of Health for recipients of Federal research grants. He said they might impose unnecessary burdens on scientists and jeopardize the United States' pre-eminence in biomedical research.
LEAD: Sylvester Stallone has sued an art broker for $5 million, saying she led him to pay millions of dollars too much for several artworks.
LEAD: A retired police officer, working in a Brooklyn jewelry store, was killed yesterday by a robber, the police said.

LEAD: The cause of human rights came triumphantly of age in the liberating 1980's. The decade began with the collapse of military rule in much of Latin America and ended with the toppling of one-party absolutism in Eastern Europe. Seemingly impregnable tyrannies were humbled by ordinary people who risked their skins demanding fundamental rights.

LEAD: Spencer Brown, a poet and former principal of the Fieldston School, died of cancer of the kidneys on Tuesday at the Skyview Nursing Home in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. He was 80 years old and had lived for many years in Pleasantville, N.Y.

LEAD: The Lodestar Group, a New York-based investment fund that specializes in corporate mergers and acquisitions, has lowered its stake in ADC Telecommunications Inc. to 4.5 percent from 6.4 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Lodestar gave no reason for the sale of the ADC shares.

LEAD: Roman Catholic officials in the United States and Panama have reacted sharply over the last several days to criticism of the Vatican for giving Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega refuge in the Vatican mission in Panama.

LEAD: Wayman Tisdale, a forward with the Sacramento Kings of the National Basketball Association, has bought part of the Oklahoma City Cavalry, a Continental Basketball Association expansion team, the C.B.A. said yesterday in Manhattan.

LEAD: An hour or so before dawn on New Year's Day, Jerry Kravat, a tall and rumpled figure in white tie and tails, comes home to his Upper West Side apartment, uncorks a bottle of champagne, presses buttons on his video-cassette recorder and reruns New Year's Eve.

LEAD: A $67 million addition to the Hunter College Campus Schools that would eventually make possible an increase in enrollment from the present 1,600 students to 2,200 is under consideration by the city. The proposal would add about 100,000 square feet to the school, enough for 20 new classrooms and a new gymnasium.

LEAD: Marcia Ann Casey and Carl C. Hoss were married last evening at the Old North Church in Boston. The Rev. Dr. Robert W. Golledge, assisted by Canon Jonathan F. Young, performed the Episcopal ceremony. Mrs. Hoss is the daughter of Mrs. James P. Casey of Bristol, Conn., and the late Mr. Casey, a former Mayor of
LEAD: The showpiece of the Reagan Administration's housing program was a voucher system, created to give a cash subsidy to poor people so they could choose their own rental housing.

LEAD: Guerrillas of the Palestine Liberation Organization took up combat positions in southern Lebanon today to prevent eight days of fighting between rival Shiite militiamen from spilling into areas under Palestinian control.

LEAD: Mary Rebecca Hulick, a vice president and a marketing manager at Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York, and William James Bendix, a partner in the Brooklyn law firm of Medina & Bendix, were married yesterday at St. Edmund's Episcopal Church in San Marino, Calif., by Bishop Oliver B. Garver Jr. Mrs. Bendix, 31 years old and a graduate of Mount Holyoke College, is the daughter of Mr.

LEAD: SHOULD an assistant football coach in the Big Eight accept a job as head coach in the Ivy League? Ron Brown, receivers' coach at the University of Nebraska, thinks not. He has turned down the chance to be the head coach at Brown University.

LEAD: AS history is made in Prague, an American couple with strong ties to Czechoslovakia have watched the events on television in their home here. Milena Jelinek, an assistant professor in the film division of the Columbia University School of the Arts, personally knew many players in the current drama before coming to the United

LEAD: There was quite an instructive report on Chinese television this week, showing a ceremony at the Great Hall of the People in Tiananmen Square and featuring some of China's new heroes: the People's Armed Police.
LEAD: At the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany in New York, Mylene Sheridan Hodgson was married yesterday to John Talbot Curtis 2d by the Rev. Dorsey W. M. McConnell.

LEAD: Katherine Marion Blakeley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher P. Blakeley of Ambler, Pa., and Mark Douglas Teich, the son of Helen C. Teich of Floral Park, L.I., and the late David Teich, plan to marry in March, her parents have announced.

LEAD: To the Editor: Every time I fly to Kennedy International Airport from Los Angeles and ride the Carey bus into Manhattan I go through the same experience Simone Galdfarb described. And finding a taxi in the vicinity of Grand Central Terminal is impossible. I usually end up pulling a very heavy suitcase 10 to 11 blocks before

LEAD: NEED a New Year's resolution? Here's one: Renew your passport first thing. If it expires any time in the coming year, this is a must, but even if it has longer to run, the United States Passport Service says that at this time of year you can get your new passport back by mail in two weeks. Things may not run that speedily again until well into the fall.

LEAD: IT has been a year for innovation in the county's music world, from a 136-year-old parish getting its first organ - a stunning Moller - to a double performance of ''Siegfried,'' in what is planned to be an annual Wagner festival. But these are just two of the highlights one recalls when looking back upon 1989.
LEAD: CAL RODGERS AND THE VIN FIZ The First Transcontinental Flight. By Eileen F. Lebow. Illustrated. 275 pp. Washington: Smithsonian Institution Press. $22.95.
LEAD: John Biskup, who wore a big black No. 1 on his white Syracuse jersey, became No. 1 with his coach, Dick MacPherson, in the last minute of the Peach Bowl game today.

LEAD: Paula Ruth Mazur and Robert Philip Mickelson, both independent movie producers in Los Angeles, were married there last evening at the Park Plaza Hotel by Rabbi Barry Cohen. The bride, who will keep her name, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Mazur of New York. Her husband is a son of Dr. and Mrs.

LEAD: My mother is in the later stages of Alzheimer's disease. Although she is otherwise in general good health, I know that one day I may face the same situation Andrew Malcolm did. I struggle to remember any snatches of conversation that indicate what my mother's desires would be. But each recollection that suggests yes is counterbalanced by another that suggests no.

LEAD: American military and diplomatic officials today offered contradictory explanations of the origins of Friday night's raid on the Nicaraguan Embassy residence here. Both versions were immediately challenged by Nicaraguan diplomats involved in the incident.

LEAD: WITH the calendar approaching 1990, it's fashionable to assess what has happened since the calendar was turned to 1980, a decade in sports when money got bigger but not necessarily better, when ''drug rehab'' and ''Olympic boycott'' entered our vocabulary. It's also fashionable to assess ''the best'' of the decade.

LEAD: MEMOIRS OF A BASTARD ANGEL. By Harold Norse. (Morrow, $22.95.) From an audacious opening (''Call me bastard'') to a coyly symmetrical ending more than 400 pages later (''This is but the draft of a draft, as Melville said of Moby Dick''), Harold Norse's ''Memoirs of a Bastard Angel'' charts a colorful life rich in literary affiliations but lacking in fulfilled ambitions.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Slusser of New York and Windsor, Calif., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Sarah Ann Slusser and Matthew Baylor Arnold, a son of Dr. Mary B. Arnold of Barrington, R.I., and the late Dr. John H. Arnold.
LEAD: In America's No. 1 party town, it's party time once again. But then when is it not?
LEAD: FARMINGDALE'S Lotus Garden is the neighborhood Chinese restaurant I would most like to have in my neighborhood.

LEAD: Bohemia - $161,800 1591 Feuereisen Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 15-year-old high ranch; dining room, eat-iun kitche, family room; taxes $3,900. East Islip - $660,000 2 The Keel 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 27-year-old waterfront colonial; dining room, c/a, 2-car attached garage, 1 acre; taxes $11,000
LEAD: THE LABYRINTH OF EXILE A Life of Theodor Herzl. By Ernst Pawel. Illustrated. 554 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $30.

LEAD: THE concert schedule usually takes awhile to recover fully from the holiday break, and next Sunday at 4, the First Congregational Church of Greenwich will help bring in a return to musical normalcy with a weekly series of hourlong candlelight events. It was the idea of the music director, Richard Vogt, to have an informal setting for these short musicales so tea, hot chocolate and other refreshments will be available, starting at 3:45.

LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Things from the late 1940's are suddenly quite interesting, not because baby boomers are nostalgic for a moment that was just before their time but because, as eras end, it is natural to look back at their origins and think about some of the roads not taken.

LEAD: At Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, L.I., Lenore Jane Kantor and Eric Scott Goldman, 1987 graduates of the University of Pennsylvania, were married last evening. Rabbi Philip Schechter and Cantor Wayne Siet officiated. The couple's parents are Dr. and Mrs. James L. Kantor of Oyster Bay Cove, L.I., and Mr.

LEAD: FOR the deans of the nation's graduate schools of business, the 1980's presented its share of challenges. Enrollments grew rapidly, bringing on intense competition for professors in fields like accounting and finance. And business schools began rethinking their curriculums amid a growing awareness that

LEAD: TWO LIVES, ONE RUSSIA, by Nicholas Daniloff. (Avon, $4.95.) After two weeks in a Soviet prison, the journalist Nicholas Daniloff felt closer to his great-great-grandfather, who was imprisoned in Siberia during the Decembrist uprising of 1825. ''This discursive interwoven narrative fits comfortably the sprawling and interconnected way life unfolds in the Soviet Union,'' Colette Shulman said here in 1988, ''encompassing the whole human experience and obligating one always to live with conflicting ideas and realities.

LEAD: International 3-17 American troops made a ''screw-up'' when they searched the Nicaraguan ambassador's residence in Panama City, President Bush conceded. The Nicaraguan government ordered 20 U.S. diplomats to leave Nicaragua within 72 hours in protest. 1 U.S. versions of search of embassy residence differ

LEAD: Tax on Condominiums Question: How are the real estate taxes on condominium apartments calculated? Should similar apartments in the same building pay the same taxes? . . . K. B., Manhattan Answer: According to Jeffrey Schanback, deputy commissioner for the property division in the city's Department of Finance, when tax apportionment assignments are first made for condominiums, the portion to be paid on each unit is also established.

LEAD: Dr. Nancy Jill Steiner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David S. Steiner of New York and Llewellyn Park, N.J., was married last evening to Michael Jeffrey Halpern, the son of Edith Halpern of Rye Brook, N.Y., and the late Frank Halpern. Rabbi Robert Rothman performed the ceremony at the Pierre in New York.

LEAD: What kind of year was 1989? Not a bad one, if new films and cameras are your ultimate fantasies. And even if you don't know an ISO speed from a fill-flash button, chances are the quality of your pictures improved during the last 12 months.
LEAD: THE Kobak recipe for 12-step holiday eggnog:

LEAD: Three teen-agers were arrested yesterday and charged in the killings of a pregnant woman and an 18-year-old girl in a Queens housing project. The who were killed as the youths tried unsuccessfully to shoot a man with whom they had argued earlier.

LEAD: Q. We have a septic tank that is no longer used. I have read that, if left unfilled, there is danger of a cave-in. Is the danger greater or less if the tank is not used, and if filling is advisable, which is best, soil or stone?
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: A CENTURY of draining and road building, mosquito eradication and waste dumping has reduced the Hackensack Meadowlands to a featureless reed-choked vista that greets motorists driving the northern reaches of the New Jersey Turnpike. Few birds sing, and about the only thing that nests in the once-fertile mud are discarded tires.
LEAD: For more than 300 years, the family of Rabindra Ghosh has profited from a unique right bestowed by a Mogul emperor: control of about 40 miles of the Ganges River near here.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Martin Heller of Madison, N.J., and Sanibel Island, Fla., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Jennifer Heller, and Dr. Noah Heftler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Heftler of New York and East Hills, L.I.

LEAD: I only wish my father were alive to read John W. Miller's article ''Birdmen of Harlem,'' (Nov. 19). My Dad raised and raced pigeons, in Brooklyn, for more than 40 years. His obsession started when he was about 9 years old. He even secretly kept some pigeons in his bedroom until my grandmother got wise to him.
LEAD: An official said his disclosure of the arrest of a man identified as the top Noriega aide appeared to have been based on erroneous data. Page 6.

LEAD: THE Union and Confederate troops, their muskets stacked, marched to the regimental dinner two by two, opposing armies celebrating a holiday truce and separated on this day only by tables of brownies, cinnamon buns and pies.

LEAD: The Government has not recovered documents from the invasion of Panama that reveal any smoking gun that would bolster its drug-trafficking case against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega or lead to new charges, Federal officials say.

LEAD: No decade stands alone. As Thomas Mann observed, ''it is only we mortals who ring bells and fire off pistols'' when the calendar flips from years numbered 80-something to years numbered 90. The Roaring Twenties arose from the roar of war in the preceding decade and collapsed into a roaring depression in the next.

LEAD: The marriage of Gail Schargel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Schargel of Mamaroneck, N.Y., to William Powell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Manley Powell of Elkins, W. Va., took place last evening at the Hampshire Country Club in Mamaroneck. Rabbi Albert L. Sturmer officiated. Mrs. Powell, a graduate of Lehigh University, is a commercial real-estate appraiser for the Appraisal Group in Charlottesville, Va.
LEAD: The Knicks have not played especially well in their last five games, but they have found ways to win them all.

LEAD: Rumanian intellectuals, writers and artists emerged this week after long decades spent in the darkness of the Ceausescu regime, and found themselves groping for words.
LEAD: YOU don't have to be Jewish to love kosher food. In fact, less than a third of the 6 million consumers who spent about $1.5 billion for kosher products last year were Jewish.

LEAD: THERE are any number of reasons why our family found itself cooling off in the pastel blue water of a date palm irrigation reservoir in Ghardaia, Algeria, about to drive across the Sahara - too many Foreign Legion films in my youth, the indelible impression ''Lawrence of Arabia'' made on its original release, even the fact that, when we were children, my best friend had a sandbox while I did not.

LEAD: One of the most enduring symbols of the holiday season is the Christmas tree, and New York City certainly has no shortage of dazzling ones. And this may be the very best time to see them, after Christmas, when the crowds and traffic have thinned. Most will be up through this week.

LEAD: Q. We have a septic tank that is no longer used. I have read that, if left unfilled, there is danger of a cave-in. Is the danger greater or less if the tank is not used, and if filling is advisable, which is best, soil or stone?

LEAD: To the Editor: In Mayer Horn's reply to Simone Goldfarb's letter concerning the Carey Airport Express facility on Park Avenue (Travel, Oct. 15), he writes, ''The Police Department has been diligent in recognizing the vulnerablity of travelers at the Park Avenue stop.''

LEAD: THE serenity of Boerum Hill, a neighborhood lined with Greek Revival, Italianate and early Victorian brownstones, is quite a contrast to the bustle of downtown Brooklyn, just a five-minute walk away. Many residents think of the area as a hidden treasure.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH it's much too soon to be nostalgic for the 80's, it's hard to picture them being anyone's good old days. For me the last decade had no memories as sweet as charlotte russes or mello rolls.

LEAD: NORTHWESTERN UNIVERSITY and the city of Evanston are clearing more land, including a historic landmark, for a new phase in the development of a $400 million, 24-acre research park aimed at speeding technology to the marketplace and putting university and city land on the tax rolls.

LEAD: Followers of our regular Works in Progress feature are aware that, among other things, the Iraqi Government is rebuilding the ancient city of Babylon; that lifesize replicas of Columbus's three ships are under construction in Spain; that Fidel Castro is restoring Havana's Hotel Nacional to the flamboyance of its heyday in the 1920's; that a stadium in Barcelona is having its floor lowered in preparation for the 1992 summer Olympics, and that a company in California has finished a prototype for a personal aircraft that some of us may own in the next century.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: JUST ENOUGH ROPE: An Intimate Memoir. By Joan Braden. (Villard, $19.95.) Joan Braden has taken a lot of heat for this book, which has been criticized as a vapid kiss-and-sell by a Washington society hostess with the capital's most notorious ''open'' marriage. The title, ''Just Enough Rope,'' refers to the amount of freedom the author has received from her husband, the syndicated columnist Tom Braden.

LEAD: To the Editor: About once a month, I am a day-tripper to New York City. I find eating a pizza slice in the Port Authority Bus Terminal has all the cachet Letty Cottin Pogrebin found in the exotic Italian Riviera. One woman's crepes suzettes is another woman's pepperoni pizazz. JOAN MARY MACEY Binghamton, N.Y.

LEAD: WARM LENTIL SALAD, ROAST CHICK-en with mashed potatoes, scallops crusted in potato slivers, olive-flecked risotto and tarte Tatin. These may have been the hot restaurant orders in 1989, but ''sauce on the side'' was the most uttered phrase. In 1990, that request will become a mantra.
LEAD: I KNOW, I know. You are tired of hearing about the decade. But automobiles are worth thinking about. And looking at.
LEAD: THE BATTLE OF BRITAIN The Greatest Air Battle of World War II. By Richard Hough and Denis Richards. Illustrated. 413 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $29.95.
LEAD: Fifty-eight percent of black high school seniors failed their final examinations this year, a disastrous showing that has revived the controversy over segregated education in South Africa.

LEAD: THE captors held my husband and me for six years. Like many hostages, we let them into our home unwittingly. Who would have guessed those wide-eyed faces disguised heinous schemes - plans to ransack our drawers, extort candy in check-out lines, vandalize our furniture with crayons and grape juice, and hijack phone conversations with demonic screams?

LEAD: About 150 people marched through the streets of Howard Beach, Queens, yesterday to protest a state court's dismissal this month of the riot convictions of three defendants in a racial attack in 1986.

LEAD: I want to say how happy - overjoyed, really - I was upon reading ''Where Foster Children Become Family'' on Nov. 26. Having worked as a psychologist with foster children and their natural and foster parents, I know firsthand the difficulties involved in helping the children find a better way of life.
LEAD: SOUTHERN COMFORT The Garden District of New Orleans, 1800-1900. By S. Frederick Starr. Photographs by Robert S. Brantley. 308 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $35.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. James R. Farrell of Oradell, N.J., have made known the April wedding plans of their daughter, Kathleen Adair Farrell, and Mikael Peter Thygesen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Thygesen of Harrison, N.Y.

LEAD: The book that took Harry Devlin 20 years to write, ''Portraits of American Architecture: Monuments to a Romantic Mood, 1830-1920,'' recreates an era when a Classical vision of life, so orderly, so rational and carefully conceived, steadily lost its hold over this country's imagination, giving way to the force of Romantic thought.
LEAD: IN one of his celebrated asides, Oscar Wilde proposed that life imitates art. Tom Wolfe said much the same thing in an essay on the contemporary novel for a recent issue of Harper's Magazine.

LEAD: Two men, including a paralegal in the Queens District Attorney's office, were killed, and a Yale University sophomore was seriously wounded, when a gunman opened fire on a crowd of people standing outside a Manhattan nightclub near Union Square early yesterday, the police said.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: IN Europe, the circus is not just something to take your kids to - grown men and the government fight about it passionately in the popular press. So when the Olympics of circus arts is held in Paris every January, the historic Cirque d'Hiver building becomes the hottest spot in the city on a chilly winter weekend.

LEAD: What is it with New Year's Eve, anyway? I don't think I've actually ever met anyone who liked it, and yet we all persist in celebrating. It's a silly holiday, one of forced revelry, a night when - like the senior prom - reality can't possibly fulfill expectations.

LEAD: From Liverpool, With Hysteria ''So this is America,'' Ringo Starr said 25 years ago when several thousand wailing fans greeted the Beatles at Kennedy International Airport. ''They all seem out of their minds.'' A. J. S. Rayl, who has reported on the entertainment industry for a number of publications, and the freelance photographer Curt Gunther, who was lucky enough to tag along with Brian Epstein and his four charges as they crisscrossed this country, have put together BEATLES '64: A Hard Day's Night in America (Doubleday, $24.95), a tribute to Beatlemania in pictures and words.

LEAD: The engagement of Ellen F. Friedman to Samuel David Bender, a son of Dr. Eileen T. Bender and Dr. Harvey A. Bender of South Bend, Ind., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph N. Friedman of New York and Neponsit, Queens. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: MIDDLE-CLASS NEW YORK IS SLIDING slowly into decline. A novelist friend who spent his whole life on the West Side is thinking Suffolk because his young son is hounded by drug dealers twice a day as he goes back and forth to school. An elderly woman is knocked to the sidewalk on Park Avenue and brutally beaten with a pipe until she surrenders her pocketbook.

LEAD: Professional sports on free television will be replaced more and more by pay-per-view and cable network broadcasts. Nonprofessional, or college-sports networks, will continue to grow, but with more broadcasts on pay-per-view and cable networks as well.

LEAD: No individuals face criminal charges in the death of a Dickinson College freshman who fell from a bedroom window at Alpha Chi Rho on Sept. 29, but the local police have charged the fraternity with ''furnishing alcoholic beverages to a minor.''
LEAD: A listing of Caribbean islands on Dec. 10 omitted some B.W.I.A. flights from Miami. B.W.I.A. flies daily to Aruba and Curacao and twice a week to Martinique.

LEAD: IN the battle among banks for retail customers, the victors are likely to be those that use high technology best. So banks are now spending more than $10 billion a year on electronic technology to attract more customers, serve them more efficiently and keep staffs free to sell more profitable products.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard D. Carr of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anita Celine Carr, to Jeffrey John Hass, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Myron R. Hass of Sweetwater Oaks, Fla. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: IT'S another easy morning on Little Jim Bridge in Florida's Indian River country, the sun just beginning to warm the backs of the regulars fishing from the catwalks and debating, again, how best to hook the noble snapper.
LEAD: THE ANCIENT CHILD By N. Scott Momaday. 314 pp. New York: Doubleday.

LEAD: Money may at first seem an unlikely venue for propaganda. But any coin in any pocket has a message. Whether a bust of George Washington reminding us that we were the first of the great revolutionary governments or a profile of Lincoln reminding us of the Civil War and our experience with slavery. Each coin has some meaning underlying the mundane utility of money.
LEAD: Odd new neckties are finding their way into the men's-wear stream. Short and stubby, they look as if Harpo Marx got to them with his scissors.

LEAD: Sense of Revolt in Moldavia The rebellion storming through the Communist bloc now glitters just beyond a border town in the Soviet republic of Moldavia, a region filled with nationalist fervor. LEAD: FOR a number of very basic reasons, I think the open outcry system of trading futures contracts will be with us for a long time to come. The pit system is cheap, efficient and enormously successful. In contrast, the architects of computerized trading systems have yet to show that they can compete economically with the pit system.
LEAD: Cornelius Holden and Keith Williams each scored two baskets in an 11-2 surge midway in the second half, which carried Louisville to an 86-79 victory over Kentucky today.
LEAD: The Spanish news agency issued ''an energetic protest'' tonight with the American authorities over what it said was an intrusion into its offices in Panama by American soldiers there today.

LEAD: To speak of the postal history of Alaska, the next-to-newest state after Hawaii, seems anomalous. But Alaska yields inexpensive pleasures of discovery for the hobbyist.

Not that the couple has anything to worry about, said Mrs. Ansary, who expects about 50 people to show up; for the last few years, consumption of alcoholic beverages has decreased dramatically at all their holiday parties.

LEAD: In the eerie quiet that envelops the Capitol when Congress is out of session, there is a sense of dread about what comes next. The ethics turmoil that consumed the House of Representatives for much of 1989 is about to reappear in the Senate.
LEAD: Polly Cronyn Parrott, a former editor at The New York Herald Tribune died at her home in Plandome, L.I., on Thursday. She was 79 years old.

LEAD: A bitter trade dispute with the United States over wheat imports is posing a tough challenge for Nigeria's President, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, and is likely to come up when he visits Washington next month to meet with President Bush.

LEAD: IN the computer industry, which is known for flamboyant characters and child prodigies, American Telephone & Telegraph's Robert M. Kavner is emerging as a statesman. A newcomer to the business and an accountant by training, he is orchestrating an extraordinary shift in the fractious industry: Laying the foundation for a single software standard upon which computer equipment and program manufacturers can agree.
LEAD: WHERE THE BUCK STOPS The Personal and Private Writings of Harry S. Truman. Edited by Margaret Truman. 388 pp. New York: Warner Books. $22.95.

LEAD: Track and Field Coghlan Wins Two Races: Eamonn Coghlan, saying he was running to stay in shape, not for serious competition, won two races yesterday in the Manufacturers Hanover New Year's Classic in the Army field house at West Point, N.Y. Coghlan, the former Irish Olympian who set the world indoor mile record at 3 minutes 49.78 seconds in 1983, took the two-mile run in 8:53.15.

It is framed in natural wood, which picks up the browns of the bureau on which the cup and letter rest. The cup is Royal Stafford procelain, with a beautifully curved black and white handle.

LEAD: ''Old, not modern'' is how Dr. Johnson defined ''antiques'' in his 18th-century dictionary. In 1930, when United States Customs tackled the question, it came up with the more precise regulation that an antique was a work of art or a handicraft made before 1830, giving rise to the accepted notion that a genuine antique must be 100 years old - at least to pass through Customs duty-free.
