LEAD: JUSTIFIABLE HOMICIDE: Battered Women, Self-Defense, and the Law. By Cynthia K. Gillespie. (Ohio State University, $24.95.) The idea in our law that it is excusable to kill in self-defense goes back to medieval England. The cases that led to the development of the common law on self-defense fell into two classes: there were the highway-robber cases, where an unknown assailant sets upon someone who, in fighting back, kills his attacker; and then there were the barroom brawls, in which a dispute between two men escalates into a dangerous armed battle.

LEAD: A WINTER flu or cold will linger longer if you've got the blues, according to Dr. Peter Salovey, a health psychologist and researcher at Yale. Instead of hibernating under a sea of blankets feeling bad for yourself, try to keep active, he advises, and think optimistically.
LEAD: TERRIFYING LOVE Why Battered Women Kill and How Society Responds. By Lenore E. Walker. 342 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $19.95.

LEAD: ''I WALKED 10 steps from my desk to the secretary's and couldn't remember what files I came out for.'' ''I spent 15 minutes finding my car at Westfarms.'' ''Even with two of us, we couldn't think of a co-worker's name.''

LEAD: A new mixed-use development with a nautical motif has been completed in what was once an industrial area in South Norwalk, Conn. Named Windsway, the project comprises 12,000 square feet of office space and 39 rental apartments. It is in one of six so-called enterprise zones created by the state to stimulate renovation and development through tax-abatement incentives.

LEAD: When Fiona Shaw opened as Rosalind in ''As You Like It'' at London's Old Vic last summer, the theater critic Michael Billington wrote in The Guardian that the Irish-born actress ''has a touch of Celtic fairy about her that makes you believe her when she says, 'I have, since I was 3 years old, conversed with a magician.

LEAD: When the sticky champagne glasses are cleared from the tables New Year's morning and the confetti swept up, the Venetian Room at the Fairmont Hotel will be just a memory, perhaps the last of the famed hotel supper clubs to shut its doors.

LEAD: Kappa Sigma is the oldest nationally chartered fraternity at Washington State University. It scheduled a dance for late October, and it needed some way to decorate its house. So a group of students pledging for membership set out to round up a variety of materials around Pullman that included 50 sheets of plywood, a dozen rolls of tarpaper, five bales of hay, two fake geese and a cement statue of the Virgin Mary.

LEAD: Wilma K. Hecker of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Loren Celia Hecker, to Jeffrey Zane Taufield, the son of Mrs. Robert S. Taufield of Englishtown, N.J., and the late Mr. Taufield. A March wedding is planned.

In the show designated, however, it doesn't work out that way. Nevertheless, the mask form is as old as art itself and most of the 40 artists here rise to the occasion, especially Harold Olejarz, in his ''Cedar Man.

LEAD: An entry in the Travel Watch column on page 21 of the Travel section today mislabels an exchange rate for Brazil's currency of a year ago. A dollar on Dec. 22, 1988, was equal to 935 old cruzados, not new ones; the new cruzado, equal to 1,000 old cruzados, was not introduced until Jan. 14.

LEAD: WHO is Arif Nasr? reads the sign we created to display at one town fair. The bold words underline a dark silhouette. Choosing a silhouette for illustration was not just a design concept. We don't know what Arif looks like. We don't know what he looks like and yet we continue to work on his behalf.

LEAD: Since 1971, a program called Mabon (Mothers and Babies Off Narcotics) has been sheltering and treating drug addicts. Once the residents were trying to beat heroin; today they are trying to beat crack. At the moment there are 20 women and 23 children enrolled in the program run by Odyssey House and located on Wards Island.

LEAD: The year 1989 will go down as the one that David Levy lost to a computer. The Scottish international master and computer programmer was flatly crushed 4-0 in his Dec. 11-14 match with the world's most powerful nonhuman chessplayer, Deep Thought, the creation of a team of scientists at Carnegie-Mellon University in

LEAD: I deplore the acts described by Steven Lewis, as do all conscientious hunters. He does a disservice by lumping us together with the unethical few who choose to violate laws and ignore the rights of landowners. I count it a great privilege to receive permission to hunt on private land. The landowners become my friends.

LEAD: Acid rain appears to pose a long-term threat to forests, but ozone and natural causes of stress are also implicated in forest decline and may be more harmful to trees in the short run, scientists in a Federal research program have found.

LEAD: Lenin once condemned czarist Russia as a ''prison house of nations,'' and put part of the blame for the country's social and political problems on the myriad peoples forced together under the czar's hand. The words of the Soviet Union's founder must echo in the mind of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the man now holding the keys to the prison.

LEAD: The Ramans are back - if indeed they exist. In 1973 Arthur C. Clarke published a classic puzzle-story about enigmatic aliens, ''Rendezvous With Rama.'' In that novel (set in the year 2130) an enormous spaceship shaped like a hollow cylinder entered the solar system; all attempts to communicate with it were unsuccessful, yet the spaceship (dubbed Rama) allowed itself to be boarded by a team of human explorers, who discovered many marvels of bioengineering inside but no sign of the Ramans, the advanced beings who presumably built the impressive craft.

LEAD: A senior United States Embassy official said today that his earlier disclosure of the arrest of an Israeli identified as Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's closest associate appeared to have been based on erroneous information from the American military.
LEAD: When everything comes together right, when the Florida sun stays warm, Antonio Francisco can pick 90 buckets of tomatoes a day.

LEAD: THERE is a tacit agreement among morning people that they are superior to lie-a-beds. Because their feet hit the floor first in the morning, they have a jump on the day and assume an advantage over those who sleep later.

LEAD: Jim Brock is executive director of the Cotton Bowl football game, which will pay its competing teams about $3 million each to play in Dallas tomorrow afternoon. The five big bowl games - Cotton, Rose, Orange, Sugar and Fiesta -will pay their 10 teams a total of about $36 million, much of the money coming from television.

LEAD: From Harvard to the Hard Rock Cafe to Hollywood, people concerned about highway deaths on New Year's are promoting the designated driver concept, and researchers say it is catching on, but habits do not change easily.
LEAD: To the end, Nicolae Ceausescu was uncompromising. Never mind the tide of reform sweeping other Communist countries, he declared.

LEAD: In a mood of friendship and good will, at least 15,000 Jews and Palestinians danced, sang, laughed and talked to one another today as they formed a human chain for peace that snaked two and a half miles around the walls of Jerusalem's Old City.

LEAD: YOU see the image in your camera's window and press the button. The film advances - and there is another scene, moving you to press the button. With the device around your neck, you are a director, an auteur - an imagist with the power to preserve your experience.

LEAD: AS a sculptor and foundryman in this seaside town for the last 16 years, Richard Remsen has seen retired people move in and families and businesses move out, creating what he considers an unnatural and empty environment.

LEAD: In her article ''Power Lines and Battle Lines'' (Opinion Page, Nov. 5), Amy Handlin asks (Rhetorically, I hope), ''Are not public officials elected to represent the emotions and fears, as much as the tangible needs, of their constituents?'' I cant' help but wonder if she would approve of such responsibilities as they were once manifested, namely, in electing officeholders who played upon the public fears of certain minorities and other ''undesirables'' moving in.

LEAD: SURVIVING the decline in the economy will be the overriding issue for 1990, say leaders of the county's business community. Although the consensus is that Westchester will fare better than many other areas, there is concern that layoffs and a lack of affordable housing will hamper the county's economic recovery.

LEAD: Aw, come on, everybody, lighten up a little. It wasn't that bad. The decade, I mean. You know which one I'm talking about. The one that's going to end tonight. The (shudder, shudder) 80's.

LEAD: The end of the 1980's prompts a review of the top echelon of American bridge. Others have retired from tournament playlike Charles Goren and Sam Fry Jr.

LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev had better start addressing cards now if he intends to return by next New Year's Day the holiday greetings he was to receive this weekend. James Lawlor of Fairfield, Iowa, said his idea was to send the Soviet President a huge card ''and have everybody in America sign it.'' A busy year later he ended up with an 800-foot-long ''card'' signed by a half-million people.

LEAD: MARBLE is durable, but susceptible to soiling, staining and becoming dull. Periodic maintenance will keep it looking its best and prompt action will remove most stains.

LEAD: EARLY mass transit in New York City consisted of occasional horse-drawn coaches competing with other vehicles on the city streets. By putting coaches on rails, the loads that horse teams could carry was increased, and in 1853 the Third Avenue Rail Road Company laid tracks up Third Avenue.

One difference, though, is the S-VHS option. Studios seldom offer the format, because it requires a specially equipped VCR and the market is narrow.

LEAD: September wedding plans have been announced for Megan Louise Robinson and Joseph Richard Pope Jr. by the prospective bride's parents, Sarah Bonham Robinson of Westfield, N.J., and Bruce M. Robinson of Pleasanton, Calif. Mr. Pope's parents also live in Westfield.

LEAD: DON'T think that because tomorrow is New Year's Day, Christmas is finally over. The holiday does not end officially until next Sunday, Jan. 6,- which is Twelfth Night, also known as Epiphany. On this day, all decorations must come down in order not to invite bad luck for the coming year.

LEAD: The composer and saxophonist Henry Threadgill has spent the last decade or so leading some of the most provocative bands in New York. His new group - a loose septet featuring Curtis Fowlkes on trombone, Brandon Ross and Masujaa on guitars, Marcus Rojas and Edwin Rodriguez on tubas and E. J. Rodriguez on drums - doesn't break any patterns.

LEAD: TONIGHT, THE ALVIN AILEY American Dance Theater will close what has been one of its most difficult - and yet most successful - seasons. Ailey died on Dec. 1, five days before the troupe's opening at the City Center. Out of the red-hot crucible of grief and mourning, the Ailey dancers performed as never before.

LEAD: Hermann Julius Oberth, a pioneer of the space age who worked with Werner von Braun to help develop Germany's V-2 rocket, died on Friday. He was 95 years old. Mr. Oberth died at a hospital in Nuremberg after a short illness, the Hermann Oberth Museum in Feucht said in a statement.

LEAD: FOUR years after crack flooded into New Jersey, state support for drug treatment programs remains oriented primarily toward heroin addiction, and the programs can handle only a fraction of the cocaine and heroin addicts, private health and drug experts say.

LEAD: With the next forcible return of Vietnamese boat people expected within two weeks, Hong Kong officials disclosed today that refugees inside detention camps here have drawn up resistance plans that include setting fires, arming themselves with homemade weapons and taking hostages.
LEAD: A chart last week depicting reported AIDS cases was incorrectly labeled. The numbers were in thousands.

LEAD: In October, four fraternity-associated sexual assaults prompted the University of Missouri to suspend the 28 ''little sister'' organizations that had paired their members with fraternity members in rush and fund-raising activities. All of the attacks, the university's police said, were alcohol related.

LEAD: The C. Oliver Iselin estate in Upper Brookville, L.I., is being developed into 16 luxury homes, each on at least five acres. Iselin, a banker and sportsman who died in 1932, owned three boats that successfully defended the America's Cup.

La Guardia's papers filled just 600 boxes - and the

LEAD: A BABY'S first year is a time of joy, learning, love and money. Lots of it. And as more items are created just for baby, and baby-boom parents want their baby to have it all, even more costs are added.

LEAD: It was, says David Puttnam of his first film since he resigned as chairman of Columbia Pictures two years ago, ''very complicated to choreograph.'' For Michael Caton-Jones, it was ''a bit like trying to make Ben Hur with three horses, one of them rather old and sleepy.'' Neither the producer nor the director was greatly exaggerating.

LEAD: I NEVER wonder where I will be on New Year's Eve. As long as my friend Beverly has New Year's Eve parties, I'll be there. Her parties are the most luxurious highlights of my social calendar. But this year I will be smarter. I am ready to have a great time without eating myself silly and waking up in the morning without my self-respect.
LEAD: At least 75 people, many of them homeless, have died of exposure to the cold in northern India and Bangladesh during the last three days, news reports said today.

LEAD: Q. We have a septic tank that is no longer used. I have read that, if left unfilled, there is danger of a cave-in. Is the danger greater or less if the tank is not used, and if filling is advisable, which is best, soil or stone?

LEAD: Viewing American foreign policy these days can seem a bit like watching a badly dubbed and poorly edited foreign movie. The actors often seem to be speaking the wrong lines and their actions often seem to be all out of order.

LEAD: Oliver L. North, the former National Security Council aide convicted of three charges in the Iran-contra affair, made his musical stage debut Friday night as a narrator of ''Peter and the Wolf,'' Prokofiev's classic musical tale for children.

LEAD: WHILE 1989 was not a banner year for discovering restaurants rated excellent, there was one clear winner in that league. La Provence (86 Washington Street, South Norwalk, 855-8958) combines a comfortable decor inspired by the south of France, with food to match. The restaurant, operated by two graduates of the Guy Savoy restaurant in Paris, features some of the most original and delicious fare to be found in Connecticut in years.
LEAD: As American troops sought to secure order here last week after having ousted Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega from power, the American invasion of Panama turned into an occupation.

LEAD: SIDNEY LUMET IS PLAYING A familiar role. He is at work, directing the latest movie in his long and prolific career. He is on his native soil, or, more accurately, native asphalt - the streets of New York, streets that have spawned so many of his films. He is wearing his customary clothes, a work shirt and jeans, and chewing Juicy Fruit gum in the same frenetic way he shoots takes.
LEAD: Andy Warhol was wrong. In my case, at least, fame clocked in at only 6:42 minutes, and that was before the final cut.
LEAD: Arthur Gelb, managing editor of The New York Times since 1986, retires today at age 65 and will be succeeded by Joseph Lelyveld, his deputy since last July.

LEAD: For decades, kosher restaurants have been part of the New York scene, featuring traditional fare like matzoh balls, chopped chicken liver and lox. But within the last few years, kosher pizza and falafel eateries have proliferated, as have upscale restaurants offering kosher cuisines like French, Moroccan and Chinese.

LEAD: Pentagon officials insist that the American intervention in Panama successfully demonstrated the armed forces' proficiency at airborne operations. But a closer examination of the Panama attack indicates that its large scale increased the number of civilian casualties and possibly forfeited the opportunity to seize Gen.

LEAD: Brace yourself, the world is getting smaller. Fax machines and the Concorde have brought the ends of the earth together with record speed. Now as we enter a new decade, designers are addressing a universal problem - lack of space. Many have created sophisticated and ingenious objects that address every need from fitness to storage.
LEAD: For a 70-year-old maple on Milford Common, 1989 was another year of familiar but sublime transformation, from the promises of spring to the reality of winter. (NYT/Stephen Castagneto)
LEAD: A Coast Guard vessel reached a Greek freighter taking on water northeast of Hawaii today and evacuated half its crew, the Guard said.

LEAD: IT is probably inevitable that a society as star-struck as ours should focus on leaders in analyzing why organizations succeed or fail. As a long-time student and teacher of management, I, too, have tended to look to the men and women at the top for clues on how organizations achieve and maintain institutional health.
LEAD: FIFTEEN years ago tonight, Helen and Jimmy Hunter had dinner plans.

LEAD: Two sightseeing planes collided off southern New Zealand today and one crashed, killing seven people on board, according to news reports.

LEAD: The music at The Vil-lage Vanguard a few weeks ago seemed normal, at first. Branford Marsalis, sounding mostly like John Coltrane, but throwing bits of Sonny Stitt and Sonny Rollins, Wayne Shorter and Lester Young into his saxophone improvisations, worked in front of a standard rhythm section of piano, bass and drums.

LEAD: To the Editor: Next time you visit Versailles, take the tour of Madame DuBarry's apartments even though it is only given in French. The guide, who was British, gave the tour in French and was reluctant to offend the French tourists by speaking English. She could not explain why the tour was not offered in English.

LEAD: FRANZ SCHUBERT WAS NOT THE ignored and misunderstood genius that the romance of historical anecdote has seduced us into believing. And curiously, it is the stage pieces - which subsequent generations have chosen to ignore - that first brought him to the attention of the Viennese music public.

LEAD: Tonight, at the crack of midnight, the 12th annual New Year's Eve performance of the Sorvillo Symphony, played on pots, pans, tambourines and an occasional kettle, will be heard in front of Helen and Carmen Sorvillo's home in Howard Beach, Queens. Mr. Sorvillo, an art teacher, and Mrs. Sorvillo, who works for Newsday, have been welcoming the new year in this manner since the birth of their eldest son, Paul.
LEAD: There was no shortage last week of Christmas-related donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

Benoit of Cos Cob, Conn. A February wedding is planned. Miss McGillicuddy, the owner of McGillicuddy Interior Design in New York, graduated from Holy Cross College and the New York School of Interior Design.

LEAD: The Shawangunk cliffs tower like gothic ramparts over a sleepy valley west of New Paltz, N.Y. Seen from a distance, they appear as impregnable as a fortress, and one might wonder how anyone could scale them. But then at the base of the cliffs you discover that whenever rock is deposited in such a massive formation, it is never entirely sheer.

LEAD: James J. Florio has vowed to be a much different Governor of New Jersey than Thomas H. Kean, in management style if not in his policies. But the discussions of changes he hopes to make in the structure and substance of government are likely to be overshadowed by the slowing economy and a looming fiscal crisis.

LEAD: To enjoy the full flavor of cooked onions, it isn't enough to cook them just until they are soft; they must be soft and golden brown. It takes a little longer, but it is worth the time. In this Indian-style lamb recipe, the onions are used as a topping, preserving their texture and their sweetness, which is usually partly lost when they are combined with other ingredients.

LEAD: I SAW my first television in 1932 - a BBC production of Pirandello's play ''The Man With a Flower in His Mouth.'' I have seen a lot of television since, in most of the countries of the world, and have spent three years as a television critic. I am convinced that the future of broadcasting rests with radio.

LEAD: PROSPECTIVE tenants in New York often have to contend with costly real estate brokers, cranky landlords and choosy co-op boards. But foreign governments at the United Nations in search of new office or living space have an additional complication: the United States Government.

LEAD: Mark Anderson Design made its name in graphics: product packaging and annual reports for Apple Computer; trade-show exhibits for Herman Miller and U S Sprint. Now it is branching out into functional art objects - a chair, a lamp, a toaster - that pay somewhat flippant homage to the principles of architecture and design.

LEAD: We live in the northeast section of Vermont. Once the leaves fall off the trees, you cannot walk anywhere, not even on your own property, until the last weekend of November.

LEAD: As early as 1902 singers started putting their art on Mr. Edison's fairly recent (1877) invention, only they recorded on flat disks rather than the cylinders favored by the inventor. It is safe to say that every great singer, and thousands of lesser ones, made records. Eventually their original records disappeared, but they were not lost.

LEAD: Ulysses Dove's ''Vespers'' drew tumultuous cheers in a performance by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater on Friday night at City Center, and it is easy to see why. Like ''Episodes,'' his new work this season, ''Vespers'' is an explosive dance set to driving percussive music. But the older dance, performed to music by Mikel Rouse, is a purer conscious venture into formalism.

LEAD: Dotty Schnure, a mother who has a job away from home, always used disposable diapers on her two young daughters. She estimates that she used 90 small diapers a week per child when they were infants, 60 medium-size diapers a week per child for the next three months, and 30 large diapers for the next two years - roughly 4,920 diapers per child.

The maverick movie maker who tilted at Hollywood and lost is back home making movies from the same Kensington mews house where he first began nearly two decades ago.

LEAD: In regard to the article ''Helping Women With Child Support'' (New Jersey Q & A, Nov. 19): The efforts of Sandy Feld and Aware are to be applauded. The fact that there are deadbeat dads who don't pay child support is reprehensible. It makes all dads look bad. However, on behalf of the innocent children of divorce everywhere, there might be other factors to consider.

LEAD: The annual holiday concerts of the New York String Orchestra under Alexander Schneider celebrate youth and experience. This year's orchestra consisted of 63 players (including winds and a percussionist) between the ages of 15 and 22, assembled for the 81-year-old Mr. Schneider's 11-day seminar. The teaching, one suspects, must somewhat contradict what the students learn at modern academies, just as some of the conductor's interpretive choices depart from current notions of correct period practice.
LEAD: ''I'M between a rock and a hard place,'' said George B. Melick, director of the Hunterdon County Board of Chosen Freeholders. ''Nobody in their right mind wants a landfill in their backyard.''
LEAD: Louis Lipps strolled to work on Friday in a blue suit, a portable phone and a folder of papers in hand.

LEAD: WHEN I was 4 years old, I didn't understand why I couldn't eat dessert before dinner and why I couldn't smoke cigarettes. Now that I am 17, I've got the answers to those questions, but these days something else is bothering me. It has to do with my grandfather. He was kind and helpful, and most of all, he was like a second father to me, but I don't understand why he smoked.
LEAD: Dave Jamerson scored 39 points to lift Ohio University to a 79-73 come-from-behind victory over Fordham tonight in the Volunteer Classic.

LEAD: THE entrance to the Gazelle d'Or, the old converted hunting lodge of Baron Jean Pellenc in Taroudant, southwestern Morocco, is a long drive lined with whispering eucalyptus trees that bend and touch 30 feet overhead. The road passes through a tall wrought-iron gate, its guard in a white djellaba, a hooded overgarment for both men and women.
LEAD: For some people the dawn of the century's final decade is not an occasion for cosmic resolutions or personal soul searching.

LEAD: A dog that was shot by a mailman this week will be buried in a silk-lined casket at the expense of the Postal Service, and the letter carrier has been charged with felony counts that could send him to prison for more than five years.

LEAD: The Commercial Property column on Dec. 17 about foreign investment in the suburbs misstated the size of the addition to the Royal Executive Office Park for which approval is expected from the village of Rye Brook, N.Y. It is 340,000 square feet.

LEAD: BETHLEHEM may have been crowded, but Caesar Augustus produced a more accurate count of the population 1,989 years ago than the Census Bureau is likely to achieve in its 1990 count in Westchester.

LEAD: For the last five years, 8,000 workers and 7,000 soldiers toiled each day to build the House of the Republic, a great and solid palace measuring 300 feet from ground to flagpole that was to have been a memorial to a man and his wife - Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu.

LEAD: LAST month former Senator Thomas Eagleton resigned from the board of directors of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, charging that the exchange is too riddled with cronyism to discipline unethical traders. Mr. Eagleton recommended that the Chicago exchange replace traditional open-outcry trading with an electronic system that leaves an audit trail.
LEAD: Too many Americans believe that the best New Year's noisemakers are guns - unaware that a bullet shot into the air returns to earth at nearly the same velocity as when it was fired.

LEAD: Bach's Magnificat and Vivaldi's Gloria will be the major works in a concert of holiday Baroque music by the Taghkanic Chorale and Orchestra at the Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue at 10th Street, at 9 o'clock tonight. The 120-member choral ensemble, conducted by Dennis Keene, will sing Venetian antiphonal pieces, the Rondeau from Jean Joseph Mouret's Symphony of Fanfares, and Handel's ''Coronation'' Anthem.

LEAD: A FEW months ago, I mentioned to some associates that I was thinking about writing an article on why I liked working with women. Men invariably responded with flippancy, raised eyebrows, ribald chuckles or lewd innuendo. Women unhesitatingly gave the topic a serious context. Most wanted a full discussion of the subject right then and there.

LEAD: An article on Dec. 10 about a stock transaction involving Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins of New York City misstated provisions of Federal gift-tax laws. The maximum each taxpayer can give without paying gift taxes is $600,000 in total, not per recipient.

LEAD: During more than a year in self-imposed exile, former President Chun Doo Hwan has declined to answer questions about the abuses of power and corruption that marked his repressive eight-year rule of South Korea - the dark side of the nation's economic miracle of the last decade.

LEAD: Consistency is not a keystone of the coming year's styles. Quite contrasting ideas will coexist, satisfying the ever-growing eclecticism of fashion followers.

LEAD: For years, experts have dubbed Czechoslovakia's spy agency the ''two Czech'' service. Agents of the Office for the Protection of State Secrets got one check from Prague, the pun goes, and another from their real bosses at K.G.B. headquarters in Moscow.

LEAD: One shop has a faux French accent and the other a real Spanish one, but they both speak the same fashion language. It's a language understood by young fashion followers on a budget who nonetheless change their clothes as often as the color of their lipstick. Two new boutiques on Lexington Avenue within a block of each other are now vying for these young women constantly seeking out the latest trend.

LEAD: Connecticut's glutted condominium market, where owners and investors have come and gone with the winds of profit and loss, is about to get an infusion of what state officials call ''forever housing.''

LEAD: To the Editor: Over the years I've done quite a lot of high-mountain driving - all but one or two of Europe's most formidable passes - and confess to being scared by any grade close to 30 degrees.

LEAD: THE CROWDS LINING UP AT THE Ziegfeld are liable to be a lot less festive than ordinary holiday moviegoers, even those on their way to see a big film whose star is surely Oscar bait. In fact, they're apt to be experiencing serious apprehension. ''Born on the Fourth of July'' is a film with a painful subject, and it's the work of a director extremely adept at inflicting pain.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Armand P. Neukermans of Palo Alto, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter Els Maria Neukermans and Peter Standish Paine 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paine Jr. of New York and Willsboro, N.Y. An August wedding is planned.

LEAD: Samuel Beckett, who died Dec. 22 at the age of 83, was not only the pre-eminent playwright of his time, he was the most influential of artists. Shaping his drama around his perception of the impermanence of life, he greeted existential absurdities with characteristic humor. His signature brand of uproarious pessimism is represented by the statement made by Nell, the mother encased in an ashcan in ''Endgame'': ''Nothing is funnier than unhappiness.

LEAD: Cold weather drove prices up sharply for several commodities last week. Futures contracts for heating oil reached six-year highs, peaking at $1.02 a gallon before profit taking caused declines at week's end. In November, heating oil futures sold for slightly less than 60 cents a gallon. An explosion that shut down the nation's second-largest refinery, an Exxon complex in Louisiana, added to the upward pressure.
LEAD: It wasn't a bad day at all for Paul Hackett.

LEAD: Twelve thousand invitations, each good for two people, have been sent out for the inauguration of David N. Dinkins tomorrow as New York City Mayor on the steps of City Hall, a spokeswoman for the inaugural committee said yesterday.
LEAD: Esther McCoy, an architectural historian and critic, died of emphysema on Friday at her home in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 85 years old.

LEAD: As Leonard Bernstein and an international orchestra churned through Beethoven's Ninth Symphony in a concert in East Berlin Christmas Day, it was evident that the maestro had not played a better house in many a year. The musicians came from East and West Germany, the United States, the Soviet Union, France and Britain, and the performance came on the first Christmas in 28 years that East and West Berliners had mingled freely.

LEAD: With fortress-like security thrown up to meet a threatened attack, an almost empty Northwest Airlines jumbo jet from Paris landed here today, uneventfully except for the crush of reporters and television crews assigned to greet the few passengers.

LEAD: When Frederick Law Olmsted finished laying out his Riverside Park a century ago the beauty and serenity of the area on Manhattan's Upper West Side triggered a real estate boom that led to the building there of scores of four- and five-story brownstones, many with panoramic views of the Hudson River.

LEAD: Poised on the brink of a new decade, the world will pause Sunday night for one second. A ''leap second'' will occur at the very end of Dec. 31, 1989, making it the longest day of the year. The reason is that the extra second is needed to keep the world's clocks in time with the rotation of the planet, according to Government timekeeping officials.

LEAD: BEFORE the Reagan Administration cut off liberal money to the arts and humanities, I traveled around to a lot of posh little writing-teaching gigs. They'd fly you in, you'd get a pile of manuscripts to look over and a bunch of students. After some seminars and receptions, you'd take your check and fly home.

LEAD: EACH human brain cell can store the equivalent of 10,000 bits of information, and the brain has about 10 billion brain cells, according to The Body Almanac. The memory capacity of the brain, therefore, is estimated at 100 trillion (100,000,000,000,000) bits, or slightly more than 10 terabytes. Each brain cell can discharge an electrical impulse about 200 times a second.

LEAD: Just as Poland led the way among Eastern European nations in the move to democracy, it is leading the way in abandoning Communist economics in favor of capitalism.

LEAD: WHILE holiday revelers roam from party to party preparing to ring in the new decade, a dedicated group of civil servants in the Office of Legislative Services in Trenton sit hunched over computer consoles working feverishly to keep the government running smoothly into the new year. For them, the happy New Year's Eves are the odd-numbered ones: when they can join the merrymakers, perhaps take a saved-up vacation day and participate in the holiday cheer.

LEAD: The last day of the decade is clearly an occasion for retrospect. In audio, the 80's were a watershed - a time of fundamental change. The cardinal event was the birth of digital sound, a truly radical turning point whose ultimate implications are not yet fully realized.

LEAD: It appears the New York State Supreme Court will soon settle the question of whether Vincent (the Chin) Gigante (wearing bathrobe, accompanied by his chauffeur) is suffering delusions of persecution, as his relatives contend, or fear of prosecution, as Federal officials insist. Federal investigators say that Mr.

LEAD: To the Editor: A warning for readers regarding duty-free shops in airports. At the airport in Moscow I purchased what I thought was a 14-karat white-and-yellow-gold Omega watch for the equivalent of $670 only to find out from the authorized dealer in New York that not only was it stainless and goldplate but also that had I bought it here it would have been $475.

LEAD: Maura Terese Croghan and James R. Eustace, 1985 graduates of Fairfield University, are planning a May wedding, the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. John H. Croghan of Miami, have announced.

LEAD: With fortress-like security thrown up to meet a threatened attack, an almost empty Northwest Airlines jumbo jet from Paris landed here today, uneventfully except for the crush of reporters and television crews assigned to greet the few passengers.

LEAD: When Frederick Law Olmsted finished laying out his Riverside Park a century ago the beauty and serenity of the area on Manhattan's Upper West Side triggered a real estate boom that led to the building there of scores of four- and five-story brownstones, many with panoramic views of the Hudson River.

LEAD: Poised on the brink of a new decade, the world will pause Sunday night for one second. A ''leap second'' will occur at the very end of Dec. 31, 1989, making it the longest day of the year. The reason is that the extra second is needed to keep the world's clocks in time with the rotation of the planet, according to Government timekeeping officials.

LEAD: BEFORE the Reagan Administration cut off liberal money to the arts and humanities, I traveled around to a lot of posh little writing-teaching gigs. They'd fly you in, you'd get a pile of manuscripts to look over and a bunch of students. After some seminars and receptions, you'd take your check and fly home.

LEAD: This year on Long Island even the wealthiest school districts were not immune from irate and aroused voters. In Hewlett-Woodmere (''In 5 Towns District, a Teacher Impasse,'' Nov. 26), a bond and two budgets were defeated before a reduced budget was finally approved.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ORIENTEERING World Men - Peter Thoresen, Norway. World Women - Marita Skogum, Sweden. PADDLEBALL One-Wall: P.P.P.A. Division A Men's Doubles - Robert Sostre and Arsenio Rondon, Bronx, N.Y. Mixed Doubles - Robert Sostre and Madeline Frederick, Bronx, N.Y. Men's M.V.P.

LEAD: EACH human brain cell can store the equivalent of 10,000 bits of information, and the brain has about 10 billion brain cells, according to The Body Almanac. The memory capacity of the brain, therefore, is estimated at 100 trillion (100,000,000,000,000) bits, or slightly more than 10 terabytes. Each brain cell can discharge an electrical impulse about 200 times a second.
LEAD: For three quarters tonight, the Nets looked almost as good as the Detroit Pistons. Then reality set in.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: An April wedding is planned by Priscilla Ann Hook and Kevin Holleran, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Eugene R. Hook of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., have announced. Mr. Holleran is a son of Mrs. Richard P. Holleran of Downingtown, Pa., and the late Mr. Holleran.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Susan Patricia Crawford and Murdock Hardy Martin, graduates of Yale University, were married yesterday at St. Paul's Lutheran Church in Santa Monica, Calif., by the Rev. Reginald Schultz-Akerson, assisted by the Rev. Ernest Pipes, a Unitarian minister. The bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Charlton Crawford of Santa Monica.

LEAD: AS the Hillsborough Holdings Corporation prepared its filing for bankruptcy last week, it became the darling of Wall Street. A parade of investment bankers, having sniffed out the fact that the highly leveraged company, formed in 1987 by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, was planning to file for protection from its creditors, came peddling their skills at reorganization.

LEAD: CONCERNS over high infant mortality rates among high-risk populations on Long Island have prompted Nassau and Suffolk Counties to begin more aggressive campaigns to investigate and reduce the causes of such deaths.

LEAD: For the Devils, speed was at the top of their wish list during the off season, so Sylvain Turgeon was not a surprising acquisition. He had speed in his legs and wrists, a combination that can turn games around in a hurry.
LEAD: Michael Moore got a taste of Hollywood when he had to search for a distributor to handle his scorching documentary, ''Roger and Me.'' And now he's had a taste of New York.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: It's taken 10 years for the imes to catch up with the B-52's. With the Top 10 successes of their seventh album, ''Cosmic Thing'' (Reprise 9 25854, all three formats) and its hit single ''Love Shack,'' the group has finally moved beyond cult status. The B-52's were always popular on college radio stations, but from the perspective of the early-80's mainstream, the group was a novelty act, at once studiously retro and unnervingly futuristic.

LEAD: Thank you for your article about Kathy Boylan, our Island's most prominent peace activist [ ''About Long Island: Waging Protest Against the Machines of War,'' Oct. 1 ] . It would be interesting to ask why a deeply religious Catholic woman, along with a 67-year-old nun, would risk 14 years in prison, not to mention swimming through highly polluted icy cold water, to protest the Navy's launching of another Trident nuclear submarine.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. David L. Marshall of Darien, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter Lucy Berry Marshall to Gregory Martin Sandor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph J. Sandor of New Canaan, Conn. A July wedding is planned.
LEAD: For This Week: Time off. Happy New Year. When It's Icy

LEAD: Elizabeth Anne Nelson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Nelson of Middlebury, Vt., was married there yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church to Robert Davis Egan, a son of Dorothy D. Egan of Hudson, Ohio. Msgr. Paul M. Bresnehan and the Rev. David Andrews, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: HURRYING through the tunnel at Veterans Stadium, the Los Angeles Rams' left guard, Tom Newberry, yelled, ''Warm-weather California sissies, huh?'' With a grin he disappeared into the locker room to calmly celebrate a 21-7 wild-card victory over the Philadelphia Eagles in a cold raw rain, which qualified the Rams to go against the Giants next Sunday at Giants Stadium in the Super Bowl XX

LEAD: A new year, a new decade and, in New York, a new era begin today, with the swearing in of David N. Dinkins as New York's Mayor. The moment recalls a line from the old Christmas carol about ''the hopes and fears of all the years . . .''

LEAD: The New York City Transportation Department has issued its parking-rule changes for 1990. ALTERNATE-SIDE RULES SUSPENDED Martin Luther King Jr.'s Birthday Jan. 15 Lincoln's Birthday Feb. 12 Washington's Birthday Feb. 19 Good Friday April 13 Passover (first two days) April 10,11 Passover (7th and 8th days) April 16, 17 Ascension Day May 24 Shabuoth May 30, 31 Feast of Assumption Aug.
LEAD: The Nobel Prize in Literature that Camilo Jose Cela received this year has come at a time when the Spanish literary world is astir with what is being called ''the new Spanish narrative.''

LEAD: FOR six years, American corporations have been buying their own stock in a big way. The original idea was to help protect the company from a takeover. But now the takeover threat is waning while the buybacks are as strong as ever. Clearly, they have taken on a life of their own, with important consequences for

LEAD: The walls of David N. Dinkins's borough president's office, once covered with photographs recounting his political career, are bare except for dozens of nails from which the pictures hung. They have been packed away until his new office at City Hall is prepared.
LEAD: The school system here has been experimenting with democracy, shattering the wall between principals and teachers and allowing both to share power in running their schools.
LEAD: The Indian Government has withdrawn permission for the filming of the book ''The City of Joy'' on the ground that it would show Calcutta in too negative a light.

LEAD: Alcide Chaisson, who is 69 years old and lives in a trailer near Crystalaire Airport, a small field northeast of Los Angeles, was charged Friday with obstructing a flight path. He said small planes buzzing his desert home drowned out his radio and he fought back by flashing sun into pilots' eyes with a 4-foot-square mirror.

LEAD: Scott Burton, an American sculptor whose work balanced stubbornly and elegantly between art and furniture while evolving into a new kind of public sculpture, died of AIDS on Friday at Cabrini Medical Center in New York City. He was 50 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: Gary Anderson is the third-most accurate kicker in National Football League history. Today, he was No. 1 for the Pittsburgh Steelers.
LEAD: The National Bank of Poland is devaluing the Polish zloty by 32 percent, Polish media reported today.

LEAD: Despite some seemingly spectacular successes, the drug war in South America is not going well. Critics say the American military attack on Panama, justified in part as an anti-drug initiative, has only fragmented what is already a largely ineffective effort.
LEAD: It has been a year of hurricanes and housing scandals, but also of quieter tales of American people and places. Here are the last, or at least the latest, chapters from the journals of 1989:
LEAD: George Perles, a controversial but successful coach on three levels, yesterday became the first of half a dozen finalists to be interviewed for the Jets' head-coaching job.

LEAD: Confronted by growing demands that the Communist Party dissolve itself, top officials of this country's old order say they will call a special congress to dismantle the disgraced party even before free elections are held in April.

LEAD: Anybody looking to decipher the Brazilian term lambada, which applies to a dance, music, cross-cultural sensibility and product of marketing hucksters, would have left Margareth Menezes's show at S.O.B.'s on Saturday night no more insightful than when he came in. Miss Menezes, who recently performed with David Byrne, the fan of third world music and singer, is being promoted as a lambada singer; in truth, she is a decent singer familiar with Afro-Brazilian music.
LEAD: Pat LaFontaine scored three times, extending his goal-scoring streak to seven games, to lead the New York Islanders to a 4-2 victory over the Buffalo Sabres tonight.
LEAD: AT a number of American newspapers, it has become almost a fad to publish pullout news sections focused on a single topic.

LEAD: The new Hong Kong Cultural Center stands on one of Hong Kong's finest waterfront sites, looking out over Victoria Harbor with its quaint wooden fishing junks and busy passenger ferries parading past the colony's glistening glass and metal skyscrapers. But the $77 million center, designed by a committee of government architects, has no windows.
LEAD: Hollywood's big names and big studios are increasingly being drawn to Mexico to make feature films and television movies.
LEAD: Gregory Johnson's Purple Heart was pinned to his pillow, and a three-foot-high inflatable Santa stood near his bed.

LEAD: The old, worn wooden stands that surrounded Bill Coleman did not appear as they will Monday night, when the painted faces arrive, the lights go on, the bands begin to play, the Orange Bowl comes alive, and a lifetime of memories, joyous or painful, will be compressed into 60 minutes of football.

LEAD: The Soviet nation bid an ambivalent adieu to 1989 in midnight revels, joining President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in expressing regret over the ''bitterness'' of the withered economy while hailing the ''waves of revolutionary renewal'' that have tattered the Kremlin's Eastern European bloc.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Clemson's defense became West Virginia's nightmare in the Gator Bowl on Saturday night.

LEAD: The Administration was right to apologize after American troops broke into the Nicaraguan Ambassador's residence in Panama. But President Bush is much too cavalier when he dismisses Friday's raid as a mere ''screw-up.'' Nor can the raid be pardoned, as he implies, just because the troops found a cache of weapons.

LEAD: In a soaring service of prayer and song, David N. Dinkins yesterday heard Archibishop Desmond M. Tutu, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and more than 1,000 New Yorkers wish him godspeed as he assumes the New York City mayoralty today.
LEAD: Shortly before her 59th birthday last month, Joyce Dinkins found herself at the center of an outpouring of affection.

LEAD: Lisa Rose Kuvin, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sanford Kuvin of Palm Beach, Fla., and Jerusalem, was married yesterday at her parents' home in Palm Beach to Benjamin Myer Schreier, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Schreier of Birmingham, Mich. Rabbi Leonid Feldman performed the ceremony.

LEAD: There seems to be no escaping the long arm of Madison Avenue. Advertisers have now found a way to intrude electronically into people's lives while they browse in shopping malls or wait for buses or trains.

LEAD: Today is New Year's Day. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Federal and state offices closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only. Only the main office, at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue, will be open. Banks: Closed. Parking: Sunday rules in effect.
LEAD: A group headed by Peter V. Ueberroth, the former commissioner of baseball, and Thomas Talbot, a California entrepreneur, has bought control of Hawaiian Airlines for $37 million.

LEAD: A noted Ukrainian poet who has jousted with pre-glasnost Soviet officialdom at home ran into New York's criminal element Saturday night when a sheaf of her hand-written notes and poetry disappeared from the trunk of a parked car, the police said yesterday.

LEAD: With the impasse over the fate of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega entering its second week, the new President of Panama and his Attorney General disagreed today over whether to file charges against the deposed strongman or leave the question of his prosecution to the United States.

LEAD: With demand outstripping capacity and freight rates rising, the new year might seem ripe for a flood of orders for new bulk-cargo ships - a flood reminiscent of those in the early 1970's and the early 1980's. But that will not be the case this time, many people in the industry say.
LEAD: All financial markets in the United States and most world markets will be closed today because of New Year's Day.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL 2-9 The Communist Party in Rumania will dismantle itself during a special congress that top officials of the ousted Government will call before free elections are held in April. Page 1 Helicopter pilot describes Ceausescu's escape attempt 6

LEAD: HE tugged at the Los Angeles Raiders cap snug atop his head and his eyes shifted as if he were anticipating a blitzing linebacker. Darian Hagan, a teen-ager laden with adult-like responsibility, was explaining in his own way how he became a man so hurriedly, so unexpectedly.

LEAD: Ruth W. Messinger, who is to be sworn in today as Manhattan Borough President, was married yesterday to Andrew Lachman, the special assistant to the superintendent of Community School District 2 in Manhattan. Rabbi Allan Miller officiated at the New York home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred Wyler, who also have a home in Westport,
LEAD: Midway Airlines Inc. announced Friday that Jeffrey H. Erickson had resigned as president and chief operating officer to pursue personal business.

LEAD: There is still a lot of the professor in Jacques Delors, the 64-year-old president of the European Commission, the European Community's excutive branch. But unlike most professors, Mr. Delors, who used to teach at France's elite Ecole Nationale d'Administration, has the opportunity so see much of his vision transformed into reality.
LEAD: Israel paid thousands of dollars in cash to Nicolae Ceausescu for every Rumanian Jew he allowed to emigrate for two decades, an Israeli newspaper reported.

LEAD: A few seconds before midnight, the chief priest of a small hilltop sanctuary known as Sengen Shrine fidgeted in his scarlet robes and looked nervously at his watch while listening to the radio for the electronic beep signaling the arrival of the Year of the Horse.

LEAD: One of the many sad bridge stories of 1989 concerns the final of the Australian National Team Championship, played in Canberra, the capital, in February. It attracted an entry of 178 teams, far more than an equivalent American event would do, and there were players from New Zealand, Japan and the United

LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said today that the ransacking of the Nicaraguan Ambassador's residence in Panama by American troops on Friday has brought Nicaraguan-American relations to their deepest crisis in 10 years.
LEAD: A Bronx man was fatally shot Saturday night on the subway after trying to stop a man who had stolen a portable cassette player from his friend, the police said yesterday.

LEAD: The collapse of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association produced an array of victims, from retired California investors who bought unsecured bonds to American taxpayers. But it also turns out that not all the investors in the failed institution were losers.

LEAD: Morocco appealed for help today in its struggle to keep a 230-square-mile oil slick away from its coastline and to halt the spill that began when an Iranian tanker was damaged in an explosion nearly two weeks ago.

LEAD: FOOTBALL PHILADELPHIA (NFC) - Released Carlos Carson, wide receiver. Activated Greg Garrity, wide receiver, from injured reserve. HOCKEY RANGERS (NHL) - Recalled Mike Richter, goaltender, from Flint of the International Hockey League. COLLEGES DUKE - Appointed Barry Wilson head football coach.

LEAD: Senator Sam Nunn, the leading Democratic figure on military issues on Capitol Hill, says the United States should seek deeper cuts in American and Soviet troop strength in Europe than the Bush Administration has proposed in arms negotiations.

LEAD: Bear and Big Bowls Q. How many times did Bear Bryant coach Alabama in the four major bowls and how did his teams do? A. In an Alabama coaching career of 25 years from 1958 through 1982, in which his Crimson Tide appeared in bowl games all but the first of those years, Bryant had a 10-7 record in major bowls: Cotton, Orange and Sugar.

LEAD: In Japan, Year of the Horse Japanese observed a national New Year's ritual combining a Times Square-like countdown and Eastern mysticism. Page 3. Worry Over Khmer Rouge Prime Minister Hun Sen of Cambodia said the Khmer Rouge had obtained American arms from non-Communist guerrilla factions.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The feisty Amato Opera, as intimate as the Metropolitan is grandiose, revels endearingly in the contrast. After its two little chandeliers rise to the ceiling before the current production of ''The Barber of Seville,'' a recording of the opera's overture is played on an antiquated sound system that, in the concluding crescendo, produces a thunderous roar of audio distortion.
LEAD: The Devils led, 3-0, midway through the game tonight but sagged badly in the second half as they lost to the Detroit Red Wings, 6-4.
LEAD: A new wheel for cyclists has bypassed conventional spoked designs in favor of aerodynamic blades.

LEAD: Nancy Fay Bauer and Michael Anthony Cooper, both candidates for Ph.D. degrees at Harvard University, she in philosophy and he in English, were married yesterday at the Memorial Church at Harvard by the Rev. Arthur O. F. Bauer, the bride's father, a Lutheran minister.
LEAD: An angry rebuke from Coach Roy Williams was all Kansas needed Saturday night to pull away from previously unbeaten Stanford and post an 83-61 victory in the final of the BMA Holiday Classic.

LEAD: ''Personally I'm optimistic on everything,'' said 10-year-old Chris Park, pausing to contemplate the minting of a crisp new decade and a historic changeover at City Hall -New York's first new Mayor in his lifetime.

LEAD: The questions seemed so simple and yet so all-encompassing that they defied any easy answers: ''Who's laughing now? Laughing at what? Who's laughing last?'' The question, the questioner continued, ''which was always a question of power,'' is: ''Why should we be laughing at all?''

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson said yesterday that the attack on Panama had allowed the Bush Administration to deflect criticism of its secret diplomatic missions to China after the crackdown on demonstrations there.
LEAD: His friends always said George Bush would be a foreign-policy President, but even they didn't expect this.

LEAD: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today dismissed Science Minister Ezer Weizman from the Israeli Cabinet, saying the influential Labor Party minister had met with leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization and given them advice on how to thwart a Government peace initiative.

LEAD: Steve Spurrier, who won the Heisman Trophy in 1966 as quarterback at the University of Florida, today returned to the school as head football coach after a scandal-plagued decade for the Gators that resulted in the ouster of his two predecessors.

LEAD: As Americans look to the year 2000, most of them anticipate a better life for themselves, but at the same time they foresee a worsening of many of the nation's social and economic problems, according to a new Gallup Poll.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The debate over how to cut the military budget has been complicated by a confusing array of numbers and budgetary terms.
LEAD: The icicles dripping off frozen Florida oranges on Christmas weekend warmed hearts in Brazil, the world's largest producer of frozen orange juice.

LEAD: An ancient economics scoring rule is that a session is a failure when the size of the panel exceeds the size of the audience; by that measure, most of the sessions at the annual convention of the American Economic Association here were a success.

LEAD: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, in a year-end plea to Congress and the White House for additional Federal judgeships, warned yesterday that ''the war on drugs will fail if the judiciary is not given the judgeships necessary to do the job.''

LEAD: Loco 7 is the name of a train that journeys through time in New York City, into the 21st century. It is also the name of an ambitious multi-media piece by Federico Restrepo, a Colombian dancer and director now working in New York, which was performed by Mr. Restrepo's Puppets and Drummers company on Saturday night at La Mama Annex.

LEAD: HORSE RACING Passing Ships Romps: Racing over a fog-enshrouded track that obscured the running of the Aqueduct feature, Passing Ships romped to a 17 1/2-length victory yesterday in the $85,650 Display Handicap for 3-year-olds and up. Passing Ships, the odds-on choice, covered two and a quarter miles on the good track in 3:55 3/5 to earn $51,390 for Gold'N-Oats Stable with his fifth consecutive victory and his sixth in 13 starts in 1989.
LEAD: The Israel Museum has opened an exhibition on a part of ancient life that is not often presented today - cosmetics and toiletries in use from ancient Egyptian times through the Roman Empire.

LEAD: Dial a number and the video screen in your wall becomes a window into the place you are calling. You can see and converse with people on the other side, even slide documents through the window, via fax machine. All this could be possible once the country is wired with fiber-optic cable. But that will cost some $250 billion and won't happen for decades unless Washington decides it should be done sooner.
LEAD: THOSE on Donovan Ruddock's Christmas-card list got a personalized card this year.

LEAD: A Titan 3 rocket carrying British and Japanese communications satellites roared into space tonight after nine postponements as the Martin Marietta Corporation entered the commercial launching business.
LEAD: The Diary of H. L. Mencken Edited by Charles A. Fecher Illustrated. 476 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

LEAD: Victor G. Trapasso, the president and chief executive officer of the GT Realty and Management Company of Herndon, Va., died of cancer on Thursday at Alexandria Hospital in Alexandria, Va., where he lived. He was 54 years old.

LEAD: ''It's nice to have a black Mayor, and it'd be even better if he could really do something about the crime and about the homeless. The best thing about New York is when people really want to get together and do something, people really do get together.'' -Michael Kanatous, of Brooklyn. [30:1.

LEAD: ''For myself, as a Democrat, respectfully,'' quietly begins the best public speaker in American politics today, ''I think we have given an appropriate period of deference to the newly victorious President.''
LEAD: IN the past few years - and increasingly so now that the Iron Curtain is being torn apart - East European athletes have streamed from their homelands for the West.

LEAD: Fourteen pieces of Japanese artwork from the collection of the late John D. Rockefeller 3d, including paintings, screens and poem scrolls, will be on view for seven months beginning Jan. 18 at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street. A major part of the show is a pair of folding screens in gold leaf, recently acquired by the museum, that date from the Edo Period (1615-1868).

LEAD: Prime Minister Hun Sen expressed concern today that Khmer Rouge forces were coordinating military operations and strategy with non-Communist guerrilla armies supported by the United States, and he said the Khmer Rouge had obtained weapons from the non-Communist factions.
LEAD: It is not necessary to visit New York City to evoke images of the deprivation in which so many live. Letters to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund draw a vivid portrait.
LEAD: An article in Business Day on Saturday about economists' views of changes in Eastern Europe misidentified a Princeton University professor. He is Alan Blinder.

LEAD: At a time when bankers and economists speak of a global financial village, with the world's centers of finance closely linked and interdependent, the Tokyo stock market is increasingly going its own stable and buoyant way.

LEAD: A Federal district judge in Arizona granted a Government motion on Friday to dismiss three counts in a lawsuit related to the Government's seizure of the insolvent Lincoln Savings and Loan Association in California.
LEAD: President Corazon C. Aquino announced changes in her Cabinet today in the aftermath of the military mutiny against her Government earlier this month.

LEAD: An America West jetliner skidded off the end of the runway at Tucson International Airport on Saturday night, and three of 127 people aboard were injured, one seriously, the authorities said. The Boeing 737, Flight 450 from Phoenix, apparently lost hydraulic pressure while landing. (AP)
LEAD: At the stroke of midnight, Poland becomes the first Eastern European country to leap into the capitalist era.

LEAD: Fanyana Zwane was watching television with two of his sons one evening last August when two Soviet-made hand grenades smashed a window and exploded in their living room, seriously wounding 12-year-old Gabriel. The neighborhood in the black township of Soweto, where the Zwanes live, was shocked but not surprised.

LEAD: In the world of commodity futures trading, Leo Melamed is widely considered to be the chief lobbyist, spokesman and public relations man - and an adept one at that. In 1990, Mr. Melamed, the chairman of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange's executive committee, will need all those qualities and others to restore his industry's tarnished image.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. is suing the Bush Administration to be allowed to provide its Cable News Network to Vietnam.
LEAD: Because of holiday production requirements, The Times is printed today in two sections.

LEAD: A 26-year-old police officer was found dead in a ditch near the Long Island Expressway yesterday, the police said. The officer was found two hours after detectives arrested her husband in the shooting of a man he had found with her in a parked car, and the husband was also charged with killing her.

LEAD: When Westley Allan Dodd was arrested in November and charged with killing three young boys in this Columbia River community, his case provided critics of the legal system with a tragic demonstration of their argument that the law has failed to protect society from sex offenders.

LEAD: After a six-month break, their longest in 19 years, New York State lawmakers will gather here Wednesday to begin a new session. But, pressed with demands for greater spending and hemmed in by what appears to be a near-chronic budget deficit, few legislators seem particularly eager to return.
LEAD: As older Americans strive for healthier, more active lives, New York City is offering to help, by sharing its innovative fitness regimen tailored for men and women over age 60.
LEAD: In the rapidly changing world of perestroika, Leonid Abalkin is not the only economist of influence. But he is apparently highly valued for his political flexibility and grace under pressure.

LEAD: The gaffe was monstrous, the price paid for it enormous. Afterward, Coach Roger Neilson's mistake, the one that made Pittsburgh's tying goal possible and its subsequent 5-4 victory almost inevitable, was explained, analyzed and rehashed again and again.
LEAD: William Scott, a British artist acclaimed for his still life paintings and drawings, died of Alzheimer's disease on Thursday at his home outside Bath in Somerset, England. He was 76 years old.

LEAD: Jill Lynne Armel and Ens. Evan Dayan Dash were married yesterday at the Inter-Continental Hotel in New York by Rabbi Thomas Weiner. Mrs. Dash is the daughter of Marilyn W. Armel and Paul H. Armel, both of New York. Ensign Dash is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Dash of New York.

LEAD: The Government has devalued Nicaragua's currency for the 40th time this year and raised the price of gasoline and public transportation. The move by the Nicaraguan central bank brought the official exchange rate to 38,150 cordobas to a dollar. The previous rate was 36,330 cordobas. Friday's action raised urban and inter-city bus fares by 30 percent.
LEAD: In the world's stock markets, 1989 was a year of the unexpected.

LEAD: The Los Angeles Rams made big pass plays today, two of them for touchdowns. They ran for 144 yards, including a 54-yard sprint by Greg Bell, which set up the clinching touchdown. Their offensive line and defensive gimmicks also contibuted mightily as they upset the Philadelphia Eagles, 21-7.

LEAD: BETWEEN a riot and an earthquake, death and scandal, the games seemed a bit anticlimactic this year. But for one wandering sports columnist, 1989 did have its moments, from datelines as diverse as Trinidad and Paris.

LEAD: Former President Chun Doo Hwan testified for the first time today about his repressive eight-year martial rule over South Korea, but he was cut short as a melee broke out in the National Assembly and walked out amid screams, curses and shoving.
LEAD: As New England's coldest December on record shivered to a close, lawmakers and consumer advocates called for an investigation into heating-oil prices that have shot up with the mercury's fall.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: With Drexel Burnham Lambert's ''junk bond'' money machine sputtering, Frederick H. Joseph now faces the challenge of navigating the firm through what may be its toughest time in the market.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Know any unemployed adorable babies? Rush them over to central casting. Prime-time television has become obsessed with pregnant women and childbirth scenarios. In recent months, the phenomenon has been prominent on ABC's ''Thirtysomething,'' NBC's ''L.A. Law'' and ''Cheers,'' and CBS's ''Beauty and the Beast,'' in which, heaven help us, Mom was killed in the delivery room and the newborn was kidnapped.

LEAD: With a third of the National Basketball Association season completed, the Knicks' 20-7 record is tops in the Eastern Conference and second-best over all in the 27-team league after the Los Angeles Lakers' 21-6.

LEAD: Neil Kinnock, leader of the opposition Labor Party, will meet with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Moscow on Jan. 16, a party spokesman said today. No details of the visit were available, the spokesman said.

LEAD: United States officials in Panama who thought they had captured Mike Harari, an Israeli identified as a close associate of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, may have mistaken the Israeli's driver for Mr. Harari, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: In an interview with Martin Scorsese not long before ''The Last Temptation of Christ'' opened, I asked when he had first read the novel on which the film was based. The answer emerged 15 minutes later: he had heard about the book as a film student at New York University. But first his conversation took a revealing detour through his childhood in Little Italy, where he was an asthmatic boy who spent endless hours at movie theaters watching biblical epics in Cinemascope and even more time rooted in front of the family television set watching black-and-white reruns of ''The Red Shoes.

LEAD: The Polish celebration of the new year has already ended. The crash program to propel the economy into capitalism has gone abruptly into effect, and that means pain. LEAD: The two Player of the Year races of the Greater New York Bridge Association have never been closer than they were in 1989, with decisions coming Dec. 17, in the final hour of tournament action at the Winter Regional Championships.

LEAD: First there was the melting pot, but that seemed overly romantic. Then came patchwork quilt, a down-home image that Jesse Jackson has used over the years. Now the metaphor of the moment is gorgeous mosaic, Mayor David Dinkins's favorite description of New York City. ''I see New York as a gorgeous mosaic of race and religious faith, of national origin and sexual orientation,'' he said in his Inaugural Address on Monday, turning his oft-used campaign slogan into - a trademark, the equivalent of George Bush's ''kinder, gentler nation.

LEAD: In its latest effort to tap the nostalgia boom, Life magazine is offering a discount to advertisers who run old ads next to new ones. Advertisers who pay the current price for a full-page ad get the adjacent page for an old ad at the rate in effect when the ad first ran. The vintage ad must be at least 10 years old, and advertisers are promised at least a 24.1 percent discount over a standard two-page spread.

LEAD: Among the innovations the 1980's brought to pop music were the rise of MTV, home videos, the compact disk and rap. But what comes next? ''I'm in fossils.
LEAD: Construction spending rose 1.5 percent in November, hitting a 10-month high, the Commerce Department reported today.

LEAD: Fares for Metro-North commuters went up 15 percent on New Year's Day - except for riders to and from Connecticut. At the last minute, Gov. William O'Neill vetoed any increase within Connecticut's boundaries. By blocking needed funds, he pandered to affluent Fairfield County commuters. In a gubernatorial election year, that's good politics but weak leadership.

LEAD: PRO BASKETBALL Technicals and Foul Shots Abound There were 10 technical fouls in this game, which visiting Detroit won, 115-113, by scoring 15 of its last 17 points from the free-throw line. Orlando's Sidney Green was ejected after picking up his second technical. Bill Laimbeer scored 14 points in the second half and had the Pistons' only field goal in the last six minutes, a 15-foot jumper that gave Detroit a 111-104 lead with three minutes left.

LEAD: For several days last summer Felix Bloch, the suspended diplomat, was being tailed by the F.B.I. and the agents in turn were tailed by journalists and photographers - all on the streets of Washington and much of it on television news.

LEAD: If anything unites the European continent it is the ubiquitous pig in all its culinary renderings. But it is hard to imagine the pig being more deeply rooted in folklore, tradition and gastronomy than it is in Spain.

LEAD: The Likud and Labor parties averted a breakup of their governing coalition today with a compromise under which Ezer Weizman, the independent-minded Labor Party Science Minister, would keep his post but be suspended from the Government's decision-making core.
LEAD: Budget officials said today that falling sales-tax revenues and rising welfare costs will leave Connecticut with a budget deficit of $65 million for the fiscal year ending June 30.
LEAD: To hear Rupert Murdoch tell it, the British portion of his publishing and television empire is consuming too much of his time, and Andrew Knight is just the man to do something about it.

LEAD: The scoring, the shooting and the assists were down and the defense was spotty in the last four games for the Knicks, indications that their home-court supremacy and winning streak were in jeopardy.

LEAD: John MacLeod, former coach of the Dallas Mavericks, said yesterday in Dallas that he was ''just waiting'' to hear back from the Sacramento Kings, who have reportedly narrowed their search for a new head coach to MacLeod and two others.

LEAD: ''Not all operas should be played. It is good to hear some unknown operas, but also good to forget some. There is no real reason to stage Wagner's 'Ring' now that Patrice Chereau has done it for our time at Bayreuth.''

LEAD: The San Francisco 49ers' Joe Montana, who finished 1989 with the best all-round passing year in National Football League history, has been named the league's most valuable player by The Associated Press in balloting by sportswriters.

LEAD: BABY BOOMERS brought up on a steady diet of children's cereals in the 1960's and 70's must be struck by the commercials for adult cereals over the last two or three years. Unlike the commercials of their youth, which emphasized fun and tie-ins with television characters, adult cereals trumpet their fiber and dried fruits.

LEAD: Public Enemy's show early on New Year's Day at the World was a mess of contradictions. The group, notorious because of its anti-Semitic statements, both in interviews and on its most recent single, ''Welcome to the Terrordome,'' allows inconsistencies to make its show politically incoherent. Group members pronounce anti-authoritarian slogans like the ambiguous ''fight the power'' while keeping a squad of stone-faced guards -dressed in military outfits, and the image of power - onstage.

LEAD: Barbara Ruth Miller, a Foreign Service officer, was married yesterday in Omaha to Dr. James H. Alleman, the director of the International Center for Telecommunications Management at the University of Nebraska at Omaha. Judge Samuel V. Cooper of the Douglas County Court in Omaha officiated at the home of the bride and bridegroom.
LEAD: An agreement among seven Northeast states that will ease restrictions for teachers who want to cross state lines for a job is getting a mixed reaction from educators.

LEAD: Two Roman Catholic nuns, one of them American, were killed Monday night when their pickup truck was attacked on an isolated highway in this remote Atlantic Coast region by armed men who Government and church officials said were American-backed contras.

LEAD: For some people, the way to celebrate good fortune - their own or that of others - is to give to those whom fortune has overlooked. Few occasions bring that generosity out more than a wedding, or the prospect of one.
LEAD: Ethiopian rebels said today that they seized a third town in central Ethiopia in their drive southward toward Addis Ababa, the capital.
LEAD: Solomon Birnbaum, a Jewish scholar credited with establishing the authenticity and age of the Dead Sea Scrolls, died here on Thursday. He was 98 years old.

LEAD: EVERYONE in the food industry is talking about a return to homey cooking in the 1990's - call it bistro, traditional American, unfussy Italian, whatever - which started me thinking about offal, something I associate with home cooking in France. Offal, or variety meats, includes liver, kidney, tripe, tongue, brain, sweetbreads and other internal organs.
LEAD: Savings institution regulators today printed what amounts to one of the largest real estate listings ever published.
LEAD: What is thought to be the first ''guaranteed tuition'' plan at the secondary school level has been announced by Phillips Academy at Andover, Mass.

LEAD: WANT to open a winery in New York State? Want to teach or learn about New York wines? The New York Wine and Grape Foundation, expecting a burst of winery openings in the 1990's, has begun a publishing program designed to meet such information needs.

LEAD: Nuclear experts have concluded that the Soviet Union learned almost nothing of how to make the hydrogen bomb from the atom spy Klaus Fuchs and may have instead deduced the crucial secret by analyzing radioactive fallout from American nuclear blasts.

LEAD: The two American retail subsidiaries of the Campeau Corporation said yesterday that they had received a two-week reprieve from a threat by their bank lenders to declare $2.34 billion loans in default.

LEAD: There were no celebrations in the coal towns of Appalachia today, no banners unfurled, no outward signs of joy that there may soon be an end to one of the nation's longest and most bitter miners' strikes.

Kenneth Wolf, an ironworker from Patchogue, L.I., was in critical condition last night at the City Hospital Center in Elmhurst, with two broken legs, broken ankles and hip injuries, the police said.

LEAD: The Camden County Prosecutor said today that two gunmen fired at him on Monday in what he described as an unsuccessful drug-related assassination attempt. He shot one of the assailants in the head, he said.
LEAD: Vincent T. Malone, a retired senior vice president of the Manhattan stockbrokerage firm of Pershing & Company, died of cancer on Friday at his home in Monmouth Beach, N.J. He was 64 years old.
LEAD: The personal computer, which has dominated the computer industry since the early 1980's, has a new competitor that could someday take away a significant share of the office market.
LEAD: Barry Alvarez, an assistant for Notre Dame the last three seasons, took over yesterday as the head coach for Wisconsin.

LEAD: With college students returning to campuses after the holiday break, long-distance telephone companies are continuing their nationwide crackdown on students who steal telephone services by using illegal credit card numbers and access codes.
LEAD: Dr. William Roper, the top health adviser at the White House, will be named head of the Federal Centers for Disease Control, Federal officials said today.
