LEAD: Bombs that killed a Federal judge and a Savannah lawyer last month as well as two others disarmed before exploding were made from the same material, a Federal Bureau of Investigation spokesman here said today.
LEAD: The Bush Administration has told the Democratic leadership in Congress that it cannot meet the statutory deadline for its 1991 budget and will submit it Jan. 29, a week late.

LEAD: THERE is no dearth of experts ready to tell us what to drink. Most concentrate on what to buy for the next few weeks, with occasional tips on wines to lay down for the future. Would anyone dare suggest what we will be drinking for the next 10 years?
LEAD: The dollar rose sharply yesterday, forcing the Federal Reserve to intervene by selling dollars several times to stem its rally against the Japanese yen.
LEAD: George B. Vest, general counsel of the Federal Reserve Board from 1945 until his retirement in 1957, died of liver cancer on Sunday at his home in Washington. He was 94 years old.

LEAD: ON a cold day, nothing makes for a simpler, friendlier party than curry. Fortunately, it cooks quickly and well in a microwave oven. Serve with a large bowl of rice - the pilaf in Micro-Tip does well - and small bowls of selected accompaniments like raisins, sliced banana, grated coconut, chutney, yogurt and roasted unsalted nuts.
LEAD: Lebanon's already severe political and military tensions have been further strained by the prospect of widespread labor and economic upheaval.

LEAD: * American General Corp., Houston, a holding company, said it had completed the sale of its group life and health insurance operations to Associated Insurance Cos., Indianapolis. The price included $175 million in cash and a $10 million note.

LEAD: Brent Goulet, dropped from the United States national soccer team last fall after a scoring slump, was among 28 players invited yesterday to report to the team's training camp when it regroups Friday to prepare for the World Cup.(AP)

LEAD: Franco Zeffirelli's extravagant staging of Puccini's ''Turandot'' generated considerable heat when the Metropolitan Opera unveiled it in 1987. Like most of the director's other recent productions, it seemed predicated on the notions that operagoers' eyes should get as thorough a workout as their ears, and that no expense should be spared in the pursuit of detail.
LEAD: To The Living Section:

LEAD: The annual State of the State address, which Gov. Mario M. Cuomo will deliver here on Wednesday, is often described as a road map for the coming year, filled with gubernatorial directives and proposals. But it also has its share of dead ends.

LEAD: The Devils rebounded from a loss to one of the worst teams in the National Hockey League with a victory tonight over the team with the best record in the league.
LEAD: A farm couple pleaded not guilty Tuesday to charges of slaying five transient workers to cover up a cattle-theft scheme in northwestern Missouri.

LEAD: When John Robinson came in from the cold to lunch with local reporters today, he looked like a man braced for a rare but occasional afternoon chill. In a city of short sleeves and sunglasses, he wore a light sweater.

LEAD: To many parishioners, the recent invasion of St. Patrick's Cathedral by dozens of angry AIDS protesters was an act of desecration. But to Christopher Hennelly, a former seminarian among those arrested inside the church, it was a prayer for self-preservation.

LEAD: Howard E. Kershner, a businessman and an outspoken conservative about politics and economics who retired 50 years ago to devote himself to relief causes for children, died of a pulmonary ailment on Monday at the Southland Lutheran Home in Norwalk, Calif. He was 98 years old and had lived for several years in La Jolla,

LEAD: Barry E. Loughrane has resigned as chairman and chief executive of Diversified Agency Services, the division of the Omnicom Group that includes its direct marketing, financial advertising and other specialty communications companies. Bruce Crawford, president and chief executive of Omnicom, will take over as chief executive of Diversified Agency Services.

LEAD: The Mayor of this drab factory town north of Tokyo is upset that some people viewed recent statements of his as racist, especially his comment that with so many dark-skinned foreigners in town, Japanese were having trouble seeing them at night.

LEAD: Genentech filed an application with the Food and Drug Administration seeking approval to sell gamma interferon to treat patients with chronic granulomatous disease. If approved, it would be the third drug created by genetic engineering to be sold by the biotechnology company, based in South San Francisco, Calif.

LEAD: Joseph A. Fernandez took over as chancellor of New York City's schools yesterday with gestures that swiftly underscored his intention to reshape the troubled system: he visited a school in Brooklyn where teachers share leadership with the principal and he brought the president of the teachers union along for the tour.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The credit markets opened the new year on a somewhat sour note yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities dipped slightly in light trading.

LEAD: An Israeli reputed to be Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's closest associate may have eluded capture on the night of the United States invasion because he was warned to flee nearly six hours before American troops swept into the capital, the deputy commander of Panama's new police force said today.
LEAD: George Perles of Michigan State is the front-runner in the Jets' search for a new coach, several sources in the National Football League and in the college ranks said yesterday.
LEAD: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, plans to price $1.4 billion in debentures today equally divided between four-year and 10-year maturities.

LEAD: Group W Sports Marketing has contracted to sell advertising time on the Madison Square Garden Network, a cable television sports service. The Westinghouse Broadcasting Company division was formed last year to serve as advertising representative for regional cable sports networks. The MSG Network will maintain responsibility for its local ad sales effort in New York.

LEAD: On the late September day that Gerry Cooney's comeback on Jan. 15 against George Foreman was announced, Gil Clancy happened to bump into Bob Martin, the legendary Las Vegas oddsmaker. Clancy, the CBS boxing analyst who had once been the trainer for Emile Griffith, a five-time champion, as well as for Foreman, had decided to drape a white towel over his shoulder again and return to the gym as Cooney's trainer.

LEAD: Dr. Nathaniel H. Pier, an internist whose practice consisted largely of AIDS patients, died of acquired immune deficiency syndrome at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 37 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: A picture caption yesterday about the inauguration of Andrew P. O'Rourke as Westchester County Executive misidentified the justice who administered the oath. He was Samuel G. Fredman.

LEAD: NBC said yesterday that it would begin coordinating the sale of advertising time on its broadcast and cable-television networks, a move that could enable advertisers, for the first time, to buy commercial packages that include the two media.

LEAD: A state grand jury today indicted the mayor of Atlantic City, James L. Usry, and three others on corruption charges in a wide-ranging investigation of influence peddling among government officials in the gaming resort.

LEAD: Nonsmoking New Yorkers reporting for jury duty are accustomed to plenty of exposure to secondary smoke as other jurors light up while waiting to be called. That was supposed to end on Monday, when New York's Clean Indoor Air Act took effect.

LEAD: The Federal Express Corporation said it was one of five companies sharing a Defense Department contract valued at more than $700 million. Federal Express estimated its potential share of the $724 million contract at about 68 percent.

LEAD: Joseph A. Loftus, for 25 years a reporter for The New York Times and then a special assistant for communications to Secretary of Labor George P. Shultz, died of heart disease yesterday at his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 82 years old and had suffered a series of strokes.

LEAD: If you have thought about extending your backpacking activities into cold weather, you might start by attending the Appalachian Mountain Club's Jan. 26-28 winter camping workshop at its Pinkham Notch lodge in the White Mountains in New Hampshire.

LEAD: In his first major act as Mayor of New York, David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he would indefinitely delay hiring 1,848 police officers who were to have gone on the payroll on Jan. 16 as recruits at the Police Academy. He said he might also have to delay another class that was scheduled to start in

LEAD: People irritated by the use of the verb ''aggravate'' to mean ''irritate'' had better prepare to have their irritation aggravated. The Manchester Guardian Weekly reports that a panel of language experts regularly consulted by the Random House Dictionary gives this usage its blessing. In 1969, a majority of the panel regarded it as a solecism.
LEAD: Like thousands of new immigrants, foreign diplomats and exchange students before them, Nabil Mushara, Mohammed Lafi and Issam Kassis spend four hours a week studying Hebrew for beginners.

LEAD: Just over a year after he retired from competition after suffering a hairline leg fracture and other injuries in an automobile accident, Eamonn Coghlan, the world-record holder in the indoor mile, announced that he was suspending part of his retirement, the part that takes place under a roof.
LEAD: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo outlined a plan today that would make New York the first state in the nation to subsidize health care for all its uninsured children.

LEAD: In the final stages of major national championship events, a vast majority of the players are between the ages of 30 and 55. They have acquired the experience, in terms of technique, psychology and partnership adjustment, and they have not reached the point at which stamina begins to fail after hours of grinding concentration.

LEAD: FERNANDO MATEO'S flagship Carpet Fashions shop (111 Fourth Avenue, at 12th Street) built its reputation on a far-ranging stock of floor coverings. Now Mr. Mateo and Bill Seyler, vice president of the company, are venturing farther uptown, where about 8,000 samples are on display at a new store at 143 East 54th
LEAD: * Ralph McGill has joined the McDonald Group, Atlanta, as senior vice president and a creative partner.

LEAD: It wasn't a challenge and it wasn't a warning, but Alejandro Pena said yesterday that he wanted to become the right-handed stopper in the Mets' bullpen and not just the man who set the stage for John Franco to chalk up the saves that make relief pitchers rich and famous.
LEAD: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were up sharply for the week ended yesterday.
LEAD: Test wells drilled at the Federal Government's Fernald uranium processing plant show a new source of uranium contamination in an underground waterway.
LEAD: The Sports of The Times column yesterday cited the result of the 1962 World Series incorrectly in some editions. The Yankees beat the San Francisco Giants.

LEAD: Tonight's Nets game would have been even more bizarre had the Nets won. As it was, New Jersey's 110-96 loss to the Milwaukee Bucks was loaded with unusual events. How weird was it? The Nets played a horrendous second quarter in which they scored only 10 points, committed 13 turnovers, and did not score for the first 4 minutes 56 seconds.

LEAD: EVEN if he said so himself, John Tauranac, a New York writer and graphic designer, has ''built a better mousetrap.'' Mr. Tauranac, who designed the official Metropolitan Transportation Authority map 11 years ago, has produced new New York subway and bus maps in conjunction with the Transit Center, an alliance of mass-transit operators.

LEAD: THE archeologists have unearthed the foundation of a long-lost addition, an afterthought grafted on by an owner who just could not stop tinkering with his original design. The historians have read through reams of letters, uncovering a telling paragraph here, a helpful sentence there.

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson called on the Bush Administration on Tuesday to offer a reward for the capture of whoever is responsible for the bombings that killed a Federal judge and a civil rights lawyer in the South.

LEAD: Thieves raided an Italian villa that houses a collection belonging to the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, stealing four paintings and a piece of 18th-century furniture that have a total value of $115,000, the police said.

LEAD: A front-page article by The Associated Press in some copies yesterday about the killing of two Roman Catholic nuns gave an incorrect date for the collapse of the cease-fire in Nicaragua. It ended on Nov. 1.

LEAD: In the literature of pop songs that celebrate sophisticated flirtation, the collaborations of the composer Cy Coleman and the lyricist Carolyn Leigh rank just below those of Cole Porter in their wit and mischievous eroticism. Songs like ''The Best Is Yet to Come,'' ''You Fascinate Me So,'' ''Witchcraft,'' and ''When in Rome'' combine slinky syncopated melodies and tongue-twisting double-entendres to portray a game of romantic hide-and-seek that almost always ends in a passionate embrace.
LEAD: Stephen Thompson, who scored 24 points, converted a 3-point play with 5 seconds left as Syracuse rallied from 13 points down, then lost a 5-point lead before beating Pitt tonight, 80-78.

LEAD: Despite Ronald Reagan's pledge to shrink the bureaucracy, Federal employment rose in five of his eight years in the White House. When he left, the headcount was higher than at any time since World War II. So much for that promise.
LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities skidded for the second straight session yesterday, as dealers sold securities on signs that the economy may not be as weak as many had expected.

LEAD: The space agency said today that a computer chip had failed on the Magellan spacecraft, but the defect will not endanger the $550 million mission to map the surface of cloud-shrouded Venus starting in August.

LEAD: One recent Saturday afternoon on the South Side here, a 14-year-old boy received a telephone call from a gang leader. He was calling, he said, to recruit drug dealers. The boy, who did not know the gang leader, politely declined.
LEAD: In a toughly worded statement, China today rejected as ''speculations pure and simple'' recent reports that the dissidents Fang Lizhi and Li Shuxian would be allowed to leave China soon.

LEAD: Peru, which said it would boycott a drug summit meeting in Colombia next month to protest the United States attack on Panama, has reversed itself and will attend the conference, American and Peruvian officials said today.

LEAD: The Charter amendments approved overwhelmingly by New York City voters in November impose a dizzying array of requirements and deadlines for restructuring city government. Putting aside his personal differences with many of the Charter changes, Mayor David Dinkins moved wisely this week to insure a smooth transition.

LEAD: A close friend of a man dying of AIDS shot him to death in his hospital bed on Tuesday, then killed himself. Groups counseling people with AIDS expressed sympathy today both for the pain of the dying man and for what they said must have been the fear and loneliness of his friend.

LEAD: TRW Inc., of Cleveland, and Motorola Inc., of Schaumburg, Ill., have built a microprocessor chip with four million transistors as part of a Defense Department program to create very-high-speed semiconductors. It is intended for high-speed mathematical applications and can also repair itself.
LEAD: Redoubt Volcano quieted down today after a violent outburst that sent ash and steam eight miles into the sky and caused some airlines to cancel flights.
LEAD: The Azerbaijanis are a Turkic-speaking Shiite Muslim people who live on both sides of the Soviet-Iranian border, in territory that has been a battleground for peoples and tribes for centuries.

LEAD: Executive Committee Chairman - Ion Iliescu First Deputy Chairman - Dumitru Mazilu Deputy Chairmen - Cazimir Ionescu and Carol Kiraly Secretary - Dan Martzian Members - Bogdan Teodoriu, Vasile Neacsa, Silviu Brucan, Gheorghe Manole, Ion Caramitru and Nicolae Radu Working Committees
LEAD: When President Vaclav Havel declared an amnesty for 20,000 prisoners on New Year's Day, he obviously was not thinking about what the effect would be on the country's biggest automobile factory.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: From his living room window, Myron Vold can see a great many deer, a bald eagle's roost and an occasional red fox chasing a quail. He also sees a spectacular variety of traffic accidents on U.S. Highway 61, one of America's most beautiful and treacherous highways.

LEAD: LIFE-SIZE household items like pianos, cars, outboard motors, magazines and mantels are intrinsic to David Mach's artwork: overscale constructions that juxtapose seemingly disparate elements. One of his latest pieces, on view through Jan. 13 at the Barbara Toll Fine Arts gallery (146 Greene Street, between Prince and Houston Streets), glorifies a washing machine by placing it in the locked jaws of a fiberglass hippopotamus.

LEAD: The Pacific Stock Exchange said yesterday that it had appointed Leopold Korins president, effective Jan. 22. Mr. Korins, who is currently managing director of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, is also expected to be named chief executive officer by the exchange's board of governors on Jan. 25.

LEAD: Dominick R. Capello, Superintendent of the New Jersey State Police from 1962 to 1964 and later a private detective, died on Sunday at Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck, N.J. He was 80 years old and lived in Hackensack, N.J.

LEAD: Bernard Stephens, a retired editor of newspapers for labor unions, died of a heart attack yesterday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 72 years old and lived in Albertson, L.I.

LEAD: Rumors and conspiracy theories, once the spice of this Balkan city's romantic reputation, have crept back to life here, spreading old-fashioned intrigue through the hotel lobbies and coffee shops.

LEAD: A 12-year-old girl was repeatedly raped, burned with a red-hot knife and stabbed with an icepick late Tuesday night during a five-hour attack by three teen-agers in a Harlem apartment, the police said yesterday.
LEAD: Murray S. Kaplan, a lawyer and textile executive, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 82 years old.

LEAD: All day, from the moment they arrived for practice until the sun began to fall in the late afternoon, the Los Angeles Rams were forced to remember the game they played almost two months ago on a warm Sunday at Anaheim Stadium.

LEAD: The interim Government of the Communist Prime Minister, Hans Modrow, promised today to keep political opponents better informed about national affairs and to consult pro-democracy forces before making important decisions.

LEAD: The Arts & Entertainment Network, on cable television, is unusually active these days on the original-programming front. Tonight at 9 o'clock, the monthly ''American Playwrights Theater'' series continues in its one-act mode with Paul Zindel's ''Let Me Hear You Whisper.'' And this Sunday at 8 P.M., Michael Palin sets off on a seven-part travelogue called ''Around the World in 80 Days.

LEAD: Bearing down on what he called wasteful spending, Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez yesterday took city cars away from 14 top-level Board of Education officials who, he said, were using them chiefly to get to and from work.
LEAD: An Army woman led an attack against troops of the Panamanian Defense Forces last month, the first time a woman has commanded American soldiers in battle, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: St. John's, in an apparent reaction to criticism of its soft nonconference schedule, announced yesterday that it wanted to add games against Georgia Tech and Indiana to its 1990-91 basketball schedule and renew a home-and-home series with U.C.L.A. next season.

LEAD: The rupture of an underwater Exxon pipeline, far more serious than officials calculated on Tuesday, has allowed more than 200,000 gallons of heating oil to leak into the Arthur Kill between Staten Island and New Jersey. Environmentalists said the leak posed a significant danger to wildlife.
LEAD: Tolls for Port Authority bridges and tunnels would rise, to $6, in 1993, and the PATH fare would go up, to $1.50, if a long-range plan released this week becomes a reality.

LEAD: Richard Z. Steinhaus, a lawyer and lobbyist, died of a heart attack on Dec. 25 at St. Thomas Hospital while on vacation in the United States Virgin Islands. He was 61 years old and lived in Loudonville, a suburb of Albany.

LEAD: Presenting an election-year array of new programs, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today proposed a universal health insurance program for children and an overhaul of the method that the state uses to distribute education aid.
LEAD: Paul Corbin, a political consultant who was an aide to Senator Robert F. Kennedy, died of cancer on Tuesday at his home in Alexandria, Va. He was 75 years old.

LEAD: Some gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund break the heart, as much for the donors' situation as for that of the recipients.

LEAD: Arthur Gold, a Canadian pianist who performed for nearly 40 years as part of a piano duo with Robert Fizdale, died of lung cancer yesterday at the Manhattan apartment he shared with Mr. Fizdale. He was 72 years old, and also had a home in Water Mill, N.Y.

LEAD: Dr. Herbert Pollack, a physician, educator and Government consultant, died of cardiac arrest Tuesday at George Washington University Hospital in Washington. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan before moving to Washington about 10 years ago.

LEAD: Leonard Zahn, a stockbroker and philanthropist, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 73 years old and had homes in Palm Beach and Kings Point, L.I.

LEAD: Nearly one-fourth of the Justice Department's organized crime prosecutors have resigned since Attorney General Dick Thornburgh announced plans to put their strike forces under the control of local United States attorneys.

LEAD: BATHED in the burnt-orange light of a fading day, a youthful-looking man with a beard is working at his computer on his deck, his dog at his feet. The message of the advertisement for American Telephone & Telegraph Company is clear: you can stay home in a beautiful setting and still pursue a career that will pay for the deck and the dog food.
LEAD: Donald J. Trump has agreed to endorse a line of photographic business cards made by a small Georgia company he had sued for calling the product ''Trump Cards.''
LEAD: Experts are finally gaining insight into the genetic and chemical roots of childhood obesity and are trying to develop sensible programs for childhood weight loss.

LEAD: International A3-15 Gen. Manuel Noriega surrendered to United States authorities in Panama, giving President Bush the final victory he had been seeking. Gen. Noriega was flown to Florida to face trial on drug charges. Page A1 As word spreads of surrender, joy erupts in Panama

LEAD: Generations of children have delighted in the scary lore that Tyrannosaurus rex was the largest and fiercest predator ever to walk the earth. A leading paleontologist has announced, however, that another family of dinosaurs every bit as large and ferocious flourished 30 million years before tyrannosaurs ever saw the light of day.

LEAD: * Bristol-Myers Squibb Co., New York, the pharmaceuticals company, appointed William T. Comer president of its Bristol-Myers Pharmaceutical Research unit and Bristol-Myers Squibb Licensing Group.

LEAD: The latest telegrams were being delivered to the coach of the 1989 unofficial-but-pleased national college football champions, and a floral arrangement was on its way to Dennis Erickson's unfinished office.
LEAD: Communist Party leaders met today with opposition groups for the first time in discussions that could result in the formation of a transitional government until free elections are held.
LEAD: A Hartford lawyer is helping unhappy spouses negotiate the legal complexities of what he calls the ''most powerful judicial institution in America,'' divorce court.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Mike Tyson says he had a drinking habit that intensified after Robin Givens filed for divorce in October 1988, but that he has stopped drinking entirely.

LEAD: A $400 million offer to buy various real estate assets of the financially distressed L. J. Hooker Corporation has been withdrawn, according to an executive of the Shidler Investment Corporation, a Honolulu company that is part of the investment group involved in the deal. Ian Killips, a Shidler partner, said the LHJ Funding Company broke off negotiations because of Hooker's decision to sell the properties individually.

LEAD: President Bush announced tonight that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega had surrendered to the United States military authorities in Panama, giving the President the final victory he had been seeking in the invasion of Panama.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Weeksville, a historic community in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, is to be the subject of a free lecture on Feb. 7 at 7:30 P.M. at Lehman College, Gillet Hall Auditorium, Goulden Avenue and Bedford Park Boulevard, in the Bedford Park section of the Bronx.

LEAD: David W. Johnson, who led a sharp two-year turnaround at the Gerber Products Company, was named yesterday to become president, chief executive and a director of the Campbell Soup Company, one of the world's largest but most troubled food companies.
LEAD: * Aetna Life and Casualty Co., Hartford, sued Massachusetts, challenging the state's 7.9 percent limit on automobile insurance premium increases for 1990.

LEAD: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega is likely to be brought to a Federal court in Miami on Thursday in the first step in a long and uncertain legal journey as the United States tries to prosecute him on a variety of drug-related charges.

LEAD: One of cultural Baltimore's favorite sons is in danger of becoming its fiscal orphan. The Peabody Conservatory, a source of civic pride since 1857, is suffering its biggest crisis since Johns Hopkins University rescued it from extinction 12 years ago.

LEAD: Salvatore J. Licata, an AIDS educator with the New York City Health Department, died of AIDS-related illnesss on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 50 years old. In 1985, Mr. Licata helped found People With AIDS Newsline, a monthly newspaper written by and for people with AIDS. He also wrote articles for the newspaper.

LEAD: WHEN water freezes and expands inside pipes, itcan cause major damage requiring expensive repairs. Frequently, the pressure causes the pipes to burst or, at the least, to leak at the seams. And, because pipes usually freeze when and where coping with them is most difficult, preventing the problem is as important, if not more so, than knowing what to do if it occurs.

He was 86 years old and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

LEAD: When Seattle police officers began riding 21-speed mountain bicycles into drug strongholds in bright yellow Gore-Tex raincoats, black nylon pants, fashionable helmets and oversized galoshes, the gang members giggled.

LEAD: Two articles in Business Day on Monday - about the stability of the Tokyo stock market and about the 1989 record of the world's stock markets - referred to the performance of the Japanese market. Their percentage figures appeared contradictory.

LEAD: Under the baseball cap and behind the dark glasses, Kevin Greene seemed lost in the crowd of players that walked off the field in the late-morning sunshine today. He stopped suddenly near the shade of a nearby tree, and then he smiled when someone asked him about Phil Simms.

LEAD: In a gracious program note for this year's Dance Chance performances at Dance Theater Workshop, Patsy Tarr, the producer and curator of the series for eight years, cautions future audiences not to underestimate the value of the experimental.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Because of a transmission error, an article and a caption on Dec. 20 about an American entrepreneur in Zaire misidentified him. He is Elwyn Blattner.

LEAD: Robert Campeau, the Canadian developer who borrowed heavily to buy two big American retailers and then brought them into severe financial straits, surrendered about $100 million worth of his own stock in his flagship company, the Campeau Corporation, yesterday to a Canadian bank when he defaulted on a loan to two of his private companies.

LEAD: * Dime Savings Bank of New York, Garden City, L.I., appointed David J. Totaro first senior vice president and director of marketing, and Jack L. Wagner first senior vice president, responsible for the bank's data processing activities.

LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current. The Ballroom * (June 30, 1989), 253 West 28th Street (244-3005) - The Ballroom features tapas, the national tidbit of Spain, served as appetizers with dinner or, more traditionally, as a bite with a drink at the long wooden tapas bar.

LEAD: State regulators are investigating a doctor who speeded up delivery of a baby, put the infant in a Christmas stocking and dashed to a television studio next door to display her as the county's first newborn of the 1990's.

LEAD: IS the business cycle dead? The United States economy has now completed seven straight years of expansion, the longest in its peacetime history. Most economists foresee no recession in 1990 or 1991, and 1992 will be another Presidential election year, when the odds tip strongly against recession. Japan, West Germany and most of the other capitalist countries of Europe and Asia are also on a long upward roll, with no end in sight.

LEAD: Recommending choices to appease both environmentalists and the oil industry, a panel headed by Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. says more study is needed before oil companies drill off the coasts of California and Florida.

LEAD: Some 200 admirers of the late Andrei D. Sakharov gathered yesterday at a memorial service in the New York Public Library at which leaders of the international struggle for human rights paid tribute to the physicist and Nobel Peace Prize winner. Dr. Sakharov, who was 68 years old, died Dec. 14 in Moscow.

LEAD: New York State's loan program to improve and upgrade municipal sewer treatment systems will be managed by an underwriting team of Goldman, Sachs & Company and Kidder, Peabody & Company, Thomas C. Jorling, chairman of the State Environmental Facilities Corporation, announced yesterday.

LEAD: The Vatican said today that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega was given no special guarantees beyond the promise of a fair trial in the United States before he agreed to leave the papal embassy and surrender to American forces in Panama Wednesday night.

LEAD: It will be a good New Year for shareholders of Lin Broadcasting, who will profit from the company's merger deal with McCaw Cellular Communications. But it will be an extraordinary one for Lin's chairman, Donald A. Pels, as he sells his 1.3 million stock options to McCaw for about $200 million.
LEAD: There had been for the Rangers, in the brief hours of euphoria produced by their first triumph in 12 games, talk of perhaps making a move. The stall that had become a full stop had ended.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: More than 2,000 years ago, a crafty Chinese feudal king put down a rebellion in his province, went on to conquer six neighboring kingdoms, and then gave himself the name Qin Shihuang, meaning First Emperor. Having established peace, the first Chinese Emperor maintained it ruthlessly, burning books that challenged his laws and burying alive 460 scholars who disagreed with him.

LEAD: President Bush can now fairly and proudly claim success for the military phase of his Panama policy. The surrender of Manuel Antonio Noriega to U.S. custody is a personal triumph for the President and a great relief to most Panamanians.
LEAD: The incentive for winning National Football League divisional playoff games this weekend is clear and concise for the participants.
LEAD: Mark Murphy's Songs
LEAD: Governor-elect James J. Florio yesterday appointed his campaign manager, Doug Berman, as State Treasurer.

LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities ended narrowly mixed in fairly light trading yesterday, as market participants largely shrugged off developments in the foreign exchange, energy and equity markets.
LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency proposed regulations today to reduce hydrocarbon releases from cars and trucks when gasoline evaporates.
LEAD: Escapes Stories By Joy Williams 168 pages. The Atlantic Monthly Press. $18.95.

LEAD: Dutch salvage workers trying to clean up a huge Atlantic oil spill said today that the accident could have been controlled much faster if the Spanish or Moroccan authorities had allowed a crippled Iranian oil tanker into their coastal waters for repairs.

LEAD: As Mark Jackson stepped out of the shower in the Knick dressing room last night with a huge contingent of reporters waiting at his locker, he turned to his teammate Eddie Lee Wilkins and said, ''Welcome back, Kotter.''

LEAD: A man suspected of helping Costabile (Gus) Farace elude the authorities for more than eight months in the murder of a Federal drug agent was found shot to death in Brooklyn early Wednesday, slumped over the steering wheel of a car.

LEAD: ''I understood pain at a very young age: I've been a torch singer since the age of 4,'' Lainie Kazan joked while introducing her version of ''La Vie en Rose,'' Edith Piaf's signature song, at Rainbow and Stars (30 Rockefeller Plaza) on Wednesday evening. ''But I was never a little sparrow,'' she added.
LEAD: New Jersey Blue Cross and Blue Shield today was granted an overall increase in rates of 24.6 percent, effective Feb. 15, for 605,000 subscribers. The insurer had sought a 33 percent increase.

LEAD: It may be that the dawning of a new year, makes an art dealer's fancy turn to thoughts of fresh, undiscovered talent. Whatever the reason, a number of debuts are under way this weekend, in galleries on 57th Street and in SoHo.

LEAD: For 40 years, the Portuguese community in Naugatuck has celebrated St. Paio, a patron saint, and the celebration has evolved into the biggest social event of the year for the 6,000 Portuguese and Portuguese-Americans who make up 20 percent of the town's population.
LEAD: The First Executive Corporation said today that a deal to sell a subsidiary, the Executive Life Insurance Company of New York, had collapsed.

LEAD: The man described his day. He wakes. He goes to buy milk for his children. For the babies, there is no formula to buy. He goes to work. The bus line is long and slow. It is cold at work. There is no heat, no equipment for proper work. He finishes work and goes to buy something to eat. But there is no food to buy.
LEAD: The official Laotian radio has said that 1989 was ''a nightmare year for socialism'' but that the ideology will prevail and citizens should rally around the Communist Party leadership.
LEAD: The Islanders began their schedule with a luxury losers do not always enjoy: they were virtually ignored.

LEAD: Despite a late surge in light-truck sales, American auto makers ended December and last year with total sales badly depressed and little confidence that the current salesroom incentives are enough to solve the problem.

LEAD: Amnesty International has issued a report asserting that the Israeli Government appears to have encouraged the killing of Palestinians in an effort to crush the uprising in the occupied territories.

LEAD: The union of United Nations civil servants has asked Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar to extend the contracts of several Chinese workers at the Secretariat who the union says have been asked to leave their jobs under ''pressure from the Chinese Government.''

LEAD: Federal prosecutors insisted today that they would prevail in a trial of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, but a senior Administration official said the Government would be prepared to discuss a negotiated settlement if the deposed Panamanian leader provided detailed information about international drug trafficking activities.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a report in the Business People column on Monday misstated the age of Frederick H. Joseph, chief executive of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. He is 52 years old.

LEAD: When Dustin Hoffman plays an autistic savant or Daniel Day-Lewis a man with cerebral palsy who paints with his left foot, it is easy to praise the distance these men have come to create their roles. But when unknown actors disappear into their characters, it is easy to forget they are acting at all; who knows how far they have transformed themselves?
LEAD: A Federal district judge ruled Wednesday that a protester was not legally responsible for traumatizing the crew of a Navy weapons train that ran over and maimed him at a demonstration in 1987.

LEAD: Continuing to move aggressively in his first days in office, Joseph A. Fernandez, the New York City Schools Chancellor, said yesterday that he would take command of schools and school boards that do not measure up to his academic standards.

LEAD: Now that Catherine has been murdered and Vincent has begun a prolonged period of mourning, CBS's ''Beauty and the Beast'' (Wednesdays at 8 P.M.) is gingerly grooming a new leading lady to flesh out the title. Exit Linda Hamilton. Enter JO ANDERSONas Diana Bennett, special-crimes investigator for the Manhattan District Attorney's office.

LEAD: A state museum has decided to shut down an exhibit featuring the exposed graves of 234 prehistoric American Indians because of ''heightened sensitivity to display of human remains,'' an official said.
LEAD: It seemed like the classic mismatch.

LEAD: When Dick Motta retired as coach of the Dallas Mavericks in 1987 after 19 seasons of marking X's and O's with three National Basketball Association teams, he did so after a 55-27 record by the Mavericks and a first-place finish in the Midwest Division. Yesterday, the 58-year-old Motta was back as an N.B.A.

LEAD: A 23-year-old Bronx man has been indicted on murder and robbery charges in what the police said was an unprovoked attack on a young advertising executive last month in the East Village, the Manhattan District Attorney said yesterday.
LEAD: Thoroughbred racing begins a new season amid a mixed forecast: a year of poor business but wonderful racing.

LEAD: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. paid a $1.3 million fine today to the State of Illinois for securities fraud, an administrative penalty stemming from a highly publicized Wall Street corruption case.
LEAD: One day it may become respectable again, maybe even fashionable, to speak plain truths about some of the world's more important political realities.

LEAD: Mayor David N. Dinkins filled two more major positions in his administration yesterday, selecting as his director of operations a New York City school official whom he credited with helping to reduce the bureaucracy at the Board of Education. The Mayor also named an investment banker to head the city's economic-development effort.

LEAD: FOR performers and visual artists, recognition can be immediate -as a newcomer makes a striking first impression in a debut. Or, after a period of anonymity, a more experienced professional may attract attention after finally having the opportunity to demonstrate originality. In a theater or concert hall, there can be an audible certification of that newness, with the sound of an audience rustling programs to find the name of a previously unknown and soon-to-be-memorable performer.

LEAD: Something of an endangered species, the long-form mini-series returns to ''Masterpiece Theater'' on Sunday evening - on Channel 13 at 9 Channel 31 and 49 at 10 and Channel 21 at 11:30 - in Frederic Raphael's ''After the War.'' The 10-hour Granada Television production is to be presented in eight installments.
LEAD: Zydeco by Fernest

LEAD: A picture caption on Wednesday about the inauguration of Andrew P. O'Rourke as Westchester County Executive misidentified the justice who administered the oath. (The error was repeated in some copies yesterday in a correction in this space.) The justice was Samuel G. Fredman.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The assets of the nation's 469 money market mutual funds decreased by $955.0 million, to $365.04 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 144 institutional funds increased by $625.7 million, to $88.23 billion. The assets of the 227 general-purpose funds were down $112.1 million, to $119.87 billion.
LEAD: One of three engines on a Northwest Airlines jet fell off the plane yesterday as it flew over northern Florida, but the pilots were able to land safely.

LEAD: Leonard Elliott, an actor and comedian who performed on the Broadway stage and in Manhattan nightclubs, died of cardiac arrest on Sunday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: The MCI Communications Corporation and Telefonos de Mexico S.A. signed an agreement to provide voice and other telecommunications services between the United States and Mexico. MCI, whose international division is based here, and Telefonos de Mexico said they expected to begin providing voice service early next week.
LEAD: Soldiers with acetylene torches cut into crushed railroad cars today searching for victims of Pakistan's worst train wreck, which officials said killed at least 210 people and injured 700.
LEAD: Small and grinding deprivations led the people of Brasov, Rumania, to take up arms against tyranny on the night of Dec. 22 in the revolution that toppled Nicolae Ceausescu.

LEAD: It is not so much a matter of taste as a taste of matter that creates problems for the chubby housewife whose name gives the title to ''Beth,'' one of the three plays in Steven Sater's ''Carbondale Dreams'' package of one-acters at the Judith Anderson Theater. The plays, presented two at a time, explore the tensions between family togetherness and individual yearnings.
LEAD: * Asarco Inc., New York, a metals producer, sold its last operating coal mine, located in Peoria, Ill., to a group of former managers of the mine for $3 million.
LEAD: When Lionel Simmons stops running so gracefully on the basketball court, perhaps he should run for political office.

LEAD: In a charming new film called ''Sidewalk Stories,'' a couple of street artists are bickering over a prospective customer. As the argument intensifies, one hustler gets up from his chair. And gets up. And gets up. My goodness, it's Tom Hoover, all 6 feet 10 inches of him.

LEAD: A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday approved a settlement between the Securities and Exchange Commission and a typesetting supervisor accused of illegally trading on confidential information from advance copies of Business Week magazine.

LEAD: The 1990 Annual Conference for Conductors is to take place today through Sunday at the Kellogg Center of the School of International Affairs at Columbia University, 420 West 118th Street. A major feature will be a retrospective of the career of George Szell, the music director of the Cleveland Orchestra for 24 years, until his death in 1970.

LEAD: Drilling Delay Is Proposed A panel headed by Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. recommended to the White House a delay in oil drilling off Florida and California. Page A16. Hoping for a Bargain Potential buyers jammed the phone lines of the Federal agency that is selling thousands of properties owned by failed savings units.

LEAD: In a strange night of high drama at the theater, a woman watching an Off Broadway performance on a Greenwich Village stage last night was shot, apparently when someone seated nearby dropped a pistol to the floor, sending a single stray bullet in her direction, the police said.

LEAD: Litton Industries put up for sale three divisions that supply electrical and electronic interconnection products. The three divisions, which have combined annual sales of about $170 million and employ about 2,200 people, are: Advanced Circuitry and Inter-Pak Electronics, based in Springfield, Mo.; VEAM, based in Milan, Italy, with domestic operations in Watertown, Conn., and Winchester Electronics, based in Watertown.

LEAD: Faced with the refusal of customers to buy and assurances from the Government of President Carlos Saul Menem that he is serious about stabilizing the economy, many stores began to roll back prices today that had doubled and tripled over the holiday weekend.

LEAD: ''When the Colored Band Goes Marchin','' a one-man show combining autobiography and black history, is to be presented by John Patterson on weekends through Jan. 28 at the Castillo Cultural Center, 500 Greenwich Street. In the piece, Mr. Patterson draws upon his own writings and works by Frederick Douglass, Langston Hughes, W.
LEAD: A woman extradited from Austria will remain in jail without bond to face charges that she operated an international marijuana-smuggling ring, a Federal district judge has ruled.

LEAD: The sad story of Hong Kong's Vietnamese boat people gets sadder by the day. News that the refugees are now willing to risk violence to avoid repatriation only increases the urgency for a more humane global response.
LEAD: The financially strapped Braniff Inc. said today that David Murchison had been named its chief executive.

LEAD: The revival in Chelsea on Manhattan's Lower West Side is not so much Gothic as it is theatrical. The neighborhood, a center for New York show business in the 19th century, is dotted with small theaters of every description that, starting today, are proceeding to make a festival of themselves.

LEAD: The Giants remember the horrible game they played eight weeks ago in a 31-10 loss to the Los Angeles Rams. They know they will have to be a different team Sunday when they meet the Rams at Giants Stadium in the National Football League playoffs.

LEAD: Less dramatically than in Berlin and less bloodily than in Bucharest, the winds of Communist change have swept across the Gobi Desert to stir up political life in the sparsely populated nation of Mongolia.

LEAD: The Pacific Telesis Group, the regional telephone and communications company based in San Francisco, said yesterday that it plans to eliminate 11,000 jobs, or 16 percent of its work force, in the next five years to cut costs.

LEAD: Dave Dravecky, the former San Francisco Giants pitcher, underwent surgery for four and a half hours at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York yesterday to remove a tumor from his left arm.

LEAD: New York's ''new'' City Council, given real power in the just-approved City Charter, is off to a disappointing start. At its very first meeting under the new Charter this week, the Council sent the message that it likes the perks of power, but isn't yet too interested in the responsibility.

LEAD: Faced with fiscal problems that have forced him to delay hiring more than 1,800 police officers, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he favors creating a special fund to help pay for the police, but he did not say how the money should be raised.

LEAD: Federal marshals in the Northeast and elsewhere are throwing mattresses on the floor for Federal prisoners and driving hundreds of miles a day in a hunt for empty jail beds as the authorities grapple with badly overcrowded prisons.
LEAD: James P. McDonald, a retired public relations executive, died on Dec. 27 at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Tenafly, N.J.

LEAD: Last year was a tough one for both investment advisers and mutual funds, with most of them failing to match the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. But the investment advisers seem to have done better than the stock mutual funds, according to figures released yesterday.

LEAD: March 1982: After the death in 1981 of the armed forces chief, Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, three senior officers - Col. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Col. Ruben Darlo Paredes and Col. Roberto Diaz Herrera - cut a deal to resolve ja power struggle. Paredes is promoted to general, takes over as armed forces chief and agrees to retire in August 1983, leaving Noriega to take over, with Diaz Herrera as second-in-command.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A transport plane flew through a group of falling Army paratroopers at Fort Bragg on Wednesday, killing one soldier and injuring another, Army spokesmen said.

LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration says it has begun testing retail milk supplies in 13 cities after an independent survey found samples in several areas tainted with potentially harmful drugs. The agency said Tuesday that while it was concerned that these unconfirmed findings might indicate ''violative drug residues in milk,'' it saw ''no public health threat associated with animal drug residues in milk'' at the levels reported by The Wall Street Journal last Friday.

LEAD: Michael P. O'Donnell, a 33-year-old executive who gave up a budding Wall Street career to return to his first love, the food service business, will become president and chief executive of Ground Round Inc., the restaurant chain announced yesterday.
LEAD: Ambiguity of the Law

LEAD: The eight-team International League of Football, which begins play in eight cities in Europe in April, began assigning head coaches to teams yesterday and Walt Michaels wound up as coach of the Helsinki team in Finland and Jack Elway as coach in London.

LEAD: The Rev. Dr. Edward Nason West, the retired Canon Sacrist of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, where he was master of ceremonies for more than 40 years, died of pulmonary failure on Wednesday at St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: A table yesterday showing corrected figures for population shifts in the United States misstated the census region for Pennsylvania in some copies. It is the Middle Atlantic region. In addition the 1980 population total and percentage change for the Midwest were incorrect in some copies. The 1980 total was 58,868,000 and the increase was 2.2 percent.

LEAD: Shows, Nature, Museums ''MAGIC OVER THE RAINBOW,'' a show of illusion and magic, presented by Danny Orleans and Jan Rose, 1:30 and 3:30 P.M. Sunday, at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. Admission: $8 and $12. Tickets from the box office or by calling Y-Charge: 996-1100. ''GROUP SOUP 2,'' a collage of skits, dances and songs with an assortment of props and costumes; created and directed by Judith Martin, with music composed and played by Donald Ashwander, at 2 P.M.

LEAD: Even if Gino De Dominicis is not as wild and wacky as some of his supporters believe, and even if his mixed-media work may not be a ''mix of sanctity and damnation'' that ''has not been seen in a European artist since the times of Rimbaud,'' as the critic Italo Tomassoni recently wrote in Flash Art, he is still an endearing, imaginative and occasionally inspired artist.
LEAD: The Economy

LEAD: With contributions to the 78th annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund pouring in, one gift in particular stood out this week - a check for $50,000 from Grenville and Sandra Craig of Paris and Princeton, N.J.

LEAD: For the first time since his Lincoln Savings and Loan Association was taken over by Federal regulators in April, Charles H. Keating Jr. took the stand in a crowded courtroom here today. He denied any wrongdoing and answered questions about his involvement in the institution.

LEAD: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission today unanimously approved a proposed rule that would restrict dual trading on the nation's largest commodity markets, a first step toward the possible banning of the practice from all futures markets.
LEAD: A 16-year-old youth was held on $50,000 bail yesterday after a prosecutor said the youth admitted being part of a group that raped, sodomized and tortured a girl, 12, in Harlem Tuesday night.
LEAD: A motorist who pleaded guilty to charges stemming from a rampage along a crowded downtown street last year was sentenced Wednesday to a minimum of 13 years in prison.

LEAD: Stock prices fell broadly yesterday, depressed by caution before the Government's report today of employment data for December. The Dow Jones industrial average fell by 13.65 points to close at 2,796.08, just below the important 2,800 technical level.
LEAD: An article on Monday about new year's observances in Japan referred incorrectly to the calendar used in the West. It is the Gregorian calendar, based on the solar year.
LEAD: The Evergreen Media Corporation, a privately held radio company, agreed today to acquire a station and a statewide network in Texas for $58.5 million in cash and debt. Evergreen is purchasing

LEAD: The leveraged buyout of Michaels Stores Inc., an Irving, Tex., retail chain, by MSI Holdings has ended because of financing problems related to the weakening ''junk bond'' market, the company said. Michaels Stores said it would take a fourth-quarter charge of $3 million to $5 million to cover expenses.

LEAD: Gerhard Schroder, a former Foreign Minister of West Germany and a co-founder of the Christian Democratic Union that has been in power for much of the post-World War II period, died of heart failure on Sunday at his home on the North Sea island of Sylt, his family said. He was 79 years old.
LEAD: As the AIDS epidemic rages in New York and California, Texas is struggling with a less noticed but no less destructive AIDS plague of its own.

LEAD: One would think that the major endeavors by so well loved a composer as Franz Schubert have all been heard by now. But in its quest to present the composer's complete works chronologically in a 10-year Schubertiade, the 92d Street Y has already made some significant introductions. LEAD: Ed Futerman, the attorney for the suspended Canadian sprinter, Ben Johnson, said yesterday he had not been contacted about a possible match race against Carl Lewis in September.

LEAD: ''I've been on this earth 50 years, and I've read a lot of suspense stories, but I've not heard anything as bizarre and troubling as this.'' - Mayor Raymond L. Flynn of Boston,on the apparent suicide of a victim-turned-suspect. [A21:4.]

LEAD: The Devils received offensive production from defensive specialists tonight and defeated the Los Angeles Kings, 4-2, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena to move into sole possession of first place in the Patrick Division.
LEAD: Two senior executives of D. F. King & Company, a firm that solicits proxies from investors in takeovers and other corporate contests, resigned yesterday, the firm said.

LEAD: Declaring the old Communist trading bloc a dead letter, Czechoslovakia's Government said today that it would propose the annulment of the group's previous trade agreements at a meeting of the Soviet-led organization next week.
LEAD: Edwin F. Shelley, a management consultant and an inventor and engineer, died of a heart attack yesterday at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in New Rochelle.
LEAD: The Peace Corps announced today that it would send its first contingent to Poland, 60 volunteers who will train English teachers there.

LEAD: Vladimir Ussachevsky, who composed the first piece of electronic music heard in concert in the United States and who went on to lead the pioneering Columbia-Princeton Electronic Music Center, died of a brain tumor yesterday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 78 years old.

LEAD: The Senate Ethics Committee has expanded its investigation of Senator Dave Durenberger to include a deal through which he was reimbursed for renting his Minneapolis condominium to himself, the Minnesota Republican said today.

LEAD: Many people in Washington believe Marian Wright Edelman, the president of the Children's Defense Fund and an icon of sorts among many liberals, made a fundamental error when she bluntly accused two members of Congress of sabotaging a child care bill before adjournment late last year.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A visit to the ninth-floor office of Colombia's top police officer, Gen. Miguel Maza Marquez, underlines the adage that office decor speaks volumes about the occupant.
LEAD: Only the injured Brian Williams was absent today as the Giants practiced for the playoff game here Sunday against the Los Angeles Rams.
LEAD: The drummer Ed Blackwell is one of those musicians who radiate influence.

LEAD: The board of Apple Computer Inc. approved the repurchase of up to 2.5 million more shares of its common stock. LEAD: It is disturbing that so many Americans have fallen prey to the easy temptation of Congress-bashing. While some bashers attempt legitimately to hold Congress accountable for its obvious shortcomings, others illegitimately undermine it as an institution.
LEAD: The space agency began the countdown today for the launching of the space shuttle Columbia on Monday on a 10-day satellite rescue mission.
LEAD: The dollar dropped precipitously yesterday as a result of unexpected intervention in the foreign exchange market by the West German central bank.
LEAD: A 31-year-old woman was found severely beaten in her apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan on Wednesday and died that night, the police said yesterday. There have been no arrests.

LEAD: The opportunity to get a new luxury apartment in a rental complex is rare in the suburbs and older towns around New York City. Hardly any rental buildings have been built for several years, and most of the rental offerings have been made by investor-owners of condominiums.

LEAD: Heavy fighting that has raged for nearly two weeks between rival Shiite Muslim factions in southern Lebanon gained intensity today as the combatants ignored an appeal from their spiritual leaders for an end to the bloodshed.

LEAD: After 10 days of trying to persuade Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to give himself up, the Vatican's envoy to Panama on Wednesday entered the spartan quarters that served as the deposed Panamanian dictator's temporary sanctuary and delivered an ultimatum: His refuge in the Vatican Embassy would expire at noon today.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about Mayor David N. Dinkins's decision to delay the hiring of 1,848 police officers misstated a campaign promise he made about subway crime. He pledged that by the end of his first term he would put an officer on every train every night, not in every car.
