LEAD: The new chairman of the New York City Council's education committee -long known for his outspoken views -has asserted in an interview that, in contrast to ''children of European-born'' parents, ''there appears to be no liking of learning'' among black and Hispanic children.

LEAD: To the Editor: In 1977 and 1978 I was privileged to serve with an august group of people on the Governor's Commission on Alternatives to Abortion, headed by the then dean of the Fordham Law School, Joseph McLaughlin, who subsequently was named to the Federal bench. The conclusions of that study group were the basis for subsequent policies of Gov.

LEAD: The United States is prepared to provide up to $3 million to an international commission to begin planning the voluntary relocation of contras to Nicaragua provided that democratic conditions exist there, the State Department said today.

LEAD: Duane C. Bogie, a television producer who helped create the ''Hallmark Hall of Fame'' drama series, died of brain cancer Tuesday in Parkland Hospital in Dallas. He was 67 years old and had homes in Dallas and Litchfield, Conn.

LEAD: Capt. Linda Bray led an attack in the Panama invasion, apparently the first time that a woman has commanded American forces in battle. But she was acting as a Military Police officer; women are still barred from combat roles in the armed forces. Since women like Captain Bray already serve with distinction in danger zones, isn't it time to allow them into combat too?

LEAD: The Panamanian people overwhelmingly approve of the sending of United States troops to remove Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega from power, and they want them to stay for at least six more months, according to a poll taken in Panama that was made public last night by CBS News.

LEAD: Nils Hansell, an amateur sailor best known as the originator of Operation Sail, an international maritime festival in New York City in 1964, died of pnuemonia last Saturday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 80 years old and lived in Princeton.

LEAD: A Federal appeals court yesterday threw out the first verdict ever requiring an American cigarette manufacturer to compensate the family of a smoker who died of cancer. But at the same time, the court, may have made it easier for smokers and their families to prevail in future lawsuits against tobacco companies.
LEAD: Priscilla Burton, a retired secretary in Providence, R.I., liked the aerobic exercise of jumping rope but wanted a rope she could swing more slowly and with less stress.

LEAD: The Government will dismiss 126,000 employees this month in an effort to weed out unqualified civil service workers who got their jobs through patronage, an official said today. The affected employees hold temporary positions received through the intercession of politicians, said Patricia Santo Tomas, head of the Civil Service Commission.

LEAD: One day this week, Joseph A. Fernandez noticed that his office windows were dirty. He called an engineer. Sorry, he was told, the engineers' contract stipulates that the windows are cleaned once a year.

LEAD: David L. Gunn, who embarked six years ago on what he called a ''suicide mission'' to turn around New York City's crumbling mass-transit system, announced his resignation yesterday as president of a now ''acceptable, but not perfect'' system.
LEAD: A memorial program honoring Samuel Beckett, who died on Dec. 22, is to be broadcast on WBAI-FM (99.5) on Sunday from 11:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M.

LEAD: Open auditions for the Brooklyn Philharmonia Chorus are to be held on Tuesday at 7 P.M. at the First Presbyterian Church, 124 Henry Street, in Brooklyn Heights. Performances by the group, the oldest community chorus in Brooklyn, are scheduled for April and May in Brooklyn and Manhattan. Information: (718) 640-3028.

LEAD: Even in this era of deregulation and free markets, rationing remains the Federal Government's preferred solution to some problems. While competition may be constrained, some social purpose is served, or so goes the theory, by limiting immigration, radio and television licenses - or the right to land and take off at airports where traffic is at full capacity.

LEAD: Anheuser-Busch Inc. said it plans to begin selling its new non-alcoholic brew, O'Doul's, around the country starting on Monday. The brewery said it has had strong initial sales in selected cities where the beer has been on shelves since March. Anheuser-Busch, the world's largest brewery, said O'Doul's would meet the desires of a growing segment of consumers who like the taste of beer but do not want the alcohol.
LEAD: A small group of former dissidents is setting up a committee to make sure that human rights are observed here as Rumania rids itself of the remnants of the Government of Nicolae Ceausescu.

LEAD: The Hofstra football coach for the last nine years, Mickey Kwiatkowski, moved from Division III to the Ivy League yesterday when he was appointed head coach at Brown University, succeeding John Rosenberg, who resigned Dec. 4.

LEAD: Hundreds of Vietnamese who helped the Americans during the Vietnam War and who were punished for it after the Communist victory are on their way to the United States. Three jets brought the first 156 former re-education camp inmates and their families today to Bangkok from Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, and 151 more are expected on Saturday.

LEAD: For someone who has had genuinely mixed reactions to Zubin Metha's New York Philharmonic concerts over the years, Thursday evening's program at Avery Fisher Hall was an especially dispiriting event.
LEAD: Leila Hadley and Henry Luce 3d were married yesterday at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. David H. C. Read.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The current college campaign composes a conundrum because there is no distinguishing the strong from the not so strong. They all seem average in ECAC Hockey and Hockey East, the two Eastern Division I leagues, which are beginning the second half of their seasons.

LEAD: An air of edginess is evident among the San Francisco 49ers as the defending Super Bowl champions prepare for today's National Conference semifinal against the Minnesota Vikings at Candlestick Park. Actually, the edginess has been apparent for most of this season, a season of incessant role changes for this franchise, ranging from management to coaches to players.

LEAD: Theodore I. Felner, a retired executive of Burlington Industries and of Macy's New York, died of an embolism on Wednesday at his winter home in Pompano Beach, Fla. He was 81 years old and also had a residence in Manhattan.

LEAD: When the baby boomers needed backyards, America got suburbia. When they protested, America got sit-ins and antiwar marches. When their hormones began to act up, America got the sexual revolution.
LEAD: CBS will cancel ''Beauty and the Beast'' after its broadcast on Jan. 24.
LEAD: The Economy

LEAD: Among the eight selections that the Modern Jazz Quartet played in its first set on Tuesday evening at the Cafe Carlyle, Madison Avenue at East 76th Street, five were part of the group's concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Nov. 25, 1974 - ''Django,'' ''Softly as in the Morning Sunrise,'' ''True Blues,'' ''Skating in Central Park'' and ''Odds Against Tomorrow.
LEAD: A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday blocked the Metropolitan Transit Authority from enforcing a rule that bans musicians from using amplifiers in New York City subways.

LEAD: My bicycle was stolen the other day. Or maybe I should say my friend was kidnapped on West 23d Street sometime between 7 P.M. and 10 P.M. She was a Raleigh three-speed, English, heavy, black and one of the most remarkable machines I've ever had. No effete, high-strung 10-speed from Italy or Japan was she.

LEAD: A new Air Force One jet will be delivered to President Bush on Sept. 30, almost two years late, largely because of efforts to make it resistant to a nuclear explosion, the Boeing Company said Thursday. Boeing, which has been building two modified 747 jumbo jets for the President's use, originally promised that a new Air Force One would be ready in November 1988.

LEAD: How Many Words Do You Want? An Insider's Story of Print and Television Journalism By Leslie Midgley Illustrated. 344 pages. Birch Lane Press. $19.95. Right Places, Right Times Forty Years in Journalism Not Counting My Paper Route By Hedley Donovan Illustrated. 463 pages. Henry Holt & Company.

LEAD: The head is a strange instrument, an awesome thing, a thing of multiple utilities. It can be used to cogitate; it can be used to ruminate; the skeletal remnant can be a memory device - ''Alas, poor Yorick! I knew him, Horatio.'' And it can be used as a weapon - like being armed with your head.

LEAD: The Nippon Life Insurance Company, the large Japanese insurer that already has a sizable stake in Shearson Lehman Hutton, the brokerage unit affiliated with the American Express Company, has agreed to make a $200 million investment in American Express itself.
LEAD: Following is a transcript of President Bush's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

LEAD: With interest rates headed down, as they are now, holders of bank credit cards with payments based on a fixed rate of interest can save as much as $100 a year in fees by switching to cards with interest payments tied to a variable rate. The fixed rate charged on many bank cards has been holding at current levels for a few years - good for card holders while interest rates rise.
LEAD: Soviet officials have informally suggested that Moscow is prepared to make deeper troop cuts than those it has previously proposed in the Vienna arms talks, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: When Zoriano Caballero picked up his newspaper yesterday, his eyes scanned the grim mug shot of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. He focused on the prisoner identification plate the fallen Panamanian leader held to his chest: ''U.S. Marshal, Miami, FL 41586 004.''
LEAD: Alexis P. Fekula, an oil and gas consultant and choral conductor of Russian liturgical music, died of heart disease on Thursday in Boston. He was 58 years old and lived in Southport, Conn.

LEAD: Wilfred B. Doner, founder of W. .B. Doner & Company, an advertising agency based in Detroit, died Thursday, apparently of a cerebral hemorrhage, at his home in Birmingham, Mich. He was 75 years old.

LEAD: Ian (Ernie) Horvath, producing director of the Jose Limon Dance Foundation, a founder of the Cleveland Ballet and a former soloist with the Joffrey Ballet and American Ballet Theater, died of AIDS yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital in New York. Mr. Horvath was 46 years old.

LEAD: Gertrude Simon Kosting, a health-care worker and the president of the Huxley Institute of Connecticut, died of an embolism on Tuesday at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. She was 84 years old and lived in Weston, Conn.
LEAD: Stocks retreated broadly yesterday in continued moderate trading. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 22.83 points, to 2,773.25.
LEAD: Recriminations in Boston

LEAD: The Pacific Standard Life Insurance Company, a carrier with $7 billion of insurance in force that had invested heavily in ''junk bonds'' and ''junk mortgages,'' was declared insolvent by the California Department of Insurance at the end of November. In the weeks since then, many financial advisers have asked whether the insolvency is an isolated event or whether other insurers are also at risk.

LEAD: New Jersey's most flamboyant prosecutor resigned today after his tale of a high-speed chase and shoot-out between him and men he described as drug dealers, terrorists or members of the Ku Klux Klan turned out to be a hoax.
LEAD: ''What kind of crazy way is this to run a place? If they treat me this way and I'm the Chancellor, what is going on here?'' -Joseph A. Fernandez, New York City Schools Chancellor. [1:4.]

LEAD: Even as the Bush Administration celebrates its success in capturing Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, intelligence experts have turned their attention to the question of how much damage or embarrassment General Noriega can cause the United States in his new role as criminal defendant.

LEAD: Pressure mounted today from new and revived political parties, including the Liberals and the National Peasants Party, to postpone elections beyond the April date set by the provisional Government. Count Otto von Lambsdorff, head of West Germany's Free Democratic Party, said at a news conference here that in talks held with leaders of the new

LEAD: To the delight of traditionalists and the consternation of feminists, the first woman ever to be named chief spokeswoman for the Government of Japan was humbled today by one of the nation's most powerful remaining male strongholds, the world of sumo wrestling.

LEAD: The man identified by American officials as a top aide to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega appeared on Israeli television tonight to deny that he had served as security adviser to the fallen Panamanian dictator.
LEAD: A 49-year-old Suffolk County police officer with 20 years on the force was arrested today on charges of raping and sodomizing a girl, the authorities said.
LEAD: Orders for manufactured goods rose 2.4 percent in November, reaching their second-highest level ever, the Commerce Department said today.

LEAD: A former chemist for the Food and Drug Administration was sentenced today to 30 days in jail for taking $4,300 in bribes to influence the Government's approval of generic drugs. United States District Judge
LEAD: Peter Carlsen, a writer and editor who specialized in design and architecture, was found dead, apparently a suicide, on Dec. 26 at his home in Manhattan. He was 43 years old.

LEAD: If a defendant pleads not guilty to a felony charge, the New York State Constitution provides that he cannot be tried for that charge unless he is indicted by a grand jury. The idea is sound: No one should be accused, arrested or required to answer a felony charge at trial if there is no evidence to support the charge.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega today plotted strategy with defense lawyers amid questions about the future of the defense team itself.

LEAD: The Justice Department said today that it spent $224,000 on an attempt to identify the source of an unauthorized disclosure of a preliminary criminal investigation involving Representative William H. Gray 3d, Democrat of Pennsylvania.

LEAD: Robert Sivard, a painter and illustrator whose sprightly canvases range from urban street scenes to the lives of famous painters and literary figures, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Washington. He was 75 years old.
LEAD: The last of the Colorado Rockies left the Devils yesterday when Aaron Broten was traded to the Minnesota North Stars for Bob Brooke.

LEAD: George Balanchine, perhaps more than other choreographers, liked to revise his ballets over the decades. Two that he reworked, ''Danses Cocertantes'' and ''Tchaikovsky Suite No. 3,'' shared the New York City Ballet's program with Peter Martins's recent ''Barber Violin Concerto'' on Thursday night at the New York State

LEAD: Susan Eisenhower, granddaughter of the President who led the United States in the early years of the cold war, and Roald Z. Sagdeyev, a former leader of the Soviet space program, announced today that they will marry in Moscow next month.
LEAD: Hallmark Cards Inc. and Dakin Inc. said today that they had reached an agreement in principle for Hallmark to acquire Dakin, a leading marketer of plush stuffed toys, for an undisclosed amount.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Two researchers at the Elexis Corporation, a company in Miami that makes pulse monitors, have patented an electronic flea repelling device for household pets. The heart of the device, which is mounted on a pet's collar, is a transducer that sends out periodic ultrasonic pulses that do not bother a dog or cat but apparently are intolerable to fleas.

LEAD: New jobs were created at a markedly slower rate in December, but the nation's unemployment rate remained unchanged at 5.3 percent, completing a year of exceptional stability, the Labor Department reported today.

LEAD: When Michael Palin agreed to circle the world in the company of a small television crew from the BBC, he knew the result would be no more a learned travelogue than the Jules Verne novel that inspired the journey.

LEAD: The morning of Dec. 5, 12-year-old William Porter left his crowded railroad apartment on 132d Street in Harlem, walked down the dirty stairs, past the rotting sofa filled with garbage in the front of his building, and started off to school.
LEAD: Jospeh Crook Anderson, a retired Army colonel and former military attache, died of leukemia Monday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 75 years old.

LEAD: Most Treasury securities prices declined yesterday as the fixed-income market shrugged off the smaller-than-expected rise in employment that the Government reported for December. The bond market also paid little notice to the strong rise in December factory orders.

LEAD: The choreographer Michael Shawn will receive $175,000 from the producers of the 1988 musical ''Legs Diamond'' in an out-of-court settlement of a suit in which he charged that the producers had dismissed him because he had tested positive for the AIDS virus.

LEAD: Federated Department Stores, a subsidiary of the financially troubled Campeau Corporation, said yesterday that it had eliminated 52 positions in its Cincinnati headquarters, or about 14 percent of its already reduced corporate staff.
LEAD: The Maine Attorney General asked a state judge today to block on antitrust grounds the Georgia-Pacific Corporation's $3.8 billion hostile bid for the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation.
LEAD: For people looking for an alternative to raising horses and greyhound dogs, Robert L. Tottey of Ithaca, N.Y., has invented an ''escape-free rodent raceway.''
LEAD: Rumania's new leaders paid last respects today to Secretary of State Corneliu Bogdan, the first of their number to die since they took power two weeks ago.
LEAD: Turner Broadcasting System said Thursday that it had won its battle with the Bush Administration over providing its Cable News Network and a satellite receiving station to Vietnam.

LEAD: Aaron Pryor, the former world junior welterweight champion, said in a motion filed Thursday in Hamilton County Municipal Court in Cincinnati that he should receive treatment for drug dependency instead of a conviction for possession of drug items.

LEAD: On Wednesday, when Dipendra Bir Bikram Shah Dev, a young man of 18, rode a fine carriage from temple to temple to mark his coming of age as Crown Prince, a lot else was going on in this city transformed almost beyond recognition in less than a decade.
LEAD: At the age of 58, after making the playoffs 11 times as an assistant coach, Bud Carson will run his very own National Football League playoff team for the first time today.

LEAD: More than four months after they were forced to leave their homes, tenants of a Gramercy Park building that was coated with asbestos when a Consolidated Edison steam pipe exploded last summer can move back to their apartments beginning Jan. 15, the utility said yesterday.
LEAD: Terry Dehere of Seton Hall played his high school basketball at St. Anthony in Jersey City, just a few minutes from St. Peter's College.
LEAD: Carmen Hill, a former National League pitcher who compiled a 49-33 record in 10 major league seasons over 16 years, died on Monday in Indianapolis. He was 94 years old.

LEAD: This was an exceptionally rich week for patents on novelty inventions. From a spaghetti sipper to a new jump rope, patents were granted for simple devices offering a creative, often whimsical twist to things most people assume cannot be improved.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega arrived in Miami guarded by dozens of police sharpshooters and bodyguards, part of an extraordinary security blanket that continued today as camouflaged military helicopters crisscrossed city skies while his lawyers conferred with their client at a secret location.

LEAD: Since the National Football League season began four months ago, the Giants have added only eight players to their roster. On Saturday, the day before their first playoff game, they will probably add one and perhaps two or three.

LEAD: There is talk of creating a ''homeless czar.'' The position was mentioned to me by a well-connected Republican. He knows of my ambition to replace Dan Quayle on the ticket in 1992. ''Get yourself a czardom,'' he counseled. ''Like Bennett.''

LEAD: New York City's new Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, said yesterday that he would file a charge of incompetence against the principal of a Brooklyn high school whom he removed from office over her handling of two disturbances by the school's students.

LEAD: The Kyoto Measuring Instruments Corporation, based in Kyoto, Japan, has invented a retractable tape measure with a digital readout. The device is said to be easier to use and to read than the standard tool, in which measurements are marked on the tape itself.
LEAD: Elsie the Cow, meet Adam Smith.

LEAD: The medieval squares and coffee houses of this city have come alive again with politics. But the heady talk has been more about what may have been President Vaclav Havel's first mistake than about the crimes and abuses of the Communists.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In the dazzling sunlight filling a gilded hotel suite on Madison Avenue, Isabelle Adjani was recalling the bleak season two years ago when she went on French national television to prove that she was alive and well.

LEAD: The Christmas trees may be down and the decorations put away for another year, but the holiday season is not yet over. The Feast of the Epiphany, which for Western Christians marks the homage of the Three Kings, is celebrated tomorrow. And holiday themes continue to dominate the letters to The New York Times Neediest Cases

LEAD: Mayor David N. Dinkins, saying fiscal troubles may force trims in more city programs, told the heads of all city agencies yesterday to outline new spending cuts to help close a budget gap of up to $150 million for the rest of the fiscal year that ends June 30.

LEAD: Prospective buyers eventually encountered fewer delays today in telephone calls seeking to learn more about the thousands of single-family homes, apartments, office projects and other properties inherited by the Government from failed savings institutions and now being auctioned off.

LEAD: Mike Saunders, the Knicks' trainer the last 12 years, was hospitalized yesterday with multiple facial fractures and lacerations after his vehicle skidded on ice and struck a tree yesterday morning at the team's training center at the State University of New York campus in Purchase, team officials said.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Senator Dave Durenberger, who is already facing a Senate investigation of his financial dealings, today strongly denied new accusations of impropriety regarding the Government's reimbursement for his rental of a Minneapolis condiminum.

LEAD: A headline on Thursday about an art theft at an Italian villa misstated the ownership of the four paintings and one piece of furniture that were stolen. They belong to the villa's owner, Giuseppe Panza di Biumo, not to the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation.

LEAD: The papal envoy to Panama, the pivotal figure in 10 days of tense negotiations that ended in Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's surrender, insisted today that the general's departure from the Vatican mission resulted not from an ultimatum but from a precisely calibrated psychological campaign.

LEAD: Fighting between Liberian forces and rebels opposed to the West African country's leader, Gen. Samuel K. Doe, has devastated two towns in northeastern Liberia and sent thousands fleeing across the border, Western diplomats said today.

LEAD: Happy players at the end of a pairs contest often report that they had a ''big game,'' meaning that they did very well. But to deserve the title ''Big Game'' with capital letters, one needs a score of 75% or better, which is very rare.

LEAD: A convicted killer of two children was accused today of killing 11 women, most of them prostitutes, in a series of attacks that began here in March 1988, a year after his release from prison for the earlier slayings.

LEAD: Complaints that Poland's program of economic change is exacting too much pain are increasing, but the counry's Finance Minister insisted today that a severe economic program was the only way to reduce inflation and revive Poland's crumbling economy.
LEAD: Demand is growing for both used and new computers for the home and office, and an increasing number of purchases and sales are being made through computer brokerages.

LEAD: Richard Hoffman Wels, a lawyer who was influential in the reform of New York State's divorce laws, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 76 years old. Mr. Wels, an expert on family law, helped to modernize the state's matrimonial laws. For nearly 40 years, he was a leader of the New York State Bar Association and the American Bar

LEAD: The holiday travel rush is over, but passenger security precautions know no season. Here is some advice for travelers from Christopher Grose, president of Control Risks Limited, an international security consultant whose United States headquarters is in Bethesda, Md.

LEAD: The recent explosion in petroleum prices, especially diesel fuel, is raising transportation prices in a way not seen for a decade, economists and industry executives say. Airlines and trucking companies are imposing fuel surcharges or indexing their rates to fuel costs.

LEAD: Dick Steinberg yesterday conducted his second interview to select the next head coach of the Jets and left little doubt what he is looking for: a motivating, teaching leader who can bring the often-troubled team together.

LEAD: The National Collegiate Athletic Association will conduct an official investigation of the Clemson football program, the school said yesterday. A preliminary investigation uncovered 14 alleged rule violations, ranging from wrongful payments to illegal recruiting contacts, the school said.

LEAD: Asahi Breweries Ltd., the third-largest beer producer in Japan, said it plans to build a plant in the United States and produce its Super Dry beer, one of the company's largest exports. Asahi is planning to invest about 10 billion yen, or about $70 million at today's exchange rate, to build a plant near Denver in

LEAD: International 3-7 Strikes and protests in Bulgaria were held across the country by Slavic majority members opposed to religious and cultural freedom for ethnic Turks. Page 1 A Soviet Communist Party leader was forced to step down from his position as the head of a region on the border with Iran, which has been the site of disturbances and crowd violence.
LEAD: Ernest T. Brainard, who apparently was the nation's oldest active stockbroker, died on Wednesday as he was getting ready to go work. He was 99 years old and lived in West Hartford.

LEAD: N.B.A. Bird Injured in Loss to Clippers Ron Harper and Benoit Benjamin sparked a 16-2 fourth-quarter rally and the Los Angeles Clippers ended a 10-year losing streak at Boston Garden last night with a 114-105 victory over the Celtics, who played most of the game without Larry Bird. Bird sprained his left ankle with 42 seconds left in the first quarter and played just 19 minutes, 4 in the second half.

LEAD: The authorities in the northern state of Kashmir have imposed an indefinite curfew in Srinagar, the capital, and 10 other cities after militants seeking independence threatened to disrupt the region, Government officials said today.

LEAD: President Bush today left open the door for Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to try to arrange a reduction of the charges in his drug-trafficking case, but the President said he ''is not seeking a deal.''

LEAD: A spokesman for the New Jersey Attorney General's Office yesterday accused Exxon Corporation officials of ''stonewalling'' an investigation into the spill of at least 200,000 gallons of oil into the Arthur Kill.

LEAD: When Charles Stuart jumped off a bridge to his death in Boston Harbor Thursday, he apparently took with him the answers to one of the most bizarre murder mysteries in Boston's history. But his death is only the beginning of what is sure to be a period of soul-searching, even anger, in a city long torn by racial conflict.
LEAD: In a similar spirit, a Brooklyn inventor won a patent several weeks ago for what she called a ''chain bar.''

LEAD: There will not be any Greenwich mansions at Levittown prices in the Government's sale of 30,000 properties taken over from failed savings institutions. But a look yesterday at some of the 20 residential properties offered in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut showed housing for every pocketbook and life style and, maybe, a chance to save a few thousand dollars.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Two teen-agers who admitted beating a West Hartford man in 1988 because he was a homosexual have each been given one-year prison sentences. Superior Court Judge Raymond R. Norko sentenced Lawrence Brush, 19, and James M. O'Brien, 17, on Thursday. Two other teen-agers involved in the West Hartford beating, Sean G.

LEAD: Federal District Judge Stanley Sporkin took charge of the questioning of Charles H. Keating Jr. today, and in almost five hours of intense inquiries the judge voiced deep concerns about accounting methods used by the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association and its parent, the American Continental Corporation.

LEAD: Score one for Mayor David Dinkins. In his first days in office he announced that he had delayed hiring the next class of New York City police recruits. The gesture, though blunt, was brave and important. Nobody wants fewer police officers. But neither does anyone want the city to stumble back into fiscal trouble.

LEAD: Another fad is taking hold in the business of keeping warm: ceramic electric heaters. Like the portable kerosene burners and quartz electric heaters that preceded them, ceramic heaters have a few advantages over older models. But they are also the subject of advertising and sales promotions that sometimes promise too much.

LEAD: A vicious round of finger-pointing began here today as prosecutors, the police and the news media began tracing the trail of faulty assumptions, disregarded suspicions, blunders and perhaps even lies that put the wrong man at the center of one of the most highly publicized and emotion-charged murder cases in the city's history.

LEAD: Kenneth Osborne has known grave disappointment. When he was 19 years old and a carefree college football player, his spine was severed in a car crash, leaving him paralyzed from the chest down. It was hell to adjust. But he did. ''That took some serious time,'' Mr. Osborne said.
LEAD: Baseball

LEAD: These days, almost all American-made nylon carpets offer some sort of stain protection, which makes it easier than ever to remove spots. So, parties that chase the post-holiday blahs need no longer leave permanent reminders.
LEAD: A crippled Iranian tanker that spilled 19 million gallons of oil off the Moroccan coast was turned away today by Portugal, the third nation to deny the ship entry.

LEAD: The pilots of a Northwest Airlines jetliner who flew for nearly 25 minutes on Thursday unaware that one of the plane's three engines had sheared off and plummeted 35,000 feet would have had no way of knowing what had happened, aviation experts said yesterday.
LEAD: Bruce Jay Heim, an investment banker, died of complications of AIDS on Thursday at his home in Bernardsville, N.J. He was 37 years old.

LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 9.83 percent, up from 9.78 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.35 percent this week, down from 8.39 percent the week before.

LEAD: A collapse of Government regulation of the oil tanker industry created conditions that led to the Alaska oil spill, a panel of scientists and oil industry experts concluded in a report released today by the state of Alaska.

LEAD: A plea of not guilty was entered in Port Crane, N.Y., late Thursday for William Reedy, the Detroit bar owner who is accused of driving while intoxicated in the accident that killed Billy Martin of the Yankees on Christmas Day. Town Justice P. Murray Benjamin also granted a request by Gerald Mollen, the Broome County District Attorney, for a 60-day adjournment to present findings to a grand jury.
LEAD: Since Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega turned himself over to U.S. authorities this week to face drug trafficking charges, two contradictory predictions have been made about his trial.
LEAD: The nation's savings institutions lost $6.4 billion in deposits in October, rather than the $5.6 billion in outflows originally reported, the Office of Thrift Supervision said today.

LEAD: Arlene Dinnerstein Friehling, a former owner of the Stevensville Country Club, a resort hotel in Swan Lake, N.Y., died of cancer on Wednesday at the Community General Hospital in Harris, N.Y. She was 59 years old and lived in Liberty, N.Y.

LEAD: President Bush complained yesterday that by juxtaposing pictures of him in a jocular mood during a news conference last month and the arrival of the bodies of American soldiers killed in Panama, some television news organizations had made him appear insensitive to the deaths.

LEAD: * American Magnetics Corp., Los Angeles, said it would consider inquiries from various groups, including one organized by members of senior management, regarding the purchase of the company's card-reader and access control businesses.

LEAD: When King Herod ruled Judea, Jewish sages said of its capital, ''Whoever has not seen Jerusalem in its splendor has never seen a fine city.'' In fact the splendor of Jerusalem changed dramatically during the centuries under the influence of several major religions. Today visitors can trace the city's history in a new museum actually woven into the ruins of its most ancient fortress.

LEAD: THE PHOTOGRAPH ABOVE, TAKen in Bucharest before the overthrow of the Rumanian Government, illustrates a work in progress that will now likely never be completed. LEAD: EVERYONE knows that education is broadening, stimulating, the key to a better job and expensive. Now add ''habit-forming'' to the list.
LEAD: GOV. THOMAS H. KEAN became New Jersey's most familiar chief executive during his eight years in office.

LEAD: CRYSTALS, PSYCHIC READINGS, NEW-age music, organic food, holistic medicine - aromatherapy fits right in with all those ideas that are passing from the counterculture to the trendy. Welcome back, Age of Aquarius.
LEAD: THE BOOK OF MAMIE By Duff Brenna. 338 pp. Iowa City: University of Iowa Press. $22.50.

LEAD: The Harwin Corporation, a Manhattan development company that has been involved in many residential renovations, has gone into a joint-venture partnership with the Ziegelman Organization, which has concentrated on larger residential conversions, to upgrade five central Harlem apartment houses with 242 rental units and eventually convert them into condominiums or cooperatives
LEAD: To the Editor: Why does Los Angeles International Airport allow religious groups and charities to bother passengers in the terminals?
LEAD: ADVANCE, RETREAT Selected Short Stories. By Richard Rive. Illustrated by Cecil Skotnes. 121 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $16.95.
LEAD: THE HIGHEST ALTAR The Story of Human Sacrifice. By Patrick Tierney. Illustrated. 480 pp. New York: Viking. $22.50.

LEAD: Regarding the Dec. 10 article ''Effort to Display Menorah on Town Green Finally Succeeds,'' it is unfortunate that the Teaneck Town Council has decided to follow the United States Supreme Court's lead in Allegheny County v. Greater Pittsburgh A.C.L.U. and now allows a menorah on the municipal green.
LEAD: The Browns and the Buffalo Bills, Great Lakes teams that thrive in cold weather favoring the run, shocked each other today by creating aerial havoc.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Martin P. Dillon of Merrick, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter Eleanor Ann Dillon to Daniel Petigrow, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Petigrow of Stony Brook, L.I. A November wedding is planned. Miss Dillon, 24 years old, graduated from Cornell University and is an account executive at Burson-Marsteller, a public relations company in New York.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Borden Iler of Middletown, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joan Elizabeth Iler, to Christopher Stuart Burdge, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Burdge of Shelter Island, L.I., and Boca Grande, Fla. A September wedding is planned.
LEAD: James W. Farrands, the first northerner in 120 years to be elected Imperial Wizard of the Ku Klux Klan, plans to move to North Carolina, where, he said, the people are ''more genteel.''

LEAD: Working on an indictment of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega that draws heavily on the testimony of convicted drug traffickers, Federal prosecutors are scrambling to make deals with co-defendants and searching for new witnesses and documentation to fortify a case that involves not only individual guilt or innocence but also the Bush Administration's political influence.

LEAD: For This Week: Discard the old catalogues as the new ones arrive. If the seed lists of plant societies have arrived, do not hesitate to check them over and mail orders promptly. Start to plan next year's garden. Be sure gift plants are kept out of drafts and cool; too much sunlight and overwatering will shorten their lasting time.
LEAD: At the Westview Country Club in Miami, Nancy Beth Raffel was married last evening to Mark Russell Osherow. Rabbi David Sandmel, the bride's brother-in-law, officiated.

LEAD: AN experimental program intended to encourage welfare recipients who head single-parent families to obtain counseling, job training and employment has proved more successful than had originally been anticipated, state officials say. As a result, plans are now being made to expand the program beyond the six New
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: David N. Dinkins has shown himself to have, among other things, a keen eye for sartorial elegance. So it was only fitting that the 8,000 or so invited guests who watched while New York City's new Mayor was sworn in last Monday comprised a most stylish group. Luxurious fur coats were in abundance, as were cloth coats with rakishly turned-up collars.

LEAD: A CATHEDRAL could be built with all the books written on prayer - how to do it, why to do it, when and where to do it, its glories and its dangers. In mid-December, the Vatican added to this library. With papal approval, the watchdog Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith issued a 7,000-word warning to Catholics on the pitfalls of meditation derived from

LEAD: If there ever was any doubt that George Steinbrenner is the biggest spender in baseball, doubt it no longer. The Yankees' owner spent so much more money on players in the 1980's than anyone else that the Players Association should erect a monument to him at Yankee Stadium in the form of a giant, 24-carat gold dollar sign.
LEAD: THE major automobile companies can easily reduce the cost of their cars by simply removing all directional signals. No one uses them anyway.

LEAD: Martin Heidegger's centenary year has come and gone, and just as well. It came at a bad time. In Berkeley, New Haven, Moscow, Chicago, Paris and Marburg (and other places besides), conferences and parties have been celebrating the philosopher's birth. Two or three years ago, when these jamborees were planned, it was still possible for most people to write off Heidegger's flirtation with Nazism as merely that - a foolish minor entanglement, which Hannah Arendt, who was briefly his lover, could generously attribute ''partly to the delusion of genius, partly to desperation.

LEAD: MANY of the county's aging schools are currently involved in ambitious renovations. After years of deferred maintenance and austerity budgets, county school districts are confronting leaky roofs, sinking foundations and cranky boilers.

LEAD: The Bush Administration's plan to step up military involvement in the war on drugs in Latin America was dealt a setback this week when Colombia balked at a crucial element, the stationing of United States vessels off its coast, Administration officials say.

LEAD: SUPPOSE a house-hunting couple wants to make a bid on a house. They aren't sure how much under the asking price to offer, so they ask the broker. The broker says, ''Well, the house has been on the market for six months, you saw how old the furnace is, so why don't you try this number?''

LEAD: Greg Woodard scored a career-high 27 points tonight as Villanova took advantage of another poor shooting night by Syracuse and sent the Orangemen to their first loss of the season, 93-74. The loss ended Syracuse's home winning streak at 15.

LEAD: Caroline Livingston Neville and James Raymond Freney were married yesterday at St. Edward Roman Catholic Church in Palm Beach, Fla. Msgr. Gerald A. Hughes performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Marilyn Horne will be the guest soloist in a benefit concert by the New York City Gay Men's Chorus, March 1 at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall. Proceeds from the event will benefit the chorus's AIDS Outreach Fund, which makes donations to organizations that help people with AIDS. The mezzo-soprano will sing Brahms's ''Alto Rhapsody'' and excerpts from ''L'Italiana in Algeri'' and ''Tancredi,'' both by Rossini.

LEAD: The traditional conference-to-bowl alliances should be preserved. When bowl bids to the five major New Year's Day games are extended, also designate the four games that will then be the quarterfinals of the playoffs. The winners of these games would meet in two semifinal games, and the winners of those would meet in the title game.

LEAD: THE ATMOSPHERE IN CAROLJU Gilligan's office at the Harvard Graduate School of Education could hardly be less like my own days as a Harvard graduate student - those seminars mired in torpor from which students were periodically roused by revivifying jolts of pedagogical bad temper. Professor Gilligan's faculty and student colleagues at the Project on the Psychology of Women and the Development of Girls seem relaxed and almost unaccountably buoyant as they gather around the conference table on a rainy Cambridge morning to describe their current work.

LEAD: Congeleur, who has spent much of the last two winters running second to King's Swan and Its Acedemic in stakes races, finally turned the tables on those two yesterday and narrowly won the $86,700 Aqueduct Handicap.

LEAD: THREE years ago, Beveridge Webster, a world-famous pianist, and Herbert Baumel, a violinist whose career spans symphony orchestras and Broadway musicals, started to make music together.
LEAD: Besides increased television coverage, one reason for auto racing's current state of vigor worldwide is the extent of participation by major automakers.

LEAD: INVISIBLE MATTER AND THE FATE OF THE UNIVERSE. By Barry Parker. (Plenum, $23.50.) Barry Parker explores what may be the ultimate mystery in ''Invisible Matter and the Fate of the Universe,'' combining history, astronomy, cosmology and physics. Mr. Parker, a professor of physics and astronomy at Idaho State University, traces a line of research from the first faint questions about our own galaxy's missing mass in 1932 to those questions' growth into a major concern for thousands of astronomers worldwide.

LEAD: As a dental hygienist with almost 30 years of experience dealing with both patients and my D.D.S. colleagues, I have often dealt with the senses of humor of both. Dentists lose hands down when it comes to laughing at themselves, as demonstrated by the anguished letters of protest over Barbara Klaus's column of Dec.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Ellen Neuwald Sherman, a literary agent, died of lung cancer Tuesday at her home in Laguna Hills, Calif. She was 74 years old.

LEAD: WHEN 10-year-old Amanda Bagatta of Smithtown was wheeled into the operating room for surgery to remove her tonsils and adenoids, her father went along with her, holding her hand along the way. And he stayed in the operating room until the anesthetic had taken effect.
LEAD: A three-week confrontation over a pay increase ordered by a Government tribunal has closed the New Delhi edition of The Indian Express, the country's most outspoken newspaper chain.

LEAD: Q. I have read about the problem that some people have with condensation forming between the two panes of glass in double-pane windows, but my problem is different. My apartment has windows of this type, but with a metal frame. When outside temperatures drop below freezing, condensation forms on the metal and then freezes to form a coat of ice on the inside.

LEAD: The former Brooklyn Dodger catcher Roy Campanella was listed in serious condition yesterday at the Northridge (Calif.) Hospital, where he was being treated for pneumonia, which developed after he was admitted to the hospital on Dec. 30 suffering from a cold.

LEAD: IT is a land of vast and ancient temples, of spices and brightly dyed cloth, a land whose wealth was once proverbial. Today, Madras and its state, Tamil Nadu, retain the visible marks and the continued tradition of India's Dravidian-speaking peoples, whose Hindu culture preceded all the many foreign invasions.

LEAD: To the Editor: Recently returned from France where we spent a night in Deauville, at the Royal. Had been delighted to see your article on Deauville (Travel, July 23) shortly before we left. Armed with the article, my companion and I headed for the Bar du Soleil for dinner to discover that it is only open for lunch.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: MORE than 7 in 10 public-school teachers in the United States are women. Moreover, male teachers seem to cluster in specific parts of the country - in the North, for example, which has more male teachers than the South. Oregon, Minnesota, Washington State, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin have teaching forces that are about 38 percent male.

LEAD: SINGLE-HANDLE kitchen and bathroom faucets often feature replaceable cartridge valves. Signs that a cartridge faucet needs repair are water dripping from the spout, difficulty in adjusting the water temperature, hot water entering cold water outlets like toilet supply lines and inadequately heated water at some faucets.
LEAD: THE slogan on the recruiting posters has a definite savor. ''The Law on the Sea,'' it says. There are flags flapping in the background and the tall bow of a cutter slicing the waves.

LEAD: IF the wind-chill factor is minus 7 degrees and it's Sunday, we must be inspecting the campus of the University of Massachusetts in Amherst. I am a few years out of practice in looking at campuses, but it all came back recently when I made a round of New England colleges with a high school senior to test a new travel offering: college tours conducted by a Long Island company that takes a van or bus of young people between Friday afternoon and Sunday evening, providing driver, hotel rooms, chaperones, meals and transportation for $315 a person.

LEAD: The head of East Germany's Communist Party proposed today that all NATO and Warsaw Pact forces quit both Germanys within a decade, adding spice to an already bitter political struggle shaping in East Germany.
LEAD: Shifting tactics from bombing and killing, Colombia's cocaine traffickers have kidnapped about 20 members of wealthy families in recent days, the police say.
LEAD: Classical

LEAD: A front-page contents listing in the Travel section today omits the page number in some copies for an article about French housewares and carries an incorrect number for an article about events in Boston. The housewares article appears on page 6, the Boston report on page 10.
LEAD: BROOKLYN BOY By Alan Lelchuk. 298 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Publishing Company. $19.95.

LEAD: The sheriff's department in Tulsa, Okla., has a ski boat that once belonged to a drug dealer and is now used to dredge the lake for evidence. The police in San Diego own two helicopters, taken in a drug raid, that they need but could not otherwise have afforded.
LEAD: The Islanders, who have been beating almost everyone else for the last five weeks, finally beat Quebec tonight.

LEAD: College presidents and athletic directors gathering today in Dallas for the 84th National Collegiate Athletic Association convention will once again wrestle with the excesses of big-time basketball and football.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: On Sunday, Dec. 17, President Nicolae Ceausescu summoned top party officials across the country and, on closed-circuit television, issued orders to kill.

LEAD: WANT to keep track of your cows? Festoon your sleigh or your mantel? Summon the butler to bring some tea or call your guests to the barbecue? For these and other tasks, Bevin Brothers has the bell for you.
LEAD: Every time the young welder from Haiti called a factory or a restaurant about a job he'd seen advertised, he was told it was already filled.

LEAD: The last time the Giants were in the playoffs was three years ago, when they finished with a 14-2 record and went on to win Super Bowl XXI. Compared with the current Giants, the 1986 version was older, more experienced and more sophisticated.

LEAD: The success of the College Preview Tour depends on the individual tour leader at each university. The tour guide at Tufts was so enthusiastic about his school that he made me wonder why I had not previously considered it. However, the guide at UConn gave the distinct impression that four years there could the worst four years of your life.

LEAD: Ron Brown has his work cut out for him in trying to implement a successful ''coordinated campaign'' for the Democrats (''Ron Brown's Party Line,'' by Robert Kuttner, Dec. 3). Here in Massachusetts, our state party is a disaster, lacking the money, skill and resources to provide effective campaign services for Bay State Democratic candidates.

LEAD: Leslie Jean Hoffman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Hoffman of Trumbull, Conn., was married last evening at Temple Israel in Great Neck, L.I., to Dr. Jonathan Drew Altus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Altus of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Eric A. Silver performed the cermony, assisted by Cantor Zion
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: SCHRODINGER Life and Thought. By Walter Moore. Illustrated. 513 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. $39.50.

LEAD: The relevance that the past always holds for the present comes into focus in an unusual way this week. On Friday evening at 9, the Joffrey Ballet's acclaimed reconstruction of Vaslav Nijinsky's 1913 choreography for ''Le Sacre du Printemps'' will be televised for the first time, as part of the Dance in America/Great Performances series on the Public Broadcasting Service.

LEAD: TURRETED Victorian, sand-colored adobe or period French, the traveler's choice of accommodations in California's Sonoma County is as varied as its scenery. Whether you want the anonymity and professional service of a large hotel or the intimacy and do-it-yourself approach of a bed and breakfast, there are lodgings to suit your preference.

LEAD: Patti McCarthy returned home to Gramercy Park yesterday for the first time since she and others were forced out by a steam-pipe explosion last summer and found an elderly neighbor sobbing in the lobby, heartbroken by the condition of her apartment. So Miss McCarthy asked another neighbor to go with her into her own apartment for support.

LEAD: IT has always been one of the most striking buildings on Madison Avenue - an ancient limestone facade over a newer but still elegant iron storefront below. Now the 1893 Christian Herter house at 819 Madison, at 68th Street, is in the middle of a renovation - at least of its 1933 storefront - and the results should be available for inspection this spring.

LEAD: As the Denver Broncos head into the playoffs and take aim on a possible third Super Bowl appearance in the last four years, Coach Dan Reeves can take comfort in a rock-solid defense and productive running game, elements that generally win championships. But he is not a satisfied coach. Reeves is feeling obvious discomfort about his team's flaccid finish during the regular season.

LEAD: David I. Farber of Port Washington, L.I., received a $100 birthday gift. As he explained it in a letter to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, ''I got it for my ninth birthday. From my aunt. It was originally for college, but I changed my mind. I thought that I should give my money to charity more than college.

Socolow of Chappaqua, N.Y., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lief of New York and Weston, Conn. An April wedding is planned. Miss Lief, 28 years old and a graduate of the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University, is a television producer at A.

LEAD: Through the writings of Kahn, Angell and Giamatti, the dynamics of baseball have been elevated to the stuff of pure poetry (''Joe Montana: State of the Art,'' by Irvin Muchnick, Dec. 17). Conversely, I have always believed a bias existed against football as fodder for good journalism and literature.

LEAD: When white American artists looked at black Americans, what did they see? Stereotypes, like banjo players, watermelon eaters, slaves and idlers? Or dignity and purpose? All of the above, as evidenced by a and idlers? Or dignity and purpose? All of the above, as evidenced by a complex new show, ''Facing History: The Black Image in American Art, 1710-1940,'' to open at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington on Saturday.

LEAD: SCIENCE IS BORING, and scientists are just this side of crazy. At least that is what children think, according to Rebecca L. Lubetkin, executive director of the Consortium for Educational Equity at Rutgers University, which provides training and assistance to educators.

LEAD: There are department stores that make shopping a pleasure. One is Nordstrom, a Seattle-based family-owned store that is coming to the Northeast. Another is Swezey's, a Long Island family-owned store with locations in Patchogue, Riverhead and Setauket.

LEAD: Susan Jane Klein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Klein of North Bellmore, L.I., and Dr. Kenneth Jay Cohen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Cohen of Brooklyn and Sag Harbor, L.I., plan to marry in February. Miss Klein, 26 years old, is a doctoral candidate in clinical psychology at St. John's University.

LEAD: The awful and wonderful events in Rumania over the past three weeks bring to mind a forgotten mini-collection that dates back to the days just after World War II. The wreckage that was Rumania had just come under Soviet Communist domination, when Rumanian stamps became the subject of an obscure decree.
LEAD: LAST January, Donald Fulcher and his wife, Susan, year-round residents on Cape Cod, put their modest two-bedroom, one-bath house in South Yarmouth on the market for $119,000. Nothing happened.

LEAD: The idea of filling bowls of different sizes with varying amounts of water so that each bowl produces a different pitch when struck, is both basic and ancient. It is also fairly universal: makeshift instruments of this sort have appeared in many cultures, although few serious traditions of performance on such instruments have come down through the centuries.
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Dec. 24 about the preparations for the Panama invasion misidentified an American killed in the operation. He was Pfc. Roy Dennis Brown Jr.

LEAD: If the cold war is truly over, isn't it time to bring its mysteries in from the cold? Eastern Europe's new governments have a rare chance to serve both justice and history by unlocking the secret archives of their former Communist masters. When tyrannies collapse so suddenly, there's little time to shred papers.

LEAD: Friday night's performance by the New York City Ballet featured the season's first view of ''Afternoon of a Faun'' and ''Antique Epigraphs,'' two ballets by Jerome Robbins to Debussy, and a surprise, a modified version of Peter Martins's ''Echo.''

LEAD: When Yolanda Mendolia saw the dizzying ascent of prices that began before the holidays, and how low her husband's salary was by comparison, she decided her only choice was ''to put myself in the hands of God.''

LEAD: LIKE highway-fatality statistics, the numbers coming out of the National Science Foundation have lost their ability to shock. But for those who can still bear to look, there is blood on the floor: In a recent science test taken by high school seniors in 14 countries, American students ranked 14th.

LEAD: IN AN UNLIT PARKING LOT, JUST OFF the road leading north out of Munich, the prostitutes are in their jeeps. It's about 10 P.M., and there are maybe two dozen vehicles in the lot, some of them dark, with curtains drawn around the side and back windows. In the others, the cab lights are on so the men who are walking or cruising by in their own cars can get a good look at the girls inside.

But even accepting this as a given does not mean that nice gestures should go by the wayside. For the fact is that the most meaningful of gestures cost nothing but a second or two of thought.

LEAD: Women in the armed forces continue to be barred from direct combat roles, but that does not mean they are not prepared for the day that policy changes. There was praise all around last weekrr as word spread that during the invasion of Panama, Capt. Linda L. Bray became the first woman to command American troops in combat.

LEAD: How wonderful it was to see former President Jimmy Carter's portrait on the cover of The New York Times Magazine (''Carter Redux,'' by Wayne King, Dec. 10). As a Democrat, I am thrilled to find the true Jimmy Carter rediscovered. I only hope my party also will recognize the contributions he made.

LEAD: Back in the late 1960's, most people saw nothing more than cattle and horses rambling over the rolling prairie northwest of Dallas. Ben Carpenter saw the community of the future. So, in 1969, he set about building it.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH curry usually brings to mind Indian food or dishes flavored with a premixed packaged spice blend, the term is actually an umbrella for a variety of preparations. They do have in common a collection of spices, notably turmeric, cumin, coriander, ginger and pepper. These are the main components, but the list can be expanded with many others.

Schuker, an educator who in a 44-year career in the New York City public school system built a reputation as an iron-willed administrator and an outspoken proponent of the merit system for hiring teachers, died of heart failure Friday at his home in Forest Hills, Queens. He was 84 years old and also had a home in Boca Raton,

LEAD: March wedding plans for Jane Margaret Mintzer and David Louis Hoffman have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Steven A. Mintzer of West Islip, L.I. Mr. Hoffman is a son of Dr. and Mrs. William A. Hoffman of Westport, Conn.

LEAD: There are 16 bowls in which ranked college teams play each other. Why not have the top 32 teams (based on average ranking between the polls of the writers, the coaches, and the New York Times computer) play each other, with No. 32 playing No. 31 and so on down the line?
LEAD: In many ways, it is the same place but with different names: Devil's Island, the Gulag - any of history's most nightmarish penal colonies. In Panama, they call it Coiba.

LEAD: Department stores are in trouble these days. Several are singing the bankruptcy blues, while economists and accountants look for answers in their charts. But if they really want to know the cause, they need only try a shopping trip or two.
LEAD: A dispute between Illinois and Kentucky over a stretch of the Ohio River has lawyers researching sand, riverboats and fishing licenses.

LEAD: I was sorry to read about your card anxiety, Elex Ingersoll (Opinion, Dec. 17), since I anticipate this seasonal occupation. It is such fun! Usually, I write notes along with the card, as well as receive a few from numerous friends and relatives who incidentally, have escaped me in these mobile times.

LEAD: NOT all the animals in the ''Animal Show'' are recognizable, some being fragmentary, others outright inventions. They cluster close, nonetheless, as if to keep the human world at bay. The small display, on view at the Mattatuck Museum in Waterbury, consists of works by Reuben Nakian as well as by Eddie Oates, Karen Rossi, Gil Scullion and Peter Woytuk, Connecticut sculptors to a man and woman.

Miss Wysoki, 23 years old, is an assistant account executive at the Hill & Knowlton public-relations concern in New York.

LEAD: IN housing, New York City has changed horses in midstream. Mayor David N. Dinkins has come into office at about the halfway mark of the expensive, long-term municipal housing program begun by former Mayor Edward I. Koch in 1985.

LEAD: A healthy farm economy for New York State this year and the rest of the 1990's was forecast this week by agricultural experts at Cornell University in Ithaca and the State Department of Agriculture and Markets here.

LEAD: THE University of Chicago Graduate School of Business has long been known for producing captains of industry, not leaders of humanity. Now the school is trying to redress the imbalance, using a new Leadership Education And Development program as the counterweight.

LEAD: THE CHORUS of alarms over the deterioration of science education in American colleges has reached a crescendo. LEAD: The turmoil of the last decade has slightly reshuffled the silver industry. At least one company, Towle, is in dire straits. One of the fine old names in silver, dating back to the late 1600's, the company in September filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy laws - again.

LEAD: As political developments seem to bring surprises every day in the Soviet Union, a surprising torrent of music from that country has been pouring our way on recordings. Some of it, by Soviet artists, is attributable to a confusing tangle of international distribution agreements that followed the recent split-up of the Soviet Melodiya label and Mezhdunarodnaya Kniga, the Soviet export company that formerly handled the label and still owns several hundred titles from the Melodiya catalogue.

LEAD: Photographers equipped with SLRs and interchangeable lenses may have been tempted lately by ads trumpeting a new breed of lenses. These lenses promise outstanding color rendition, contrast and resolution. The only missing attraction is an outstandingly inexpensive price. But before you leap, you should understand what makes these chunks of glass so marvelous and so costly.

LEAD: EASTER ISLAND: The Mystery Solved. By Thor Heyerdahl. (Random House, $24.95.) The explorer Thor Heyerdahl argues in ''Easter Island,'' as he has in such books as ''Kon-Tiki,'' that ancient peoples were more developed and mobile than modern thinking gives them credit for. Easter Island, off South America in the Pacific Ocean, has long been a subject of scientific speculation for its large stone statues, its cultural history, its language and even its plant life, all of which are distinct from those of its island neighbors.

LEAD: AT Aunt Ruth's house there is always candy. And every child who visits there eats tons of it. Aunt Ruth believes children need candy. Their mother believes they need fruit. LEAD: Hampton Inns of Memphis is building a 154-room hotel near Newark International Airport, the 14th to serve the terminal's immediate area. The $5 million facility on Route 1-9 in Elizabeth, N.J., facing an entrance to the airport, is expected to be finished in about a year. Airport officials attributed part of a major increase in hotel business around the terminal to the growing practice among business executives of flying in, attending meetings overnight in conference rooms and returning home the next day.

LEAD: DESPITE the bargain-basement image and second-rate reputation of the community college - the ''K Mart of Education'' is what some people call it - its inner life is often rich and complex. In one row there may be a middle-aged professional actor, an ex-marine who studies Amish philosophy, a wife and husband who separated during the term, a young day-care worker who hugs abused children every day, a French emigrant and an intelligence officer who says he was left to die in an outpost in Vietnam because he refused to perform illegal activities.

LEAD: Tastes change; the immutable verities of today seem dated and clumsy tomorrow. And often, a shift in one seemingly small area of taste reveals itself to be linked with larger changes in our cultural preferences.

LEAD: The Sudanese Government has unleashed Arab militiamen against African tribesmen, killing between 300 and 1,500 African villagers in one attack and many others in a series of raids, reports from Western officials in Khartoum say.

LEAD: LIKE the Chimera of Greek mythology, multimedia - a combination of techniques, hardware, software and applications - is a fabulous creature comprising elements of several familiar beasts. It encompasses computers, television, textbooks, libraries, overhead projectors and blackboards. As electronic technology makes multimedia more sophisticated, it has become - depending on whom you ask - either the most revolutionary educational technology since the textbook, or a marketing buzzword concocted by computer makers to sell more machines.

LEAD: Hailing the Rumanian revolution that ousted President Nicolae Ceausescu, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union said today that he found the new atmosphere here ''absolutely purifying'' and pledged Moscow's support for any political system Rumanians chose.

LEAD: What do some college students under age 21 do when they want a drink and the legal drinking age is 21? They may find a bar that does not force the issue, or, failing that, find false identification.

LEAD: Perhaps no dinners have ever sparkled as brilliantly as the annual Waterloo banquets held by the first Duke of Wellington at Apsley House, on the anniversary of the battle. Not only were there 69 candles burning in various silver-gilt candelabra down the center of the table - surrounded by formations of silver dancing nymphs - but the whole extravaganza, known as the Portuguese service, was set off on the gleaming surface of a silver-gilt plateau 26 feet long.

LEAD: NEARLY three quarters of a century ago, as their state emerged from its rambunctious frontier days when money and water equaled power, Californians imposed strict new rules of government under the idealistic Progressive Party Governor, Hiram Johnson. Provisions were made for the recall of elected officials, for lawmaking by public initiative and for nonpartisan local elections - measures emulated elsewhere and credited with having kept state politics comparatively honest.

LEAD: There is a fragility inherent in the symbolism of every great street in New York: Broadway stands for a theater that is perpetually in crisis, Wall Street for financial empires that seem ever ready to decamp to New Jersey, and Fifth Avenue, perhaps the most celebrated of them all, for a luxury and a style that once seemed unique to New York, but now feels more and more like what can be found in every medium-sized city and shopping mall from here to La Jolla.

LEAD: Dwight Gooden, who came out of the 1980's with a sore right shoulder and lingering memories of his ordeal with drugs, reports that he is entering the 1990's with no qualms, no fears and no demons and says, ''I couldn't be more upbeat.''

LEAD: Boston in the wintertime has a nasty reputation. The snow flies, the slush forms and the wind howls on a daily basis. But the city is small and easy to negotiate, and the crowds are thin. LEAD: The article ''Riverhead May Lose $300,000 Grant'' (Dec. 10) states incorrectly that I, Harold Smith, am the owner of the 1881 Vail-Leavitt Music Hall. LEAD: With every snowfall, New York City's parks are taken over by an army of sledders who swarm the hills, large and small. It is one of the less-heralded pleasures of city life; when snow crunches under the blades of your Flexible Flyer, the hustle and bustle of New York can seem very far away.

LEAD: Time was when the managers of the Janus Capital mutual fund group paid scant attention to their customers. Cash-flow multiples and moving averages concerned them far more. But faced with persistent redemptions, Janus concluded in 1987 that performance alone wasn't enough. The marketing specialists came in, the advertising budget went up, and in 1989 the company's accounts doubled.

LEAD: AN unexpected byproduct of the weaker real estate market has been the return of the Veterans Administration mortgage as a popular financing tool, one that developers and sellers appear keener to honor than in the mid-80's, when sales were booming and any loan subject to possible bureaucratic delay was scorned.
