LEAD: The illusion of the perfect couple, secure in their jobs and striving for the next rung on the social ladder, persists here, despite the grotesque turn the story of Carol and Charles Stuart took this week.

LEAD: MARK GRAMPP loves old drive-in movie theaters. Steven Hirschberg admires the Pride Cleaners building in Danbury and the Carvel stand on the Darien-Norwalk border. Philip Langdon wrote a book about chain restaurant buildings and is also fond of gas stations. Stuart Sachs goes for gaudy commercial strips.
LEAD: ENGLISH COMEDY

LEAD: WHAT is regional theater in New Jersey all about? Look at the programs, promotional brochures and newsletters of the state's major playhouses and you'll come upon lofty phrases about cherishing life and affirming the spirits.

LEAD: Every business depends on forecasting, whether its executives know it or not. How many new franchise stores should we open in 1990? Will we have enough cash on hand in November to pay expenses? Will our current staff be adequate to meet manufacturing demand in 1992? When do we need to reorder widgets?

LEAD: With consumer demand for silver sinking, silversmiths in the 80's started to cast about for other products that could benefit from their venerable names. To survive, several began to import and market stainless steel and to move into other tabletop products like crystal and china to fill out their lines and make their accounts more attractive to department store retailers.

LEAD: TO THE AVERAGE American high school student, science education is often a lesson in boredom. There are hundreds of technical terms to memorize, outdated books to plow through and teachers who drone on and on.
LEAD: LAST JULY, two months before fall semester began, William Glavin toured Babson College, in Wellesley, Mass. He went into every dorm room, every classroom. He checked the sports fields and gyms.

LEAD: HUNTINGTON'S Petite Gourmet restaurant knows what it is about. Its priorities are straight. A few years ago, this diminutive storefront was a fancy-food shop selling coffee beans, croissants and cheese while dishing up lunches for weary shoppers.

LEAD: The woman who resigned as director of the Corcoran Gallery of Art last month after a six-month dispute over her decision to cancel an exhibit of Robert Mapplethorpe photographs has been named director of the Norton Gallery and School of Arts in Palm Beach, Fla.

LEAD: We get the impression from the letters ['Dentists Fail to Smile in Response to ''Smile, Darn You, Smile,'' ' Dec. 24] that Barbara Klaus's article about dentists hit a nerve. Apparently there has been considerable erosion of the funny bone. Come, gentlemen, you must allow us our gibes as you laugh all the way to the bank.

LEAD: VERMONT earned the most from public college and university tuition for the 1988-89 academic year, collecting an average of almost $5,500 per student. A large number of students at Vermont's public colleges are from another state and therefore pay the higher nonresident tuition. California charged the lowest average tuition - about $500 per year.

LEAD: A report on Dec. 10 about the marriage of Zerlina Stall and Dr. Edward J. Kaplan included outdated information on the officiating clergy. Rabbi Charles M. Feinberg performed the ceremony alone; Rabbi Erwin Zimet had become ill and has since died.

LEAD: In a signal of Japan's eagerness to take part in the emerging new order in Europe, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu plans next week to announce a package of more than $1 billion in loans and guarantees for Poland and Hungary, Japanese officials said today.

LEAD: How much longer must New York City elections remain hobbled by outmoded manual voting machines prone to breakdowns? The decrepit booths should have been replaced years ago. Yet an indifferent Board of Elections still dawdles over the choice of a vendor for modern voting equipment. A 1985 study of the board's operations by the New York City Partnership, a coalition of civic-minded business leaders, set as a top priority the purchase of electronic voting equipment commonly used in other big cities.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: MOST Americans say they would personally pay an additional $200 a year in taxes to improve public education. Three-quarters of the 1,234 adults surveyed by the Gallup Poll said Federal spending on programs to improve public education should be increased. The poll found that the public supported increased spending on education even when the condition of higher taxes was added.

LEAD: With his knack for publicity, Richard Leakey became an important leader in the campaign to ban the sale of elephant ivory and crush a flourishing illegal international trade supported by poaching. Last October, with strong backing from the United States, a ban was adopted at a meeting of the 103 member countries of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (known as CITES and pronounced sight-ese) in Lausanne, Switzerland.
LEAD: Seton Hall has recruited a Soviet basketball player who plans to enroll in the school later this month, a report in a newsletter says.

LEAD: Twenty-three years ago, black American drama was not yet a part of the country's cultural milieu. Largely unwelcome on Broadway, black playwrights had their work confined mainly to a few Off Broadway and Harlem-based theaters. When the Negro Ensemble Company opened in Greenwich Village in 1967 - and in that inaugural year staged plays by Richard Wright and Wole Soyinka - it ushered black drama into the mainstream, helping to alter the nation's cultural landscape.

LEAD: We hardly knew each other. He and his wife had left the city, as we had, relocating to this small town in upstate New York with the idea of finding cleaner air and less noise and russet-colored dogs in russet-colored leaves. I had two young sons, he had three, and we shared the conviction that this small, clean, safe part of the world would insure our children ''a better way of life.

LEAD: FAILURE - a word fraught with emotion, easily spoken in daily conversation, but feared by the person to whom it is applied. Error, mistake, wrong, defeat, loss, all words that when directed at us evoke embarrassment and pain. We are trained and culturally conditioned to want to succeed, to be the best, to win.

LEAD: If the world needed one last sign of new warmth between East and West, it came last week. Susan Eisenhower, granddaughter of the cold war's first general, President Eisenhower, announced her engagement to Roald Z. Sagdeyev, a former chief of the Soviet space program. The couple, who met at a conference on Soviet-American relations in 1987 and got to know each other better a year ago when she helped him work on his memoirs, admitted they had felt some trepidation about how officials in their countries would react.

LEAD: The engagement of Anne Thomas Gibbons to William Edward Sutcliffe 3d has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Anne T. Gibbons of Fairfield, Conn., and Maxfield S. Gibbons of Greenwich, Conn. Mr. Sutcliffe is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sutcliffe Jr. of North Redington Beach, Fla. A 1990 wedding is planned.
LEAD: Melvin Newbern scored a career-high 27 points and Willie Burton had 21 tonight as Minnesota defeated previously unbeaten Illinois, 91-74, in a Big Ten Conference game.

LEAD: The Federal Aviation Administration has proposed to fine Delta Air Lines $70,000 and suspend the licenses of a Delta pilot and a dispatcher for operating a mechanically faulty jetliner last June 17.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Zaven Ayanian of Matawan, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Lynn Ayanian, to Dr. Daniel Joseph Pereles, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Pereles of Potomac, Md. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: CLASSICAL 'Des Knaben Wunderhorn' Thomas Hampson, baritone; Geoffrey Parsons, piano. Teldec 244923-2; CD only. Mahler is the composer most closely associated with ''The Youth's Magic Horn,'' the collection of German folk songs published in the early 1800's by Achim von Arnim and Clemens von Brentano.

LEAD: WHILE planning a recent hiking trip to New Zealand, I mulled the paradox of the Milford Track. The three-day trek from lake to sea is so renowned for its scenic glories that it's billed as ''the most beautiful walk in the world.'' But the Milford is also a popular tourist destination and is strictly controlled by the authorities.
LEAD: The Fine Art of Bicycling

LEAD: Lower Manhattan is alive with mixed-media experiments, and ''Urchin 1,'' which ends a three-night run tonight at 8 at Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue, is an energetic example of that all-encompassing genre. But before it blasts into Lincoln Center orbit, so to speak (this is a science-fiction piece), it needs enriching.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Paulette Bates Alden wrote the article I had always wanted to write (''A Reluctant Education,'' Dec. 10). I have been through the same: post-coital tests, biopsies, nagging (or cajoling) my husband to have intercourse at what I estimated to be the precise moment of ovulation.

LEAD: An article on Nov. 26 about dining in Santa Fe misidentified the train station that is now Tomasita's; it was a station of the Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe, not the Denver & Rio Grande. The article also misnamed a brand of beer; it is Negra Modelo.

LEAD: OUR daughter and only child is now a sophomore in college, but it is just recently that my husband and I have begun to realize exactly what that means. She is out of the nest, on her own, flown the coop - whatever cliche we use to describe the process of an adolescent becoming an adult and leading her own life.

LEAD: The Beekman Estate, a private investment and development company in Manhattan, is seeking to add a new building to a shopping center it bought a year ago in Westport, Conn. The 6,200- square-foot addition to the Jennings Plaza shopping center, at 1045 Boston Post Road Extended, would be finished in about a year if expected approval is given later this month by the Westport Planning and Zoning

LEAD: To the Editor: It is always pleasing to have bed and breakfast accommodations spotlighted (''The New Bed and Breakfast'' by Eric N. Berg, Travel, Oct. 15). While the B & B's described by Mr. Berg are certainly a growing phenomenon across the country, traditional B & B's are hardly on their way out.

LEAD: It's a depositor's worst nightmare come true. That friendly savings and loan association down the street, which had been paying some of the highest rates in town, is suddenly declared insolvent. What is a person to do? Below are answers to some commonly asked questions. Q. Who's in charge?

LEAD: The networks are competing more fiercely and frequently over the rights to titillating true stories. Lately, ABC and NBC have been duking it out over the life and death of Rock Hudson, the Hollywood star who died of AIDS in 1985. Last year, NBC announced plans for a biography and commissioned a script, but ABC quietly moved in and beat the peacock to the punch.

LEAD: When the All-Pro or Pro Bowl teams are chosen, some specialists are hailed for their skills. Place-kickers, punters, even special-team tacklers. But never a blocking back. Although success in football has been defined by coaches from Amos Alonzo Stagg to Bill Walsh as boiling down to blocking and tackling, there is no such species as the All-Pro blocking back or a Pro Bowl blocking back.

LEAD: Like a man who appreciates equally a good joke at his expense and his ultimate vindication, Michael Roemer recalls the day in 1970 that he showed the movie he had just finished to executives of Columbia Pictures. Written and directed by Mr. Roemer, it is an intricate but low-key black-and-white comedy about a small-time Jewish racketeer called ''The Plot Against Harry.

LEAD: Jazz, through much of its history, has been seen by critics, fans and musicians as sticking close to a simple progression, where one stylistic innovation follows another. And while the meaning of the change can be implied from as many critical angles as can be found - from Marxist or social criticism to psychoanalytical to formalist - the idea of a predominant style remains.

LEAD: A small seaside hotel and an adjoining waterfront residence on Ocean Avenue in Ocean Grove, N.J., are being rehabilitated into 11 condominium apartments. The Victorian-style hotel, built in 1870, and the home, built in 1920, had been used as rental apartment houses and had fallen into neglect when they were bought for $750,000 last summer by the Booth Development Company of Ridgewood, N.J.

LEAD: Susan Amy Epstein and Eric S. Aledort, 1988 graduates of the Georgetown University Law Center, plan to marry in October. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Stanley H. Epstein of New York and Dr. and Mrs. Louis M. Aledort of Tenafly, N.J.

LEAD: Two decades ago, climbing skirt lengths produced a new kind of underpinning: panty hose. In this new decade, panty hose are again playing a key role, but now they are opaque tights, making the wearer feel less exposed in a short skirt or more pulled together, no matter the hem length.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick E. Bona of Boonton Township, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Christine Bona, to Robert E. Cabana, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard E. Cabana of Boonton Township. A May wedding is planned. Miss Bona, 22 years old, is an export coordinator in the kraft paper and board division of the Union Camp Corporation in Wayne, N.J.

LEAD: Beetle comes rushing into the room with the evening newspaper, displaying the banner headline: ''Ceausescu Toppled and Gone.'' Her proper name is Sylvia Betty, and she has been married to Frederic Raphael for 33 years. When she met him, she told him that Beetle was a family pet name and that he was to promise never to use it, but since his way of showing his love for things is to tell of their secrets, he has never called her anything else.
LEAD: It's happening again. Brooklyn is losing another piece of its identity.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: The death of a 20-year-old sophomore at Clemson University has raised questions about drinking by under-age students on campus.

LEAD: Little noticed among the rattling upheavals that dominate the news, the 12 nations of the European Community are formulating a plan to synchronize beepers. Unsuspecting observers may see this as no more than sensible coordination, removing yet another barrier to the free movement of commerce in the Common Market.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: THE Federal Government provides three-quarters of financial aid to college students. States furnish 6 percent and individual institutions contribute the remaining 19 percent. Student aid amounted to $26.7 billion during the 1988-89 academic year. - The College Board, ''Trends in Student Aid: 1980-1989''

LEAD: The biggest real estate sale in American history is under way as the Federal Government acts on Administration orders to move quickly to dispose of properties taken over from failed savings and loan institutions. Last week the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency handling the dispositions, listed about 30,000 properties it had acquired since Sept.

LEAD: Q. I have read about the problem that some people have with condensation forming between the two panes of glass in double-pane windows, but my problem is different. My apartment has windows of this type, but with a metal frame. When outside temperatures drop below freezing, condensation forms on the metal and then freezes to form a coat of ice on the inside.

LEAD: In the most ambitious mission undertaken since the Challenger accident four years ago, the space shuttle Columbia is scheduled to be launched tomorrow to rescue and bring back to Earth a bus-size satellite that is slowly falling out of orbit.
LEAD: THE MYTH OF HETEROSEXUAL AIDS By Michael Fumento. 411 pp. New York: A New Republic Book/Basic Books. $22.95.
LEAD: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez yesterday announced a sweeping reorganization of his central headquarters staff that will eliminate 14 bureaus and 218 jobs.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Kleckner of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ilene Sondra Kleckner to Kent Richard Friedman, a son of Alfred Friedman of Hallandale, Fla., and the late Carol Z. Landham. An April wedding is planned.
LEAD: It's time for preventive government interference.

LEAD: To the Editor: There are still a large number of reasonably priced B & B's in both urban and rural areas. There are plenty of people (probably the majority of B & B travelers) who are not looking for all those luxuries and amenities offered by these so-called bed and breakfast places. In my opinion such places should call themselves inns and omit the words bed and breakfast completely.

LEAD: A report in the Travel Advisory column on Nov. 26 about airline-ticket prepay charges referred incompletely to their use. The $25 charge, for reserving seats in advance but picking up tickets at the airport, is imposed by some airlines on passengers who reserve directly with them, not just those who reserve through travel agents.

LEAD: All six of the Soviet Union's East European allies are in the midst of momentous change, but it is taking place at different rates and in different ways. Here is a status report. POLAND: Coalition Government

LEAD: OAKLAND Saturday night: everyone's ready for partying, for motorized cruising down once gas-lighted avenues. From the MacArthur to the Nimitz, the old heroes have been turned into highways and the highways are free. So get in your bumper car and bump around the town natives call Bump City.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Ferdinand of New Haven have announced the engagement of their daughter Donna M. Ferdinand to Lloyd M. Prezant, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Prezant of the Bronx. Ms. Ferdinand, who is 30 years old, works in the corporate safety office of the Southern New England Telephone Company in New Haven.
LEAD: THE DIANE GOODE BOOK OF AMERICAN FOLK TALES & SONGS Collected by Ann Durell. Illustrated by Diane Goode. 63 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $14.95. (Ages 4 to 10)

LEAD: THE United Nations has proclaimed 1990 International Literacy Year. A fourth of the world's adults are illiterate, but the problem is not confined to developing nations. Thirteen percent of Americans 20 years old and older are considered functionally illiterate. The basic skills of functional illiterates do not reach beyond the fourth grade.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: AND WE SOLD THE RAIN: Contemporary Fiction From Central America. Edited by Rosario Santos. (Four Walls Eight Windows, Cloth, $18.95; Paper, $9.95.) No Central American - save Guatemala's 1967 Nobel Prize winner, Miguel Angel Asturias - figured in the literary boom that brought so many young Latin American writers to print in the 1970's and 80's.

LEAD: At the Presbyterian Church in Rye, N.Y., Karen Leslie Cox, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bert George Cox of Rye and Boca Grande, Fla., was married yesterday to John Joseph Mandy Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mandy of New Paltz, N.Y. The Rev. David L. Uhl performed the ceremony, assisted by Msgr. Donald J.
LEAD: Inmates have rioted at a prison in Slovakia, taking over some parts of the building, the Communist Party newspaper reported today.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: When Susan Bergeron, a high school senior who is a local official of Students Against Driving Drunk, learned that Montgomery County was selling its own brand of liquor, she was furious.

LEAD: Q. I have read about the problem that some people have with condensation forming between the two panes of glass in double-pane windows, but my problem is different. My apartment has windows of this type, but with a metal frame. When outside temperatures drop below freezing, condensation forms on the metal and then freezes to form a coat of ice on the inside.

LEAD: THE transformation of Manuel Antonio Noriega from invincible leader of Panama and foreign nemesis to manacled criminal defendant in Miami buoyed the American psyche. It was a political triumph for President Bush.

LEAD: ART BUCHWALD DID A COLUMN recently about his lucky wife. She had fallen in front of their house, as I recall, and broken her wrist. ''Lucky it was your left wrist and not your right,'' one friend said. ''Lucky you were so close to home,'' said another. ''Lucky you were at the foot of the stairs and not the top,'' said a third.

LEAD: Reacting to a report that called Wellesley College ''covertly racist,'' the college's trustees have approved the hiring of five additional minority faculty members over the next five years. These new positions are in addition to the current faculty limit of about 320 that was established by the trustees.

LEAD: The Nov. 26 article ''State's Elderly Gain Influence as Lobby Group'' described the power of some of the elderly in getting the 1988 expanded Medicare bill repealed this year. As one senior citizen who would have been paying a surtax in the expanded Medicare program, I am disgusted by the opposition of the more affluent seniors to helping their more needy peers.
LEAD: Mike Richter, who had been both humbled and heroic in the most important game of his season, extended his left pad as far as he could, stretched out his glove as far as it would go.

LEAD: New Communist Schooling Nowhere is the fragile future of communism more candidly admitted lately than within the Higher Party School, the elite Moscow finishing school for apparatchiks. Page 14. Japan's $1 Billion Plan Tokyo plans to announce a package of more than $1 billion in loans and guarantees for Poland and Hungary, Japanese officials said.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: President Bush has authorized the release of $184.6 million in disaster aid to help with the recovery from Hurricane Hugo, which struck the South in September, and the earthquake in California in October.

LEAD: Create a playoff system beginning sometime in early- to mid-December, culminating in a championship bowl on that boring late January weekend between the end of the pro season and the Super Bowl.

LEAD: IN a university town like New Haven one might expect to find a variety of inexpensive, ethnic restaurants and indeed that is the case. But in all this diversity there is just one Indian restaurant, India Palace.

LEAD: May wedding plans have been announced for Dr. Lauren Dee Putter, a clinical psychologist in Philadelphia, and Dr. Andrew William Menzin, a resident in obstetrics and gynecology at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania.

LEAD: Perfect, a rock band that has drawn stadium-size audiences to rock concerts in its native Poland, made its New York debut Thursday at CBGB. In Poland, Perfect has been a legendary dissident band - formed in 1979, disbanded under pressure in 1983, reunited in 1987 with the blessing of Solidarity. Here, playing a short set (only the songs that they have translated into English), Perfect was an aggressive, accomplished band whose songs suggested that in rock, Poland is a

LEAD: Crew members of the munitions train that ran over S. Brian Willson in 1987 insisted that they, too, had been traumatized by the incident. So while Mr. Willson, whose legs were severed as he sat on the tracks to protest American arms shipments to Central America, was suing the Government, the train's crew was suing Mr.

LEAD: Harry R. Karp, an electrical engineer and retired editor in chief of Data Communications magazine, died of complications following heart surgery Thursday at Beth Israel Medical Center in Newark. He was 67 years old and lived in Westfield, N.J.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: A state grand jury has issued subpoenas to about a half dozen Exxon Corporation employees in New Jersey as law-enforcement officials continued a criminal investigation into the spill of at least 200,000 gallons of heating oil into the Arthur Kill, officials said today.

LEAD: WHEN my children were young, we took separate vacations. Each June I packed them off to their grandparents, a continent away, and when they returned, we were all glad to see each other again. I'd had a respite from single parenthood, and they'd had a month of unqualified approval and unlimited indulgence.

LEAD: Since the landmark visit of the Peking Opera to the Metropolitan Opera House 10 years ago, smaller Chinese companies have appeared in New York with some regularity. When the Guangdong Yue Troupe played at the Beacon Theater in 1982, one of its lead performers was the actress Hong Xiannu, whose daughter, Hong
LEAD: To the Editor: I'd like to recommend two restaurants and a tearoom in Edinburgh.

LEAD: The University of Miami will receive tangible evidence - a large, ornate silver bowl named after Gen. Douglas MacArthur - to go along with its selection in the polls as the nation's No. 1 college football team.

LEAD: Uniforms have long been synonymous with elite private schools. Crisp white shirts, ties, gray slacks or pleated skirts gave students that satisfyingly neat and, well, uniform look. But these days some public schools, too, are seeing salvation in standard student dress. Uniforms or dress codes, they reason, will put an end to clothes-horse competitions.

LEAD: The man identified by American officials as a top aide to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega appeared on Israeli television tonight to deny that he had served as security adviser to the fallen Panamanian dictator.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley H. House of Shawnee Mission, Kan., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mimi Anne House, to Jay Anthony James, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund H. James of Verona, N.J. A June wedding is planned. Miss House, who is 23 years old and a graduate of the University of Arizona, is a candidate for a master's degree in English at the University of California at Los Angeles.
LEAD: Mary Denise Cavallaro and First Lieut. Anthony David McCann, U.S.A., plan to marry in May.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Designers have uncovered their plans for this year's bathing suits, and the news is revealing. The two-piece is back, in plenty of new variations.

LEAD: This year the Novocain began to wear off. The shot administered during the third quarter in Pasadena was at once more powerful and longer-lasting than Giants 39, Broncos 20. It blocked out 23 years of humiliation - Who's Rocky Thompson? What Fumble? - while cocooning us against the ensuing Strike Year and the woulda-coulda-shoulda of 1988.
LEAD: Although automobile sales and other parts of the economy are sluggish, fashion retailers are cheered by the response to resort fashions that began arriving in the stores last month.

LEAD: Kainan Kelly Cramer, the president of Cramer & Sirras, a legal recruiting firm, and Mark Steven Bergman, an associate in the law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, both in New York, were married yesterday at the Army Navy Country Club in Arlington, Va. Rabbi Harold S. White officiated.

LEAD: The article on Jimmy Carter's new career was accompanied by brief biographies of other Presidents who had active public careers after their White House years. You stated that John Quincy Adams was the only former President to serve in Congress. However, Andrew Johnson was elected to the United States Senate from Tennessee in 1875, six years after his Presidential term ended.
LEAD: Silverware makers are hoping that sterling flatware and serving pieces, so popular at the turn of the last century, will make a comeback by the turn of the next.

LEAD: As a model, Helen Lee found that hours under strong lights and frequent changes of climate were affecting her skin. As a result, she spent a lot of time in beauty salons. So two years ago she opened the Helen Lee Salon, at 115 East 57th Street in the Galleria building.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: DANIEL PARRELLA of Pawcatuck loves music, from Mozart to the Rolling Stones. So when he turned 4 last fall, his parents signed him up for Kindermusik, a program of music instruction for children 4 to 7.

LEAD: Arthur Kennedy, who appeared in more than 70 Hollywood films and won a Tony Award on Broadway for creating the role of Biff in Arthur Miller's ''Death of a Salesman,'' died of a brain tumor on Friday at the Connecticut Hospice in Branford. He was 75 years old.

LEAD: In Pete Dunne's ''In the Natural State'' (Dec. 3), I was particularly aggrieved by the words ''as a lifelong New Jersey resident wrestling with his future - with the question of remaining here, or seeking a place that is what New Jersey was...''

LEAD: Hannah Marion Terhune, an associate in the law firm of Pitney, Hardin, Kipp & Szuch in Morristown, N.J., and Second Lieut. Harlan A. Carvey, U.S.M.C., are planning an April wedding, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James E. Terhune of Bernardsville, N.J., have announced. Ms. Terhune graduated from American University and the George Mason University School of Law.

LEAD: By their quotes you may know them - at least that's the challenge in this quiz: quotes to tax your memory, quotes to test your history, quotes to try your patience and good humor (since not every one is what it seems). But don't quote us on that. WHO SAID:

LEAD: Dana Marie Hokin and Robert Vincent Garvey were married yesterday at St. Malachy's Roman Catholic Church in New York by the Rev. James E. Russo. Alexandra Hokin was her sister's maid of honor and Joseph Garvey was his brother's best man.

LEAD: A British Airways flight from London to Miami with 360 people aboard landed instead at Logan International Airport here today after an anonymous caller warned that a bomb would explode in flight.

LEAD: Radio Moscow said today that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had not canceled all January meetings with foreigners to deal with domestic problems, contrary to earlier reports that upset world financial markets.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: On page 33 of Arts and Leisure, with the Gallery View column, a painting by Cy Twombly is reproduced upside down in some copies. In the correct copies, a square enclosing a small numeral 2 appears in the lower right quadrant.
LEAD: AN 87-year-old woman once told Nola Denslow: ''They try to keep us alive so long, and then they don't know what to do with us when they succeed.''
LEAD: Suzanne Pauline Sunshine and William Robert Mendel were married last evening at the Plaza in New York by Rabbi Harvey M. Tattelbaum.
LEAD: 12 Italian Cities Are Girding For World Cup
LEAD: IN Alan Ayckbourn's farce, ''How the Other Half Loves,'' now at the Arena Players Theater in East Farmingdale, Bob Philips is having an extramarital affair with Fiona Foster, his boss's wife.

LEAD: ALICE ALONE. By Amanda Brookfield. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) No novel that includes a middlingly sympathetic dentist can be all bad, but Amanda Brookfield's ''Alice Alone'' comes close. Alice Hatton is an Englishwoman in her early 50's who, like countless other middle-aged people, has been left staring discontentedly at an empty nest when her children have grown.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Paul Ellant of Great Neck, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jody Patricia Ellant, to Howard Jay Reiter, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley F. Reiter of New Haven. The wedding is to be this winter.

LEAD: My heart went out to Paulette Alden. Having gone through an ordeal of my own to have children, I understand only too well. In my case, after five pregnancies (one miscarriage, one ectopic pregnancy and two near-miscarriages where I had to have bed rest for the first trimesters), I now have three sons.
LEAD: The Streetscapes column on Dec. 3 misidentified the religious services conducted in the Church of Sweden by the Swedish Seamen's Church. They are Lutheran, not Baptist.

LEAD: SOMEONE should've warned me before I married him! The things one overlooks in the clutches of romance! Things so fundamental to compatible coexistence that they should be written into the marriage vows, possibly under ''worse,'' as in ''for better or worse.'' One of these is that thou shalt not suffocate thy partner through insufficient oxygenation!

LEAD: COINCIDING with the invention of type, woodcuts began as crude, simple images. But those produced for the cognoscenti by Durer and Cranach can scarcely be told from engravings, so fine are their lines and so sparkling their tones.

LEAD: The manufacture of sterling flatware is among the oldest industries in the nation. None of the leading silversmiths is less than a century old, and some trace their origins to before the American Revolution. From one generation to the next, these companies had always considered their market to be forever green.

LEAD: The United States is prepared to provide up to $3 million to an international commission to begin planning the voluntary relocation of contras to Nicaragua, provided that democratic conditions exist there, the State Department said Friday.

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.
LEAD: Iran has dismissed an Iraqi proposal for reviving peace talks between the two countries as ''a new campaign of public deception,'' Iran's official press agency said today.

LEAD: Q. I have read about the problem that some people have with condensation forming between the two panes of glass in double-pane windows, but my problem is different. My apartment has windows of this type, but with a metal frame. When outside temperatures drop below freezing, condensation forms on the metal and then freezes to form a coat of ice on the inside.

LEAD: A 1989 study of elementary-school children in North Carolina found that teachers judged latchkey children (children who care for themselves after school) to be better adjusted than children with other after-school child-care arrangements. Researchers at the University of North Carolina at Greensboro reported that teachers found no difference in the academic performance achievement of latchkey children and other students.

LEAD: Philip Glass, Lynn Redgrave and members of the New York City Ballet and the Martha Graham Dance Company are to take part in a benefit for the Spoleto Festival U.S.A., Jan. 29 at 7:30 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall. The music, dance and theater series has been held in Charleston, S.C., for 13 years; this year's opening is May 25.

LEAD: ''Anyway, they tell some queer stories about Money Hill. There is Lige Byliss, come from over back Alipartis way; used to be one of the Point fishing crew that had a seine over there when shad used to run more plentiful than they do now. Lige was ready to swear that the hill was haunted; never would go near the place at night, after what he said he saw there one time.

LEAD: Lily McKinley tossed small handfuls of clothes into a large yellow dryer at the West 79th Street coin laundry last week while listening to a description of Videotown Laundrette, which is scheduled to open on the next block in two weeks. She shook her gray hair and light blue knit cap skeptically at the tanning salon and video rentals the new laundry will offer.

LEAD: THE herald of our budding 1990 concert year in Westchester is the Lark Quartet. LEAD: The United States' ''war on drugs'' was first declared by President Richard Nixon in the early 1970's. The current drug crisis provides ample proof that this particular war has been a colossal failure. The reasons range from obscene profits and widespread corruption to national interests and geopolitical maneuverings.
LEAD: St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Virginia Snyder McGraw to Charles Bushnell Seaverns. The Rev. John Andrew performed the ceremony.

LEAD: I cannot understand why everyone seems to be taking Umberto Eco's latest hit, ''Foucault's Pendulum,'' so seriously (''A Literary High-Wire Act,'' by Marshall Blonsky, Dec. 10). Mr. Blonsky quotes Salman Rushdie as saying that the book is ''humorless.''

LEAD: I AM at home recovering from an illness. My son's. Nothing serious; just the usual virus that a 7-year-old seems to get every other month. He's trying to see how far he can shoot up the mercury before Mommy passes out. Anything less than 104 and he's toying with me. Put the toys away, Mama. 105.

LEAD: THE name Epanterias amplexus doesn't have quite the ring of Tyrannosaurus rex, long considered the largest of the flesh-eating dinosaurs. But now the tyrannosaur may have to abdicate its position as king of the reptiles to its lesser-known predecessor, which stalked the earth 30 million years before the first tyrannosaur was born.

LEAD: THIS new year is the 100th since the last of my ancestors left Eastern Europe to settle in Connecticut. 1990 is therefore a coming of age for my family, and I've been thinking how fitting it is that our anniversary falls during one the largest periods of immigration in recent American history. These days, however, the immigrants often come from other directions: South America, the Caribbean and Asia.

LEAD: Sales of new homes rose by 9.6 percent in November, the biggest jump in four months, according to the Commerce Department last week. The Northeast and Middle West posted the strongest gains. After months of soft prices and slow sales, do the November figures signal an end to the housing slump? Four experts give their views.

LEAD: ONLY recently have I realized that for years I have been giving friends and relatives the wrong advice. I don't know why it has taken me so long to come to the truth. Maybe seeing Woody Allen's ''Crimes and Misdemeanors'' made me see the light.
LEAD: Federal agents and law-enforcement officials from three states met this week to coordinate their investigation of the recent rash of bombings in the Southeast.

LEAD: In 1921, the anthropologist Wallace E. Armstrong travelled to Rossel, the easternmost island in the Louisiade archipelago of Papua New Guinea. He found a group of 1,500 islanders cut off from their neighbors, a group possessing a vastly different language and set of customs from the other Melanesian peoples of the area.

LEAD: In 1921, Isadora Duncan, the great pioneer of American modern dance, went to teach and choreograph in the Soviet Union. Excited by the social changes she saw, she created several dances to Soviet workers' songs. Five rarely revived ones were offered Friday night at Eden's Expressway in a program called ''From the Repertory of Isadora Duncan,'' and the stagings by Julia Levien and Hortense Kooluris proved fascinating.

LEAD: AT MY FIRST WHIFF OF THE STEAMING GOLDENJU bowl of chowder thick with mussels, scallops ringed by coral roe, salmon and sole, I knew this was not the Ireland of old. That was a place I'd visited many times for the sound of Gaelic, for warm folk and cold Guinness, but never for food. A smoking peat fire, the slosh of fishermen's boots, a roaring laugh in Boluisce's Seafood Bar at Spiddal - all this was as familiar as the brine of wild Galway oysters.

LEAD: Moscow's proposal that members of Comecon, the Soviet-led trade bloc, begin trading at market prices is a sign that the old order is crumbling. To help fill the void, the West should move quickly to encourage new forms of economic collaboration among Eastern European nations. Otherwise, support for democratic government and for reform itself could be undermined.

LEAD: The Tweedy, Browne Company, a New York investment firm, has purchased a 5 percent stake in the Paine Webber Group. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Tweedy, Browne said the shares had been purchased as an investment.

LEAD: The Supreme Court has ruled unanimously that universities, as employers, enjoy no special exemption from civil rights laws that allow Federal investigators to see their personnel files. It is a correct decision, even if too glibly dismissive of serious arguments for confidentiality in academic employment decisions.
LEAD: Several governors whose states have already cut the air pollution causing acid rain today denounced a plan that would have them help pay for reducing the problem in other parts of the country.
LEAD: More than $9 million in damages has been awarded to a Texas woman by a Federal District Court jury that found that the Xerox Corporation discriminated against her because of her age.

LEAD: The observance of photography's 150th anniversary may have ended in December, but you wouldn't know it from the number of exhibitions of photographs on view this month. It's as if a brand new season has begun in the art world, with photographs once again playing a major role. There's a feeling of fresh possibility in the air, in part because the 1980's are now history, and in part because history itself -in particular, the history of art - suddenly seems a subject on artists' minds.

LEAD: With New York's share of Federal aid and the size of its Congressional delegation at stake, officials here and in New York City have recruited the help of several powerful unions in an effort to have the state's population fully counted in the Census.

LEAD: The White House said today that it opposed Democratic proposals to change the Social Security tax, including one that would cut the amount 130 million workers pay over two years by $62 billion.

LEAD: The University of Alabama, where the pressure of being head football coach is so intense that Bill Curry left after a 10-2 season, yesterday hired as Curry's replacement Gene Stallings, who has a losing record as both a college and a professional coach.
LEAD: The Dayton Hudson Corporation, owner of Target and Mervyn's retail stores and the Dayton Hudson Department Store Company, yesterday named Stephen E. Watson president beginning Feb. 1.

LEAD: As American investigators try to piece together the business and political affairs of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, one of the most intriguing figures remains an Israeli who some say was a key adviser to the former Panamanian strongman.
LEAD: A Federal judge today blocked sections of a new anti-abortion law scheduled to take effect next week.
LEAD: Georgie Auld, a saxophonist who played with Bunny Berigan, Artie Shaw and Benny Goodman, died of lung cancer on Monday at his home here. He was 70 years old.

LEAD: Stephen M. Wolf, the chairman and chief executive of the UAL Corporation, has warned employees that a recapitalization of the company, which owns United Airlines, would ''cripple United financially.''

LEAD: One of public television's more adventurous and distinguished excursions into family entertainment, ''Wonderworks,'' returns for a new season this weekend, having been moved to 10 o'clock on Sunday mornings on Channel 13 from early prime time. The series is produced by a consortium of stations that is headed by WQED in Pittsburgh and that, perhaps significantly, does not include Channel 13.

White's story about a spider named Charlotte, performed by On Stage Productions, 3 and 7 P.M. tomorrow and at 3 P.M. on Sunday. Last performances. At Hartley House Theater, 413 West 46th Street. Tickets: students and the elderly, $8; others, $10.

LEAD: Martin H. Newman, executive director of the Will Rogers Memorial Fund and former president of Century Theaters, died of cancer Monday in New York Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: The new Government said today that 207 Rumanians were killed in September when a passenger ship sank after colliding with a Bulgarian tugboat on the Danube river.

LEAD: The New York City Ballet has an interesting crop of young male dancers moving up the ranks in the company. And a slew of role debuts in a performance of ''Les Gentilhommes'' on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater offered a good chance to watch some of those dancers at work.

LEAD: The ''Evening of 20th-Century Keyboard Classics'' offered on Monday at Merkin Concert Hall was eccentric in its length and juxtaposition of diverse performing forces. It might also have been better named ''An Evening of 20th-Century Keyboard Neo-Classics.'' But it was full of good music well performed, and it built to two really excellent combinations of creation and re-creation at the end.
LEAD: Arthur J. O'Brien, former president of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Jupiter, Fla. He was 80 years old.

LEAD: The assets of the nation's 483 money market mutual funds surged by $6.82 billion, to $375.23 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 144 institutional funds increased by $1.91 billion, to $90.14 billion. The assets of the 241 general-purpose funds were up by $1.26 billion, to $124.50 billion.

LEAD: Robert B. He was 84 years old and had lived for many years in Delray Beach,

LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about an increase in corporate bond defaults in 1989 misstated the financial situation of Integrated Resources Inc. The company is seeking to reorganize itself but has not filed for Chapter 11 protection under the bankruptcy laws.

LEAD: Eight years ago a former Assemblyman named Thomas H. Kean moved his belongings and a wobbly new administration into the Statehouse here, after stunning the public and himself with a 1,797-vote victory over Representative James J. Florio.
LEAD: The most striking development inside the Soviet Union in the past year has been the emergence of a genuine labor movement.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev implored Lithuanians today to remain within the Soviet Union, warning that secession would mean economic calamity for this tiny republic, while weakening Soviet security and endangering his own position and program.

LEAD: Stocks rebounded yesterday as investors sought bargains in the wake of the market's recent weakness. The Dow Jones industrial average, ahead as many as 22 points at midmorning, closed the day 10.03 points higher, at 2,760.67.

LEAD: Grim and silent, about 200 off-duty New York City police officers, many of them from distant precincts, crowded into a Manhattan courtroom yesterday to witness the sentencing of a drug dealer convicted last year of murdering an undercover police officer on the Upper West Side.

LEAD: Stephen H. Mayer, chairman of the MEM Company, a toiletries concern with headquarters in Northvale, N.J., died of a stroke on Wednesday at Tucson (Ariz.) Medical Center. He was 74 years old and had homes in Tucson and Denver.

LEAD: The 80th New York National Boat Show opens today at 10 A.M. in the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan. Today's session, which runs from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., is for so-called red-carpet visitors, those willing to pay $15 a ticket to avoid the crowds.

LEAD: Leftist rebels accepted a Government proposal today to ask the Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations to mediate peace talks, and proposed that negotiations start within 30 days.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The dismembered body of a woman found in the Bronx Monday night was identified yesterday as a bank secretary from Brooklyn, the police said.

LEAD: Wally Joyner, the California Angel first baseman, and Juan Nieves, a Milwaukee Brewer left-hander, filed for salary arbitration yesterday, leaving 184 players still eligible to file by the deadline next Tuesday. Arbitration hearings will be scheduled for the first three weeks of February.

LEAD: Poland's sweeping new economic reform plan has just one goal: to increase economic growth. To achieve that goal, the Government is relying on companies like Dresso, one of the nation's largest sportswear makers.

LEAD: In the worn old corridors of New York's City Hall these days, police guards at the metal gate outside the Mayor's wing are armed not only with pistols but with newspaper pictures of new deputies and commissioners, to avoid the embarrassment of stopping the wrong people.
LEAD: The Royal Ballet announced today that it had canceled plans for a United States tour in July and August because the company could not obtain adequate financing.

LEAD: Joe Montana, the National Football League's top quarterback, won the Jim Thorpe Trophy yesterday as the league's most valuable player. He is the third successive San Francisco 49er player to win the award, following Roger Craig and Jerry Rice.

LEAD: As President Bush wrapped up his first year in office with a quick hop to Malta, an afternoon in the Caribbean, a political swing through the Southwest, some hunting and fishing in Texas and Alabama and two trips to Florida, an old friend mused about the busy schedule.

LEAD: Pressing for a way to restore its credibility with creditors and suppliers, the directors of the Campeau Corporation took steps last night to allow the company's American retailing divisions to operate independently.

LEAD: Carolyn Haywood, a popular author and illustrator of children's books who is best known for her ''Betsy'' and ''Eddie'' series for 7-to-10-year-olds, died of a stroke yesterday at her home in the Chestnut Hill section of Philadelphia. She was 92 years old.
LEAD: * Kellogg Co., Battle Creek, Mich., appointed Carlos M. Gutierrez vice president for product development.
LEAD: The commander of P.L.O. guerrillas in the Sidon area of southern Lebanon threatened today to retaliate for attacks against his men by Lebanese Shiite Muslim militiamen.
LEAD: 'Carried Away' Again

LEAD: Harold Zyskind, professor emeritus of philosophy at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, L.I., died of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, on Tuesday at the Veterans Hospital in Northport, L.I. He was 72 years old and had been in the hospital for the last 15 years.

LEAD: Andris Liepa, a former principal dancer with the Bolshoi Ballet, has withdrawn from his contract with American Ballet Theater after failing to appear for scheduled rehearsals, the company announced yesterday.

LEAD: Astronomers reported today that they had confirmed the existence of one of the largest concentrations of galaxies and matter ever found. The finding could change the way astronomers think about the structure of the universe.

LEAD: Larry Feign's Hong Kong Chinese are shameless racists who love to gamble, toss garbage out their apartment windows and make money. A greedy, materialistic lot, they prefer stability and prosperity to democratic freedoms.

LEAD: Ansett World Aviation Services of Australia has ordered $110 million worth of jet engines from Pratt & Whitney to power as many as 12 Airbus aircraft, Pratt & Whitney said. Ansett ordered PW4000 engines for six A300-600R Airbus twinjets, a total of 14 engines including spares, and took options on 12 more engines to power another six planes, said Pratt & Whitney, a unit of the United Technologies Corporation.

LEAD: The wedding took place outdoors in Port Antonio, Jamaica, on New Year's Day in a stylistically suitable Palladian ruin befitting JOHN F. SALADINO, the interior designer who has said that a living room ''is meant to have the feeling of age and decay.''
LEAD: A state panel in California has concluded that the 1986 immigration law has resulted in widespread job discrimination against Hispanic residents and others.
LEAD: * Friends of Libraries U.S.A. has selected Martin Marshall Jaccoma Mitchell to create a campaign to promote literacy and reading.
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company temporarily shut down four assembly plants with a total of 9,700 hourly workers because of slumping auto sales, the company said today.

LEAD: For years, prosecutors have been barred from using illegally obtained evidence at criminal trials. But for years, with the Supreme Court's blessing, they've used a backdoor tactic to get such evidence before juries. For example, when the defendant takes the witness stand, prosecutors will introduce such evidence during cross-examination - not, in theory, to prove guilt, but to impugn the defendant's credibility.

LEAD: Monday is the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only; post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Closed. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the vacant position of New York City Health Commissioner referred incorrectly to the extent of opposition to the candidacy of Dr. Woodrow A. Myers, Health Commissioner of Indiana. Some advocates for AIDS patients not all, oppose his appointment.

LEAD: ''Terminal Hip,'' Mac Wellman's ''Spiritual History of America Through the Medium of Bad Language,'' is a post-Joycean Jabberwocky. Expect no exegesis. Just sit back and enjoy the torrent of language, as Mr. Wellman zigzags through time, space and participle.

LEAD: The number of air traffic delays rose sharply last year, especially at the nation's five most congested airports, Government officials reported yesterday. Aviation experts found the figures particularly disturbing because delays increased even though the number of flights fell slightly.

LEAD: Eleven months ago, a team of doctors performed an abortion on a comatose Long Island woman, Nancy Klein, in a desperate attempt to help her chances of recovery. The operation culminated a wrenching two-week court battle for her husband, who fought opponents of abortion all the way to the Supreme Court to gain legal guardianship of his 32-year-old wife and the right to decide on her abortion and, perhaps, her last chance for life.

LEAD: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator rebounded in December as United States semiconductor shipments and orders increased, signaling a recovery from the summer slowdown, the Semiconductor Industry Association said today.
LEAD: Reversing a Reagan Administration decision, Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. has proposed raising the fee coal companies pay to mine Federal land.
LEAD: FRIDAY DANCING BEARS, ETC.

LEAD: Jim Hanifan, who was named interim head coach of the Atlanta Falcons when Marion Campbell resigned Nov. 28, was hospitalized and in police custody yesterday after being arrested on charges of driving under the influence of alcohol. He was also charged with having no proof of insurance, committing simple battery on an officer and driving without lights.
LEAD: An article on Dec. 30 about the legacy of the playwright Samuel Beckett misstated the date of his death. It was Dec. 22.

LEAD: To judge from their initial preening for the TV cameras, you'd think that officials in Yonkers, N.Y., had been vindicated by the Supreme Court for resisting a Federal judge's order to build low-income housing. True, the Court does say the judge was too quick to impose contempt fines against four City Councilmen who defied his order, and does absolve them of personal liability.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Lieut. Gen. Basilio Olara Okello, a Ugandan rebel leader who led a coup against the civilian Government of President Milton Obote in 1985, has died of diabetes complicated by malaria. He was 61 years old.
LEAD: Charles Stuart asked one of his brothers to help him kill his wife ''weeks before'' she was fatally shot on Oct. 23, a lawyer for the brother said today.

LEAD: An army's primary mission is supposed to be the defense of national territory. In Latin America, that is rarely the reality. Costa Rica's President, Oscar Arias, proposed on the Op-Ed page this week that Panama abolish its army, as his country did in 1948. His suggestion makes good sense.

LEAD: The Bush Administration criticized the United Nations today for bowing to Soviet pressure to cut off informal contacts with representatives of Baltic nationalist movements seeking independence from Moscow.

LEAD: Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney announced today that improved management would save the Pentagon $2.3 billion and eliminate 16,000 jobs next year, but he declined to go into detail on what jobs would be cut.
LEAD: The arrival of a new year and a new decade inspired donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to express a multitude of hopes for the destitute and the sick.

LEAD: J. Henry Smith, a former chairman of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States who later became New York City's Human Resources Administrator, died of pneumonia Wednesday in the infirmary of Meadow Lakes, a retirement community in Hightstown, N.J., where he lived. He was 79 years old.

LEAD: Three pillars of the Pittsburgh Steelers' four Super Bowl victories - the running back Franco Harris, the linebacker Jack Lambert and the wide receiver Lynn Swann - head the list of 15 finalists for induction into the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

LEAD: As a woman starts across the street, a van roars up. Strong arms wrest her purse from her grasp. As the van lurches away, she falls beneath the wheels and is crushed to death. . . . Members of a drug gang kidnap an enemy's 12-year-old brother, hack off the boy's finger and enclose it with a ransom request.

LEAD: Three members of a personal-injury law firm in Manhattan have been indicted on Federal charges that they falsified evidence and bribed witnesses to lie in 19 accident cases dating to 1979, United States Attorney Andrew J. Maloney announced yesterday. Four private investigators and an office manager for the firm were also charged.

LEAD: Robin Burns, who climbed quickly in the cosmetics industry with the success of Calvin Klein's Obsession, is going on to a new challenge as president and chief executive of Estee Lauder U.S.A., a unit of the cosmetics maker Estee Lauder Inc.
LEAD: The Rev. Victor J. Maritato, a priest in the Diocese of Brooklyn who had served as a Navy chaplain for 21 years, died Sunday at his home in Pompano Beach, Fla. He was 65 years old.

LEAD: ''Beautiful'' and ''graceful'' may have been the last words Al Held would have chosen to describe the paintings he produced between 1953 and 1955. Adjectives like muscular, crude and raw might have been more in the artist's mind at the time, and they do apply to these Abstract Expressionist works.

LEAD: With international travel to the United States soaring, the Customs Service is testing new procedures to prevent the long delays that have characterized peak travel seasons at the nation's busiest airports.

LEAD: Switching orbital lanes and climbing in altitude, the astronauts of the space shuttle Columbia maneuvered into position today for their planned retrieval of a faltering bus-size satellite Friday morning.
LEAD: Arriving neatly between the spring and fall collections, Nell Neuville Merlo was born Wednesday to the designer CHARLOTTE NEUVILLE and her husband, KEN MERLO.
LEAD: Some 40 black ministers met yesterday to coordinate a response to what they called an escalation in political and personal attacks against blacks.
LEAD: Prime Minister V. P. Singh offered key concessions to Sikh separatists today, but said he knew of no sure way of ending the violence.

LEAD: An article on Wednesday about the winner of a $35 million Lotto prize misstated the Federal tax he will have to pay. While 20 percent will be withheld from his 21 annual checks, the actual tax owed would be 28 percent under current Federal law.
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the dairy industry misidentified a farmer from Maize, Kan. He is Gene Woodard.

LEAD: New York City is a long way from the country, but that doesn't stop some of New York's best bar bands from twanging their own kind of down-home music - high-octane honky-tonk that adds a modern urban kick to old-fashioned rockabilly. At the Lone Star Roadhouse on Wednesday night, Roscoe's Gang and the World Famous Blue Jays shared a bill of New York country-rock.
LEAD: Baseball

LEAD: It was late morning and the sun had already risen high above the field where the Denver Broncos were preparing to begin their day of work. Mark Jackson stepped into the warmth, seated himself on a table and squinted into the glare that has suddenly returned after a season that still somehow seems lost and full of misery.
LEAD: Government
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Black Rock Coalition will present J. J. Jumpers, Eye and I, Faith, Mascara and Karen Davis on Sunday at CBGB. 315 Bowery, at Bleecker Street (982-4052). Music begins at 9 P.M.; admission is $10.
LEAD: Flood water lay across southwest Washington and northern Oregon today, closing part of a busy Interstate highway and other roads and forcing about 3,000 people to leave their homes.
LEAD: As an 80th birthday present for CHARLES H. DYSON, his family gave more than $12 million to several organizations. Then they told him they had.

LEAD: President Vaclav Havel's third-floor office in the Prague Castle these days has the urgent chaos of a theater stage the day after opening night. Mail is piled on the floor. Young secretaries and assistants rush in and out. Unwanted paintings stand around against the wall like discarded scenery. Telephones ring and ring and often go unanswered.

LEAD: Barbara Grossman has been named publisher of Charles Scribner's Sons, effective Jan. 29, the company announced Wednesday. She is currently a senior editor at Crown Publishers, where she has worked for eight years. The current Scribner's publisher, Robert Stewart, will have his own imprint at Scribner's and will be a senior editorial vice president of the adult trade division of the Macmillan Publishing Company, of which Scribner's is an imprint.

LEAD: * Ryobi America Corp., to Doe-Anderson Advertising Agency, Louisville, Ky., for its power tools, with a budget of $1 million.

LEAD: rrTelemark skiing, considered an exotic hybrid of cross-country and downhill skiing just a few years ago, is growing rapidly in popularity. More skiers are learning how to do it; they are participating in a variety of events, and the equipment is improving and becoming more specialized.
LEAD: One of Wall Street's leading merger and acquisition advisers, Eric J. Gleacher, resigned yesterday from Morgan Stanley & Company to start his own firm.

LEAD: American Ballet Theater announced yesterday that it will receive a bequest of $1 million from Eugenia Doll, the philanthropist and former wife of the choreographer Leonide Massine. The company said the bequest by Mrs. Doll, who created the role of the Flower Girl in Massine's ''Gaite Parisienne,'' was earmarked for its newly established endowment fund.

LEAD: Mark Jackson, the Knicks' playmaker, and Charles Barkley, the Philadelphia 76ers' All-Star forward, paid yesterday for what Commissioner David Stern called the informal wagers between themselves in the game Wednesday night.

LEAD: While foreign companies welcome the lifting of martial law in the capital, the action is unlikely to have an immediate effect on their commercial or investment activities here, officials of a dozen companies said today.

LEAD: The ever-busier Gerard Schwarz resigned last year as music director of the Music Today series at Merkin Concert Hall. But his absence, along with the apparent good taste of the series' new music adviser, Andre Emelianoff, has opened up this ensemble to a variety of alternative leaders.

LEAD: Jurors who gave the Houston Lighting and Power Company a favorable verdict in a $419 million lawsuit will be flown from Dallas to Houston at the utility's expense for a tour of its nuclear plant and a stay at a luxury hotel.

LEAD: In response to viewer complaints, Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America has agreed to alter a television commercial for its Galant car that quotes in part from St. Paul's Letter to the Corinthians. The voice-over for the spot, set outside a New England church, originally began: ''Yea, when I was a child I spoke as a child and acted as a child.

LEAD: N.B.A. Bullets End Road Slump Jeff Malone scored 22 of his season-high 39 points in the third quarter as Washington snapped a club-record road losing streak at 13 games with a 100-89 victory over Miami last night, the Heat's 12th consecutive defeat. Malone reached the 10,000-point milestone for his seven-year career with his eighth point of the game.
LEAD: East Berlin to Create Force
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: * American Telephone and Telegraph Co. said it would set up a trust to borrow about $550 million through a private placement to buy stock that will be used for future company contributions to its existing non-management employee savings plan.

LEAD: Bundled like mummies against the freezing winds, those few Beijing residents who are now permitted to walk in Tiananmen Square strolled there and quietly speculated about whether the shifting political breezes may be carrying the first signs of a thaw.

LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current. Corner Bistro Diner's Journal (Dec. 4, 1987), 331 West Fourth Street (242-9502) - This is a funky neighborhood tavern where regulars gather to watch sports on television.
LEAD: The Boys Choir of Harlem, founded by DR. WALTER J. TURNBULL, has a lot to celebrate when it observes its 20th anniversary on the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday on Monday.

LEAD: As commentators attempt to forecast political events in 1990 and the decade, they would be well advised to confer with Lord Macaulay, a 19th century British historian and arguably the finest designer of dramatic narrative ever to inhabit a page.

LEAD: A veterinarian dismissed from the Food and Drug Administration said today that the agency's review of a genetically engineered drug designed to make dairy cows produce more milk had been marked by overly close ties to the animal drug industry.

LEAD: When the National Collegiate Athletic Association began its 84th convention last Sunday, Richard Schultz, the association's executive director, made it clear that he wanted to change what seemed to be a prevailing public perception that the N.C.A.A. was a scandal-ridden, do-nothing organization whose primary function was managing the greed of its members.

LEAD: New York State's highest court today overturned a decision revoking for 10 days the license of Dorrian's Red Hand restaurant in Manhattan, where Robert E. Chambers met Jennifer Levin before killing her in Central Park in 1986.

LEAD: The Clorox Company said yesterday that it had transferred the Clorox Detergent advertising account from DDB/Needham in Chicago to the Foote, Cone & Belding office in San Francisco. A Clorox spokesman said the move had been made to consolidate its Clorox brand laundry products at one agency; Foote, Cone already handles the others.
LEAD: Who is ''Z''?

LEAD: Two of jazz's great individualists, the singers Betty Carter and Abbey Lincoln Moseka, will step on stage tonight and give a lesson or two on how to secure a place in jazz history. After a phrase or so, the singers will show off carefully constructed personalities built not out of economic necessity, but out of an act of the imagination.
LEAD: Bureaucrats have thrown a hurdle in the way of the giant frogs from Cameroon that a man wants to enter in Calaveras County's annual frog jump.
LEAD: A former deputy director of the city's Department of General Services was sentenced yesterday to 5 to 15 years in prison on charges of stealing more than a $1 million from the city.
LEAD: Link to Ellington
LEAD: Almost one of every four drivers between the ages of 16 and 45 who were killed in New York City traffic accidents in recent years tested positive for cocaine use, a new study has found.
LEAD: Arthur J. Shawcross, who is accused in a series of slayings in the Lyons area, was charged yesterday with a ninth killing.
LEAD: The winter scourge of influenza has made an early appearance this year, already striking hard in Texas and rapidly spreading its trail of aches across the country.
LEAD: Florida's orange harvest will plunge by some 29 percent this year because of damage from the Christmas weekend freeze, the Department of Agriculture estimated today.

LEAD: When word came that invading United States troops were on their way, Hermel Rodriguez Aguilar came out of hiding, summoned up his courage and went to claim power from the local military officials who had made a habit of beating and jailing opposition politicians like him.
LEAD: Every major ballet company seems to be rummaging in the dustbin of recent history for a forgotten work to expand its repertory and satisfy the public's thirst for the new.

LEAD: Harry Plotnik has been kept under wraps for 20 years, but he is none the worse for wear. Harry is the glum Jewish gangster at the center of ''The Plot Against Harry,'' a funny, sharply drawn and appealingly modest film that very nearly missed seeing the light of day.

LEAD: The Government raised the issue of national security for the first time today in the drug-trafficking case of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, arguing that classified information had been improperly disclosed.

LEAD: ENDING a protracted and occasionally bitter eight-month negotiation, the Omnicom Group and Ammirati & Puris announced yesterday that Ammirati, the New York advertising agency known for its stylish promotions for BMW cars and Club Med resorts, is buying itself back from the giant conglomerate.
LEAD: Dudley Field Malone, a theatrical agent and manager, died of lung cancer on Jan. 1 at his home in Bellport, L.I. He was 59 years old.

LEAD: Anderson led an 18-2 second-half run with 11 points as Indiana turned a 6-point deficit into a 10-point lead and a 77-63 victory over Northwestern tonight, making Bob Knight the top-winning coach in Big Ten Conference history.

LEAD: In what appears to be a significant admission of racial problems within the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the agency has reached out-of-court settlements in recent months in major discrimination cases involving black employees.

LEAD: Come Quilt With Me Inc., a quilting-supply mail-order business, and the 92d Street Y are sponsoring their ninth annual quilting bee at the Y on Sunday from 1 to 5 P.M. There will also be talks on quilting in America and Japan throughout the afternoon. Admission is $5, and quilts may be appraised by the quilter Genie Barnes for $20.

LEAD: Until two years ago, Frank Rubino was the typical Miami ''white powder'' lawyer, representing defendants in drug cases. His most notorious client was a high official in the operation of Carlos Lehder Rivas, the convicted Colombian drug smuggler. His client list included Tony Roman, a.k.a. Antonio Piedra; Giuseppe Pellerito, a.k.a.

LEAD: With power struggles already tearing at France's Communist and Socialist Parties, the country's conservative Gaullist movement has now been shaken by an unexpected onslaught on its longtime leader, Jacques Chirac.

LEAD: A man convicted of exposing himself to a child was licensed as a New York City teacher even though licensing officials knew he had covered up the fact that he had once been convicted in an assault case, an investigative commission said yesterday.

LEAD: YOU can see a dance this weekend called ''I'm a Frayed Knot,'' inspired by Nathaniel Hawthorne's ''Scarlet Letter.'' Home videos are featured in another dance, ''Malad Justed,'' in which a fish responds to Navy war exercises in its sea. But two other dances, by choreographers known for their individualism, will tackle relatively familiar dance subjects - women and clowns.

LEAD: Schumann's Piano Quintet (Op. 44) - with which the Guarneri String Quartet, joined by the pianist Bella Davidovich, ended its concert on Wednesday evening at Alice Tully Hall - is one of the composer's ripest creations. Using a combination of instruments almost wholly novel in 1842, the composer immediately mastered it, producing a rich amalgam of emotion, ebullience and intelligence.

LEAD: They are acquaintances at best, having met about a half-dozen times at all-star games and summer basketball camps. Yet Kenny Anderson and Bobby Hurley, last year's most highly rated high school playmakers, know plenty about each other, and will soon learn a lot more.
LEAD: An article on Jan. 2 reported on a dispute at The Jerusalem Post, where journalists have accused the new publisher of trying to turn a liberal daily into a right-wing platform.
LEAD: A robber got more than he bargained for when he held up a convenience store on Wednesday and ran into Billy Conn, the 72-year-old former light-heavyweight champion, the police said.
LEAD: Rosie's Farmland Diner on Route 46 in Little Ferry may be the best-known diner in America, but it is still a real diner.

LEAD: Daniel David Brockman, a prominent tax lawyer and supporter of the arts, died of cancer at his home in Manhattan yesterday. He was 86 and had homes in Manhattan, East Hampton and Marbella, Spain.

LEAD: Jurgen Breitenstein, a 30-year-old mathematics teacher, decided a year ago to join the thousands of ethnic Germans who had left Rumania for West Germany in search of freedom and opportunity. Now, after the toppling of Nicolae Ceausescu, Mr. Breitenstein is not sure whether to follow through on his decision or stay and support the dwindling

LEAD: If one were to study up-to-date restaurant-industry consumer research, read all the media soothsaying about dining in the 1990's and then go out and build a new restaurant, it would probably resemble Ten Twenty-Two. Christopher Idone, the owner (and the co-founder of the caterer Glorious Foods), is nothing if not canny about popular taste.

LEAD: Pledging to keep state spending increases in the next fiscal year below the inflation rate, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today that he would present a tight budget next week that would grow by a little more than 4 percent.

LEAD: rrThe cooks at the United States Naval Academy used to wonder if any nuclear submarine fuel had been slipping into David Robinson's hardtack and gruel, the way he shot up toward 7 feet on government time.
LEAD: The Polo for Brunch

LEAD: Aided by a spirit of conciliation that has overtaken its long-contentious political factions, Namibia could be ready to declare its independence ahead of schedule, officials involved in the process say.

LEAD: Drew Middleton, who covered World War II and postwar Europe for The New York Times and later served as the newspaper's military correspondent, died quietly in his sleep Wednesday night at his apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 76 years old.
