LEAD: Here in the root and stalk of tobacco country, everyone knows that marketing something that carries a health warning from the Surgeon General is bound to provoke an argument. Mix in race and you really have a shouting match. Just ask the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Joan Osborne is singing blues and rock songs at tomorrow at 11 P.M. at Delta 88, 332 Eighth Avenue, at 26th Street (924-3499). There is a $7 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, no cover at the bar.

LEAD: THE drop in the Tokyo stock market earlier this week, attributed partly to fears of turmoil in the Soviet Union that could weaken the outlook for Japanese involvement in Eastern Europe, knocked down the yen and lifted the dollar. The weakening yen is likely to worsen the huge United States trade deficit with

LEAD: The city schools underwent their fourth consecutive day of violence yesterday when a youth at Junior High School No. 4 was stabbed in an argument with another student, and hospitalized with injuries.
LEAD: The Dame in the Kimono Hollywood, Censorship and the Production Code From the 1920's to the 1960's By Leonard J. Leff and Jerold L. Simmons 350 pages. Grove Weidenfeld. $22.50.

LEAD: President Bush today hailed the lifting of martial law in China as ''a very sound step,'' but he found little support in Congress for his view that China's action was significant or that his policy toward Beijing was effective.

LEAD: COMPANIES The directors of the Campeau Corporation took steps to allow the company's American retailing divisions to operate independently. After four days of meetings at the company's Toronto headquarters, the directors said Campeau's U.S. operations would be overseen by a new board, with a majority of American residents.
LEAD: Whenever a Nets victory appeared questionable, Purvis Short's jump shot was the answer tonight.
LEAD: The Mentor Graphics Corporation of Beaverton, Ore., said today that it would acquire the Silicon Compiler Systems Corporation for about $110 million in newly issued Mentor shares.
LEAD: A Federal jury has stunned lawyers here by awarding $17.5 million in a malpractice case against a local law firm.

LEAD: The arrival here of King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia of Spain for a state visit has reawakened all the ambivalent and contradictory feelings Mexico harbors for its mother country, with the Spanish couple getting a reception oscillating between warmth and hostility.
LEAD: A record number of debt ratings were lowered by the Standard & Poor's Corporation last year, according to preliminary figures compiled and released yesterday by the financial rating service.

LEAD: SOME of the biggest losses from Robert Campeau's spending binge on department stores have been borne by individual investors who purchased ''junk bond'' mutual funds that bought large quantities of bonds issued to finance the Campeau Corporation's purchases.

LEAD: Bill McCartney of Colorado was named 1989 Kodak Football Coach of the Year in Division I-A, the American Football Coaches Association announced at its annual convention yesterday in San Francisco. McCartney led the Buffaloes to an 11-0 regular season before losing by 21-6 to Notre Dame in the Orange
LEAD: ''My personal fate is linked to this choice. The two states must live together.'' - President Gorbachev, addressing Lithuanian on separatism. [A1:6.]
LEAD: A Friendly House Call for 'Annie'

LEAD: Pat LaFontaine extended his goal-scoring streak to a club-record 11 games with his league-high 39th goal and added five assists tonight as the Islanders beat the Minnesota North Stars, 8-4, for their fifth consecutive victory.

LEAD: A number of events are taking place in observance of Martin Luther King Jr. Day on Monday. Here is a sampling of events this weekend and on Monday. TODAY LOCAL 1199 of the Drug, Hospital and Health Care Employees Union, 310 West 43d Street (947-1944). A photographic memoir of King and the civil rights movement by the photojournalist Flip Schulke opens today with a reception at 6 P.M.

LEAD: Ann Stringer, a war correspondent who in 1945 transmitted the first report of the linkup of American and Russian forces, died of a heart attack Wednesday at the Skyrest Nursing Home in Carbondale, Ill. She was 71 years old and had lived until 1987 in Manhattan and Amagansset, L.I.
LEAD: Alexander Lowenthal, a Pittsburgh businessman who was active in civic affairs, died of congestive heart failure Dec. 29 at his home in Pittsburgh. He was 91 years old.

LEAD: Jennifer Bartlett has always divided opinion, and it is not in her nature, or in her art, to do anything else. Her ambition, once fired, has no limit. It was doubtless natural that one or two people would be disconcerted, and one or two professional feathers ruffled, by the original and imaginative design for a garden in Battery Park City that she has designed in partnership with Alexander Cooper and Nicholas Quennell.

LEAD: Mike Figgis's films could be watched at any hour, but they're really best suited to the middle of the night. With only two theatrical features to his credit, the terrific 1988 sleeper ''Stormy Monday'' and now ''Internal Affairs,'' a dizzying police thriller, Mr. Figgis has established himself as a master of steamy sex appeal and brooding, nocturnal murk.

LEAD: The results of a Government study on death rates in nearly 6,000 hospitals were challenged today by researchers who said the Federal analysis failed to account for variations in the severity of patients' illness when they were hospitalized.

LEAD: Listening to the concert of the American Composers Orchestra on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, one couldn't help but reflect on a curious argument that seems to be gaining currency: that the symphony orchestra, as an outgrowth and repository of European musical tradition, is an artificial overlay on American culture, superfluous if not subversive of homespun values.

LEAD: The new president of the New York City Transit Authority vowed yesterday to continue the rebuilding begun by his predecessor. He also described the subway system as unfriendly and said he would emphasize improving the appearance of trains and stations.

LEAD: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr., reversing a Reagan Administration decision, today proposed raising the fee that coal companies pay to states and the Federal Government for mining on Federal land.

LEAD: Fernest and the Thunders, a blues and zydeco band from Lafayette, La., is appearing tonight through Sunday at Tramps, 45 West 21st Street. Sets begin at 8:30 and 11 P.M. and 12:30 A.M. tonight and tomorrow, 8 and 10:30 P.M. and midnight on Sunday; there is a $12 cover ($10 on Sunday) and a two-drink minimum at tables.

LEAD: Starting Tuesday, The American Banker, a daily trade newspaper, will appear without a front-page ad for the first time in a century. Gerald Taylor, the senior vice president for advertising, said that this and other design changes had been made so that American Banker ''will no longer look like a high school newspaper.

LEAD: In an action that stunned heart researchers, the Food and Drug Administration has withdrawn its approval of continued experimental use of the Jarvik artificial heart because of deficiencies found in its manufacture.

LEAD: The Japanese Government is expected to announce soon that it will extend its ''voluntary'' quotas on automobile exports to the United States, but Japan's major manufacturers note that the action is now an annual political gesture that has no effect on the sales of Japanese cars.
LEAD: Duke overcame a 10-point deficit in the last nine minutes to defeat previously unbeaten Georgia Tech by 96-91 last night.

LEAD: The prime winter racing season in Florida unofficially begins in the coming week, with the Tropical Park Derby on closing day at Calder on Sunday and the opening of Gulfstream Park two days later.

LEAD: Already facing the threat of lawsuits and criminal prosecution by the attorneys general of two states, the Exxon Corporation was ordered yesterday to explain to Federal environmental officials what caused the leak of more than a half-million gallons of oil from a pipeline off Staten Island 11 days ago.
LEAD: Introducing some of his players at a news conference today, Tom Flatley, the general manager of the New York Saints, described Scott Huff as an enforcer. Huff seemed to preen.
LEAD: A front-page article on Wednesday and an article on Thursday about the killing of a former Peruvian Defense Minister misidentified him. He was Enrique Lopez Albujar.
LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities dipped in very sluggish trading yesterday, as dealers moved to the sidelines in advance of two important economic reports today.
LEAD: Businessland Inc., a leading computer retailer, said today that it would lay off from 5 percent to 7 percent of its worldwide work force of 3,900.

LEAD: Mexico and its commercial bankers are expected to sign their landmark debt reduction agreement early in February, according to the chairman of the 15-bank advisory committee and the Mexican under secretary of finance.

LEAD: Cable television may need competition at the local level, the Federal Communications Commission said today in deciding to study possible changes in rules that allow just one cable system in most communities.

LEAD: Jack Lazar, the founder of Kimberly Knitwear Inc., in Manhattan, died Thursday at his home in Teaneck, N.J. He was 79 years old. With his wife, the former Helen Bandow, as the designer, Mr. Lazar opened the company in 1946. Over the years, Kimberley's knit dresses and other items came to be fashion staples in wardrobes of women from the Duchess of Windsor to secretaries.

LEAD: Nell Webster, an actress and art dealer, died of ovarian cancer on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 63 years old. Mr. Gorbachev doesn't fit the mold of Soviet leaders with his political and economic reforms, his unilateral force reductions, his freeing of Eastern Europe, his willingness to reveal the lies of his predecessors and now his statement that a multiparty system in his own country would not be a ''tragedy.

LEAD: ON a June afternoon my friend Sherry's driver's license arrived in the mail. She drove over to my house, honked, and waited for me behind the wheel of her mother's white-walled, baby-blue Buick Catalina, with the motor running. I slipped into the front seat, shivering less from the air-conditioning than the sight of her white moccasin caressing the gas pedal.

LEAD: Speaking just before the ordination of a married man with four children to the Catholic priesthood yesterday, John Cardinal O'Connor of New York said that the event did not augur any change in the Catholic Church's insistence that in most of its branches only men vowed to celibacy can serve as priests.

LEAD: TWO years ago, protests forced the state to drop a plan to reduce the mute swan population, but now, with an estimate of more than 1,900 swans in Connecticut, environmental officials have resurrected the proposal.

LEAD: A COOLING economy in Long Island is not the only challenge facing Nassau and Suffolk County employers. The rising cost of health insurance has become a serious drain on revenues and makes it increasingly difficult for companies to grow and compete in a chilly economic climate.

But not long ago some of the horses were near death, having been starved and neglected, and others were destined for the slaughterhouse. That was before Patricia Whalers of New Milford came into their lives.

The ''chamber'' was eventually dropped, and this season a ''symphony'' has been added, so Saturday's 8 P.M.

LEAD: Anniversaries aren't just sentimental occasions. They are useful pegs for marking the position of events in the stream of time. They give us perspective.

LEAD: The Rev. Thomas Fletcher, who retired in 1981 after 20 years as rector of St. Mark's Episcopal Church of New Britain, died Friday at his home in Farmington, Conn., after a brief illness. He was 75 years old.

LEAD: Daniel Censullo, chief operating officer of PATH, spoke about current and future improvements of the PATH system in the Nov. 26 New Jersey Q & A. Nowhere is access to PATH for the disabled community mentioned.

LEAD: FOR most of its 19 years, Amtrak has been regarded as a kind of lost cause. Its trains were derided as unreliable, its service and food as primitive and its budget as a drain on the Federal treasury. But the national railroad appears, at last, to be moving in the right direction.

But one of his recent bits of business seems to have caught on in a relatively big way. It's a jacket with horsehead appliques that face each other, like knights on a chessboard.

LEAD: Recent history says yes. From 1984 through 1989, no N.F.C. team won its division with less than 10 victories. But six A.F.C. teams managed to win. In the last two seasons, four N.F.C. teams have missed the playoffs despite winning 10 games, none have done that and missed in the A.F.C.

LEAD: Tomorrow is the fifth official celebration of the Martin Luther King holiday, and enough time may have passed for at least a preliminary reckoning of this new national institution. There has been a strained, showman's smile about the holiday since it sprang unexpectedly from Congress in 1983, as though in recompense for the 20-year institutional disengagement on most public issues touching race - from cities and transportation to schools.

LEAD: ''I TELL clients that their workers don't have to work harder to become productive, they have to work smarter,'' said Sybil Conrad, a Scarsdale communications consultant. ''For example, in one of my workshops, I teach employees that they can begin to work smarter by listening better.''

LEAD: At the outset of the new decade, the outlook for television and video is exciting but uncertain. Great technical changes are in the offing, but the exact form of these changes is still undecided. Several competing technical proposals for High Definition Television (HDTV) lay claim to the future, each championed by different countries and their industrial giants.

LEAD: FOR almost a century, Florence Griswold's mansion, at 96 Lyme Street in Old Lyme, has been closely associated with Impressionism - first, as the boardinghouse where the artists themselves stayed, but more recently as a museum specializing in their work. ''Native Inspiration,'' the museum's current show, is therefore a departure since it incorporates artists from movements preceding, paralleling and following

LEAD: IN A CROWDED AUDITORIUM, THE CHAMPION hunches over a chessboard. He is surrounded by cameramen. Taking refuge in himself, he pillows his jaw in his hands. He is thinking hard in order to make himself think harder. His opponent, also a champion, is some 300 miles away, pondering the next move, engaged in calculations on a scale too colossal for anyone in the audience to grasp.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: For This Week: Now, while woody plants are dormant, is an excellent time to prune, especially trees and summer-blooming shrubs. But if the plants bloom early in spring, delay pruning until immediately after bloom. Start seed indoors of early flowering plants such as pansies. Check coldframes to be sure young plants and seedlings are secure and their soil moist.

LEAD: No A.F.C. team has won the Super Bowl over the last five years, but the A.F.C. holds the edge in interconference games, 54-52, over the last two years, including post-season play. LEAD: High above the presidential palace here, the flag of Panama flutters next to that of Peru.

LEAD: Climbing from the bottom to the top of the ratings heap during the last decade or so, NBC was adventurous, taking chances on series such as ''Miami Vice,'' ''Hill Street Blues,'' ''Cheers'' and ''The Cosby Show.'' Today, undoubtedly under pressure to stay a very profitable No. 1, the network, now owned by General Electric, has become noticeably more cautious.

LEAD: Gretchen L. Mergenthaler caughtthe flu over Christmas weekend, and throughout the following week she sneezed, coughed, sipped orange juice and breathed through her mouth when she slept. Her ears hurt so much that ''when I went outside, it felt like two anvils hit me in the side of the head,'' she said.

LEAD: THERE are not many sights more ridiculous than a 40-year-old father crawling out of a sleeping toddler's bedroom. On my knees, moving one hand at a time, I try to leave the room without making a sound. Putting a child to bed will unwind even the most assertive and confident parent.

LEAD: The engagement of Sabrina Suzanne Frances Pray and Arno Bryant Fischer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arno Fischer of Greenwich, Conn., has been announced by her parents, Mrs. F. Richards Ford 3d of Greenwich and Malcolm S. Pray Jr. of Greenwich and Palm Beach, Fla. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: SELF-PORTRAIT OF SOMEONE ELSE. By Vincent Eaton. (Viking, $16.95.) Vincent Eaton's dark, angry and intense first novel uses police documents, psychological evaluations, interviews, straight narration and interior monologues to chronicle the self-destruction of Tim Buckles. At 28, Buckles appears at first to be leading a normal life.

LEAD: IN a reprise of a role it has not played for more than a decade, the county has recently become an industrial-employment mecca, in this case providing jobs for hundreds of General Motors employees who were laid off at 12 plants nationwide.

LEAD: THE Copper Beech Inn, occupying the shade of a venerable copper beech tree on Main Street in Ivoryton, has been considered one of Connecticut's most elegant restaurants for almost 20 years. It has survived a change in ownership, menu changes and minor tinkering and has managed to maintain its reputation for leisurely dining in restful and attractive surroundings.

LEAD: ''It's bigger than our House of Fashion,'' exclaimed Mariya Solomin after a tour of Calvin Klein's workrooms and offices, which occupy six floors at 205 West 39th Street. Mrs. Solomin is the fashion editor of Zhurnal Mod, the Soviet Union's major fashion magazine.

Noah, seeded No. 8, will meet Carl-Uwe Steeb of West Germany in the final today.
LEAD: Despite repeated warnings not to take brand-new cameras on once-in-a-lifetime travel vacations, some people persist in tempting fate.

LEAD: Mayor Henry Spallone, buoyed by the United States Supreme Court's ruling that overturned contempt fines against four City Councilmen in the city's desegregation case, has asked municipal officials to examine the options of further legal action to prevent construction of court-ordered integrated housing.

LEAD: MONDAY: The stock markets are open, but most banks and Government offices are closed for Martin Luther King Jr. Day. The Campeau Corporation's Allied and Federated retailing units are to assure a banking group, which loaned Campeau $2.34 billion, that they are solvent. Otherwise, the group could demand substantial, immediate repayment and force the retailers into bankruptcy.
LEAD: In the industrial meadows just west of the Hudson River, where huge semitrailer trucks feed at block-long buildings amid fields of oily heather and filthy weeds, fashion lives.

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: Rex Harrison and Glynis Johns were on stage in their Broadway play, ''The Circle,'' but the music was from ''Gigi'' and something was very, very wrong. The two stars seemed to be having memory problems as they sang the following: REX: We met at nine. GLYNIS: We met at eight. REX: I was on time.

LEAD: A young woman in a short red tunic leaps out with a tattered flag, skips and falls ''wounded.'' Immediately, a second woman enters to take up the banner, and as she falls, two women materialize. Five bodies lie on the ground and two more appear with raised fists, overlapping in their jumps. On tape, the Red Army Chorus sings the ''Varshavyanka,'' a turn-of-the-century Polish-Russian revolutionary song.
LEAD: It is 6:30 A.M., a time when I am usually in suspended animation.

LEAD: Drum machines went ''boom-chucka-boom'' and singers growled and glared in a triple bill of industrial rock Thursday night at the Ritz. Ministry, KMFDM and Controlled Bleeding all make music that draws its power from the deepest, loudest thuds the musicians and electronics can produce. Guitar and keyboard sounds and the chanted vocals are subordinate in songs that try to turn the depersonalized sounds of assembly-line machinery into statements of personal fury and horror.

LEAD: The current turmoil in Communist countries is often described as a struggle between freedom (which is assumed to require a free-enterprise economy) and Communism (dictatorship combined with a socialist economy). Christoph Hein cuts through this confusion between political and economic issues to make it clear that democracy versus dictatorship and private enterprise versus socialism are separate issues.

LEAD: PORK AND I WERE NOT ON TASTING TERMS FORJU nearly 25 years. Our disagreement had nothing to do with religion, although it did start in church. The evening I was scheduled to play an angel in a pageant, my mother baked a big, juicy ham for dinner and I got sick as the devil.

LEAD: When I first heard that Whittle Communications would publish books that carry advertising, I was aghast! We book publishers have always boasted that of all the media we alone have not been corrupted by the advertising dollar. We swim or sink on the quality of our editorial product, not on the trendy whims of Philip Morris or Procter & Gamble.
LEAD: Trapped in a drab, claustrophobic Sydney suburb, a dour young Australian named Kay endlessly muses about trees. Anthropomorphic trees. Malevolent trees.

LEAD: I WAS HERE, AFTER 60 OR SO YEARS, in the northeastern corner of Poland, at the house of my adolescent vacations. The manor still stood, though it had been remodeled into apartments for workers in Poland's Forestry Service. What had been the park was now an impassable tanglewood descending to the lake shore, with no trace remaining of the paths.

LEAD: For his teammates on the Chicago Bulls, the Hornet contest was just another game. For Michael Jordan, Friday night's match against the Hornets was a homecoming.

LEAD: Regarding Grace Glueck's article ''And Now, a Few Words From Jenny Holzer'' (Dec. 3), I would like to draw attention to a use of words in art before this century. In an engraving titled ''Laocoon'' (circa 1820), the artist and visionary poet William Blake crowds aphorisms pertaining to art, Christianity, Classicism and economics around a central image of the famous Hellenistic sculpture.

LEAD: A HALF-DOZEN hammerhead sharks came straight at us when we dropped to about 20 feet below the surface. They moved past at an angle, apparently uninterested, then disappeared into the hazy distance as we continued to sink into the blue.

LEAD: PROLONGED cold weather taxes home heating equipment, thus increasing the likelihood of an unexpected shutdown.

LEAD: ART collectors were euphoric when, less than a month after the Wall Street crash of 1987, Sotheby's sold van Gogh's ''Irises'' for $53.9 million, the highest price ever paid for a painting at auction. Then, two years later, it was revealed that the auction house had given the buyer a loan amounting to half the price of the painting and was still holding the artwork as collateral.

LEAD: The effort of state and private colleges in New Jersey to call themselves universities (''Colleges Ask to Be Called Universities,'' Dec. 3) is an example of what the 19th-century British poet and critic Matthew Arnold called ''the grand word without the grand thing.''

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Ihler F. Grimmelmann of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lisa Kerr Grimmelmann to Dr. Miles Oakley Bidwell Jr., the son of M. Oakley Bidwell of Nassau, the Bahamas, and the late Frances J. Mott. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: Two buses collided head on today, killing 10 people and seriously injuring 5, Pakistan's official press agency said. The accident occurred 60 miles east of Islamabad, The Associated Press of Pakistan said. Officials said the two buses had been speeding.

LEAD: AT THE EDGE OF THE FRENCH QUARTER IN New Orleans, where the city's charm falls off into skid row, David Lynch is directing a scene from his new film ''Wild at Heart.'' On a scouting mission during the morning he had liked several of the people who gather here in the bars before noon, and has now decided to incorporate them into the shots.
LEAD: Lawrence Douglas Wilder, a grandson of slaves, was sworn in today as Governor of Virginia in a 30-second ceremony that changed the political face of the United States.

LEAD: On the eve of a new international effort to end the war in Cambodia, the United States, the Soviet Union, China, France and Britain appear close to endorsing a plan to install a temporary United Nations administration in Phnom Penh until free elections can be organized.

LEAD: Engineers demand firm foundations on both sides of a bridge. Investment bankers don't have engineering degrees. Shaky bridge loans these days have more than a few Wall Streeters quaking, and played a role in Friday's stock market tumble. Rising interest rates and worries over inflation also played a role, as producer prices were reported to have risen 4.8 percent in 1989, the largest annual gain since 1981.

LEAD: There are several kinds of short-grain rice available in Italy for making risotto. The most common, of course, is Arborio. It has become so popular in this country that supermarkets in many large cities carry it.

LEAD: Unlike some Japanese soldiers who spent decades in the jungles of the Pacific and Southeast Asia, Shigeyuki Hashimoto (left) and Kiyaoki Tanaka knew at least that they were no longer fighting World War II. When Mr. Hashimoto and Mr. Tanaka emerged from the woods last week after 45 years, they made it clear that they had stayed on after the big war to fight a smaller one.

LEAD: I have no doubt that Jenny Holzer is an artist, but to think of her as a visual artist, which is the implication of her selection to represent the United States at the Venice Biennale, is to have ''proved'' finally that painting is dead. Slowly but surely the single fixed image - the heart of so-called two-dimensional expression - has been usurped.

LEAD: Exxon is not having a good year. Nor is the environment. Last March brought the Valdez oil spill. On Christmas Eve, an Exxon refinery in Baton Rouge exploded. And on New Year's Day, 500,000 gallons of heating oil burst through a ruptured pipe into Arthur Kill, a 13-mile stretch of water off Staten Island that is a vital breeding ground for herons and egrets.

LEAD: The American dollar and the Japanese yen continued their 1990 swoon last week, as the West German mark, the Swiss franc and the Canadian dollar all gained ground. This week could be more of the same. The West German Bundesbank meets on Thursday, but analysts are not expecting the central bank to raise rates again.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Some politicians learn the intricacies of politics by studying political science, others by working in political campaigns. Dave Cowens is learning the hard way.

LEAD: Mrs. H. Alden Johnson Jr. of Marblehead, Mass., has announced June wedding plans for her daughter Cynthia Cole Johnson and Patrick Joseph Rogers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. W. John Rogers of Rochester.
LEAD: AT 1834 Dixwell Avenue in Hamden, three Roman soldiers and a woman holding a water jug stare at the steady traffic.

LEAD: The tangled Stuart murder case, a near obsession for the Boston news media for the last three months, has prompted charges that the press has been racist, incompetent and reckless. But news executives there vigorously defend the performance of their organizations.

LEAD: A PROPOSED shelter for homeless people on the grounds of a Roman Catholic church here has left a neighborhood and parish bitterly divided and raised a moral question: Do property values supersede the observance of Christian values?

LEAD: THE nation will honor the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. tomorrow, the holiday that marks his birth 61 years ago. But increasingly, the holiday is becoming a time when his admirers ponder not just the meaning of his life, but also the more delicate question of how best to carry on his work 22 years after his death.

LEAD: A crescent moon resting on a Pakistani mountain peak; a red dawn rising over the Serengeti Plains where young lions play; a rainbow caressing the rooftops of a Tibetan palace; a bear cub resting against its mother near Alaska's McNeil River - these wondrous images and more can be found in magnificent color in THE ART OF ADVENTURE (Collins Publishers, $45), a breathtaking pictorial essay by Galen Rowell.

Pepe of Bronxville, N.Y., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Walter Kravetz of Armonk, N.Y., and Pompano Beach, Fla. An August wedding is planned. Miss Kravetz, a graduate of Boston University, is a registered representative of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith in White Plains.

LEAD: ''What was stolen must be returned.''

LEAD: I COULDN'T believe the news! My baby daughter had just visited the pediatrician. My wife called me at my office to render the verdict. I was stunned. I asked her to repeat it. The same answer came through again, loud and clear.

LEAD: Ian Fleming could have written the plot. In September 1978, Georgi I. Markov, an exiled Bulgarian writer and critic of the Communist regime, was standing at a bus stop in London when he was jabbed in the leg with an umbrella. Four days later, he was dead, from poison apparently injected by the umbrella tip.

LEAD: Robert de Niro and Dustin Hoffman, arguably the two greatest film actors of their generation, went belly-up at the box office this Christmas. But Chevy Chase and Sylvester Stallone, who can be found elsewhere on the great acting spectrum, made out just fine. What happened? It wasn't a direct consequence of the films themselves, since all four vehicles in which these actors appeared were disappointing.

LEAD: The unfortunate truth about the FSX agreement to jointly develop a new Japanese fighter plane is that it was a compromise that ended up pleasing almost no one. LEAD: Q. Our sliding glass doors are difficult to slide. We have vacuumed the tracks and sprayed with a silicone lubricant, but this helps only temporarily. Any suggestions?

But there was almost no writing about it, and that made all the difference, since before Esther McCoy began her career as an architectural historian almost no one took California seriously as a place where great buildings could be made.

LEAD: NORTH SALEM could become the first community in Westchester to ban polystyrene foam containers when village officials consider the measure later this month. But opposition from local retailers is mounting, and the outlook for passage of the local law is uncertain.

LEAD: To the Editor: With the recent rise in the popularity of scuba diving, readers of Jane Adams's article ''Into the Void, and Back'' (Travel, Dec. 10) unfamiliar with the sport should be alerted to the possibility that the author might have been experiencing a major danger of scuba diving known as nitrogen narcosis, also called rapture of the deep, not to be confused with the bends or nitrogen saturation of the blood.

LEAD: It makes some sense to watch the Indiana Jones trilogy backward - or more precisely, in reverse chronological order. INDIANA JONES AND THE LAST CRUSADE, which will be released on video at the end of the month (1989, Paramount Home Video, $24.95), begins with Indiana as a Boy Scout, before he became the world's most daring archeologist-adventurer, before he was even Harrison Ford.

LEAD: WHIPPED UP BY A SUDDEN SQUALL, THE SEA between Majuro and Mili islands in the South Pacific began lashing the small sailboat. One of its passengers, Phyllis Rabineau, a 30-year-old senior exhibition developer who works for the Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago, was scared. ''I felt as if I were in a Jack London story,'' she recalls, ''where you're on a boat and everything imaginable goes wrong.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: It was a dirty decade. From check-kiting at E.F. Hutton to insider trading at Drexel Burnham Lambert, Wall Street misbehavior was to the 1980's what bootlegging was to the 20's - the crime that defined the era.

LEAD: To the Editor When the Supreme Court gave stockbrokers the power to insist that aggrieved customers submit their disputes to arbitration, it accorded them something given to no other American industry. (''When Naivete Meets Wall Street,'' Dec. 3) No other industry is privileged with a dispute resolution system in which the adjudicator is not required to explain the basis of the decision and no mechanism is available for review and correction of mistakes.

LEAD: Barbara Bush underwent the last of 10 radiation treatments at Walter Reed Army Medical Center Friday for an eye affliction that has impaired her vision. Doctors say they will not know for at least two months whether the radiation was effective on Graves' disease, an immune system disorder that had affected Mrs.

LEAD: In 1965, Henry Hampton, the executive producer of ''Eyes on the Prize,'' marched for civil rights in Selma, Ala. Today he works in a corner office piled high with books and papers, with a view of Shawmut Avenue, a thoroughfare in this city's South End that is, in his words, ''about the only integrated neighborhood in Boston.

LEAD: The Labeque sisters, the pianists Katia and Marielle, have furthered their careers through talk shows and other publicity measures generally frowned upon by serious musicians. They have been the subject of newspaper and magazine articles around the world. They readily give interviews. They play Gershwin, Scott Joplin and pop music.
LEAD: RADICAL SPIRITS Spiritualism and Women's Rights in Nineteenth-Century America. By Ann Braude. Illustrated. 268 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $24.95.
LEAD: When Dee Topol is ready to get dressed in the morning, she plays a little game with herself: ''Who am I going to be today?''
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: While the photography world was busy congratulating itself last year on the 150th anniversary of the medium, and while photojournalism was being recognized as an art in several touring museum exhibitions, the public territory of still photography was quietly eroding. World events, which still photography has long memorialized, rushed by so rapidly at decade's end that cameras seemed for once unable to keep up.

LEAD: IN 1969, a needlework expert named Irene Preston Miller decided to do something for the Hudson River. It was ''deteriorating,'' the Croton-on-Hudson resident said, and she thought a quilt based on river scenes might draw attention to the Hudson's attributes and motivate people to protect it.

LEAD: THE national touring company of Alfred Uhry's Pulitzer Prize-winning ''Driving Miss Daisy,'' which has understandably been called the Julie Harris Company for the last 15 months, is making its 28th and final stop at the Shubert in New Haven, through next Sunday, and that's all a sensible theatergoer needs to know.

LEAD: The 82-year-old French Gothic apartment house at the corner of Madison Avenue and East 66th Street, often regarded as one of the most distinctive structures on the East Side, has emerged from a coccoon of scaffolding that had enveloped it during more than two years of exterior restoration.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: SOMERS has changed greatly since it was known by the Kitchawank Indians as Appamaghpogh or Amapaugh (''freshwater fish'') and later - from 1788 until 1808 - as Stephentown, after Stephen Van Cortlandt who in 1734 owned 5,000 acres in the area.

LEAD: Neither JoAnne Johnson, 19, nor Allison Atlas, 20, has very long to live - not unless they receive bone marrow transplants that might defeat their leukemia. But JoAnne is black and Allison is Jewish, which means they can't look to the National Marrow Donor Program's registry for help. Neither can most of the 9,000 Americans who might benefit from transplant surgery.

LEAD: A Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday and charged with shooting three men, including two bystanders, outside a Manhattan nightclub early in the morning of Dec. 30, the police said. Two of the men were killed and the third was seriously wounded.

LEAD: The good teams in the N.F.C. (49ers, Giants, Rams) are better than their A.F.C. counterparts (Broncos, Browns, Bills) and should win the Super Bowl. But the bad teams in the N.F.C. (Cowboys, Falcons, Cardinals) are worse than their A.F.C. counterparts (Jets, Chargers, Patriots). The average teams in each conference are about the same.
LEAD: When the 49ers face the Los Angeles Rams in San Francisco today for the National Conference championship and a Super Bowl berth, the game will offer exciting offenses.

LEAD: ''Those Spiro Agnew and George Wallace watches were pin lever movements, cheap pieces of junk,'' said Lester Maddox, proudly brandishing the watch on his wrist with its chicken leg for an hour hand and pick handle for a minute hand. ''This is a 17 jewel.''

LEAD: June wedding plans have been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Ladislav Buchsbaum of Wyncote, Pa., for their daughter Erica Ruth Buchsbaum and Dr. Andrew C. Goldberg, the son of Anshel Goldberg of South Orange, N.J., and the late Marsha Goldberg.

LEAD: Two years from now, if all goes as scheduled, Nigeria will have a new national legislature, 21 new state governors and a new democratically elected President. What it does not have now are candidates for any of those jobs.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: LONG before the dawn of civilization the area that is now Bernardsville was a meeting ground. There, New Jersey's two major rock formations - the red shale of southern New Jersey and the Precambrian gneiss of the north - meet, in the same area where the Great Wisconsin Glacier halted at the foot of the Watchung

LEAD: FEW external features enhance the value and attractiveness of a home more than its trees, those actually on the property as well as any street trees that might frame the setting. A careful program of pruning - whether through a professional landscaper, in cooperation with the municipality or by one's own labors - is therefore not a luxury but an integral part of any prudent property maintenance program.

LEAD: Will laser be the people's choice in the 1990's? ''Laser videodisk will be to home entertainment in the 90's what the VCR was during the 80's,'' said Martin Greenwald, the president of Image Entertainment in a statement last summer. Since Image makes disks for Orion, MGM, Disney, CBS/Fox and about 50 other companies, he is entitled to some enthusiasm.

LEAD: Not so many years ago, if anyone came into a chess club and asked, ''Would you like to see the brilliant game I played against the computer?'' he would have been laughed out of the place. But what was surely one of the most imaginative games in the American Open Tournament, Nov. 23-26 at the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Long Beach, Calif., was won by a human against one of several computers entered.

LEAD: Ask most pundits about rap music, and they'll describe it as rude, jumbled noise. A few others may consider it million-selling post-modernism in audible form - songs as mix-and-match collages that treat the history of recorded music as a scrapheap of usable rubble and, often, trade narrative and logic for a patchwork of bragging, storytelling, speechifying and free-form rhymes.

LEAD: DAVID ENGERT, a 39-year-old manager of a Los Angeles computer company, traveled nearly 2,000 miles to get to his native New Orleans for the holidays. One of the main reasons, he said: to eat oysters at the Acme Oyster House, on Iberville Street in the French Quarter.
LEAD: A PLAN to require all practicing New York State lawyers to take continuing legal education courses has met with mixed reactions from Long Island lawyers and their county bar associations.

LEAD: ''Every year I 'meant' to send a check, but. . . . This year, seeing so many homeless on the streets, I realized it was time,'' Barbara Dixon of Manhattan wrote in a note she sent with her $100 donation to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
LEAD: Karan Singh, the Indian Ambassador to Washington and son of the last Maharajah of Kashmir, has resigned his post, it was announced today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: WHEN a weeklong tour of ''Stardust,'' a Broadway-bound musical portrait of the four decades from the 1920's through the 50's, at Bushnell Memorial Hall in Hartford was canceled, into the breach stepped Lucie Arnaz, Donna McKechnie and Michael Maguire, to present ''On Broadway,'' from Tuesday through next Sunday.

LEAD: He played only one season at Arizona State before embarking on a 21-year major league career that will land him in the Hall of Fame, but yesterday, Reggie Jackson saw his number retired by the university. And it wasn't the number he actually wore.

LEAD: ''It wasn't just one opening night,'' Agnes de Mille explained recently, recalling the debut of American Ballet Theater a half-century ago. ''During that first season, almost every night was an opening night. They had ballets by Fokine, Mordkin and Adolph Bolm. They had premieres by Tudor and Eugene Loring.
LEAD: ARE YOU CRAZY?'' friends in New York had said. ''Why on earth would you want to do such a thing?''

LEAD: Since a mail bomb killed a black Savannah lawyer in December, Federal law-enforcement officials say they have been trying to track down the source of an unusual type of string used to tie the package as well as the owner of an automatic tying machine that cinched four such parcels with identical knots.

LEAD: A REGULAR exercise program, experts say, makes a person feel better, look better, require less sleep and possess more energy. Fitness is ''in.'' And people who exercise are generally healthier than those who don't; healthy people spend less time with doctors and more time at work.
LEAD: THE reason you sit down to the piano even if they all laugh is something that Bob Gemson, Dr. Stuart Rappaport, Hayley Kobilinsky and Barbara Brand know only too well.
LEAD: Alonzo Mourning scored 26 points and Mark Tillmon added 21 today to lead undefeated Georgetown to a 74-64 victory over DePaul.

LEAD: THOUGH barroom lore has long had it that women get drunk faster than men, the phenomenon has attracted little scientific attention. Since women generally have smaller bodies than men it seemed natural to expect that they would be more quickly overwhelmed by alcohol.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. James C. Pressey of Sag Harbor, L.I., and San Miguel de Allende, Mexico, have made known the June wedding plans of their daughter, Katharine Allen Pressey, and Jeffrey Stuart Rosenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Rosenberg of Jericho, L.I.
LEAD: THE BEST AMERICAN ESSAYS 1989 Edited by Geoffrey Wolff. Robert Atwan, series editor. 298 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. Cloth, $17.95. Paper, $8.95.

LEAD: Congress will have to deal with several bills concerning coins in the next few months. One will change the look of the coins. Another will abolish the cent in favor of a new coin valued at one dollar. Both bills are mired in controversy. The bill to change the design on the reverse side of the coins is supported by the American Numismatic Association and by many collectors.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor: On Nov. 12 you published a ski guide to the United States. Imagine our surprise when a concerned individual informed us that Montana was not included.
LEAD: FOR about $2,600 a year, the Rogers Corporation gets a privilege accorded few corporations: the right to have its name not only on the top of its stationery, but also as its address.
LEAD: First glimpses of the heavens by a new spacecraft looking for evidence of the beginning of existence have revealed an almost too perfect universe, scientists said today.

LEAD: ''I SPELLED eleemosynary like it was cat or dog,'' explains Echo, the national spelling champion in ''El-ee-mos-y-nary,'' the occasionally fascinating play by Lee Blessing now at Studio Theater.

LEAD: Lisa Rieger, a daughter of Jack (Chip) Rieger of New York and Joan Rieger of Brentwood, Calif., was married yesterday in San Francisco to Matthew Warren Claman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence Claman of Dallas. Judge Joseph Karesh of Alameda County (Calif.) Superior Court officiated at the Page Brown

LEAD: Last week in Dallas, National Collegiate Athletic Association executives, university and college presidents, athletic directors and some coaches met to discuss and formulate the rules that govern college athletics. The only constituency not represented in Dallas was, perhaps, the most important: the athletes.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE road north from Chongqing, city of fog and ferries far up the Yangtze River, undulates through market towns by fish ponds, brick kilns and mulberry bushes. Bamboos brush gray slate roofs, leathery men working in the fields hold pink umbrellas above their sweating brows, pigs are being carried to an urban fate in a special cane basket called ''pig's sedan chair,'' and heavily made-up young women in high heels by the muddy roadside call out invitations to take meals at their aromatic private cafes.
LEAD: OUR NEW YORK Text by Alfred Kazin. Photographs by David Finn. 224 pages. New York: Harper & Row. $35.

LEAD: Two people, one of them the actress Viveca Lindfors, were slashed on the face within minutes of each other in separate incidents yesterday morning, apparently by members of a group of young people roaming Greenwich Village, the police said.

LEAD: William M. Freeman, a business and financial news reporter, columnist and editor for The New York Times from 1932 until his retirement in 1976, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at St. Peter's Hospital in Albany. He was 76 years old and lived in Cambridge, N.Y.

LEAD: After the World Cup soccer draw last month, Diego Maradona, the captain of the Argentine national team, said that he believed the pairings in the six four-team groups had been determined beforehand and that the official ceremony had been staged ''just for the fun of television watchers.''

LEAD: By about the year 2010, it may be possible for globe-trotters to fly from Los Angeles to Tokyo at two or three times the speed of sound - cutting the nine-hour trip to three or four hours - and pay only slightly more than they would for a ticket on a Boeing 747.
LEAD: Seventeen years after it was established to uproot corruption in New York City's criminal-justice system, a state investigative agency is going out of business.

LEAD: JAPAN'S defense is keyed to America's security needs, not our own, which is an anomaly that reflects our subservient relationship. It is time for us to step out of Uncle Sam's shadow and build a military force suited to our own needs. The place to begin is the next-generation support fighter, code-named the FSX, short for fighter support experimental.

LEAD: The program the young violinist Yuri Vodovoz presented in his New York debut recital at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday evening was clearly intended to make a statement, demonstrating the breadth of his musical interests and the stylistic versatility of his playing. Admirably, Mr. Vodovoz - who was born in Odessa, immigrated to this country in 1978 and lives in Chicago - ranged widely before intermission, flanking Beethoven's Sonata in A minor for Piano and Violin (Op.

LEAD: June wedding plans have been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Faris Young of Lake Forest, Ill., for their daughter Margaret Randolph Young and J. Sargeant Reynolds Jr., the son of Mrs. Alexander Hamilton 4th of Richmond and the late Mr. Reynolds, a Lieutenant Governor of Virginia.

LEAD: How comforting to know in a turbulent world that one of Western culture's most venerable traditions survives: the visionary interview granted by the freshly anointed artistic director upon taking office. The organization changing pilots may be as formidable and unwieldy as a major opera company or as marginal as an amateur chamber orchestra.

LEAD: As a faithful reader of Barbara Klaus's Long Island Sound columns from almost its inception, I was able to take her article ''Smile, Darn You Smile'' as I'm sure it was meant: a tongue-in-cheek poke at my profession containing many of the cliches about dentists that I have heard for years. This column was certainly not one of her most humorous, but I found myself chuckling in several places.

LEAD: A Soviet airliner with a flaming engine crashed today while attempting an emergency landing on a field in the Ural Mountains, killing 23 people, the official press agency Tass said. Thirty people were injured, the agency said.
LEAD: Praise the Lord, Thrice
LEAD: Florida Levies Drug Fund Fee On Rental Cars
LEAD: Students for and against the legalization of marijuana debated Thursday at the University of Minnesota, surrounded by a noisy, jeering crowd of 300 spectators.
LEAD: Q. Our sliding glass doors are difficult to slide. We have vacuumed the tracks and sprayed with a silicone lubricant, but this helps only temporarily. Any suggestions?
LEAD: A report in the Travel Advisory column on Dec. 10 about sesquicentennial events in New Zealand misidentified the capital. It is Wellington.
LEAD: J W.'s SEA GRILL in the new Marriott Wind Watch Hotel in Hauppauge cannot decide whether it wants to be the Plaza Hotel or a Holiday Inn.
LEAD: Religious leaders in New York are gambling that, to mend the city's racial divisions, many New Yorkers will try anything, even neighborliness.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Paquette Jr. of Gladwyne, Pa., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Ellin Louise Paquette and Frederick Christian Haab Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Haab of Villanova, Pa., and St. Michaels, Md.

LEAD: WHEN Joseph Quy Vu came to this country from Vietnam, he spent two months in a refugee camp and several more months finding a job and a place to live. That was 15 years ago. Now, though his children belong to local soccer and baseball teams and he has made some friends in his South Windsor neighborhood, he still finds adjusting to Western culture a difficult task.

LEAD: A MASTER PLAN to turn SoNo, the restored waterfront of the South Norwalk neighborhood, into one of Connecticut's prime tourist attractions is advancing with surprising brio in view of a recession-prone economy.

LEAD: Rising interest rates, a declining yen and higher oil prices are undermining the usually buoyant Tokyo stock market, hurting the stocks of large companies and sending shivers through other markets around the world.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Posnack of Airmont, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter Beth Allyson Posnack to Robert Morris Hecht, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David M. Hecht of Grand Rapids, Mich., and Vail, Colo. The couple plan to marry in May.

LEAD: If the San Francisco 49ers defeat the Los Angeles Rams here today and leap toward the franchise's fourth Super Bowl title, Joe Montana, Jerry Rice and Roger Craig will, once again, be applauded. George Seifert will be praised for guiding a return trip to the Super Bowl in his first season as head coach.

LEAD: THE transformations sweeping Eastern Europe have reverberated through the institutes and offices, the meeting rooms and magazines that, for the past decade or so, have made up the most influential body of American political thought: conservatism. The echoes, in fact, are the sound of a victory chorus, even if the conservatives' detractors do not believe they should be the only ones to celebrate.

LEAD: A steady reduction of services to students at the University of Connecticut, prompted by recent state budget cuts, have been greeted with murmurs of protest in the last few months. But the most recent money-saving effort - the planned closing of the Center for Educational Innovation, which helps student teachers and university faculty members improve their teaching skills - has upset not just students, but faculty and union members as well.
LEAD: With one second left in tonight's game, Sam Bowie trembled when he heard the referee's whistle. He knew what it meant.

LEAD: One of the few treasures to be found, every other week, in the Sunday Long Island Weekly is the Barbara Klaus column. It never fails to put a smile on your face or a good feeling in your heart. In our house, it almost invariably gets clipped out and shown or mailed to my office staff, friends and family.

LEAD: COMPANIES Debt Ahead for UAL The UAL Corporation had better learn to love debt. Either management and the employees will load the company with debt to buy it, or the board will undertake a buyback - mortgaging the company to pay some impatient stockholders a premium. The noisiest of these stockholders, Coniston Partners, threatens to unseat most of the board unless UAL coughs up a satisfactory payoff.

LEAD: There is no better antifreeze on a frigid winter day than a lusty bowl of soup. Good soup is not that easy to find. Many restaurants consider it something they have to offer on their appetizer lists, but they don't really put extra effort into it.

LEAD: Amid indications that its authority is in danger of collapsing, Rumania's provisional Government restricted political demonstrations today and decided that its executive board would meet daily rather than sporadically.

LEAD: I AM enrolled in an adult development course that spans life crises from ages 17 through death. In class we discuss death, and even though only 29, I sometimes find myself contemplating my own. I think about how my own children (yet unborn) will react to my old age. I wonder if I will outlive my husband.
LEAD: Tomas Sandstrom sat and smiled, the enigma insisting he wasn't at all made uncomfortable by the paradox.
LEAD: The body of a prominent Salvadoran leftist who was reported kidnapped in Guatemala City on Friday has been found near the border, a spokesman for his political party said here today.
LEAD: Newspapers today quoted an Albanian border guard who fled the country as saying that the security forces had fired on protesters last week and that one city was in a state of ''revolution.''

LEAD: BY a curious quirk of timing in the mid-70's, Citibank found itself building the imposing Citicorp Center project at Lexington Avenue and East 53d Street when new office construction generally in Manhattan was tomb silent.

LEAD: May wedding plans for Deborah Lois Brumley and Richard Warnock Morrell have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. George William Brumley of Atlanta. Mr. Morrell is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Warnock Morrell of New York.

LEAD: ELECTION 1990 is hardly uppermost in the minds of American voters. Non-presidential elections are often seen as mere housekeeping for democracy, and the stunning changes in Eastern Europe have overshadowed domestic politics.

LEAD: ''MAYBE I'm giving you too much of a wagonload, but that's your problem.'' Agitatedly sorting out the pieces of his life after a stroke, William Orville Douglas, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, recalls those words, once spoken by his father.

LEAD: Anna Esaki and Craig Spencer Smith were married yesterday in a civil ceremony at the Quaker Meeting House in Chappaqua, N.Y., by Dr. Bruce Gilchrist, the acting marriage officer of the Town of New Castle, N.Y.

LEAD: The tangled Stuart murder case has been a near-obsession for this city's news organizations for the past three months, but the character and tone of their reporting coverage have prompted charges that the press has been racist, incompetent and reckless.

LEAD: With their major objectives accomplished, the astronauts of the space shuttle Columbia settled down today to work on engineering and medical experiments for the rest of the mission, which is to end next Friday morning.

LEAD: For sheer inventiveness, there is little in the automotive world to rival theVoyager III, the Chrysler Corporation's vision of the ultimate minivan. LEAD: SILICON VALLEY, where it once seemed growth had no limits, is in the midst of a midlife crisis. Faced with fierce Japanese competition and a market for personal computers that is growing more slowly than the industry's early visionaries predicted, high technology has lost some of its luster. If boom times are to return, the valley's engineers and entrepreneurs will have to find ways to make the personal computer cheaper, more powerful and portable enough to live up to its name.

LEAD: In 43 years of existence, the Juilliard String Quartet has developed a highly varied repertory. Yet to the general public it remains best known for its periodic traversals of two standard bodies of literature, the 16 quartets of Beethoven and the six of Bartok. According to the program the Juilliard gave the first complete Beethoven cycle in New York in 1948-49, and has since played all 16 works more than a hundred times around the world.

LEAD: THE climatic history of the last half-million years is largely a history of ice and cold, punctuated every 100,000 years or so by brief, glorious intervals of unusual warmth called interglacials. LEAD: N.B.A. Sharp Shooting Helps Celtics Win Visiting Boston made its first 25 free throws last night in beating the Orlando Magic, 133-111. Boston never trailed. After the teams traded baskets in the first minute of the game, Boston went on a 12-point run. Ed Pinckney was the only Celtic to miss a free throw, with 4 minutes 17 seconds left in the game, as the Celtics came within one of their team record of 26 in a row.

LEAD: Y. C. James Yen, founder of a movement to combat illiteracy, poverty and hunger in developing countries on three continents, died of pneumonia yesterday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 96 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Steel imports in November fell 13 percent from October's level, and represented 18.9 percent of the domestic supply, the American Iron and Steel Institute said today. The November imports came to 1.49 million tons, compared with 1.7 million tons in October and 1.8 million tons in November 1988, the institute reported.

LEAD: The battleship Iowa, which was to have been the linchpin of the new naval center on Staten Island, will be mothballed later in the year, Pentagon officials say. That leaves open the question of what vessels will be based at the $300 million base that is taking shape in the shadow of the Verrazano-Narrows

LEAD: Southern California, the Rose Bowl winner, and Syracuse, an Eastern independent, will open the 1990 college football season in the eighth annual Kickoff Classic at Giants Stadium in late August, organizers said today.

LEAD: The Mayor of Nagasaki, who has received numerous death threats from right-wing groups over his suggestion that the late Emperor Hirohito bore some responsibility for World War II, was shot in chest today by a lone gunman in front of the City Hall in his home city.

LEAD: FOR many children, a transfer from one school to another can seem an overwhelming challenge that not only tests their academic skills but also forces them to re-evaluate who they are and where they fit in the world. The changes in their lives and relationships can lead to feelings of isolation and failure or to feelings of greater competency and higher self-esteem.

LEAD: Although ''Casa,'' Denise Stoklos's new performance piece at La Mama, bills itself as a comedy, it could just as accurately be called a mystery. In her one-hour play, this Brazilian director, performer and writer, who calls her physically sparse, mimelike style of drama essential theater, heads a cast of eight actors, including her two children, who act out rituals of daily life in surrealistic caricature.
LEAD: North Carolina's intense defense and Rick Fox's 19 points led the Tar Heels to a stunning 79-60 victory over Duke tonight in an Atlantic Coast Conference game.

LEAD: From its commanding location overlooking the estuary of the Rio de la Plata, the immense shell of Argentina's unfinished national library threatens to become a relic for future archeologists to ponder over.

LEAD: George F. Kennan said today the economic and political problems boiling over in the Soviet Union have put President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in ''danger,'' but he is not likely to be replaced in the near future because his troubles are so acute that even his rivals may not want his job.

LEAD: Some people go into orbit about their birthdays, but CAPT. DANIEL BRANDENSTEIN was in orbit on his. The commander of the space shuttle Columbia celebrated his 47th birthday Tuesday, when he was awakened to ''Danny Boy'' and a rendition of ''Happy Birthday,'' taped by staff members at the Johnson Space Center in

LEAD: Money launderers don't get their hands dirty. They barely handle the cash that buys the drugs. What they do is take the proceeds of drug sales and run them through as many transfer accounts as it takes to make the money look legitimate. They don't poison American children; they merely bankroll the poison.
LEAD: A Federal judge today ordered a hearing in connection with John Poindexter's effort to subpoena former President Ronald Reagan as a witness at Mr. Poindexter's trial.

LEAD: Industrial production rose a strong four-tenths of a percent in December, bolstered by abnormally cold weather and the end of a strike at the Boeing Company, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

LEAD: The Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency overseeing the bailout of the nation's savings and loan industry, will sell $5 billion of 40-year bonds next week, the Treasury Department announced yesterday.

LEAD: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 525,000 metric tons of United States wheat at subsidized prices for delivery in March under a long-term grain-supply agreement, the Agriculture Department said today. The wheat was sold by four private companies, which will receive subsidies under the department's Export Enhancement Program.

LEAD: A FRIEND has given me a picture book titled ''Tiffany Parties.'' I suspect somebody gave it to him, and I plan to pass it on to a third person, a neighbor who is beside herself with excitement. She can hardly wait, she says, and will keep it right next to a treasured biography of Elsie de Wolfe Mendl.

LEAD: JANUARY is the slack time in my gardening year, and never more so than this year. Prolonged and bitter cold during most of late November and December killed back the heaths I usually count on for mid-winter bloom.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Greek Government has announced that the Albanian Under Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, Sokrat Plaka, would visit Athens on Jan. 26.

LEAD: A message that purported to come from Colombia's drug trafficking cartels said today that the Government had won in the war on drugs and offered to halt illegal activities in exchange for an amnesty.
LEAD: The New York Life Insurance Company, one of the nation's largest life insurers, yesterday named a new management lineup to take charge on Aug. 1.
LEAD: Joining a long list of American advertisers who are waxing nostalgic, Maxwell House coffee is reintroducing the ''Perking Pot'' theme song that it all but abandoned in 1975.

LEAD: A senior Soviet military official said today that political change sweeping Eastern Europe would require a major reorganization of the Warsaw Pact, but he stressed that the military alliance would continue to exist.

LEAD: The Illinois High School Association today restored the 14-0 record to the basketball team at Martin Luther King Jr. High School in Chicago. But a player the association declared ineligible will stay that way.
LEAD: Jim Florio's first public announcement as Governor today declared that his administration would continue a state spending freeze as a first step toward addressing a growing budget shortfall.
LEAD: Mel Most, a former foreign correspondent and public-relations agent, died of a heart attack on Jan. 6 at Cabrini Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: John T. Geldermann was re-elected today as chairman of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. He was not challenged in his bid for a second consecutive one-year term.

LEAD: The most popular opposition leader in Myanmar, formerly Burma, was disqualified today from running in elections scheduled for May, Western diplomats said.

LEAD: Animal rights advocates said today that they would go to court to try to prevent the killing of several monkeys that have been the focus of a national debate over the treatment of research animals.

LEAD: Lawrence Clayton Freer Jr., a business executive, died Saturday at Palm Beach Regional Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla., where he had lapsed into a coma after liver failure. He was 69 years old and lived in West Palm Beach.
LEAD: Ron Harper of the Los Angeles Clippers will be sidelined for the rest of the season because of a severe injury to his right knee, the National Basketball Association team said yesterday.

LEAD: For the last 10 years, Managua's hottest New Year's party has been given by the Cubans, celebrating the anniversary of the revolution that brought Fidel Castro to power in 1959 and inspired the Sandinistas' own uprising two decades later.

LEAD: The National Basketball Association said yesterday that it had been notified by the Chicago Bulls that they intended to protest the Knicks' 109-106 victory Monday at Madison Square Garden. The Knicks won the game on a 3-point basket by Trent Tucker with one-tenth of a second remaining.
LEAD: Of all the fighters at the 1988 Olympics, Roy Jones Jr. was regarded as the most talented.
LEAD: Levi Strauss & Company said today that it will close one of three sewing plants in San Antonio in April and lay off 1,100 workers.

LEAD: The value of eating oat bran has been challenged by a small study that found oat fiber no more effective in lowering people's cholesterol levels than foods made from low-fiber refined wheat flour, which produced far fewer unpleasant side effects.

LEAD: In a giddy locker room tonight, the Islanders were trying to put into words their feelings about an improbable and stunning reality. As a result of an astonishing seven-week surge, they are in first place in the Patrick Division, tied with the Devils.
LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany said today that the Germans had no intention of setting off a debate about borders that could undermine peace in Europe.

LEAD: Federal regulators are scheduled to meet on Thursday to determine whether Neil Bush, the President's son, violated Federal banking laws as a board member of a Colorado savings and loan institution that became insolvent.

LEAD: Saying his role as a political outsider was an asset, John Silber, the president of Boston University for 19 years, declared today that he would seek the Democratic nomination for Governor of Massachusetts.
LEAD: America's oil production suffered its biggest single-year decline ever in 1989, falling by more than half a million barrels a day, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.
LEAD: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down for the week that ended yesterday.

LEAD: Detectives investigating the shooting of an off-duty police officer in Brooklyn on Tuesday night were left with more questions than answers yesterday as the officer remained in a coma at Kings County Hospital Center, police officials said.

LEAD: The Government-owned Export-Import Bank of Japan, whose principal mission is to help heavily indebted third world countries build their economies with low-interest loans, is contemplating its first loans to an industrialized country: the United States.
LEAD: Dr. Isabel Beck, a gynecologist and a pioneer in the field of family planning, died Tuesday at her home in New Rochelle, N.Y. She was 91 years old.
LEAD: The new president of Johns Hopkins University is DR. WILLIAM C. RICHARDSON, the provost of Pennsylvania State University. Dr. Richardson will begin work July 1.
LEAD: The chief of state security has resigned after allegations that his agency illegally monitored opposition activities, the Hungarian press agency said today.

LEAD: If the Nets had lost tonight, nobody would have wanted to spend much time around Bill Fitch. The Nets' coach spent 10 minutes shouting at his team following its loss to Portland on Sunday. Then on Tuesday, Fitch put his club through a grueling three-hour practice.

LEAD: In response to a note to President Bush asking for some comments about Marlin Fitzwater, the President typed this note in the White House study. The Scowcroft Award that he mentions is named after the national security adviser, who likes his Oval Office naps. The award is given to the White House official who can fall asleep in the most embarrassing situation with no remorse.
LEAD: Yuzuru Abe, a Japanese steel industry executive, died of liver failure on Sunday at his home in Tokyo. He was 73 years old.

LEAD: A few people convicted of misdemeanors in Marquette County have been handed knitting needles and told by a local judge, Patricia Micklaw, to knit away their debt to society. With yarn donated by a church, the offenders are knitting afghans, scarves, mittens and the like for the needy.

LEAD: Bozell yesterday announced a restructuring of its European operations. Roger Neill, the deputy chairman of WCRS Worldwide, now part of Eurocom WCRS Della Femina Ball Ltd., will join Bozell as chief executive of Bozell Europe, effective Feb. 15. Winston Fletcher, chairman of DFSD Bozell in London, was appointed chairman of Bozell Europe.
LEAD: Don Shula, the Miami Dolphins' coach, has agreed to a three-year contract extension, The Palm Beach Post reported yesterday. Shula's current contract expires in six weeks.
LEAD: Dr. Edward W. Strong, chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley in the early 1960's, died of cancer Saturday at his home in Berkeley. He was 88 years old.
LEAD: ''The Republicans,'' Ronald Reagan once declared, ''are the party of July Fourth and the Democrats are the party of April 15.''

LEAD: Public performances of chamber music these days seldom take place in chambers of the size for which much of the music was crafted, and when they do, adjustments are necessary. Accustomed to having to project into the void of a small or even large concert hall, performers must scale down their sound a bit, and listeners, used to straining to hear a wee distant sound, must prepare for the immediacy and sheer volume of the close encounter.

LEAD: Leading figures in South Africa's black nationalist movement began a meeting here today amid signs that they are divided over ways to respond to the increased flexibility of the Pretoria Government under President F. W. de Klerk.

LEAD: Using a genetically engineered protein, Swiss researchers have succeeded in getting nerves in severed spinal cords in rats to grow again. The finding could ultimately lead to new clinical treatments to repair nerves damaged from accidents, strokes and a wide variety of degenerative nervous system diseases.

LEAD: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. asked the Exxon Corporation today to provide $20.4 million more to help assess the damage to Alaska's Prince William Sound caused by oil spilled from the Exxon Valdez last March.
LEAD: Despite a broad-based slowdown in the personal computer market, the Microsoft Corporation today reported its best financial results ever.

LEAD: Following the death two weeks ago of its founder, W. B. Doner, W. B. Donor & Company has formally established operating committees in its Detroit and Baltimore offices. LEAD: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo may be guilty of some sins of omission in his proposed budget, but not of commission.

LEAD: ANTIQUES shows are invariably made memorable by the regal objects antiques dealers present. LEAD: Disaster is a timely teacher. The oil spill that has raised havoc at the nature sanctuary around Pralls Island in the Arthur Kill presents a costly lesson in ways to prevent and deal with such destruction. Beyond that it carries a lesson about ways to deal with nature - and the ways nature deals with itself.

LEAD: From some quarters, there was predictable praise yesterday for Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez's bold move to gain some control over the hiring of local superintendents. From likely critics of the plan, the reaction was surprisingly restrained.

LEAD: Gary Carter three-putted the 13th hole in the third round of the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic today, then announced: ''I'm very happy. I'm very excited. I'm thrilled to death. I'm looking forward to it.''
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THERE is near unanimity, it seems, in the lessons of the Campeau Corporation. After last week's bankruptcy filing by two of the company's department store subsidiaries, it is almost as hard to find anyone who has not sworn off greed and excess as it was to find anyone who admitted losing money in the stock market crash of 1987.
LEAD: Alison Webb Hunter and Cary Nicholas Potter Jr. were married yesterday at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan, Conn., by the Rev. Roland M. Jones.

LEAD: Perhaps it is because its sand-colored stone buildings so tidily fit the popular notion of the ideal campus that Yale University in New Haven seems so familiar, even to the first-time visitor. Or perhaps it is because of the pervasive influence of the school that gave the world ''Doonesbury,'' William F.

LEAD: I am writing this letter with great concern over some of the statements made concerning my actions by a professional social worker by the name of Rosa M. Calderon. In an article concerning the Mount Kisco Hispanic community [''Tensions Rise Over Illegal Hispanic Immigrants,'' Dec. 24] , Ms. Calderon made some inflammatory remarks concerning me.

LEAD: The engagement of Randi Michele Justus to Howard Keith Simon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence J. Simon of Jericho, L.I., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Michael Justus of East Northport, L.I. An August wedding is planned.
LEAD: A music review last Sunday about a concert featuring the violinist Yuri Vodovoz misidentified the city where he lives. It is New York City, not Chicago.

LEAD: TRYING to tie up some loose ends from his last seven years in office, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke offered a progress report this month on ocean dumping, the cleanup ofthe Long Island Sound and an emergency 911 telephone system.

LEAD: MORE than $2.5 million from public and private sources has been spent in the last few years to fix up Market Square, the downtown area of this northern Maine town of 6,700 people. The area is listed on the National Register of Historic Places as a fine example of turn-of-the-century commercial architecture, said Charles Upton, the town's Director of Community
LEAD: I HESITANTLY approach the entrance. I have no experience to help me. This is not one of the learned behaviors that I have repeated often enough to classify as a reflex action.

LEAD: The engagement of Deirdre Jane Slavin to Richard Bates Mitchell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry E. Mitchell of Groton, Mass., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Raymond D. Slavin of Darien, Conn. A July wedding is planned.

LEAD: Storrs Heathcote Lamb and Edward Troutman Cote Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cote of Ligonier, Pa., are engaged, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lawton Storrs Lamb of Katonah, N.Y., have announced. The couple plan to marry in May.

LEAD: AS investigations and lawsuits proceed after the Exxon Corporation's oil spill in the Arthur Kill on Jan. 2, officials here and in Washington say that because of deficiencies in Federal and state laws and regulations that govern oil corporations and pipelines, they would be powerless to avert a similar accident.

LEAD: The recent article on the closing of the Fairleigh S. Dickinson Jr. College of Dental Medicine raises some fundamental questions about the responsibility of a state for encouraging and maintaining private institutions for the benefit of its residents.

LEAD: Like a cobra intent on doing some charming of its own, the clarinetist Paul Green weaved, darted and hovered over his instrument at his recital in Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday evening, conjuring gorgeous sounds. If the gyrations had anything to do with the superb musical results, perhaps other clarinetists should study his choreography.

LEAD: The N.B.A. did a terrific job stopping Jackson and Barkley early with fines. To allow petty betting would surely open a dire Pandora's box of big time gambling in professional and college sports of whose consequences even the most fanatical advocates should shudder. ANTHONY C. E. OKOLO New

LEAD: In the early hours of the day, while life goes on around them, the parents of Ramon Ramos rise from their bed in an empty hospital room, dress, and walk the short distance to the room where their son sleeps.
