Hylfelt, was married yesterday to Mark Stetson Clowes, a son of Annette Foisie of Rowayton, Conn., and Everett Clowes of Norwalk, Conn. The Rev. Francis Geer performed the ceremony at St. Philip's Episcopal Church in the Highlands in Garrison, N
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The J. C. Penney Company is recalling more than 1,000 electric garment steamers that present a possible hazard to users, the Consumer Product Safety Commission says. Consumers reported that a locking mechanism on a steamer plug could be broken during use, releasing hot water and steam.

LEAD: The Talking column on Jan. 14 gave an incorrect telephone number for ordering seedlings and saplings from the Long Island office of the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation. It is (516) 751-7900, ext. 234.

LEAD: If their 1989 performances can be viewed as a prelude, Sid Fernandez and Jose DeLeon could be ready to burst onto the level of virtuoso pitchers this year. A study of 1989 pitching records finds their names dominating various areas. They worked so effectively, in fact, that it would seem that they should have gained more victories.
LEAD: IN THE FACE OF DEATH By Peter Noll. Translated by Hans Noll. 254 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

LEAD: Pittsburgh, one of the Big East Conference's dominant teams for three years, hadn't won a conference game this season. But Bobby Martin blocked that failure out of his mind before the Panthers' game against Seton Hall today.
LEAD: Acrylic is still a word that's short on cachet. But reformulated under names like Cashmink, Cashmaire or Cashmore, the fiber is turning up in some of the best places.

LEAD: To the Sports Editor In the midst of the recriminations thrown right and left about the Giants' overtime loss to the Rams, a couple of vital points have not been mentioned in any of the press reports I read. Forget the disputed pass-interference penalty against Sheldon White in overtime. That can be argued from now until doomsday without a resolution.

LEAD: A high school senior who was arrested near the White House on charges of selling the cocaine that President Bush later used as a prop in a nationally televised antidrug speech has been convicted by a Federal jury on three counts of drug distribution.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Fessler of Merrick, L.I., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter, Linda Beth Fessler, and Michael Jeffrey Weinstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Weinstein of Jericho, L.I.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Studin of Orangeburg, N.Y., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Cindi Studin and Dr. Mitchell Russ Berger, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Sanford Berger of Brooklyn. Ms. Studin, a graduate of Ithaca College, is an account executive at PMK Public Relations in New York.

LEAD: After 15 months on the road, the national touring company of ''Driving Miss Daisy,'' starring Julie Harris and Brock Peters and featuring Stephen Root, closes today in New Haven. Charlie Willard, the company manager, will take down the photos in the theater lobby, settle up at the box office, check the company's travel arrangements and head for his cabin in the Adirondacks.

LEAD: ''The Cossacks were indeed warriors - that's part of history - but it's misleading to think of them as mean and nasty people.'' So asserts Anatoly Kvasov, artistic director of the Don Cossacks Song and Dance Company of Rostov, which opens on Tuesday night for a 16-performance engagement at the Neil Simon

LEAD: Senior Bowl North 41, South 0: Louisiana State's Tom Hodson passed for two first-quarter touchdowns and Penn State's Blair Thomas ran for 137 yards, leading the North to victory in the 41st Senior Bowl yesterday at Mobile, Ala. It was the first shutout in Senior Bowl history and the victory cut the South's series lead to 20-18-3.

LEAD: Mrs. P. Peter Sheppe of Scarsdale, N.Y., has announced December wedding plans for her daughter, Laura Elizabeth Sheppe, and Michael Bruce Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald E. Miller of Calabasas, Calif.
LEAD: The New York State School Boards Association filed a lawsuit on Friday challenging a new school district created by the state to accommodate Hasidic children.

LEAD: One disadvantage of owning a camera is that you're out of the picture most of the time. Whenever I look at my family album, I'm struck by the absence of one vital participant - me. But photographers don't have to be missing persons.

LEAD: Syrian troops clashed today with Lebanese Army units loyal to the Christian general, Michel Aoun, in the first such encounter since an Arab-brokered cease-fire last September ended six months of fighting between the two sides.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Absolutely not. As a matter of fact, it made both players' games better. How many players, coaches, managers and most of all fans, bet on games off the books, and nothing happens to them? As long as it doesn't get out of hand, and it gets players pumped up, I'm all for it. RON RICHARDSON Jersey

LEAD: BARBARIANS AT THE GATE The Fall of RJR Nabisco. By Bryan Burrough and John Helyar. Illustrated. 528 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $22.95. TRUE GREED What Really Happened in the Battle for RJR Nabisco. By Hope Lampert. 259 pp. New York: NAL Books/New American Library. $18.95.

LEAD: There is a mysterious juncture early in the career of important composers when all at once they begin speaking in a voice that is theirs and theirs alone. For Mahler, that time came at age 20 in 1880, when he finished ''Das Klagende Lied,'' a large-scale cantata that he submitted to Vienna's Gesellschaft der Musikfreunde in hopes of winning a prize.
LEAD: Greg Foster, ranked as the world's best high hurdler for most of the last decade, is 31 years old and showing little sign of slowing down.

LEAD: Barbara Piasecka Johnson (right, with Lech Walesa), who went to work as a chambermaid after immigrating from Poland in 1968, has doubtless learned a little something about capitalism since she inherited $570 million or so a few years ago. Mrs. Johnson, who married J. Seward Johnson, the Johnson & Johnson heir, three years after going to work in his New Jersey mansion, last year met Mr.

LEAD: Susan Barth and Martin Ehrlich were married last evening at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I., by Rabbi Walter S. Wurzburger. Mrs. Ehrlich, 25 years old, is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Louis Barth of Freehold, N.J. A graduate of George Washington University, she is an employment representative at Simon & Schuster, publishers in New York.

LEAD: The engagement of Carolyn Josephine Nourie to Donald Bernard Aspinall Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Aspinall of Villanova, Pa., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Nourie of Strafford, Pa. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: In the Jan. 7 story covering heating-oil prices [''Price of Heating Oil Prompts an Outcry''] , the paraphrasing of my comments to your reporter incorrectly substituted the word ''oil'' for ''gas'' in describing the effects of interruptible gas supply, thus changing the whole sense of the comment.

LEAD: 20TH CENTURY JOURNEY A Memoir of a Life and the Times. Volume Three: A Native's Return, 1945-1988. By William L. Shirer. Illustrated. 484 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $24.95.

LEAD: In an effort to combat terrorism in Greece, which has been criticized in the West for inadequate security, a parliamentary committee has introduced a bill that would bar news agencies from publicizing statements by terrorist groups.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Reza Derakhshani, who plays tar and sehtar, two varieties of Iranian lute, will perform Persian folk music at the Uris Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art this afternoon at 2:30. Mr. Derakhshani's ensemble includes players of the tar, santur (a hammered dulcimer), kamancheh (a fiddle) and daff (a drum).

LEAD: ISSUES of travel security make everyone uneasy. The yes-no aspect of an airport is an example. At departure, an airport is supposed to lure you in and cosset you into the wonders of travel; at the end of the flight, the arrival airport is supposed to welcome you to the new place and hint at its attractions.

LEAD: Although Poland is the first East European nation since the early postwar years to install a government not dominated by Communists, many Poles are pressing the Solidarity-led Government to hasten political change.
LEAD: In response to the recent article ''Medical Waste Law Survives a Challenge'':

LEAD: Why would a real estate development company invest $40 million to put up a pair of towers containing 325,000 square feet of office space in a city that already has 3.6 million square feet of vacant office space? Three reasons, said Larry Feldman, a partner in Feldman Equities of Lake Success, L.I., which developed the just-completed Stamford Towers project in the business district of Stamford,

LEAD: To the Editor: The readout to the headline ''On the Lam in Old Chicago'' used the word gunsels for gunmen. Some years ago I read that the first use of gunsel was attributed to Max Brand, a successful writer of Western stories and books. After he used gunsel for gunslinger, hordes of pulp writers who had probably never been west of the Hudson, not to speak of the Mississippi, copied this seemingly authentic bit of the real West.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph G. Mack of Garden City, L.I., have announced July wedding plans for their daughter Dr. Denise Marie Mack and James Stewart Fraser, a son of William T. Fraser of Babylon, L.I., and the late Helen Fraser. The prospective bride, 31 years old, is the chief resident in surgery at Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia.

LEAD: Adrienne M. Knoll, a speech writer for Borough President Howard Golden of Brooklyn, and Kenneth Brown, a Brooklyn newspaper editor and publisher, plan to marry in the fall. Ms. Knoll, 29 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Knoll of Coral Springs, Fla., and a graduate of Brown University.

LEAD: Behind the arrests of eight military men in the killing of six Jesuit priests and two women in El Salvador lies an extraordinary campaign of pleas to the Bush Administration by church groups and of pressure on the Salvadoran Government by American officials demanding a full investigation.

LEAD: It is becoming a regular reflex to check the Nikkei 225 - Tokyo's closely watched stock index - early in the evening in New York. Since the beginning of the year, it has been plunging with regularity and has helped bring down many other major markets.

LEAD: Deborah Jane Hall and James Cameron Woods were married yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in North Haven, Conn., by the Rev. John H. Elledge Jr. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Almon Blakeslee Hall of Wallingford, Conn., and the late Mr. Hall. Mr. Woods is the son of Col. James R. Woods, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: January means winter term and almost no one is on the campus, but more than 150 Wellesley College students are getting some education about life after graduation. The students are participating in the annual Shadow Program, which enables a woman to follow an alumna in the field of her choice for a day in January.
LEAD: Peter Jacobsen is determined to put past disappointments behind him as he tries to win his first PGA Tour tournament in six years at the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Donald M. Fordyce of Darien, Conn., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Ann Fordyce, to Scott Kevin Barrett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James D. Barrett of Cherry Hill, N.J., and Castleton Corners, Vt. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: Suzanne Whitsun Brask, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Brask of South Orange, N.J., was married there yesterday at the Episcopal Church of St. Andrew and Holy Communion to Robert Frederick Learsch, the son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Robert Learsch of New Monmouth, N.J. The Rev. Robert B. Wardrop officiated.

LEAD: Meryl Streep acts silly, Tom Cruise looks grungy and Danny DeVito is the voice of reason; this season's films have been a parade of big-name stars acting against type. And while Ms. Streep is hilarious as the husband-stealing romance writer draped in acres of pink satin in ''She-Devil,'' and Mr. Cruise flawless as the paraplegic Vietnam veteran in ''Born on the Fourth of July,'' their performances are enhanced by an undeniable layer of surprise.

LEAD: WHAT if life had always been measured by the decade? To express it in contemporary terms, 100 years ago the Divisionist 80's were giving way to the Symbolist 90's, nostalgia for the lost Impressionist 70's was doubtless brewing, and the artists may already have known to call themselves Post-Impressionists.

LEAD: Hard-line and liberal Communists clashed today at the opening of a pivotal party congress over how quickly to renounce their 45-year guaranteed monopoly on power, and the hard-liners succeeded in delaying a vote on democratic changes.

LEAD: The Millstone 3 nuclear plant gets high marks for lower-than-average radiation levels, effective daily management, and ''safe and conservative plant operations,'' in a new evaluation by the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

LEAD: Rabbi and Mrs. Howard S. Joseph of Montreal have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leora H. Joseph, to Michael Wechsler, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Morris Wechsler of Montreal. A July wedding is planned. Miss Joseph, 21 years old, is a senior at Barnard College. Mr. Wechsler, 21, a magna cum laude graduate of Harvard University, will enter the McGill University Medical School in September.

LEAD: To the Editor: Like Leslie Maitland's parents, who returned to Freiburg, West Germany (''A Bittersweet Pilgrimage,'' Travel, Dec. 17), my wife and I were invited to return to my native town, Vallendar, after 51 years.

LEAD: JOHN L. LAHEY, president of Quinnipiac College in Hamden, recalls that in 1988, when the school began raising money for its Echlin Health Sciences Center, its only fund-raising experience was a $1 million campaign 10 years earlier that fell 25 percent short of its goal.

LEAD: Whatever Robert Ashley does, it's extreme. His compositions have always tested audience endurance, from the amplified shouting over roaring electronic distortion of his early ''Wolfman'' (1964), to the protracted television operas of the 1980's, with his own mumbling monologues, rockish percussion and vocal interjections and cocktail-jazzish piano filigrees.
LEAD: Jill Blair Akin and J. Brett Schulman were married last evening at the Pierre in New York by Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel.

LEAD: INTEREST has been so strong in a state plan to buy hundreds of condominiums to rent or sell to moderate- and low-income families that officials at the Department of Housing have had to add more sessions this week to explain details of the plan.
LEAD: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. Classical
LEAD: Concerning ''Nursing Homes Pressed on AIDS Policy,'' (Dec. 17): If by chance nursing homes expand and have enough beds for AIDS patients, are they equipped to take care of those individuals?
LEAD: In an unusually political comment, the Barry prosecutor said the case might be a ''catharsis'' bringing the District of Columbia new leaders who will fight drugs. Page 26.

LEAD: Words, as every poet knows, have a music of their own, especially when spoken sonorously by gifted performers. So why paint the lily? Yet the wedding of words to music is almost as old as poetry itself, and when the collaboration is between geniuses, even though centuries apart - as when Mendelssohn underscored ''A Midsummer Night's

LEAD: The Southern New England Telephone Company will test six new services in three Connecticut communities, but will not any time soon introduce the caller identification system, which allows people to see before they answer the number of the telephone from which the call was made, a spokesman said last week.
LEAD: After 12 seasons, Tony Dorsett's career is ending where it began.

LEAD: VOICES IN THE EVENING. By Natalia Ginzburg. Translated by D. M. Low. (Arcade/Little, Brown, $16.95.) Natalia Ginzburg has been recognized for many decades as a major force in Italian letters, but it is only in recent years that her work has begun to be read and appreciated in the English-speaking world.

LEAD: Mr and Mrs. Carlisle Ragland Davis Jr. of Birmingham, Moch., and New York Have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizebeth Pyper Davis to Hartley Raymond Rogers, a son of Prof. Hartley Rogers Jr. and Dr. Adrianne E. Rogers of Winchester, Mass. A june wedding in planned.
LEAD: A couple are being held on child-abuse charges after 20 neighbors angered by mistreatment of the couple's children surrounded their home and threw stones at it.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Arnold S. Cohen of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Loryn R. Cohen and Michael Lawrence Kass, the son of Harriet Marcus and Dr. Alfred M. Kass, both of Columbus, Ohio. Ms. Cohen, 24 years old, is a graduate of Tulane University and a marketing associate at Bear, Stearns & Company in New York.

LEAD: Is Irony Affirmative Action? According to David Mamet, American Jews have never enjoyed any of the ethnic compensations that are so much on our minds today - unless we accept irony as an affirmative action. This is from ''Some Freaks,'' a collection of his essays (Viking).

LEAD: Considering the rocky relations between Houston police officers and their last chief, Elizabeth M. Watson (left) may have taken the comments of the head of a patrolmen's group there as a compliment. ''I can't think of anything bad to say about her,'' he said. If, as expected, she is confirmed, Ms.

LEAD: Dr. Hugh C. M. Ross, a choral director who, as conductor of the Schola Cantorum of New York, worked with some of the greatest figures in 20th-Century music, died of a heart attack at his home in Manhattan yesterday. He was 91 years old.

LEAD: Jean Marie Hanavan and Christopher John Kelly were married yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Joseph-on-the-Brandywine in Greenville, Del., by Msgr. Francis J. Evans. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Taylor W. Hanavan of Wilmington, Del., and Northfield, Mass. The bridegroom is a son of Dr.
LEAD: A Federal appellate court has affirmed Alabama's right to display the Confederate flag on the top of its Capitol, ruling that it does not violate the Constitution.

LEAD: It turned out to be an up week for the American dollar. While it was buffeted by news of the jump in the November trade deficit, the dollar was pushed higher by the growing belief that the Federal Reserve, concerned about inflation, would not be lowering interest rates any time soon. Firm interest rates tend to support the dollar.

LEAD: A special internship program for those interested in museum careers is to begin in September at the National Gallery of Art in Washington. The two internships in the program, which is underwritten by a grant from the Southwestern Bell Foundation, will be open to black, Hispanic and American Indian applicants.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: MONDAY: An Office of Technology Assessment advisory committee considers recommendations to revamp the securities and futures industries. TUESDAY: Congress reconvenes with a capital gains tax cut on its agenda. The House Banking Committee resumes hearings on troubled thrifts. The Resolution Trust Corporation auctions $5 billion in 40-year bonds - the longest maturity on Government securities since 1960.

LEAD: Mr. Batcheller has painted a lovely picture of a nature lover out for a quiet morning walk, not a picture of hunting at all. Those of us who do endeavor to enjoy a marsh at dawn during hunting season, however, take our lives in our hands. KATHY MCINERNEY Portland, Me.

LEAD: PETER S. KALIKOW did not want to spend any more time going through the complex approval process necessary to build a 29-story office building in lower Manhattan. So he decided to go the easier route and build a 58-story hotel instead.

LEAD: THE Poet's Voice, launched its 12th season with the first of six readings in November at the Ferguson Library in Stamford. Five more readings are scheduled to take place at other Fairfield County libraries this year.

LEAD: The Defense Department said today that it was investigating an incident in which two women in the Army refused an order to drive other soldiers into downtown Panama City early on Dec. 20, the day that United States troops invaded Panama.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Anthony W. Ruggiero of Princeton, N.J., have announced July wedding plans for their daughter Alicia M. Ruggiero and Jonathan I. Brodsky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert G. Brodsky of Boca Raton, Fla.

LEAD: There was not just one bet between Barkley and Jackson. The first came during last season's playoffs. Then there was a series of three during the Jan. 10 game, each coming before critical situations. Betting can become infectious and contagious. The $5,000 fines to players earning megabucks has little impact.
LEAD: If Sugar Ray Leonard is really determined to give up his World Boxing Council supermiddleweight title, he has a fight on his hands, against the W.B.C. president, Jose Sulaiman.

LEAD: SINCE dawn, Taylor Dudley of Boston Beach, Jamaica, has been at work turning a pig and plenty of hot peppers into jerk, the island's devilishly hot answer to barbecue. At outdoor pits like Mr. Dudley's, roadside stands and restaurants throughout Jamaica, pork, plus chicken, conch and native fish are given the distinctive jerk treatment.

LEAD: The Bronx Opera Company, one of New York's many small but inventive troupes, has built its reputation largely on presentations of operatic rarities - works like Nielsen's ''Masquerade,'' Smetana's ''Secret'' and Offenbach's ''Bluebeard.'' But the company also edges toward the standard repertory every now and then, and for the opening production of its 22d season, it offered a lively staging of an Offenbach favorite, ''La Belle Helene.
LEAD: FEMINISM AND PSYCHOANALYTIC THEORY By Nancy J. Chodorow. 286 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $25.

LEAD: P. T. BARNUM: The Legend and the Man. By A. H. Saxon. (Columbia University, $32.95.) Ah, yezz. P. T. Barnum - Phineas Taylor, by name. Connecticut boy, born and bred; staunch believer in ''a cheerful Christianity.'' Smart fellow, and clever, too. Had a wicked sense of humor for practical jokes - those Yankees weren't all glum and gloomy.
LEAD: The space shuttle Columbia landed safely in the darkness of early morning today, ending the longest and one of the most successful rescue missions in the history of the shuttle program.
LEAD: ESCAPES By Joy Williams. 168 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $18.95.

Cuomo proposed deferring the New York income tax cut last week. The Republicans, who signaled long ago that they were eager to exploit the tax issue, seemed engaged in a contest to construct the least complimentary metaphor about the
LEAD: The whispers among Chinese officials these days are all about power struggles or major reshuffles in the leadership.
LEAD: Proceeds from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund drive are used to help people in the city's five boroughs, but there are no limits to how far from New York the donations may come.

LEAD: In their never-ending quest for inspiration, designers often rifle through the past. Anything is fair game. Done well, this delving into the archives results in new clothes with familiar, even classic connotations. While these designs may be redolent of nostalgia, they are modern in line. This season, for instance, the French house of Hermes dipped into its horsy heritage to come up with racy 1990's styles.

LEAD: To the Editor: A warning to your readers: Despite all the mental gymnastics you go through to anticipate that the price that car rental agencies quote you will be the price ultimately charged, you cannot anticipate everything.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: IN designing a new home for the Katonah Gallery - now to be known as the Katonah Museum of Art - Edward Larrabee Barnes was on familiar territory.

LEAD: THERE were no postholiday doldrums at La Rondinella, and no wonder. Some of the best food in the Five Towns is found at this gracious Italian restaurant in Woodmere. There is a Mediterranean feel and spirit at this simply appointed spot with its creamy walls, mirrors, wood lattices and fresh flowers.
LEAD: The engagement of Andrea Ilona de Cholnoky to Scott Curtis Wilson has been announced by the future bride's mother, Ingrid de Cholnoky of Greenwich, Conn. A March wedding is planned.
LEAD: Sean Rooks and Jud Buechler scored 18 points each today as Arizona held off Oklahoma, 78-74, extending the nation's longest home-court winning streak to 41 games.

LEAD: Rupert Murdoch, the Australian-born entrepreneur, announced today that his company had bought 50 percent of two independent Hungarian newspapers, making him the first Westerner to make a significant investment in Eastern Europe's emerging free press.

LEAD: In a sport where 30 is old and 40 is ancient, George Foreman beat the odds -and Gerry Cooney - last week. Foreman (above, delivering a punch), the oldest and heaviest of heavyweights, was so impressive as he knocked Cooney out in the second round that sportswriters, who had joked that the 253-pound Foreman would be ordering food between rounds, turned to speculating that the 41-year-old former champion might make a fit opponent for the current titleholder, 22-year-old Mike Tyson.

LEAD: The Texas Rangers said Pete Incaviglia, their slugging outfielder, had signed a one-year-contract with the club. . . . Bubby Brister, the Pittsburgh Steeler quarterback, had minor surgery Friday to repair a joint at the top of his left shoulder that was injured in an off-season weight-lifting session.

LEAD: An 1890's brewhouse in Middletown, N.Y., abandoned for more than half a century, is being redeveloped into 53 moderate and low-rent apartments. The three-story structure at one time produced ''Orange County - The King of All Beers - The Cream of All Ales,'' popular in the area until the mid-30's. Local historians have cited the brewhouse, a three-story brick building with an ornate facade, as a good example of a type of local brewery that flourished in the Hudson and Mohawk

LEAD: August wedding plans for Melissa Ellen Zeidman and S. Maynard Bronstein, a son of Patricia Honeyman of Oakton, Va., and Dr. Seymour Bronstein of Hazelton, Pa., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Howard Zeidman of Cherry Hill and Harvey Cedars, N.J.

LEAD: I am not a hunter, but Gordon Batcheller's descriptions of nature are wonderful. However, wouldn't it be nicer to shoot these creatures with his camera and let the scene remain for others to appreciate? HAL M. LEWIS New York, N.Y.

LEAD: KAREN HILL has been struggling for more than a year here to find developers who will accept financial and zoning incentives in return for building the subsidized and market-rate housing called for in a 1986 Federal desegregation court order. Now Ms. Hill, the director of the Yonkers Fair Housing Office, has given the first indication that a long stalemate may be ending.
LEAD: He spent a full four years in college, but with three major sports to distract him he didn't get a degree.

LEAD: Rather than discussing what the next bet should be, Barkley and Jackson should concentrate on the game and ways to help their teams win. A coach with any respect for his team would have benched and/or suspended the player for several weeks, unless, the word team really does have an ''I'' in it.

LEAD: Freehold $223,500 1 Tudor Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 22-year-old split level; c/a, 2-car garage, finished basement, patio; taxes $2,954. Montague $105,000 Riverview Way 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 9-year-old ranch; pool, eat-in kitchen, full basement, brick fireplace; taxes $2,124.
LEAD: S. Fannie Simon, a retired teacher and labor leader, died of a ruptured appendix Wednesday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. She was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Administration officials said today they strongly suspected that Israel has sent cluster bombs to Ethiopia. They said there were unconfirmed reports that the Soviet-backed Marxist Government in Addis Ababa has already used the weapons against rebels in the northern part of the country.

LEAD: THE former owner of Breakaway in Fairfield has gone south, but not far. East Coast, Marty Levine's new restaurant, is just over the town line, in Westport, in a building that once housed Beeksteak Charlie's.
LEAD: A bank robbery suspect and an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation died in a shootout here Friday night after the agent and two others had burst into the suspect's house.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: U.S. Warnings On Visiting 4 Countries

LEAD: I SIT in the back row of the Seaport deli, that twilight hub of East Setauket, alternately reading a newspaper, picking at a plate of fried seafood and surveying the comings and goings of teen-agers who casually drift in and out.

LEAD: Almost everyone doodles, but not everyone doodles his way into something called a ''Polygonzo,'' a multidimensional sculpture cube that has become a chic executive toy, as addictive as worry beads. It can be twisted, folded and pulled into 20 geometric shapes, almost every letter of the alphabet and numerous other odd and wonderful configurations.

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.
LEAD: SO, you want to sell your business. How do you go about it? Very carefully and quietly, caution the experts.

LEAD: The turmoil in Eastern Europe serves as a reminder that the Czarist regime produced remarkable talent at the bridge table as well as the chess board. Half a century ago London was full of bridge luminaries who were born on the fringes of the Russian Empire or in areas that have since been behind the Iron Curtain.

LEAD: This could be the story of the couple who cried ''betrothed!'' In their 12 years of unformalized domesticity, Mick Jagger and Jerry Hall (right) have issued, along with two children, numerous announcements and hints that marriage was imminent. In 1983, Mr. Jagger said they would be married ''any day now.

LEAD: Winter sales racks have been overgrazed. Spring merchandise is just starting to trickle in. But the fashion urge cannot be stilled. One way to satisfy it right now is with one of the new vests that department stores and boutiques are stocking. In ethnic or vintage materials, they lend a one-of-a-kind look to wardrobe basics.

LEAD: THE rash of news about the failure of some sponsors to meet their financial obligations to New York City co-ops raises the question of what tenant-shareholders and board members can do to recoup lost income and safeguard the financial integrity of their buildings.

LEAD: When Phil Rizzuto was told to dust off his tuxedo in order to be properly attired while receiving the William J. Slocum Award for long and meritorious service to baseball at the New York baseball writers' dinner tonight, he sounded confused.
LEAD: Black hands met white hands on Thursday as Tommie Stewart, an actress, moved through an auditorium of college students, touching and hugging them before she went onstage.

LEAD: THERE'S A SELFISH SIDE TO THE project, as even Gerry Holzman would admit. ''It's an opportunity to do just about anything that a woodcarver can do,'' he says. But all in all, the creation of the Empire State Carousel must qualify as a labor of love. ''Making a living museum of New York's history and culture,'' is how Holzman describes it.

LEAD: Imagine receiving national acclaim as a painter at the tender age of 22, only to slip into the shadows of a fickle, mostly uncaring art world for the rest of one's long and prolific career. Such has been the discouraging story for Jack Levine, one of the foremost Social Realists of his generation, a satirist whose gritty urban iconography and brassy style have often led to comparisons with Goya and Daumier.
LEAD: UPON its return this week, the Senate will immediately face the moment of truth on strengthening the Clean Air Act, a goal that has eluded Congress for a decade.

LEAD: For This Week: Indoors, start seed of long season annuals such as snapdragons, impatiens, petunias and geraniums. Check house plants for mealybugs; examine jade plants, look under leaves of streptocarpus, African violets and other gesneriads, also check cactuses to be sure insects are not hiding near the bases of the spines.
LEAD: FRIDAY Baseball
LEAD: PIANISTS and violinists are rarely in short supply, but next weekend it will be the wind players who will be in the spotlight at chamber and orchestral concerts around the state.

LEAD: Though rap is often seen as a monolithic force, in reality it's a genre jam-packed with contentious styles and ideologies. Two terrific new albums - from the historyoriented Jungle Brothers and the commercially minded Young M. C. - show how different rap's subcultures can be.

LEAD: Some furniture and objects are forever classics. Take, for instance, a wicker chair or a child's cradle. For generations, both have had a specific place and purpose in the home. Now, as more and more architects and interior designers are manufacturing their own furniture, many are looking at the classics for inspiration.
LEAD: Billy Martin, who died in a Christmas night automobile accident in front of his home, has left an estate that legal papers say is worth less than $100,000.

LEAD: Anybody want to buy a house? Or a seat? With share prices weakening last week as interest rates rose and housing starts hit a six-year low, the most depressing news at the New York Stock Exchange may have been the year's first sale of a seat in that august body. The price: $390,000, the lowest tab since 1985.

LEAD: In the most open challenge thus far to the Soviet Communist Party's hold on power, dissidents from 78 cities and more than 100 political organizations gathered in Moscow to debate how to create a viable political opposition.

LEAD: AN exhibition of Latin American art is not the rarity it was, even a decade ago. Only last year, a major peak was scaled when the Bronx Museum of the Arts mounted its ''Latin American Spirit: Art and Artists in the United States, 1920-1970,'' which is now visiting the Vero Beach Center for the Arts in Florida.

LEAD: To the Editor: Susan Jacoby's ''Museums Without Tears'' (Travel, Dec. 17) offers several excellent tips on ways to do more than rush to the major attractions in some of the world's great museums. Here is another:

LEAD: To the Editor: William E. Schmidt's article (''On the Lam in Chicago,'' Travel, Nov. 19) on gang landmarks has some notable omissions. Both the city map and itinerary of the Untouchable Tours ignore Al Capone's adjoining West Side suburban Cicero headquarters, the hotel-restaurant on the south side of Cermak Road (22d Street) just west of Cicero Avenue, where the most awesome machine-gun shelling in gangland history took place when Bugs Moran led a motorcade attack, which

LEAD: MOST of the county's choirs gave their winter concerts last month and are now preparing their spring programs. The Ossining Choral Society, on the other hand, has chosen to wait for the holiday bustle to fade before beginning its 53d season with a performance of Haydn's ''Creation.''

LEAD: While efforts to restore clean air to the United States have met with partial success, there is a far greater ecological disaster brewing in Eastern Europe, a report on worldwide air pollution said today.

LEAD: Q. I own a year-round home in the mountains that has a 3-foot-high crawl space. The floor of the crawl space is bare earth. There are eight vents to keep air circulating, but in the summer condensation accumulates. One contractor told me to put plastic on the ground to prevent moisture from rising, another said I should install a fan to circulate the air.

LEAD: As a former cancer patient, I can identify with Anatole Broyard's feelings of buoyancy while undergoing treatment of his illness (About Men: ''Intoxicated by My Illness,'' Nov. 12). During chemotherapy treatment, which left me bald, weak and loaded with mouth sores, I continued to play sports, to the amazement of my friends.

LEAD: The new Age of Austerity may have begun, but the back-to-back preview parties for the Winter Antiques Show were pretty grand. The show is still the premier event for antiques collectors and connoisseurs as well as interior decorators and their clients.

LEAD: Bedford, N.Y. $455,000 Cartway Lane West 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 21-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, fireplace, family room, pool, 1.4 acres; taxes $6,289. Katonah, N.Y. $321,500 28 The Terrace 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 99-year-old farmhouse; fireplace, den, terraced backyard; taxes $3,852.

LEAD: I have not walked in Isabel Davis's shoes, nor am I in the business of judging the circumstances under which consenting adults should or should not have intercourse (Hers: ''Sixteen - The Third Time Around,'' Dec. 17). But why did she take on faith the assurance of this stranger that he was ''just back from a year meditating with a Buddhist monk?
LEAD: Murdoch's Hungarian Move
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In preparation for a 14-day trip on the West Coast earlier this season, Coach Phil Jackson of the Chicago Bulls spent an afternoon in a bookstore. He bought a novel for each of his players, ranging from Elmore Leonard's ''Glitz,'' to ''Things Fall Apart,'' by Chinua Achebe.

LEAD: NOW that fish is no longer something that makes a grudging appearance at the table once a week, ways of serving it are becoming increasingly exotic. For people keeping an eye on their salt and fat intake, a touch of spice can make all the difference.

LEAD: The five victorious World War II Allies are putting on the peacemaker's mantle that the United Nations gave them more than 40 years ago, a mantle they have had difficulty wearing until recently, specialists on the United Nations say.
LEAD: Pizzocheri is a moderately well-known form of Italian pasta. What distinguishes it from those that are best known is its predominant grain, buckwheat.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: THE summer I was 19 my friend Razel had a job assisting the social director of a nursing home on Riverside Drive in Manhattan. A whirlwind of energy and optimism, she would go in with a guitar and try to cheer up the residents with a song. Then she would take the time to chat about their grandchildren or perhaps about their younger, stronger days.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: With his players trailing Kansas by 3 points, having played as if they had seen ghosts, Norm Stewart, the Missouri coach, sat his rattled Tigers down at halftime and told them to get a grip on themselves. If anyone should be nervous, he told them, it's the visiting Jayhawks.

LEAD: THE best news for the Dunbar Apartments in Central Harlem may be the city-sponsored rehabilitation activity around it, which gives a lift to the area's rental market and helps secure the Dunbar's future.
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL/3-20
LEAD: The Republican Party enjoyed virtual parity in 1989 with the Democrats in the loyalty of Americans for the first time since just after World War II ended.

LEAD: LONE TREE: A True Story of Murder in America's Heartland. By Bruce Brown. (Crown, $17.95.) Shortly before noon on Dec. 9, 1985, Dale Burr, an Iowa farmer, grabbed his shotgun, entered the kitchen where his wife of 40 years was baking cookies and shot her through the heart. He then drove into town, where he killed his banker.
LEAD: Gov. Michael N. Castle has a problem: scientific studies saying that people who live in Delaware are among the least healthy in the nation.

LEAD: OVER the years, when whites in South Africa have made their arguments against black rule, the most common contention has been that blacks are not ready for the responsibilities of power. But beginning in the 1950's, these same whites have supported a Government that has banned, imprisoned or driven into exile most of the blacks who would have been most likely to play that role.

LEAD: When all goes smoothly, the Metropolitan Opera's uncut version of ''Porgy and Bess'' runs to a Wagnerian length of nearly four hours. All did not go smoothly at the Thursday evening performance: a stage elevator malfunctioned between the Kittiwah Island and Catfish Row scenes in the second act, forestalling Bess's return to Porgy after a tropical dalliance with

LEAD: Right field is still his position of choice, but Dave Winfield, the 38-year-old Yankee slugger who missed last season after back surgery and watched as Jesse Barfield took over his familiar ground, has made it clear that he is a team player first and last.

LEAD: IN ''The Roar of the Greasepaint, the Smell of the Crowd'' - you will be subjected to the title just once - an elitist (Sir) and a commoner (Cocky) play the Game (of life, of course), or something like that.
LEAD: the others have finished their games early and gone off to the movies, the bridge table or the bar, there you are slaving over a minuscule-advantage end game.

LEAD: Lisa Beth Joseph and Daniel Mark Zelson were married last evening at the Burden Mansion in New York by Rabbi Herbert Brockman. The bride is the daughter of Carole Young of Westport, Conn., and New York and William K. Joseph of New York. Her husband is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Zelson of Orange,

LEAD: Deafening in their silence are the Knicks and the 76ers. Jackson and Barkley turned their team's efforts into a game of one-on-one. They bet - gambled - put the outcome of the game (perhaps the season?) and the fortunes of their teammates on the line. Yet neither team, nor its management, said or did anything.
LEAD: ''There were growing calls for a seizure of power by force.'' - President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, speaking of unrest in Azerbaijan. [1:6.]

LEAD: The Ice Capades 50th-Anniversary show, which opened on Friday night for a two-week run at Madison Square Garden, gets off to a surprisingly listless start. But just as one begins to despair of seeing the good, old-fashioned cornball ice dancing on which the show has built its reputation, along comes a second act that lives up to all the hype.

LEAD: Even though American movies have scrutinized the Vietnam War, art about the conflict has been scarce, perhaps because it has taken many years for artists to come to terms with what happened there. But such art exists, and some of it movingly incorporates the contradictions that permeated that era.

LEAD: Amy Batterson Wall, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hally Peter Wall of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church to Daryl Gene Nelson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Nelson of Naples, Fla. Bishop George P. Mellick Belshaw, the Bishop of New Jersey, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev.

LEAD: Helen Dow Matheson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Tompkins Matheson of The Plains, Va., was married there yesterday to David Shelburne Hilliard, a son of Landon Hilliard of Oyster Bay Cove, L.I., and Mary Eichert Hilliard of New York. The Rev. S. Neale Morgan officiated at Grace Episcopal Church.

LEAD: On Friday afternoon, David A. Clarke, the chairman of the City Council here, said with evident anxiety, ''The most important thing I want to project to the people of Washington and across the nation is that this city is under control.''

LEAD: Eight pairs of professional dancers did slow turns on a shiny black floor at the Palladium nightclub to the thump of tropical music, the right thigh of each man between his partner's legs as their hips swiveled in unison. Astride their partners' right knees, the women occasionally performed deep back bends followed by several fast pirouettes that set their miniskirts flying.

LEAD: Bill Shoemaker, in his farewell ride to Florida racing, slipped Beau Genius through an opening in the final yards to score a dramatic and sentimental victory today in the $65,500 Hallandale Handicap at Gulfstream Park.

LEAD: Aris Yunusov, an Azerbaijani political centrist who spent the predawn hours walking through the streets of Baku, said today that army and Interior Ministry troops converged on the city from the north, south and west, with the most intensive battles in the north.

LEAD: The program notes for the concert of five premieres by the National Orchestral Association at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening offered a freewheeling mix of analysis, apologia, boosterism and criticism. Of Frederick Bianchi's studiedly amorphous ''Rauschenberg Variations,'' readers were informed, evidently on behalf of the composer, ''As long as the performers are honest and try their hardest, any performance - whether by an amateur group or by the world's most virtuosic orchestra - is correct.

LEAD: It was spring in January last week - almost. Temperatures danced in the 50's and 60's, bringing fashion out from behind the smothering cloaks of winter. Women appeared in layers of sportswear - jackets, sweaters, skirts and blouses, some of it in lightweight winter white. And lightweight seasonless gabardine suits and Chanel tweeds were seen everywhere.
LEAD: A picture caption on Dec. 31 with an article about New Orleans misidentified the saxophonist playing at the Maple Leaf Bar. He was John Hart.

LEAD: Michael Jordan is on his way to a fourth consecutive National Basketball Association scoring title. The Chicago Bulls' guard has led the league in steals. He has won the slam dunk contest. He has been voted the N.B.A.'s most valuable player and its best defensive player.

LEAD: Filmed at the medical intensive care unit of Boston's Beth Israel Hospital over a period of six weeks, Frederick Wiseman's ''Near Death'' looks unblinkingly at patients and their families and doctors facing the end of life. The six-hour black-and-white documentary will be shown on the Public Broadcasting

LEAD: STORIES FROM THE STREETS ARE RICH WITH THE improbable. Here, for instance, crossing Columbus Avenue and coming into view, is a man with a preposterous past. When fortune attended, he ran a union; when it was wanting, he cracked safes. At 35, he declared himself an actor. Up to that point, he had emoted anonymously - into a microphone announcing bus routes.
LEAD: USAir Flight 188 from Washington to Cleveland had a perfect record in November. It was never on time.
LEAD: CROWN molding is installed around the top of a room to conceal the seam between the walls and ceiling. Used tastefully, it can greatly enhance a room's appearance.
LEAD: FREUD'S VIENNA AND OTHER ESSAYS By Bruno Bettelheim. 282 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.

LEAD: American Ballet Theater celebrated its 50th anniversary last Sunday night with a gala performance at the Metropolitan Opera House. A champagne supper dance for 1,200 guests followed in a heated tent over the terrace pool on the north side of the Opera House. The Henry Moore sculpture ''Reclining Figure'' separated the two dance floors.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: When Lee P. Brown walks into the red-brick Police Headquarters building tomorrow morning to be sworn in as New York City's 36th police commissioner, he will be taking charge of an embattled department struggling against an explosion of violent crime with a shrinking force.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Murphy of Wethersfield, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter Marguerite Amelia Murphy to Samuel Baumgarten Solomon, the son of Dr. Jolane Solomon and Bernard Solomon of Brookline, Mass. A March wedding is planned.
LEAD: Gov. Rose Mofford threw Arizona's 1990 gubernatorial race into confusion with her announcement on Thursday that she would not seek election to the office she inherited less than two years ago.

LEAD: A collection of colorful terra cotta wall panels designed by the late muralist Fred Dana Marsh that depict New York City's nautical heritage is looking for a new home. For over 40 years the 24 panels were the backdrop for the 250-seat Marine Grill at the McAlpin Hotel on Herald Square, which opened in 1912 and between World Wars was one of the city's more fashionable restaurants.

LEAD: STUDYING the humanities, an educational and cultural program based on the classics and embellished with the notion of human dignity, is a way for people to understand and come to terms with the complexities of modern society, according to David Danahar, dean of the College of Arts and Sciences at Fairfield
LEAD: Geri-Olympics

LEAD: The other day, NBC's ''Today'' show got a new executive producer, about a week after it had acquired a new co-host. Last fall, a new executive producer took over ''CBS This Morning'' and hired several new reporters. And no doubt something or someone new will soon be added to ABC's ''Good Morning America,'' although it has been doing very well in the ratings.

LEAD: Those who fret that rock is dead - which usually means that the music they grew up with has been supplanted by something younger folk like - might take comfort in its continued ostracism. On the theory that anything continually attacked must have some life left in it, rock seems very much alive.
LEAD: Nagasaki's Mayor is out of danger now, his suspected assailant is in custody and the sprawling, busy city that the world still pictures in nuclear ruin is back to work.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Stephanie Birney Danforth, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray S. Danforth of Providence and Exeter, R.I., was married yesterday to Lincoln Davenport Chafee, a son of Senator and Mrs. John H. Chafee of McLean, Va., and Warwick, R.I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Daniel Warren, an Episcopal priest, at the Exeter home of the bride's parents.
LEAD: TRUST By George V. Higgins. 230 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $18.95.

LEAD: Oski the bear, the official mascot of the University of California, has been suspended for two weeks, after the furry cheerleader threw a layer cake into the crowd at a basketball game, splattering an estimated 15 people.

LEAD: The drummer Louis Hayes is leading hard-bop blowing sessions -earthy and eccentric tunes, plenty of time for soloists - through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South. His trim, brisk drumming, with its careful cymbal accents, supports a quintet that features two experienced players with too little New York exposure, the trumpeter Charles Tolliver and the saxophonist Gary Bartz.

LEAD: The views expressed in your article on the Salvadoran Army could apply to many, if not all, third-world countries. The history of Central America is a sad one of many military-ruled governments. That is why we need to support the concept of freely elected civilian-controlled governments in all of Central America and the third world.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Laura Delano Roosevelt, a daughter of Mrs. Erasmus Helm Kloman of Washington and the late Franklin Delano Roosevelt Jr., was married yesterday to Dr. Charles Henry Silberstein, a son of Mrs. Herbert F. Storfer of New York and the late Dr. Richard M. Silberstein. Acting Justice Shirley Fingerhood of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated at the Colony Club in New

LEAD: Q. I own a year-round home in the mountains that has a 3-foot-high crawl space. The floor of the crawl space is bare earth. There are eight vents to keep air circulating, but in the summer condensation accumulates. One contractor told me to put plastic on the ground to prevent moisture from rising, another said I should install a fan to circulate the air.

LEAD: The engagement of Colleen Ann Cooper and Joseph A. Reardon 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Reardon Jr. of Bloomfield, N.J., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Raymond V. Cooper of Rockaway, N.J. A fall wedding is planned.

LEAD: MY husband and I find ourselves gravitating more to Jones Beach in the off seasons. In the middle of winter, bundled for the wind and the cold, we'll park at Field 6 and walk very briskly to the Central Mall about 15 minutes away.

LEAD: IF 1989 gave the world the indelible image of vast crowds on the cobbled squares of Eastern Europe demanding democracy, then 1990 may be the year when those same crowds learn that chasing out a clutch of ham-fisted commissars was the easy part.

LEAD: When Ellen Baxter was working on a report about the homeless people of New York City, she went into shelters and subway stations and parks to talk to them about their lives. The problem was enormous but her conclusion was simple. ''It was so obvious to me that what they wanted was a place to live,'' she says.
LEAD: China imposed new restrictions on foreign journalists today and banned articles that in the view of the authorities ''distort facts'' or violate ''the public interest.''
LEAD: TELLING anyone, especially one's son, that you don't really want his wonderful, thoughtful gift is enough to make mental anguish sound like a vacation.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The former British police official who tried to investigate charges of a ''shoot to kill'' policy among the anti-terrorist police in Northern Ireland says he has a document that shows that senior British civil servants were involved in removing him from the inquiry in 1986.

LEAD: I read with interest the article by Judy Chicurel about ''The Invisible Thread,'' a newly published book that intends to dispel myths and stereotypes about Jewish women in America [Women in a Jewish Tapestry, in Words and Pictures,'' Dec. 31] . I was disturbed, though, by a quote from a college student who was one of the 60 interviewees in the book.

LEAD: Barbara Stanwyck, the luminous protagonist of such classic movies as ''Stella Dallas,'' ''The Lady Eve'' and ''Double Indemnity'' and the award-winning western television series ''The Big Valley'' in the 1960's, died of congestive heart failure yesterday in a hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 82 years old.

LEAD: When the Iron Curtain ripped open, investment managers rushed through, seeking profits in the chaos of Eastern Europe. Shares in Hungary and Germany funds have been sold and plans are in the works for Poland and Berlin funds.

LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in the Diner's Journal do not have ratings. Prices are current. Bernard's Organic French Cuisine

LEAD: ''At a time when our people desperately need the message of health promotion, Uptown's message is more disease, more suffering and more death.'' So said a furious Secretary of Health and Human Services, Dr. Louis Sullivan. Uptown is the name of the menthol cigarette the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company had hoped to market.

LEAD: JUMP out of the helicopter and sink to your knees in snow. Stay low and move slowly. But the rat-a-tat-tat of the chopper and the pulse of your heartbeat make you want to sprint away. The chopper lifts, glides sideways and hovers over space before gliding down the canyon and out of sight and sound.

LEAD: MAIN STREET, in downtown Northport Village on Long Island Sound, is Main Street, U.S.A.: the quintessential American hybrid of versatility, accessibility and old-fashioned neighborliness that is fast becoming extinct.
LEAD: BENEFIT PLAY

LEAD: Among the chores awaiting Congress is deciding whether the United States should have the right to control the catch of the various species of tuna that swim within 200 miles of this country's shores.
LEAD: The art world is a microcosm of the world, says Anna Somers Cocks. ''It has economics, commercialism, politics, religion, gossip, scandal, all aspects.''

LEAD: Malcolm Brewster Barton of Bedford, N.Y., has announced April wedding plans for his daughter, Brooks Barton, and Gerald Scott Cantini, the son of Gerald Peter Cantini of Manchester, Vt., and Mrs. Barry Hyde Chappel of Norwalk, Conn. Miss Barton also is the daughter of the late Cynthia Towell Barton.
LEAD: FIRESIDE TALKS

LEAD: Shari Ellen Birnbaum, a law student at Harvard University, and David Howard Dreier, a management consultant in Boston, plan to marry in August. Mr. and Mrs. Ira M. Birnbaum of Wesley Hills, N.Y., have made known their daughter's engagement. Mr. Dreier is the son of Judge and Mrs. William A. Dreier of Warren, N.J.

LEAD: Bethpage $198,000 12 Romscho Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 70-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, wraparound porch, 2-car garage; taxes $1,900. Farmingdale $205,000 22 Eagle Lane 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 32-year-old split level; family room, new kitchen, finished basement; taxes $4,500.

LEAD: Monet Joy Berger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Berger of Las Vegas, Nev., was married there last evening at Bally's hotel and casino to Daniel Smith Levinson, the son of Linda Levinson and Fred Levinson, both of New York. Rabbi Melvin Hecht officiated. Miss Berger, 20 years old, is a student at the University of California at Los Angeles.

LEAD: THE SUN FIRST PEEKS OVER the Continental Divide just after 6 on New Year's Day, and particularly at this hour, it seems there could be no more beautiful place on earth than the Roaring Fork Valley - red-tinged clay, bright white snow and a pure blue in the sky that only high altitudes can produce.

LEAD: WHERE you stop on the road can make a big difference to the journey. I've long since sworn off McDonald's, Burger King, Roy Rogers, Red Robin and all the other dispiriting chains, with bored high-school dropouts on minimum wages staring at you blankly as you ask for something that isn't listed among the plastic letters of the ''menu board.

LEAD: IVAN M. HAVEL, the brother of Vaclav Havel, the President of Czechoslovakia, spoke last week to an audience here about ''the revolution of intellectuals'' in his country that ''literally laughed the Communist Government out of power.''
LEAD: THE PALACE OF WISDOM By Bob Marshall-Andrews. 341 pp. New York: A William Abrahams Book/ E. P. Dutton. $18.95.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Breathes there anyone who is never in a bad mood? If so, beware - that person is a disguised creature from another planet and definitely not human. Real people, even nice real people, are grumpy sometimes, down in the dumps at least occasionally and mean-mad, mean-tired or plain mean once in a while.
LEAD: MIRANDA AND THE MOVIES Written and illustrated by Jane Kendall. 208 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $14.95. (Ages 8 to 12)
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Five programs devoted to the music of Cole Porter will be featured in this year's Lyrics and Lyricists series, to begin on Jan. 28 and 29 at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. A different aspect of the songwriter's music will be discussed at each session. Subscriptions to the Monday programs are $130 to $110, and tickets for single sessions are $27.50 to $22.50 (students and the elderly may buy half-price tickets on the day of the session).

LEAD: An obituary by The Associated Press on Dec. 31 about Hermann Julius Oberth, a West German rocket scientist, misstated his birthplace. He was born in Nagyszeben, in Transylvania, an area that is now part of Rumania.

LEAD: Freely debating how to create a viable political opposition, political insurgents from across the country met today in a gathering that presented the most open challenge thus far to the Communist Party's dominance over Soviet public life.

LEAD: To the Editor: I was very pleased to see Martha White's article (''Taking the Casual Route,'' Travel, Nov. 19), which described some of the lesser-known pleasures of traveling. Over the summer my sister and I decided to take a car trip before returning to our respective colleges. We arranged to take five days off from work, got the car tuned up and took off early on a Sunday morning before our parents knew what we were up to.

LEAD: I think that both players should not only be fined, but also suspended without pay for a couple of games. Pete Rose was suspended for life for betting on baseball, yet Barkley and Jackson get off with only a fine for betting on basketball. Something doesn't seem right. BRIAN NASH Tenafly, N.J.
LEAD: PING CHONG

LEAD: THE most dangerous curve in the village of Mamaroneck is a serpentine monster on Mamaroneck Avenue that has claimed two lives and caused 22 accidents in the last five years. But this stretch of road could be carrying up to 200 more vehicles an hour under a plan by the New York State Thruway Authority to alleviate the danger at a nearby interchange on

LEAD: AS far as I'm concerned, Women's Lib will have done its job if it merely succeeds in gaining women respect. That may seem simple, but it's not. With this accomplished, though, the specific goals of the movement should fall into place. Let me make my case.

LEAD: The Port of Baltimore was idled today when dockworkers went on strike. About 2,000 members of the International Longshoremen's Association put up picket lines at the port, where 13 ships were scheduled to call this weekend.

LEAD: The recipe direction to grill does not have much meaning in January for most of us, unless the kitchen comes equipped with a charcoal grill. But last year I was introduced to an indoor alternative that takes up less room than a frying pan and fits neatly on the top of a burner.

LEAD: I read Gordon R. Batcheller's letter concerning his reason for hunting (Letters, Dec. 31, in response to ''The Hated Season,'' by Steven Lewis, About Men, Nov. 26). He says he has given up trying to explain to people why he hunts; nevertheless, he presents us with a half-complete, self-justifying statement about ''what it's like to hear a wild turkey gobble .

LEAD: Whenever an article about the tourism industry on Long Island appears, I read it with concern for the inaccuracies it might contain. There seem to be more spokespersons for our tourism industry than I care to count. Many consider themselves experts and the quotes of these persons are usually accepted as fact.
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:

LEAD: The Rev. Roderic Frohman, a white clergyman, leaned from the pulpit of a small church here last Sunday, and repeated an observation made more than 30 years ago by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. ''In America,'' Mr. Frohman said, ''11 A.M. on Sunday is still the most segregated hour of the week.

LEAD: She put up with her job as chief of radiology at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Manhattan for too long. Then she worked hard to make her private practice go. All the while, she took care of the house, her husband and her two children, now in their teens, and had not ''done a thing for this old body for a long time.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A jury has begun deliberating a civil case in which two former phone installers for the Cincinnati Bell Telephone Company are accused of defaming the company and two of its managers by charging them with engaging in a vast scheme of illegal wiretapping over more than a decade.

LEAD: Q. I own a year-round home in the mountains that has a 3-foot-high crawl space. The floor of the crawl space is bare earth. There are eight vents to keep air circulating, but in the summer condensation accumulates. One contractor told me to put plastic on the ground to prevent moisture from rising, another said I should install a fan to circulate the air.

LEAD: Getting investors today to pony up for high-yield bonds will take more than a convincing sales pitch. In the wake of recent disasters in the ''junk bond'' market and the bankruptcy filing last week of Federated Stores Inc. and the Allied Stores Corporation, Wall Street brokerages are having to respond to a new call by investors for more puncture-proof research.

LEAD: John Gotti, you poor, obsolete loser. You've missed the boat. You forgot Willie Sutton's lesson - go where the money is. Just before Christmas, when I was in New York, I saw on the local news a story about the police in Queens ''busting'' a gambling ''bank.'' A veritable army of police cruisers were outside a pitiful-looking building next to a bakery.
LEAD: WHEN the harpsichordist Igor Kipnis of Redding, a leading concert and recording artist, rehearses with an orchestra, he takes along two things: his music and his camera.

LEAD: BALANCING ACTS: Contemporary Stories by Russian Women. Edited by Helena Goscilo. (Indiana University, Cloth, $39.95; Paper, $17.50). What do Russian women want? Everything, apparently, that many other women do: the stable love of a good man and the mad passion of a lover, the security of home and hearth and the fulfillment of professional achievement, the gratitude of their children and freedom from the noose of motherhood.

LEAD: THE plight of older women in search of available, interested men became a cultural cliche of the 1980's. Now it seems that the lament of the 90's might come from younger men. Demography dictates that they will have to fight over a smaller pool of potential mates.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Audio isn't just a matter of nuts, bolts and other assorted hardware. Equally important to good sound reproduction is the study of psychoacoustics - a hybrid science straddling various borders between physics, music, engineering and biology. Its aim is to understand the ways in which human beings perceive sound.

LEAD: Ruth V. Washington, the Ambassador to Gambia and a retired United States Magistrate, died after an automobile collision early yesterday near her home in the Hartsdale section of Greenburgh, N.Y. She was 67 years old.
LEAD: An estimated 800 people demonstrated outside the Albanian Mission to the United Nations yesterday, declaring that the Communist Government there would be the next one to fall in Eastern Europe.
LEAD: CLASSICAL Scarlatti: Keyboard Sonatas (16) Ton Koopman, harpsichord. Capriccio 10 212; CD and cassette.

LEAD: Soviet troops claimed control of the Azerbaijani capital of Baku today and began settling in for a probable long-term occupation after a night of urban conflict that left scores of civilians and several soldiers dead.

LEAD: Naming this area Silicon Valley, some say, was a mistake. It should be called Ferrite Valley, after the magnetic materials used in disk drives even before the emergence of silicon-based semiconductors. Dozens of disk-drive start-ups blossomed, much like the semiconductor companies, in the area of San Jose.

LEAD: Iran has encouraged Muslims in Soviet Azerbaijan to express their Islamic identity and religious feelings, but has not tried to inflame separatist sentiment there for fear that violence might spill over into the two Azerbaijani provinces of Iran, American experts said today.

LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Government survived a Conservative Party mutiny on Thursday night over a plan to replace real-estate taxes levied by local governments with a ''community charge,'' or head tax, on every adult.

LEAD: To almost everyone, Charles Stuart's story that a black gunman had killed his pregnant wife and then shot him in the stomach seemed so believable. But specialists in family violence now say the police, the press and the public should have been more suspicious of Mr. Stuart from the start.

LEAD: August Everding's thoughtful if clumsily designed and executed new production of Wagner's ''Fliegende Hollander'' appeared Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera with entirely different singers from the ones who performed at the Dec. 11 opening. One contractor told me to put plastic on the ground to prevent moisture from rising, another said I should install a fan to circulate the air.

LEAD: He may be the fastest sprinter the world has ever seen, but Ben Johnson is no longer a world-record holder. Citing Johnson's admitted use of steroids over most of the last decade, track and field's international governing body voted yesterday to strip the 28-year-old Canadian runner of his three remaining records, in the 100-meter dash and the indoor 50- and 60-meter events.

LEAD: On Wednesday morning, Jan. 3, weekday Shuttle passengers on the Washington-New York and New York-Boston routes received a nasty New Year's present from the glitzy self-promoter Donald J. Trump. His Trump Shuttle raised its one-way weekday fares by an unprecedented 20 percent, to $119 from $99, thereby exacerbating the already excessive unrestricted air fare gouge that presently afflicts most of the nation's business (and many other) travelers.

LEAD: AT Sabbia Rosa, where silk robes spill from padded hangers in streams of coral and peach, customers eye delicate bras edged in lace. The tiny Left Bank shop on the Rue des Saints-Peres has long been a magnet for those who appreciate fine lingerie and Miss Rosa's sweet tooth for color. A vivacious woman with a froth of curly hair, she proudly shows off her guest book, with signatures from the actor Dustin Hoffman and the model Cindy Crawford.

LEAD: Drama is dancing its way into choreographic abstractions. A remarkable number of modern dancers are offering works which, because they are plotless, could be termed abstract; at the same time, they appear to concern changing human relationships. Productions of this sort are not entirely new, and they are also devised by ballet choreographers.
