LEAD: Hector Belascoaran Shayne works nights and shares his Mexico City office with a sewer expert, which no doubt contributes to the morbid outlook he presents in AN EASY THING (Viking, $16.95), the first of Paco Ignacio Taibo 2d's many crime novels to be published in English.

LEAD: Twenty-two years ago, when a young professor of computer science at the California Institute of Technology predicted that single chips containing millions of transistors would one day be commonplace, his vision was greeted with incredulity.

LEAD: For the first time, a New York City employees' pension fund will invest in federally guaranteed bank loans as part of a city effort to promote greater economic growth by making more loan funds available for small businesses.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: AT the moment it is the brightest thing on the Central Park skyline - 6,000 square feet of Day-Glo orange. No, it is not a new Christo wrap sculpture or a high-rise HoJo's; it is the protective tarpaulin around the great roof and tower of the 1906 Saint Urban apartment house at the southwest corner of 89th Street and Central Park

LEAD: After a weeklong search that took detectives to Miami Beach, a Brooklyn teen-ager was arrested yesterday in the razor-slashings of two people, including the actress Viveca Lindfors, as they walked in Greenwich Village on Jan. 13. The police said the suspect was high on LSD and alcohol during the attacks.

LEAD: Often enough, a jazz musician's artistic life traces a predictable pattern: an explosive period of youthful creativity metamorphoses into a period of refinement. The growing artist's desire for change is replaced by the classicist's concern for rules, a type of formalism that fits right in with the demands of the jazz audience, which usually wants its musical icons to defy time and stay the same.

LEAD: Faced with growing rebellion and defections in its ranks over the slowness of internal change, leaders of East Germany's Communist Party decided after an emergency session that ended early today to purge several more former leaders, but rejected calls that it dissolve altogether.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: ONE of the truly great sweetheart deals in sports has been the long and loving association between real professional football and more-or-less professional football called college football.

LEAD: An article in The Living Section on Jan. 3 about the Maytag Dairy Farm in Newton, Iowa, misidentified the university that isolated a mold spore used in the manufacture of the farm's blue cheese. It was Iowa State University at Ames, not the University of Iowa at Iowa City.
LEAD: THE sweeping set of regulations for commercial transactions is about to get the most significant addition in decades.

LEAD: WHAT with SportsChannel, SportsChannel America, SportsChannel Plus, MSG and ESPN, not to mention occasional offerings on HBO, USA and the like, cable television would seem to have sports and the alphabet pretty well covered. Wait, there's more. On Feb. 1, Mizlou Communications, the seasonal syndicator of college bowl games and other sports events, will begin the Mizlou Sports News
LEAD: A chartered fishing boat with nine people aboard capsized and broke up in 15-foot swells in a river's mouth today, leaving one person dead and six people missing, Coast Guard officials said.

LEAD: A bruising five-week leadership struggle at Spain's largest private bank ended Saturday when the board of the Banco Bilbao Vizcaya approved the appointment of a Basque financier, Emilio Ybarra Churruca, as its chairman.

LEAD: Dr. Carl Goldmark Jr., an obstetrician and gynecologist and a former president of the New York State Medical Society, died Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Meredith Monk has been an anomaly for much of her 27-year career as a composer and choreographer, creating dances that were operas, operas that were dances and mythic theater pieces that were operas and dances. To complicate matters, Ms. Monk is also a film maker. In ''Book of Days,'' to be shown tonight at 10 on Channel 13 as part of the ''Alive From Off
LEAD: TO his teammates, Joe Montana is revered as the Legend.

LEAD: MIDWAY through the skiing season, many skiers find that the ski boots they once thought were comfortable have become sources of torture. Ankles are rubbed raw. Insteps are afflicted by cramps. Shins are red and tender. Many people try to solve the problem by stuffing foam rubber into their boots, putting pads under their heels, or pasting moleskin on their feet.
LEAD: China's recent grain harvest, an indicator of national well-being, has set a record, narrowly exceeding the level in 1984, the Government announced Friday.

LEAD: President Bush will nominate James L. Kolstad to be the chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board, ending a long stalemate with Congress over who should run the agency, a White House official said today.

LEAD: In a tense atmosphere of a crew fighting for control of a sinking ship, Yugoslavia's ruling Communists today insulted, challenged and prodded each other on nationwide television, displaying a split in their ranks on the second day of the party's national congress.
LEAD: So much for Mr. Nice Guy.

LEAD: His personal and political life shattered by a criminal charge that he smoked crack, a repentant Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. said today, in public and in tears, that he had ''weaknesses'' and would seek help for them.
LEAD: Common Stock

LEAD: Student leaders, addressing a crowd of about 3,000 of their classmates today, demanded far-reaching changes in the faculties of Bucharest University and other Rumanian institutions of higher learning.

LEAD: Barbara Stanwyck, the luminous star of such classic movies as ''Stella Dallas,'' ''The Lady Eve'' and ''Double Indemnity'' and the award-winning western television series ''The Big Valley,'' died of congestive heart failure late Saturday at St. John's Hospital and Health Center in Santa Monica, Calif.

LEAD: Roman Catholics in the nation's second largest archdiocese learned today that about 30 churches and at least 6 schools would be closed to ease what church officials called a critical financial situation.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Ken Hatfield of Arkansas accepted the head coaching job at Clemson today, and a threatened player boycott was averted after he met with the team.
LEAD: The Knicks did very little right today.

LEAD: Nine Soviet miners, who helped organize a nationwide strike last summer to change their future, came to the Appalachian coalfields last week to learn from Americans who are striking to preserve the gains of the past.

LEAD: Prime Minister V. P. Singh said today that his Government wanted to set aside a $470 million settlement with the Union Carbide Corporation to compensate victims of the world's most deadly industrial disaster.

LEAD: Edouard V. M. Izac, a World War I Navy hero who served as a Congressman from California in the 1930's and 40's, died of congestive heart failure on Thursday at the home of a daughter in Fairfax, Va. He was 100 years old.

LEAD: The Indian Army opened fire today in clashes with demonstrators defying a curfew in the Kashmiri city of Srinagar, and at least 35 people were killed and 100 wounded, Indian news agencies reported.
LEAD: In the past month, the U.S. Government's ''war on drugs'' won two victories.

LEAD: WHEN you play Denver, the key to your game is what you can do about No. 7. Because John Elway is such a big-play performer, your best defense is to have your offense control and keep the ball so No. 7 stays on the sideline. The 49ers are good at that.

LEAD: One of Lee P. Brown's last acts as police chief here, before starting work as the New York City Police Commissioner on Monday, was to dismiss four officers involved in two highly publicized and widely criticized shootings of civilians.

LEAD: One of the few glories of Beirut to survive 15 years of sectarian violence has been its lively press. Three papers published in the Christian East sector of the city and seven in the Muslim West have circulated on both sides of the dividing Green Line, offering an antidote to unfounded rumors and managed information.

LEAD: Amid the shattered grandeur of the Francis Marion National Forest, Buddy, Prince, Duke and Joe took a break the other day from the logging operations that are clearing trees felled by Hurricane Hugo. It was lunchtime, and on the menu was a mixture of oats, corn and molasses.
LEAD: GAME shows are gold mines.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Championship Auto Racing Teams, the Indy-car sanctioning group created more than a decade ago out of car-owner discontent, was reshaped last October out of that same dissatisfaction.

LEAD: Along the coatrack-clogged sidewalks of Seventh Avenue in Manhattan, the garment industry took out its handkerchief and dabbed its sweaty brow and talked last week about Federated Stores Inc., the renamed American retailing operations of the Campeau Corporation.

LEAD: Mitsuo Horiguchi, a former director of the Nippon Club in Manhattan, died of emphysema and heart failure on Wednesday at Rye General Hospital in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 82 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.
LEAD: The Treasury's schedule of issues this week includes today's auction of three- and six-month bills and Wednesday's auction of two-year notes.

LEAD: The inflation rate in Britain rose three-tenths of 1 percent in December and was up 7.7 percent for the year, the Government said Friday. The Central Statistical Office attributed the December rise in the retail price index to increases in food prices and housing costs. The rate was better than the 7.8 percent rise that the financial markets had been expecting and was good news for the Government, which has been fighting inflation with 15 percent interest rates.
LEAD: President Bush, reversing his previous position, would accept a vote in Congress to make the Environmental Protection Agency a Cabinet-level department, Administration officials say.

LEAD: THE San Francisco 49ers are not an unbeatable football team. But if the Denver Broncos are going to be competitive they better have their best players on the field at all times paying strict attention. The 49ers can beat you in so many ways. If you stop this, they'll try that. They keep after you relentlessly.
LEAD: ''Born on the Fourth of July,'' the Vietnam drama, won four Golden Globe Awards Saturday night, including best dramatic picture, best dramatic actor for Tom Cruise and best director.
LEAD: Joan Fuld and Frank Strauss, officials of the Council of Jewish Federations in New York, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents in New York by Rabbi David Posner.

LEAD: All day Friday and half of Saturday, a group of nearly 280 artists, art historians, curators, museum directors, dealers and critics took over the lower level of the American Craft Museum. They constituted a sold-out symposium titled ''A Neglected History: 20th-Century American Craft.''
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: It was a day of redemption and renewal today within the high walls of the First Rising Mount Zion Baptist Church, an anchor in the capital's poor black Shaw neighborhood.
LEAD: THERE are just five trading days until the Super Bowl is played, and unless share prices rise this week the outcome could be bad news for San Francisco and for stock buyers.

LEAD: Gov. William A. O'Neill, whose popularity soared with the economic boom of the mid-1980's and sank as financial woes rocked the state government last year, will face the toughest battle of his career when he seeks re-election to a third term in November, supporters and opponents say.

LEAD: Following are the comments made today by Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. and his wife, Effi, at St. Timothy's Episcopal Church. The comments were recorded by the Federal News Service, a transcription service.
LEAD: A 15-year-old Brooklyn youth was fatally shot in the chest yesterday, apparently due to a dispute that began earlier in the day, the police said.
LEAD: The rush to buy cable television systems appears to be slowing, industry executives and media brokers say.

LEAD: Once a week here on the evening news, television viewers are making the acquaintance of a man with AIDS, hearing firsthand about his fears and frailties and watching his jaunty passage toward death.

LEAD: New York City has made its first concerted effort to list the places where homeless people spend their nights, in the hope of guiding the Census Bureau to those who live in shelters, subway stations, parks, doorways and abandoned buildings - and who would otherwise go uncounted.
LEAD: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor of the Supreme Court sometimes seems to be shaking her head involuntarily from the bench in an up-and-down motion, like someone expressing affirmation.

LEAD: The Los Angeles Lakers, playing tough, bone-rattling defense, shed their Hollywood image for Detroit's old ''Bad Boy'' look today as they won, 107-97, snapping a losing streak against the Pistons at seven games.

LEAD: IN a classic British television commercial of the 1980's, two characters in a cinematic melodrama anguish over their relationship in words that are curiously out-of-synchronization with their lip movements. But when they each quaff a beer, their voices and lips miraculously harmonize.

LEAD: Congressional leaders of both parties took issue today with Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's proposal to cut Social Security taxes, and President Bush's budget director, Richard G. Darman, called the plan ''the most irresponsible idea of the '90's.''
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Foreign investment in Portugal more than doubled last year, to $2.4 billion, the Government said Friday. In 1988, direct foreign investment totaled more than $920 million. The Trade and Tourism Minister, Joaquim Ferreira do Amaral, said Britain provided the most investment in Portugal, followed by France, Spain, the United States and Japan.

LEAD: Reports by clergymen and friends that Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. has told them he has a drug problem - and his wife's saying that he admitted he needed ''help'' -will make it more difficult for him to use a claim of entrapment as a defense to a misdemeanor charge of cocaine possession, legal experts and
LEAD: Alfred Van Santvoord Olcott, a financial planner and founder of a maritime historical society, died of complications of heart surgery at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia.

LEAD: President Elias Hrawi of Lebanon held talks in the Syrian capital with President Hafez al-Assad today on what Government officials here described as ways to oust Gen. Michel Aoun, the Christian leader.
LEAD: The Broadway composer and lyricist Stephen Sondheim has begun his new role as professor, addressing an overflow crowd of 250 people at Oxford University.
LEAD: Two gunmen opened fire on a quiet residential street on the south side of Newark yesterday evening, wounding five people. The police said the shooting may have been drug related.

LEAD: Insurgent Communists from across the Soviet Union created an organization today that is to serve as a prod for rapid democratization of the Communist Party and, failing that, as the nucleus for a formal political opposition.

LEAD: JOHN E. FROHNMAYER, the new head of the National Endowment for the Arts, spent the weekend in New York getting acquainted. On Saturday he toured the Metropolitan Museum's Canaletto exhibition. Today he speaks at a meeting of chamber music groups.

LEAD: The French computer company Groupe Bull has awarded its new corporate advertising account to DDB Needham France. The image-building account, which will cover North America, Europe and Southeast Asia, will have billings of $10 million. The other finalists for the account were TBWA, Publicis and HDM.
LEAD: The Pencil: A History of Design and Circumstance By Henry Petroski 434 pages. Illustrated. Knopf. $25.

LEAD: More than 150 people demonstrated near the Soviet Mission to the United Nations yesterday, calling on the Gorbachev Government to protect the lives of Armenians in Azerbaijan and to allow self-determination in Armenia.
LEAD: * Calvin Klein Cosmetics Co., a unit of Unilever United States, named Kimberly Delsing president and chief executive.

LEAD: Record Before Ruth Q. Henry Aaron broke Babe Ruth's career home run record. Whose record did Ruth break? A. If you had picked up a major league baseball record book in April 1921, the listing under ''Most Home Runs in a Career by a Player Since 1900'' would have read: ''Gavvy Cravath, 119.
LEAD: A pregnant woman has been charged with child abuse after prosecutors accused her of excessive drinking.

LEAD: The accordion, that lowly and often mocked instrument, has spent the last decade getting revenge. Once the simple butt of jokes, it is now heard everywhere, from highbrow stages at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where accordionists play art music, to albums by quirky rock groups and clubs featuring hard-rocking regional dance bands.

LEAD: Six months after it resigned the $5 million Helmsley Hotel Corporation account over a fee dispute, Taylor-Gordon, Aarons & Company has returned to the hospitality field. The agency has won the account for the Vista International Hotel at the World Trade Center in New York. Billings for the new account, formerly at Albert Frank-Guenther Law, are projected at $1 million to $2 million.
LEAD: The price, Tomas Sandstrom and Tony Granato, was high. The cost, roughly $700,000 a year, will be considerable. The trade for Bernie Nicholls: Was it, is it, will it be worth it?
LEAD: The new Boy Scout handbook still tells Scouts to be prepared and how to use a compass, build campfires and tie knots. But it also aims to help them cope with life in the 1990's.

LEAD: A picture caption in Business Day on Jan. 4 about Sematech, the Government-industry alliance formed to improve ways of making computer chips, referred imprecisely to Semi-Gas Systems Inc. Despite the juxtaposition with a reference to other companies' troubles, Semi-Gas is profitable and currently has no long-term debt.

LEAD: FOR the last 10 years, the staff at the Somax Posture and Sports Clinic in Corte Madera, Calif., has been studying the relationship between joint range (flexibility) and the range of motion of the body's joints during sports activity.
LEAD: Thomas H. K. Brooks, who joined Ann Taylor Inc. in April, has been named a vice chairman of the fashion chain, which is rapidly expanding under his father, Joseph E. Brooks.
LEAD: Because of a transmission error, the diagram of the deal with the bridge column Saturday duplicated two cards and was missing two cards.
LEAD: Last Tuesday, fans of ABC's ''Thirtysomething'' got unsettling news. Nancy, a major character in the critically praised television series, was discovered to have ovarian cancer.
LEAD: Leaders of East Germany's Communist Party decided to purge several more leaders, but rejected calls that it dissolve altogether. Page A7.

LEAD: Less is still more in the music of Booker T. and the MG's, who reunited last weekend at the Lone Star Roadhouse. Booker T. Jones on organ, Steve Cropper on guitar and Donald (Duck) Dunn on bass were three-quarters of the Stax Records studio band from 1961 to 1971. They backed up the top Memphis soul singers - including Eddie Floyd, who joined the group for part of the set - and, as the MG's (Memphis Group), put out classic soul instrumentals.

LEAD: Seabury Place near Crotona Park in the Bronx was named years ago for the nation's first Episcopal bishop. No similar distinction was ever bestowed on his great-great-grandson, Judge Samuel Seabury, whom Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia once hailed as ''the father of good city government.''
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: * Farmland Industries, Kansas City, Mo., an agricultural cooperative, to Grey Advertising, with a budget of $4 million.
LEAD: The Jets are expected to have a new head coach today after George Perles of Michigan State flies to New York to hammer out the details of a contract.
LEAD: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday Automobile Sales Mid-Jan. Thursday None Friday Durable Goods Dec. G.N.P. 4th Qtr.
LEAD: ''For those of us living and working in this city,'' said the playwright Jules Feiffer, ''writing in the realistic or naturalistic mode for whites only has become unreal and unnatural.''

LEAD: For years, school reformers in New York City have lamented the absence of a strong chancellor. But now that Joseph Fernandez, only three weeks into the job, is asserting his authority with unusual breadth and swiftness, critics furrow their brows. Is he, as some assert, overstepping legal bounds? Probably not.

LEAD: A short announcement on the radio early last week was enough to send streams of people through the second floor of a Sofia art gallery to gape, chuckle, even laugh out loud at hundreds of caricatures mocking the foibles of their former leader, Todor Zhivkov.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In a chilling new account of the last hour of Nicolae Ceausescu, the deposed Rumanian dictator, and his wife, Elena, a prosecutor was quoted as saying that they ran wildly around the courtyard where they were to be shot until troops hunted them down.
LEAD: For the first time since Japan became a financial superpower, the market for its Government bonds is playing a critical role in the movement of interest rates in the United States.

LEAD: * Arnold J. Blum, who has been senior vice president and creative director of the international team of McCann-Erickson Worldwide, will become executive vice president and co-creative director of Trahan, Burden & Charles in Baltimore.

LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has named THOMAS E. DuHADWAY as the agent in charge of the bureau's Washington metropolitan field office. He had been a deputy assistant director of the intelligence division, which tracks and occasionally catches spies.

LEAD: If anybody doubted it, recent polls show that Lee Atwater, the Republican national chairman, was right as well as crass when he said the death and destruction of the Panama invasion had won President Bush a political ''jackpot.'' As poker players know, while the winners crack jokes, the losers can only say ''deal!
LEAD: William E. Gibson resigned unexpectedly Friday as chairman, president, chief executive and a director of the American Federal Savings Bank.
LEAD: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON DECOLONIZATION: 10 A.M. Economic and Social Council INTERGOVERNMENTAL OCEANOGRAPHIC COMMISSION: 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

LEAD: A golf ball designed with red, yellow and blue stripes has been developed to give players a visual cue on where to hit the ball and how to gauge its spin.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Kenny Turner, who had not scored since the first half, hit a 10-foot jump shot with 6 seconds to play in overtime today to give Virginia an 81-79 victory over Georgia Tech.

LEAD: The Boots Company, the British retail and pharmaceuticals group, has appointed Sir Christopher Benson chairman. He will succeed Robert Gunn, who had the post for the last five years and will retire in July at age 65.
LEAD: The Soviet Army consolidated its occupation of Baku today as leaders of the Azerbaijan Popular Front made plans to stage a general protest strike throughout the strife-ridden Soviet republic.

LEAD: The number of mergers and acquisitions worldwide declined last year, based on figures released on Friday by IDD Information Services, although the American market accounted for a higher percentage of those deals.

LEAD: From the woods of Oregon, BARRY LOPEZ is making a rare trip to Manhattan. In a nostalgic mode, the author is to talk to high school students today at the Donnell Library Center, which he used when he was a student at Loyola High School. His subject is ''the meaning of nature to city kids,'' a spokesman for the library said.

LEAD: President Bush's misguided urge to cut the tax on capital gains finds a dubious companion in his ''family savings plan.'' Floated during the 1988 campaign and now being readied for submission to Congress, it shares at least two faults with the gains tax: it is weak medicine for America's low savings rate, and it would create new budget problems for the future.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH we've still got a long way to go before the whippoorwill's persistent three-note song celebrates soft summer nights, this is the best time of year to begin sorting out, refurbishing and replacing fishing tackle.
LEAD: ''I'm going to find a way to begin to heal my body, mind and soul.'' -Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington. [A1:2.]

LEAD: A British partnership scored a victory yesterday in one of the strongest events on the tournament calendar. Tony Forrester and Andrew Robson, playing in the Staten Bank World Top tournament in The Hague, overtook two Brazilian world champions in the final stages.

LEAD: Just as the next few months will become critically important for the team that will represent the United States in the 1990 World Cup finals in Italy, the time will also be crucial for the organizing committee of the 1994 tournament, which will be staged in the United States.

LEAD: The most immediately striking quality of Katsurako Mikami's performance at Weill Recital Hall on Saturday afternoon was the smooth, rounded tone she drew from the hall's Steinway piano - an instrument that can sound glaring in less careful hands.

LEAD: By sending troops to impose order in the southern republic of Azerbaijan, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has committed himself to a prolonged occupation that supporters already fear could be his domestic Afghanistan.

LEAD: Highland Springs, who won two stakes races and set a course record at Saratoga last summer, scored his first victory since then when he pulled away in the stretch to win the $100,000 Appleton Handicap today at Gulfstream Park.

LEAD: After a four-year delay, South Korea has authorized E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company's application to build a $97 million titanium dioxide plant with a local company, the Finance Ministry said Friday.

LEAD: Mario Lemieux, who has been adored by hockey fans in Pittsburgh and elsewhere around the National Hockey League, may have enhanced his sport's image today with his performance in the league's 41st All-Star Game.

LEAD: Less than 24 hours after watching his team snap Kansas' winning streak at 19 games, Norm Stewart, Missouri's head basketball coach, sat in an empty locker room this morning, stunned by a succession of upsets that had put his Tigers in position to be the country's top-ranked team for the first time in eight years.
LEAD: The 101st Congress returns to work on Tuesday in a world made new.

LEAD: Arthur Goldberg, who died last week at the age of 81, may go down in legal annals as a brilliant lawyer and restless public servant who persisted in seeking other callings. He was a hard-bargaining labor lawyer, an architect of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. union merger in 1955 and a hustling mediator as Secretary of Labor before becoming a Supreme Court
LEAD: Expanding its role as a computer manufacturer, the Intel Corporation will introduce a new line of work stations Monday.
LEAD: President Bush and his spokesman last week broke his Administration's policy of keeping quiet about the policies of the Federal Reserve.
LEAD: Jack Nicklaus turned 50 years old today with his competitive fires still burning. He said he planned to win events on both the regular PGA Tour and the Senior PGA Tour this year.

LEAD: Judith Frances Mazo, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Mazo of Washington, was married there yesterday to Louis Michael Seidman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Benedict S. Seidman of New Rochelle, N.Y. Judge Frederick H. Weisberg of Superior Court of the District of Columbia officiated at the bride and bridegroom's home.

LEAD: It is a world where women in hair nets and men in fedoras occupy wicker seats in the Sea Beach Express, heading for their rendezvous with the Wonder Wheel, the Parachute Jump and the Cyclone. It is a universe of linoleum-floored rooms, Arvin radios, Raleigh cigarettes and indestructible seltzer bottles.

LEAD: A new draft of the charter that will govern Hong Kong has aroused bitter opposition from political leaders, and even some businessmen who had been reluctant to oppose China said they could not support the planned political model.
LEAD: Doris Bernstein, a psychoanalyst and past president of the Institute for Psychoanalytic Training and Research, died of cancer on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 57 years old.
LEAD: International A3-8
LEAD: It takes only one shout of, ''It's the Japanese; they're buying!'' in a Wall Street dealing room to throw traders into fits of nervous activity. It is easy to understand why.
LEAD: If Theodore Dreiser were alive, he would be avidly read about the Stuart murder case in Boston. The parallels between it and his novel ''An American Tragedy'' are striking.

LEAD: At least 2,500 Mongolians defied a ban on demonstrations today by gathering in the Mongolian capital, Ulan Bator, to demand human rights and other concessions from the country's Communist leadership.
LEAD: Bob Goodenow, a lawyer and player agent from Detroit, was named the deputy executive director of the National Hockey League Players Association today.

LEAD: Edward H. Cleary, a lawyer, professor and authority on legal procedure who helped draft the uniform rules of evidence used in Federal courts, died of congestive heart failure on Friday at Scottsdale (Ariz.) Memorial Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Scottsdale.

LEAD: The new editor of the Czechoslovak Communist Party daily, Rude Pravo, placed an article on the front page of his newspaper this week, an announcement by the Interior Ministry that the secret police would be dissolved and their domestic spying activities abolished.

LEAD: Karen Ann Engelbourg, the New England regional director of development at Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass., was married yesterday at the Faculty Center at Brandeis to Donald Bruce Stewart, the executive director of public relations at Wheaton College in Norton, Mass. Edward English, the City Clerk of Newton, Mass., officiated.
LEAD: Will the real dummy please be seated?
LEAD: THOUGH the University of Connecticut's Field House has been a good-luck charm for the basketball team, for years it has been the bane of the school's coaches.

LEAD: With its aggressive strategy to strengthen the mark, the Bundesbank of West Germany has shown again why it is considered the most skilled of the West's central banks and a primary player in the economic future of Europe. But not everything has gone according to plan.
LEAD: The military Government of Haiti has begun expelling political leaders and at least one presidential candidate was reported in hiding today, a day after the imposition of a state of siege.
LEAD: BBDO Los Angeles has resigned the account of Coldwell Banker Residential Real Estate, citing difficulty in working with the client. Billings are believed to be about $8 million.
LEAD: A Bronx man was shot to death late Saturday night as he tried to come to his mother's aid during an attempted robbery, the police said.

LEAD: After months of bitter verbal sparring, labor and management at the 70-year-old Daily News began the collective-bargaining process last week on negotiations that both sides say are apt to save the paper or sink it.
LEAD: * Employees of the advertising agency Al Paul Lefton Company spent Saturday restoring the Edgecomb, a homeless shelter in Washington Heights, in northern Manhattan.
LEAD: Three years after resigning as chairman of the Lotus Development Corporation, Mitchell D. Kapor is to introduce today the first software product developed by his new company, On Technology Inc.
LEAD: Frederick Charles Shrady, a sculptor best known for his works on religious themes, died of cancer on Saturday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Easton, Conn.

LEAD: Dominick Lamanna, a physics teacher at the Bronx High School of Science who worked with students in independent research, including helping them prepare entries for the Westinghouse Science Talent Search, was killed on Wednesday in an automobile accident on the Taconic State Parkway. He was 42 years old and lived in Poughkeepsie, N

LEAD: Most housing analysts concluded months ago that fewer first-time home buyers, a slowing economy and rising land and development costs would curb home construction this year and next. But builders in many regions are starting to slash operations even more deeply than they had planned, because of tough new lending policies Congress forced on savings and loan institutions in

LEAD: HORSE RACING Dactique Triumphs in Upset: Dactique upset the odds-on favorite, Grecian Flight, scoring a three-quarter length victory in the $83,100 Broadway handicap for fillies and mares yesterday at Aqueduct. Dactique, ridden by Frank Lovato Jr. and carrying 113 pounds, got up in the final few strides to beat Grecian Flight.

LEAD: In another report of Reagan Adminstration lapses in supervision, the General Accounting Office has found that the Department of Energy and the Environmental Protection Agency gave too much responsibility to contractors for the performance of essential Government functions.

LEAD: Tremper Mountain rises gently over this Catskill village, its slopes an unbroken mass of evergreens and white birch. New York State owns the summit, but much of the lower mountain is in private hands, and some of those hands belong to developers with plans to subdivide the land.
LEAD: Lowe Marschalk had been one of the best-kept creative secrets in advertising. It was the kind of agency that most people on Madison Avenue simply used to ignore.

LEAD: COLBY COLLEGE's 96-80 victory last week over the University of Southern Maine in a Division III basketball game at Southern Maine's Hill Gymnasium in Gorham did more than preserve Colby's unblemished record.
LEAD: A sense of tragedy seems to fill the small Brooklyn courtroom where a jury is hearing the trial of a $175 million lawsuit by Veronica Prego, the doctor who is dying of AIDS.

LEAD: N.B.A. 76ers Win Fifth Game in a Row Charles Barkley had 32 points and 15 rebounds last night as the visiting Philadelphia 76ers won their fifth game in a row, beating Cleveland, 103-88, to deny Coach Lenny Wilkens of the Cavaliers his 700th National Basketball Association victory. Barkley, who reached double figures in scoring and rebounding for the seventh time in eight games, had 14 points in the third quarter, including 7 during a 7-2 flurry that put the 76ers ahead by 72-55 midway through the period.

LEAD: As they did in his campaign for mayor, supporters of David N. Dinkins raised more than was needed for his inaugural ceremony and related activities and festivities.

LEAD: ANOTHER magic bullet has plowed into the dirt. A study published in The New England Journal of Medicine last week said that oat bran may not lower cholesterol after all. But then again it may. Americans have just been treated to a behind-the-scenes look at what goes on in the world of science every day.

LEAD: U.S. MEMORIES, R.I.P.: The joint venture formed last year to rescue the American computer industry from the clutches of a Japanese chip cartel died of financial anemia last week. LEAD: In 1989, for the third year in a row, Americans drank less wine than the year before. But as they have been doing regularly for more than a decade, they continued to drink more good wine: sales of premium wines, while they constitute only a tiny segment of the wine business, were up.

LEAD: It was a whodunit with a twist: everyone knew the name of the culprit, except the detectives. They were searching for the person who had hung a banner from the Xiehe Hospital, welcoming the changes in Rumania, but nobody would tell the police who did it.
LEAD: The defense won a victory yesterday in the Bensonhurst fatal racial attack case when the judge upheld defense motions to suppress three statements made by one of the defendants.

LEAD: BUSY cooks looking for fast and easy weeknight meals seem to have an insatiable appetite for recipes that use chicken breast. That's because it is easy to pick up boned chicken breasts on the way home and prepare a full meal in well under an hour.
LEAD: Corporations are increasingly wrestling with their employees to claim frequent-flier bonuses from airlines as travel costs soar and the economy slows.

LEAD: If the Federal Government intended to send the nation's computer hackers a message in the prosecution of Robert Tappan Morris, that message may not be clear until Federal Judge Howard G. Munson sentences the former 24-year-old computer science student.

LEAD: Along with a reputation for clever and intimidating cheers, the students at Duke University relish their inspirational role in the performance of the school's basketball team. Mike Krzyzewski, the head coach, has gone to considerable lengths to foster that involvement, often lauding the students as his squad's ''sixth man.

LEAD: Buoyed by strong gains in sales volume, Merck & Company, the world's largest drug maker, said yesterday that net income rose 20 percent in the fourth quarter of 1989 and 24 percent for the year.

LEAD: Federal regulators have not reached a decision on whether Neil M. Bush, the President's son, violated Federal banking laws as a board member of the bankrupt Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association in Denver.

LEAD: The Advertising column of Business Day on Jan. 17 about a new account for the Lowe Marschalk agency misstated the relationship between the Interpublic Group of Companies and the Lowe Group, the owner of Lowe Marschalk. Interpublic owns 35.4 percent of the Lowe Group, not 29 percent.

LEAD: When Thomas R. Pickering, the United States representative here, started whispering into a portable phone during the Security Council debate on Panama last month, he reinforced the split image that many people have of him after his first year on the job.

LEAD: It was an act of humility and decency, and it didn't take Ulf Dahlen more than a minute to make. Dahlen, who has worn No. 9 throughout his brief career with the Rangers, met Bernie Nicholls, the high-profile acquisition from Los Angeles who had worn No. 9 with the Kings, and immediately offered to give up his jersey.
LEAD: An article on Monday about labor negotiations at The Daily News misstated the expiration date of union contracts at The New York Post. It is March 30, 1991.

LEAD: To the frustration of Transit Authority officials and the dismay of subway riders, a campaign to purge New York City's subways of unruly homeless people has made no discernible headway after almost three months.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Alan K. Magary, a former executive of Seth Thomas, the clockmaker, died on Saturday at his home in Woodbury, Conn., after a long illness. He was 78 years old.

LEAD: Mississippi, where one of every three adults is functionally illiterate, is embarking on an ambitious experiment in electronic education: put an I.B.M. computer program in every kindergarten and first grade, and try to have every child reading and writing by the end of the first grade.

LEAD: Engineers and computer scientists at two colleges here say they have harnessed computers to standard industrial sewing machines to produce a larger variety of garments more quickly and cheaply than conventional clothing factories do.

LEAD: Calm, dependable Philippe Venet was supposed to provide the curtain raiser for today's blockbuster spring and summer couture collections. But it did not quite work out that way. Venet emerged with vigor from his unpreposessing mood. Emanuel Ungaro, after his recent marriage to Laura Fanfani, did not give up his sexy clothes but toned them down considerably.

LEAD: In a move that intensified the pressure on Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. to resign, Federal prosecutors today brought before a grand jury the former fashion model who lured Mr. Barry into a videotaped arrest on drug charges last week.

LEAD: The Uptown String Quartet embodies a wonderful idea - a string quartet that can not only handle European classical style but that can also swing and improvise, and that plays music steeped in black American traditions. But in its enjoyable New York debut on Monday night at the 92d Street Y, the quartet - Diane Monroe and Lesa Terry on violins, Maxine Roach on viola and Eileen Folson on cello - ran up against its technical limitations.
LEAD: * DIG Acquisition Corp. said it would extend until Friday its $30-a-share tender offer for all common shares of Di Giorgio Corp., San Francisco, a food and consumer products company.
LEAD: Andrea Chambers, an associate editor at People magazine, was named vice president and executive editor of G. P. Putnam's Sons yesterday. She will assume her new position in mid-March.

LEAD: The Bush Administration pressed returning members of Congress today to support the President's handling of relations with China, but the effort was greeted by a storm of opposition from both Democrats and Republicans.

LEAD: Haiti's nightmare continues. There is no justification for Gen. Prosper Avril's crackdown on Haiti's moderate opposition. LEAD: New Jersey Governor Florio's auto insurance reform proposals, unveiled Monday, look more like cost-shifting than cost-cutting. He says they'll reduce the average driver's premium by 22 percent, from $1,112 a year to $860. LEAD: STATE politicians are increasingly eyeing the pension fund savings of state employees -which have grown to a mouth-watering $700 billion nationwide - as a means to promote local economic development.
LEAD: A mysterious outbreak of a bacterial infection in a hospital's surgical ward has been implicated in the deaths of seven patients and has forced the isolation of 20 others, officials said today.

LEAD: The neighborhood in Cove Neck, L.I., where the Avianca jetliner crashed is one of secluded estates, large homes on sizable wooded lots -and only one road. Last night, that road was jammed with emergency vehicles and with onlookers hoping for a glimpse of the doomed plane.

LEAD: Francis Girod's 1978 film ''L'Etat Sauvage'' (''The Wild State''), based on Georges Conchon's 1964 Prix Goncourt novel, is a seriously half-baked movie that oversimplifies problems of genuine political and social interest. The film opens today at the Public Theater.

LEAD: For its first hour, ''The Image'' zips along as though it were on fast foward. The dialogue is snappy, the pace frenetic and the performances by Albert Finney as a star television reporter and John Mahoney as his producer and pal leave them little time to draw breath. New York is much in evidence, not only in the glimpses of Lincoln Center and Central Park West, of subway stations and stretch limos, but in the high-pressure drive of the television studio and those who run it and are run by it.

LEAD: For the second straight day, the Denver Broncos slipped all over the Tulane University practice field today. The distraction angered Coach Dan Reeves as he continued to prepare his team for the game Sunday against the San Francisco 49ers in Super Bowl XXIV.

LEAD: It is always heartening when a musician with an established reputation in one area dares to sail out into uncharted seas. June Anderson, who has made a major career as a specialist in bel canto opera, took such a voyage on Wednesday evening at Carnegie Hall when she appeared as the soprano soloist in Berlioz's ''Nuits d'Ete.

LEAD: Citicorp yesterday priced the first-ever issue of floating-rate securities backed by credit card receivables. The bank holding company, the largest issuer in the $20 billion, three-year-old market for credit-card-backed securities, is offering $700 million of the new floating issue through the Money Market Credit Card Trust 1989-1.
LEAD: Maybe the Knicks will find happiness Saturday night in Denver against the Nuggets, the next stop in what shows signs of being a trip to nowhere.

LEAD: A Federal Bankruptcy Court has given the L. J. Hooker Corporation permission to hire a real estate concern to help it sell five properties in four states. LEAD: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that up to $15 billion would be needed, starting in 1992, to continue improving service and to pay for the first major expansions of the region's subway and commuter rail systems since the early 1970's.

LEAD: The democratic tide in Eastern Europe finally laps against the sealed borders of Albania. This hermetic Balkan enclave has for decades scorned every liberalizing current in the Communist world. But now its Stalinist rulers are busy denying reports of a ruthless police crackdown against dissenters in northern cities.

LEAD: The Coca-Cola Company and the Walt Disney Company signed a 15-year marketing agreement, extending an association that dates to 1942. The deal calls for Coke products to be available exclusively in all Disney theme parks. Coca-Cola will also have exclusive rights to use certain Disney characters in advertising.
LEAD: Blaming the United States for a rebel attack on Cuban troops in Angola, Havana said today that it was temporarily suspending its troop withdrawal.
LEAD: Douglas Reid Brash, a retired investment banker, died of cardiac arrest on Wednesday at his home in Essex, Conn. He was 66 years old and lived in Essex and Point O'Woods, L.I.

LEAD: NBC-TV said yesterday that it was consolidating its varied marketing activities. The effort will be headed by John Miller, who was promoted to executive vice president for marketing. Mr. Miller will retain responsibility for the advertising and promotion for the network's entertainment, news and sports divisions.

LEAD: Declaring that the fight against drug abuse is the big test of his Administration, President Bush today unveiled a new narcotics program that immediately drew criticism for its continued emphasis on law enforcement and stopping drug shipments.

LEAD: Conner Peripherals Inc., a manufacturer of hard disk drives for computer data storage, laid claim this week to being the fastest-growing manufacturing start-up company in American history. The San Jose, Calif., company reported revenues of $704.9 million in 1989, its third full year of operations.

LEAD: An article and a summary chart on Tuesday about automobile insurance in New Jersey misstated the percentage of drivers insured by the Joint Underwriting Association, a state agency established to cover high-risk drivers. At its peak, the association insured half of the state's drivers; it now insures 40 percent.

LEAD: The East German Christian Democratic party, one of four small parties joined with the Communists in the interim Government now running the country, said today it would withdraw from the cabinet in two weeks and rejoin only in a grand coalition with the entire opposition.
LEAD: The latest fashion statement on the University of Connecticut campus is a T-shirt with this week's Top 20 college basketball poll of The Associated Press on the front.

LEAD: Ever represent anyone who's been thrown out of a Hovercraft or who's slipped on some terrazzo stairs? Has any client been forced at gunpoint to withdraw money from a cash machine? Or has a client been bitten by a hog and lost a leg? If so, your fellow lawyers are looking for you.

LEAD: The engagement of Cathleen Callery to Michael Gioffre, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruno J. Gioffre of Rye Brook, N.Y., has been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Ina H. Callery of Port Chester, N.Y. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: To the Editor: Carol Cott Gross's helpful guide to dining with parents in Florida (''Just Had Lunch? Sorry. Dinner Time!'' Travel,Dec. 3) is superb, but, if you'll excuse me, she left out a few important suggestions:

LEAD: ''THE most mysterious city in Italy,'' a British critic said to me, a man who knows Italy better than most Italians. And, no matter how often I visit Genoa, I find it hard not to agree with him. And yet the Genoese are hospitable and the city - especially in bright weather - lies deceptively open on its hills along the sea, exposed, inviting.

LEAD: THE grayness of a late January Sunday afternoon settles over our town. I have just returned from a long walk, needed, somehow, to try to sort things out, to get reoriented to being a family of two again.

LEAD: After half a decade of denying, deploring, hinting at, acknowledging and sheepishly celebrating their mutual sexual attraction, Tony Micelli and Angela Bower have agreed they don't know their feelings well enough to discuss the future. Sam Malone, having spent five years getting together and breaking up with Diane Chambers, has been chasing Rebecca Howe for 28 months - to no avail.

LEAD: USING a paint brush or roller effectively and without creating a mess takes practice. But skill is important, too. Here are some hints on handling brushes and rollers that may improve your abilities with both tools.

LEAD: THE British playwright Joe Orton poked holes in the veneer of British social mores with the intensity of a construction worker wielding a jackhammer. In ''Entertaining Mr. Sloan,'' the Orton comedy currently on Theater Three's Second Stage in Port Jefferson, the holes are particularly wide.

LEAD: The Plaza Hotel ballroom recaptured the grand style of a turn-of-the-century party on Wednesday. The event celebrated the 50th anniversary of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York and honored the fashion designer Arnold Scaasi, a benefactor. More than 40 women wearing Scaasi dresses gathered with the Scouts on the ballroom stage to pay him tribute.

LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: An article in the [Arts and Leisure] section about the film director Mike Figgis misidentified a candidate for the role of Dennis Peck, a police officer in the movie ''Internal Affairs.'' He was Kurt Russell.
LEAD: In the dingy gray of a Moscow winter morning, the new McDonald's restaurant is an otherworldly presence, huge and sleek and lighting up Pushkin Square with a red and yellow Technicolor glow.
LEAD: A trauma team set up by University of Florida administrators was pushed into unexpected duty during its first week of existence when a recent graduate was murdered on Jan. 17 near the campus.

LEAD: The engagement of Janice Fuchella to James P. Carroll Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carroll of Fort Salonga, L.I., has been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Ann Selobyt of Newton, N.J. Miss Fuchella also is a daughter of the late Joseph Fuchella of Greenwich, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: Midwinter is the fashion doldrums, when clothes worn since October seem tired and lackluster. It's too soon to switch to spring clothes, but the wardrobe definitely needs an injection of freshness.

LEAD: Archbishop Lewis Garnsworthy, an outspoken Anglican cleric who tangled with political leaders over school funding and once scolded his own church for being too ''respectable,'' died on Friday. He was 67 years old.

LEAD: The soprano Carol Vaness is to sing the role of Fiordiligi in the season's final performance of Mozart's ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' at the Metropolitan Opera, Saturday at 8 P.M., replacing Margaret Price, who is ill. Miss Vaness is also in the new production of Gounod's ''Faust,'' which opens on Thursday.
LEAD: A new instrument that can find oil and gas hidden behind the metal walls of a well has been invented by a Washington company.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in The Times Magazine last Sunday about Aspen, Colo., misstated Marvin Davis's role in the 20th Century Fox Film Corporation. He sold his interest in 1985.

LEAD: For This Week: If the weather outdoors suits, dormant trees can be pruned especially large shade trees that are overgrown and ornamentals whose lower limbs block drive and path views. Keep the planting medium of annual and vegetable seed started indoors moist, but do not allow it to become soggy. If gift plants from the holidays are dropping leaves and yellowing, discard them.

Seven victims at the Nassau County morgue have not been identified.
