LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: To the Editor: Please thank Ruth Wolff for her delightful article on navigating a car (''Navigator to Pilot: We're Lost,'' Travel, Nov. 5). Her observations were so accurate that I had to stop reading from time to time because I was laughing so hard that I could not read the words. It has brightened my day and will lighten the burden of navigating in the future.
LEAD: Responding to a report that sharply criticized Yale's record on affirmative action, the university's president has outlined a five-year plan to recruit minority professors.

LEAD: There is only one movie house in the Sicilian town of Bagheria, outside Palermo. Giuseppe Tornatore, who at the age of 33 does not exactly go back very far, can remember when, as recently as the mid-1960's, his hometown managed to sustain eight theaters with a population half its present size.

LEAD: Outside City Hall, barricades have been put up and men with machetes stand guard, ready to protect Roberto Salinas Herrera, mayor in the ''people's democratic government'' that took office here Jan 1. Six blocks away, Natividad Salas Estrada, mayor in the ''constitutional government'' sworn in the same day, signs official papers and receives petitioners at his temporary office, a bare concrete room in a private home.

LEAD: New conventions are commonplace among tournament players, but seldom stand the test of time. They are much rarer in rubber bridge or four-deal games played in club or private homes where partnerships change constantly and the emphasis is on simple bidding.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Judge and Mrs. Michael S. London of Holliswood, Queens and East Hampton, L.I., have announced May wedding plans for her daughter, Allison Emily Wolin, and Alan Michael Luckman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Luckman of Sands Point, L.I.

LEAD: N.H.L. Bruins 2, Flyers 1: Bob Carpenter and Dave Christian scored third-period goals yesterday as the Boston Bruins extended their unbeaten streak to six games by rallying to beat Philadelphia. Carpenter tied the game at 10:39 on a deflection and Christian got the winner at 15:44, beating Pete Peeters from the right circle.

LEAD: In the two decades between the proposing of the controversial Westway project for Manhattan's Hudson River waterfront and the scrapping of the plan in 1985, the fate of the affected area became a cause celebre, especially in Greenwich Village. Now, a new reference book has been published on the buildings and architecture that were at stake in the dispute.
LEAD: About 1,000 Muslim rebels attacked six predominantly Christian villages today, killing at least one person and causing thousands of residents to flee, the military said.

LEAD: The recent arrival of the Microsoft Corporation's Word for Windows signals more than just a new entrant in the overcrowded word processing category. Word for Windows (which lists for $495 and is intended for high-end I.B.M. PC and PS/2 compatibles that use the DOS operating system) is the first program that combines advanced ''what you see is what you get'' word processing, desktop publishing features, an easy-to-use graphical command structure and powerful tools for customization.

LEAD: THE political opening of Hungary means ''the gold rush is on'' for Western investors, said R. Mark Palmer, the United States Ambassador to Budapest. And Mr. Palmer means to be right up there in the front of the pack.

LEAD: The baritone Hakan Hagegard will sing selections from Schubert's ''Schwanengesang'' and works by Ives, Duparc and Wolf at 3 P.M. today at Alice Tully Hall. Warren Jones will be the accompanist. Tickets are $18. Information: 874-6770.
LEAD: AMBULATORY surgery means that you don't have to stay in the hospital. You get there in the morning, and in the afternoon they let you go home. No big deal, right?

LEAD: It snowed heavily Friday afternoon while the Knicks practiced at Westminster College in Salt Lake City. They had a plane to catch for their game here tonight against the Nuggets, but Coach Stu Jackson was in no hurry to leave. The Knicks were working on their transition defense and the coach wanted to make sure his team understood how important an element it was when playing the

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Earl W. Glazier Jr. of Toronto and New Hope, Pa., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter, Wendy Firth Glazier, and Robert Lovell Brainard, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Edwin Brainard 2d of Edgartown, Mass.
LEAD: THE ECONOMY Waiting for the Fed's Next Move

LEAD: IT's not easy being muscular and a woman, said Lisa Ripi, who is both. Sure, no one is going to kick sand in your face, or insist you dance with them when you are a competitive body builder like Ms. Ripi of Island Park. But combining brawn and beauty has its drawbacks, she said.

LEAD: Leslie Brody, a reporter in Princeton, N.J., for The Trenton Times, was married yesterday at her parents' home in New York to Emile Camille Geyelin 3d, a reporter in Philadelphia for The Wall Street Journal. The Rev. Arthur Seaman, a Presbyterian minister, performed the civil ceremony.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: BUTTERFLY WORLD, a three-acre live butterfly park in south Florida, is the first of its kind in the United States and the largest in the world, according to Ronald Boender, its founder and co-owner.

LEAD: THE changes sweeping Eastern Europe are stirring hopes here and in some quarters of Havana that Fidel Castro's long reign over Cuba may be coming to an end. ''We are sure something has to happen in our sad country,'' a dissident in Havana wrote to a friend in the Miami area, where more than 500,000 Cubans have fled since Mr.
LEAD: BRAISING is a technique that deserves to be in every cook's repertory, especially in cold weather. It is a slow cooking method, suitable for thick pieces of food.

LEAD: IN a recent newspaper article, Michael V. McGill, superintendent of the North Shore School District, spoke out against what he called a charge of ''military imagery'' against higher school taxes. The people, he said, ''need to understand more fully what is at stake.'' He offered no real solutions to the problem, nor did he come to grips with the reality of people being torn from their roots and forced out of their homes.

LEAD: As Avianca Flight 52 circled above Kennedy International Airport on Thursday evening, Matias Moyano Rojas, the flight engineer on the Boeing 707, had to rely on fuel gauges that pilots said are often imprecise.

LEAD: The engagement of Anne Carter Lassen and William Julian Cortazzi has been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Jacqueline C. Lassen of Rosemont, Pa., and Charles W. Lassen of Mount Laurel and Barnegat Light, N.J. The bridegroom is the son of Sir Hugh and Lady Cortazzi of London and Vines Cross, East Sussex, England.
LEAD: Thousands of people in the Northeast reported seeing a strange blue-green light in the sky tonight.
LEAD: It sure is. More money changes hands on Super Bowl Sunday than on any other day, or for any other sporting event, throughout the year.

LEAD: ''STANDARD trip-cancellation insurance'' is like a standard sized window: there is no such creature. If you are preparing for a major trip this year, and you are thinking about protecting yourself against losing your deposit money, or more, assume nothing. Get a copy of the insurance brochure and read it.
LEAD: The rise and rise of Spike Lee as America's most prodigiously talented new film maker can now be studied in one exuberant, triple feature evening of home video.

LEAD: We would like to thank Francine Prose for her fine article ''Confident at 11, Confused at 16'' (Jan. 7), on our work with girls growing up, and to offer a point of correction. The discussion of the contrast between the voices of 11- and 16-year-old girls comes from a 5-year study of girls at Laurel School in Shaker Heights, Ohio (financed by the Cleveland and George Gund Foundations), and studies conducted in urban neighborhoods and schools in Boston (paid for by the Rockefeller and Boston Foundations and the Lilly

LEAD: The Board of Legislators, under new leadership in 1990, has decided to forgo afternoon meetings in favor of morning and evening sessions. To encourage attendance by the public, the Board has published a schedule of meetings (generally every other Monday) for the entire year.

LEAD: Peter MacDonald Sr., the leader of the nation's largest Indian tribe, has been ordered to face a trial in an Arizona state court in a civil suit accusing him of conspiring to defraud the Navajo Nation in a $33.4 million purchase of a ranch.
LEAD: Someone else always goes to Disney World.

LEAD: MARTIN STEVENS is accustomed to long hours and tedious duties. As a pilot for United Airlines, he is used to flexible schedules taking him from one part of the country to another with little notice.

LEAD: Judging from the amount of mail I received, my holiday column on camera clubs must have struck a nerve. I can't tell you how many readers have taken me to task for suggesting that camera clubs no longer serve photographers to the extent that they did, say, 100 years ago.
LEAD: Afternoon at the Ballet

LEAD: A beer-drinking subway rider, angered by three men who witnesses said were ''looking for trouble'' and bumped into him on a train in the Bronx yesterday, shot and killed one man and wounded the two others, the transit police said.
LEAD: While I do not disagree that education spending can be reduced, such reduction should not and must not target students with special needs.
LEAD: Louella Luhrman, an Army nurse in World War I who became the nation's oldest veteran, died Friday. She was 108 years old.

LEAD: Arrival of the President's budget on Capitol Hill creates what is charitably known as the Congressional budget process. In truth it is less a process than a Rube Goldberg nightmare of unrealistic deadlines, overlapping jurisdictions and competing mandates involving every committee in Congress. The numbers, contradictory and ever changing, will be irrelevant by September, when the decisions that matter are made.

LEAD: The marriage of Katherine Phillips Evans, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Evans of Indianapolis, to William H. Baldwin 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Baldwin Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of St. James in Brooklyn. The Rev. Dennis M. Corrado performed the ceremony.

LEAD: IT IS SATURDAY NIGHT, and I am writing my best friend in California. I am at home with my husband and three children. She is alone in a studio apartment, with romantic notions about my life as a wife and mother. We are not as close as we used to be. Dear - - -, On most nights, I'm just reading the last Dr.
LEAD: America's Cup syndicates from the United States are reacting with cautious optimism to a new proposal asking them to share their basic technology for designing new boats.

LEAD: BODY MIKE: An Unsparing Expose by the Mafia Insider Who Turned on the Mob. By Joseph Cantalupo and Thomas C. Renner. (Villard, $18.95.) Any minute now, it seems, there will be more mob canaries with tell-all books than there are mobsters to sing about. ''Body Mike'' comes from Joseph Cantalupo, a Brooklyn real estate salesman, loan shark, con artist and hustler at large, and Thomas C.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. David Roger Waldron of Flemington, N.J., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Elizabeth Norris Waldron and Douglas Stephen Boothe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Garland C. Boothe of Westfield, N.J. A graduate of Assumption College, Miss Waldron is a buyer and planner for the Warner-Lambert Company in Lititz, Pa.

LEAD: FOR the American gun lobby, ''the right to keep and bear arms'' in the Second Amendment has become such a familiar refrain that the entire text is often overlooked: ''A well-regulated Militia being necessary to the security of a free State, the right of the people to keep and bear Arms shall not be infringed.

LEAD: THE TALKING EGGS A Folktale From the American South. Retold by Robert D. San Souci. Illustrated by Jerry Pinkney. Unpaged. New York: Dial Books for Young Readers. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 9) THE BOY AND THE GHOST By Robert D. San Souci. Illustrated by J. Brian Pinkney. Unpaged.

LEAD: Mrs. Robert Waggaman of Bethesda, Md., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Victoria Mackenzie Waggaman, to Christopher Knopes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Knopes of Fairfax Station, Va. A July wedding is planned.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ''That's not me; I don't look like that at all,'' laughs Dame Judi Dench, as she recalls her begrimed, ruddy Mistress Quickly in the Kenneth Branagh film of ''Henry V,'' which has won acclaim in Britain and the United States. Backstage in her dressing room at the West End's Aldwych Theater, where she is starring in a revival of ''The Cherry Orchard,'' the short, stocky actress looks fresh-faced and ever so slightly elegant, as befits her part as a lady of the

LEAD: The President of El Salvador assured Vice President Dan Quayle today that he would investigate the killings of six Jesuit priests to see if the evidence implicated anyone ranking higher than the nine military men accused in the slayings.
LEAD: The Nets could have given in easily tonight. They were shorthanded, they were playing a good team on the road and they were trailing by 15 points at halftime.

LEAD: NEW YORK CITY'S Landmarks Preservation Commission this week begins implementing guidelines designed to speed the approval process for the repair or replacement of windows in buildings covered by the landmark laws.
LEAD: By a wide margin, more Americans want the San Francisco 49ers to win the Super Bowl than prefer the Denver Broncos, a New York Times/ CBS News Poll shows.
LEAD: An article last Sunday about an Interstate 95 interchange in Mamaroneck misstated the village's population. It is 17,616.
LEAD: Pittsburgh had developed a reputation for beating top-level opponents and losing to lesser teams, until this season. This season, the Panthers had lost to good and bad alike.
LEAD: The once-mighty Berlin wall is a pitiful sight these days.

LEAD: Serge Koussevitzky was one of the musical giants of the 20th century. As a publisher in his native Russia he brought out the early works of Stravinsky. For his Concerts Kousevitzky in Paris in the early 1920's he commissioned Maurice Ravel to create his orchestration of Modest Mussorgsky's ''Pictures at an Exhibition.

LEAD: For much of the last two days, Vincent Augello, shaken and annoyed, has been sitting alone in his freshly waxed, four-wheel-drive minivan parked between the red-brick gates in front of his five-acre estate on Tennis Court Road. He has been on guard, turning back the curious crowds and camera crews trying to cut through his weedy peach orchard for a glimpse of the wreckage of Avianca Flight 52.

LEAD: With its economy in shambles and its Government increasingly desperate for hard currency, Myanmar, formerly Burma, has sold one of its most valuable overseas assets: the better part of its embassy in Tokyo.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Q. I have dark, wood-paneled walls in my den and would like to lighten the wood. Is it possible to paint over it and retain the look (knots and lines in the wood panels)?
LEAD: An article last Sunday about Washington and its Mayor, Marion S. Barry Jr., misstated the percentage of blacks in the city. It is about 70 percent.

LEAD: Four years after changes in the tax code knocked the wind out of municipal bonds, the market appears poised for a big turnaround. For Wall Street, scrambling more than ever for new sources of income, a jump in market volume can't come soon enough. For investors and issuers, however, the expected surge in activity may be fraught with risks.
LEAD: A New York State plan to provide lawyers to people in danger of losing their homes has been stalled by a dispute over rules proposed by agencies paying for the program.

LEAD: Rather than give change to some panhandlers and not to others, many donors are delegating the responsibility of deciding to whom aid will go to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Often the gifts come with expressions of pained ambivalence about the growing armies of beggars.

LEAD: Gambling, or betting, can be an addiction, like alcohol, or any drug. But what does this have to do with the Super Bowl? The Super Bowl is only one event, although the grandest, during the long, long year of the sports calendar.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: On the city's talk shows, morning radio programs, front pages and nightly newscasts, the topic of conversation these days is the widening controversy surrounding the city's Parks Commissioner, Robert E. Delano.

LEAD: One day after he broke his right collarbone in a spill during a harness race for charity, Laffit Pincay Jr., who makes his living aboard thoroughbreds, said he expected to be sidelined four to six weeks.

LEAD: While other playwrights live in fashionable sections of London, jet back and forth to New York to arrange for Broadway productions and write screenplays for movies that are filmed in Hollywood or Moscow, Alan Ayckbourn stays home in Scarborough tending to his business of writing plays, directing them and running his small 300-seat theater.

LEAD: What makes Antoine Predock so much of an architect is exactly what makes him not so much of an international celebrity: his insistence on designing buildings that relate to the spirit of the place in which he is working. Since nearly all Mr. Predock's projects have been in the Southwest (his office is in Albuquerque, N.M.), his architecture has become a kind of contemporary expression of the traditional architectural language of the desert and the mountains.
LEAD: Machu Picchu
LEAD: An idea four years in the making at the University of Dayton became a reality this month, when the student-run convenience store, Rudy's Fly-Buy, opened for business.
LEAD: When an estimated 120 million Americans flop on sofas and subside into chairs this afternoon to watch the Super Bowl on television, David Jannone and Maria Somma will not be among them.

LEAD: Competence may not be enough. The New York City Ballet danced competently for much of the time on Thursday night at the New York State Theater. Nevertheless, the program was often lacking in both excitement and eloquence.

LEAD: It is no doubt true that, as Catherine Hanssens of the Department of the Public Advocate notes in the article ''Plan for AIDS Testing in Prison Raises Questions'' (Dec. 17), for people who have AIDS there is no more difficult place to be than prison.

LEAD: To the Editor: On Nov. 12 you responded to a query about the Catskill Mountain House (Q & A). You might care to pass on the information that there is a very handsome book, ''The Catskill Mountain House,'' by Roland Van Zandt, published by Hope Farm Press, Strong Road, Cornwallville, N.Y. 12418. This is a reprint of an earlier edition.

LEAD: Distressed by alarmingly depleted stocks of Atlantic salmon in the rivers of the United Kingdom, the Atlantic Salmon Conservation Trust of Scotland has been buying netting rights from commercial fishermen.

LEAD: THE BRIDE FLOATED INTO THE ROOM IN AJU hand-beaded, full-skirted wedding dress with a tumbling train and a long swoop of a veil. The groom wore white tie. At the reception, hundreds of off-white roses filled the ballroom, and a 20-piece orchestra played into the night. It was the kind of fairy-tale event usually reserved for young couples.
LEAD: The first hint of impending disaster was the soft but sudden intrusion of classical music over the loudspeaker.

LEAD: THE IGOR I. SIKORSKY HUMAN-Powered Helicopter Competition, sponsored by the American Helicopter Society, offers a $20,000 award for the first non-engined rotor craft that hovers for 60 seconds and attains an altitude of 3 meters. In 10 years, no one has claimed the prize, but last November a team of students at California Polytechnic State University at San Luis Obispo managed, momentarily, to get off the ground - a first.

LEAD: Carol Ann Glazer, a community development executive in New York, and David Michael Ross, a lawyer in New York, plan to marry in June. Ms. Glazer is the daughter of May Glazer of New York and the late Dr. Harold Glazer. Mr. Ross is a son of Raye N. Ross of Chicago and the late Dr. Jacob N. Ross.

LEAD: A WEEK BEFORE HIS arrest, Marion S. Barry Jr., Mayor of Washington, took umbrage at an article written about him by Bella Stumbo of The Los Angeles Times. The reporter quoted the Mayor, who is black, as saying of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, a new resident of Washington, ''He don't wanna be no mayor.''

LEAD: I am prepared to believe, after sifting through all the available scientific evidence, that (1) oat bran lowers cholesterol and that (2) it does not. Meaning only that when confronted by the conflicting arguments of acknowledged experts, I tend to think both sides may be on to something. In any event, argument is the essence of truth-seeking, whether medical or musical.

LEAD: Like a couple of his forehand shots, John McEnroe went over the line during the Australian Open in Melbourne last week. After repeated displays of his well-known ill temper and foul mouth in a tough match against Mikael Pernfors, McEnroe was booted off the court, becoming the first player in 27 years to be disqualified from a Grand Slam event.

LEAD: Edward C. Corrigan, father of Christa McAuliffe, the teacher-astronaut who was killed along with six other crew members in the Challenger space shuttle explosion four years ago, died of cancer Thursday. He was 67 years old.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Donald P. Dallas of Englewood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Karen Dallas, a third-year law student at Georgetown University, to Dr. Louis William Kantaros, a resident in internal medicine at New England Deaconess Hospital in Boston. A September wedding is planned.

LEAD: Nearly every day, Gerard Van Der Leun, a literary agent who lives in Southport, Conn., turns on his computer and begins having conversations with people he has never met. ''It can span from utter foolishness to extremely serious discussions,'' he said.
LEAD: Gradually over the last several weeks, the basic elements of the budget President Bush will send Congress tomorrow have seeped out.

LEAD: A few names have been carved in the freshly lacquered oak tables. Beer prices have been lowered to compete with other bars. But after a 13-month closing and a change of management, the West End Bar, the fixture near Columbia University that was a stomping ground for Jack Kerouac and Allen Ginsberg, is striving to recapture its fans.
LEAD: Like many hotels in northern New Jersey, the Raritan Holiday Inn at Raritan Center business park competes for guests in an overbuilt hotel market where local occupancy hovers around 60 percent.

LEAD: At Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Boston, Leslie Ann Dunne, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Clement Dunne of East Harwich, Mass., was married yesterday to George Joseph Thomas Sadler Jr., a son of Mrs. Robert L. Young of Amherst, N.H., and George J. T. Sadler of Nashua, N.H.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: With less than a month to go before Nicaragua's elections, leaders of the governing Sandinista Front and their opponents are entering the final phase of what all sides say will be a decisive referendum on a decade of Sandinista rule.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH the overall value of New York City real estate has risen in the last year, flat rents and slow sales have led to a noticeable slowdown in the rate of increase for commercial properties, according to the tentative assessments announced earlier this month by the city's Finance Department.
LEAD: HELL-BENT MEN AND THEIR CITIES By Susan Dodd. 240 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

LEAD: The Library of Congress has been bequeathed a trove of photographs and papers from Frederick A. Cook, a rival claimant with Robert E. Peary to being the first to reach the North Pole. Experts say the material might shed light on the 80-year-old argument.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Two construction workers fell 14 floors to their deaths yesterday when a ladder one was using on a concrete ledge projecting from the top floor of a midtown apartment building toppled, the police said.
LEAD: The Stamps column last week misidentified the man on the 2-cent ''Black Jack'' that paid the drop-letter rate in 1863-65. It was President Andrew Jackson, not Gen. Stonewall Jackson.

LEAD: ''ONLY a Ligurian,'' writes one of Columbus's biographers, ''could have conceived of the idea of sailing West to reach East.'' Incongruous contrast, in fact, is one of the most striking characteristics of Genoa, the capital of Liguria, the birthplace of Columbus and a city of more than one puzzling paradox.

LEAD: Aiming at both a greening of America and a cooling of the world, President Bush will announce in his State of the Union Message next week a program to increase the nation's tree cover by a billion trees a year for the next 10 years, Administration officials say.

LEAD: Publicity gimmicks have a long and occasionally worthy tradition in classical-music history, and this one was both elaborate and effective. In an acknowledged bid for attention for the Carnegie Hall concert of the Illinois Chamber Orchestra on Thursday evening, the group's first New York appearance since a little-heralded Alice Tully Hall event in 1987, its music director, Kenneth Kiesler, devised an unusual project that captured the imagination of several veteran musicians.

LEAD: When it appeared in the early 80's that sliver buildings would dominate the landscape, the owner of 1451 Lexington Avenue was poised to lead the march into the future. As things turned out, new owners decided to lead a march back to the past.
LEAD: A car bomb exploded today near the home of the spiritual head of Lebanon's Shiite Muslims. He was not injured.
LEAD: To the Editor: Ruth Wolff must have been an invisible passenger on automobile trips my husband and I have made both here and abroad.

LEAD: Every 30 years or so, an expansive period of extraordinary dance activity seems to be suddenly on the wane. Anyone looking for the end of the great dance boom that has marked American dance since the end of the 1960's might also consider the lessons of the past.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Dec. 10 about contacts between Baltic nationalists and the United Nations Secretariat misstated the United Nations' stand on the Soviet annexations of Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania. In response to inquiries from international lawyers, further checks by The Times - delayed through an oversight - have found no evidence that the General Assembly ever explicitly recognized the 1940 annexations.

LEAD: ON THE MORNING OF SEPT. 16, 1986, George Gardner picked up Patricia Nicely at a nursing home in Roanoke, Va. Only a year earlier, Nicely, a wealthy woman of 58, had been a high-level official at the National Science Foundation. Now, apparently in the grip of Alzheimer's disease, she had grown so incapacitated that a local judge had made Gardner, a 65-year-old lawyer and friend of Nicely's, her legal guardian.

LEAD: The Federal grand jury investigation of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. is widening into a broader examination of official corruption and drug use, but deep-seated suspicions from Mr. Barry's supporters about the prosecutors' motives continue to haunt the case.
LEAD: THE best things in life may be free, but Wilson H. Faude apparently is not among those who think so.

LEAD: THE creaking noises became noticeable in midsummer, late one evening when I was reading a ghost story. The house is settling, I thought. The trees are scraping the windows. A squirrel must be running across the roof. I shivered. Within a week, however, I became accustomed to a still-occasional creaking sound in the attic.
LEAD: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

LEAD: THE VOYAGE OF MAEL DUIN'S CURRAGH. By Patricia Aakhus. (Story Line Press, Paper, $12.95.) While the story elements central to Greek mythology have remained relatively stable, the oral tradition of Irish storytelling has frequently produced legends that have subtly shifted over time. Such is the case with the tale of Mael Duin, an ancient story of a questing son who sets out in a skin-covered boat called a curragh with a crew of 16 men in order to avenge his father's death.

LEAD: Jets fans could have a special interest in the Super Bowl today. That's because two assistant coaches who will be on opposite sides of the field have emerged among the possible contenders for the team's head coaching job.

LEAD: The president of the AFL-CIO, Lane Kirkland, has noted the end of a monthlong visit and union training session for nine Soviets miners by pledging to assist the free trade union movement in the Soviet Union.

LEAD: An article on Jan. 7 about Oakland, Calif., referred incorrectly to the Oakland Symphony and the Paramount Theater's relation to it. The symphony discontinued operations in 1986; the theater is the home of the Oakland Ballet and the Oakland East Bay Symphony.

LEAD: At first glance, the San Francisco 49ers' defense does not possess the glitz and pizazz that the 49ers' offense features with each snap of the football. Even among the 49er defenders, the safety Ronnie Lott overshadows his peers, with Lott easily the most recognizable and heralded of the bunch.
LEAD: Alarms shrieked through the headquarters of Genentech Inc. here one Friday morning last month, sending hundreds of employees scurrying to the parking lot.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Gerald G. Hotchkiss of Bedford Hills, N.Y., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Julia Anne Hotchkiss and David Reed Eaton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kendall C. Eaton of Farmington, Conn.

LEAD: THE county's Democrats congratulated their November election winners at a well-attended ''victory breakfast'' last Sunday, and then heard a warning from the state Democratic chairman, John A. Marino, that political parties were fast disappearing as factors in candidates' lives.

LEAD: A Poem a Day Keeps Daddy Away Some parents insist that their children dress warmly before going out. Edmund Wilson sent his daughter Rosalind out to play dressed in poetry. This is from ''Near the Magician: A Memoir of My Father, Edmund Wilson'' by Rosalind Baker Wilson (Grove Weidenfeld).
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: L. Straight Clark of Laguna Niguel, Calif., has announced the engagement of his daughter Lisa Whitcomb Clark to Peter Godfrey Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Godfrey of Villanova, Pa. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: Once gadgets of the rich and powerful, cellular telephones are moving into the mainstream. Still primarily business tools, the phones are increasingly showing up in the cars, handbags and pockets of the elderly, housewives, outdoor enthusiasts and others who need instant communications.
LEAD: Is bigger better? Lots of video fans thinks so, judging by the growing popularity of large-screen projection devices.

LEAD: Buying pork that is already ground will not give you lean meat. But if you buy a pork tenderloin, remove the small amount of excess fat and grind the meat in a food processor or an old-fashioned grinder, your final dish will not be swimming in fat.
LEAD: Alexei Yudenich, a former principal ballet dancer with the National Ballet of Canada who was a dance teacher in the South Jersey-Philadelphia area, died of cancer Thursday. He was 46 years old.
LEAD: ROOSEVELT & HITLER Prelude to War. By Robert Edwin Herzstein. Illustrated. 500 pp. New York: Paragon House. $24.95.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: CLOUDS have begun to drift over the market for those co-ops and condominiums in which conversion sponsors still own large numbers of apartments occupied by rent-regulated tenants.
LEAD: ''IT didn't come suddenly,'' said Lloyd Richards, artistic director of the Yale Repertory Theater and the dean of the Yale School of Drama. ''It took me a whole year.''

LEAD: THE plan Gov. Jim Florio announced last week to roll back automobile insurance premiums in New Jersey marks a turning point in the tortured history of an issue that has bedeviled regulators and confused consumers here since 1973.

LEAD: Tony Miles found himself in a must-win situation in the last round of the United States championship on Dec. 3 at the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Long Beach, Calif. It was vital that he gain one more point to tie for fifth place because that would assure him a playoff match for the remaining slot in this year's Interzonal
LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Maslow of Dallas, Pa., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Hilary Gail Maslow and Mark Eric Naud, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Henry Naud of Detroit.
LEAD: DISCOVERING By Robert Scott Root-Bernstein. Illustrated. 501 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $35.

LEAD: Bayport $280,000 6 Kent Court 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 5-year-old colonial; fireplace, deck, basement, 2-car garage, 0.5-acre; taxes $5,900. Farmingdale $173,000 88 Woodward Parkway 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 29-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, den, finished basement; taxes $4,000.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Morton Kulla of Miami have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Marianne Kulla, and Michael Strauss, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen N. Strauss of New York and Belle Terre, L.I. Miss Kulla, 24 years old, is a candidate for an M.B.A. at New York University. She is a cum laude graduate of Wellesley College, where she was a Dana Foundation Fellow.

LEAD: IN New Zealand, a quiet, conservative country where sheep outnumber people and wool is plentiful, it is not surprising that a large segment of the population knits. What is surprising is that the sweaters they turn out are anything but conservative.

LEAD: Among the artists most responsible for the development of abstraction during the early decades of this century, probably none has received less credit than Frantisek Kupka. Consult the standard histories and you are likely to find only a sentence of two about the Bohemian-born painter. Kandinsky, Mondrian, Malevich, even Robert Delauney, have their own chapters in those histories, but Kupka, whose works at one time or another anticipated, echoed and paralleled the paintings of each of these artists, has, by comparison, been written off.

LEAD: At 22, Jude Nwimo already has six years' experience as a tailor and designer under his belt - a belt usually worn under the cinched vests and jackets of the retro-look suits he creates as a self-styled ''jazz tailor.'' This is one young Londoner who doesn't own a pair of jeans. ''That's what's known as casual clothing,'' he said, ''and casual to me means sloppy.

LEAD: Fame may not always be fleeting, but in Massachusetts, at least, it appears to fade fast. That seems to be the case with Dave Cowens, who was the toast of the state in the 1970's as the Boston Celtics' center on two National Basketball Association champions, a player so good and so popular that he had his number 18 retired at Boston Garden.

LEAD: The ''Executive Computer'' column last Sunday, about multimedia computer techniques, misidentified a company that develops multimedia applications using the Audio Visual Connection made by the International Business Machines Corporation. The company is Competitive Solutions Inc., of McLean, Va.

LEAD: As hundreds of communities struggle to check the spread of homelessness, an ambitious program to steer Louisville's homeless into jobs and stable lives has shown some real success. But success comes in tiny steps, and at the same time, failure abounds.

LEAD: I AM having a hard time adjusting to being a homeowner. I find myself doing things I used to laugh at my father for doing: raking every single leaf off the lawn, maniacally clipping every blade that escapes my lawn mower, picking up stray beer cans and McDonald's bags while shaking my head and muttering, ''Kids.

LEAD: TWO years after Maine voters approved the expenditure of $35 million to protect land from development, the state finds itself owning more than 6,600 acres, including 16 miles of unspoiled oceanfront, and has begun to turn its attention to inland properties.

LEAD: GOOD INTENTIONS. By Joy Fielding. (Doubleday, $18.95.) Joy Fielding's eighth novel introduces us to Lynn Schuster, a social worker, and Renee Bower, her divorce lawyer, as their seemingly perfect marriages are ending in sexual betrayal. Resentful children, unloving parents, embittered clients and sabotaging male bosses are carefully interspersed throughout the plot to develop well-paced parallels between the two women's experiences.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Randi Valerie Moelis and Mark David Kantor were married yesterday at Temple Hillel in North Woodmere, L.I. Rabbis Morris S. Friedman and Stanley Platek officiated.

LEAD: The Rev. Julie Markell Brooks, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Brooks Jr. of St. Paul, Minn., was married there yesterday to Charles Andruss Zelle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis N. Zelle of Minneapolis. The Rev. Julie Neraas, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Weyerhaeuser Chapel.

LEAD: Eastern Europe's rush to freedom has inspired hope for a trans-European partnership. The superpowers concur that Europe's ''common house'' should extend from Moscow to Washington. But mixed with optimism is fear of a backslide, as democracy and free markets struggle to take root.

LEAD: To the Editor: I am a lover of spas, and I have visited many in this country and in Europe. I decided to try Eastern Europe about a year ago and discovered a whole new spa experience in Yugoslavia, on the Adriatic coast.

LEAD: A front-page article in the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday about morning television talk shows misidentified a syndicated television series. It is ''Entertainment Tonight,'' not ''Entertainment Today.''

LEAD: AS revolution sweeps Eastern Europe and turmoil erupts across the Soviet Union, the Red Army, the foundation of Soviet superpower status, is in serious trouble. Its huge stocks of modern weapons remain, but the foundation of a fighting force is the people in uniform. LEAD: When the Morton H. Meyerson Symphony Center was inaugurated in September, Dallas boosters insisted that the $106 million building designed by I. M. Pei was proof that the city had survived the oil bust unscarred. Others maintained that the stunning concert hall took Dallas another step in becoming a cultural center of international importance.

LEAD: It was only fitting that tonight's game between Seton Hall and Villanova - teams with two of the poorest records in the Big East -was a sloppy affair marred by a constant parade to the foul line.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Keller of Dallas have made known June wedding plans for their daughter Caroline Anne Keller and William H. Pruden 3d, a son of Dorothy D. Pruden of Ridgewood, N.J., and the late Dr. Pruden.

Dragonetti of Mendham. Miss Dragonetti, 27 years old and a Syracuse University graduate, is a designer with the architectural firm of Jonathon E.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: COMMUNISM has crumbled; now it is art appreciation's turn. ''Do You See What I See?'' is an all-out effort by the Katonah Museum of Art to give viewers the courage of their own perceptions, and anything goes. Well, almost anything: pedagogues hover in the wings with the facts behind the objects in the display, which originated last year in a somewhat different form at Dartmouth College's Hood Museum of

LEAD: Televised scenes of child after child being carried from the wreckage of Avianca Flight 52 by rescue workers have highlighted calls by consumer groups and flight attendants that child-restraint seats be required aboard aircraft, as they are required in cars.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: The crew of Avianca Airlines Flight 52 expressed concern to air traffic controllers about the plane's fuel supply 45 to 50 minutes before the Colombian jetliner crashed on Long Island on Thursday, the National Transportation Safety Board said last night.

LEAD: Among the military hardware vulnerable to Congressional budget cuts this year is a peculiar hybrid aircraft called the V-22 Osprey that is part helicopter and part airplane. It is powered by large rotor blades on each wing tip. When the blades are pitched up for takeoff or landing, it flies like a helicopter.
LEAD: How much of Wall Street's dirty linen should be aired in public?

LEAD: With her third consecutive Australian Open title, Steffi Graf still reigns over women's tennis. But her crown rested uneasily after she had to struggle against Mary Joe Fernandez today in the title match.
LEAD: A July wedding is planned by Jennifer Louise Clarke and Lorin M. Hitt, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Warren Edward Clarke of Newton Centre, Mass., have announced.
LEAD: To many people who know him only from afar, Guillermo Endara Galimany, a 53-year-old lawyer with a dimpled smile and a quick laugh, is something of an enigma.

LEAD: The South East Bronx Community Organization, a private, nonprofit developer, began construction last week on St. Mary's Park Homes, a $20 million affordable-housing project that will create 112 town houses between East 144th and East 146th Streets, off Willis and Brook Avenues, in the Mott Haven section of the South Bronx.

LEAD: Marilyn Louise Harrell, a real estate agent whom investigators called ''Robin HUD,'' has agreed to plead guilty to fraud and tax evasion charges after Federal prosecutors accused her of stealing $5.67 million in Government housing money, a Federal law-enforcement official said today.
LEAD: The ''Your Own Account'' column last Sunday, discussing limited partnerships, misidentified the tax form required of investors. It is a Schedule K-1, Form 1065, not a K-9.
LEAD: OCTOPUS The Long Reach of the International Sicilian Mafia. By Claire Sterling. Illustrated. 384 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $19.95.

LEAD: AS a child of the Depression I was always told that, unlike the children of some of the more affluent families down the street, I would truly appreciate the hard-fought-for things I would accumulate in my life.

LEAD: Ann Leonard Heilman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard J. Heilman of Exeter, N.H., was married there yesterday at St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church to David Michael Murphy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Murphy of Woodbridge, Conn. The Rev. James D. Decker performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Roberto Lorenzo of Rochester have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Lynn Robin Lorenzo and Michael David Pollack, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Pollack of New Rochelle, N.Y. Miss Lorenzo, 23 years old, and the prospective bridegroom, 24, are graduates of Princeton University.

LEAD: REMEMBER the White Horse Cellar in London where Samuel Pickwick and his Pickwickians arrived early for the half-past 7 o'clock stagecoach to Bath? ''The travelers' room - the last resort of human dejection,'' Charles Dickens wrote with distaste. ''The travelers' room at the White Horse Cellar is of course uncomfortable; it would be no travelers' room if it were not.

LEAD: The marriage of Katherine Elisabeth Shapiro, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Shapiro of Raleigh, N.C., to Peter Horace London, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ephraim S. London of New York, took place yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents. Judge John A. K. Bradley of the New York City Civil

LEAD: There was a standing ovation when ''Annie 2: Miss Hannigan's Revenge'' closed at the Kennedy Center Opera House on Saturday night, Jan. 20. While standing ovations are now more the rule than the exception in American theaters - where audiences often want to salute their own good taste as much as the performers on stage - why ''Annie 2''?

LEAD: The owners call what they are proposing a partnership. If they called it a marriage, they could speak of something old, something new, something borrowed and no more blues over player salaries if the players would only accept their proposal.

LEAD: Franco Harris, wearing a dark suit, red tie, neatly trimmed black beard and a large smile that broke out and stayed out - like the Louisiana sun - held a news conference yesterday in a French Quarter restaurant.

LEAD: BURIED waist-deep, and then knee-deep, in a mound of earth, Winnie, ''about 50, well preserved,'' chatters on sunnily about this and that - her happy memories, life's ''many mercies'' - even though ''sorrow keeps breaking in.''

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Domershick of Malverne, L.I., and New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alyssa F. Domershick, to Kenneth Gray Golub, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald L. Golub of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Delray Beach, Fla. A fall wedding is planned.

LEAD: The Super Bowl matches the two conference champions, supposedly the two best teams in the National Football League. But in recent years most of these championship games have been runaways, and Super Bowl XXIV in the Louisiana Superdome Sunday could be the same.

LEAD: Never in need of much encouragement to proclaim their separate identity, nationalist groups in the Basque country and Catalonia are using events in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union to justify calls for regional self-determination in Spain.

LEAD: OVER the last decade, as drug and alcohol abuse soared on Long Island and across the country, almost no treatment centers were opened on the Island. In the last few months, however, a spurt of construction will result in a doubling of treatment capacity to 400 beds on the Island. About 150 more are in the planning stages.
LEAD: Playing a new role in the drug war, the United Methodist Church has moved one of its bishops to the nation's capital to galvanize a grass-roots assault on violence and drug trafficking.

LEAD: The Mighty Lemon Drops, an English group that played at the Ritz on Saturday night, make music cloaked in a fog, both literally and figuratively. Its fog machines, which were working overtime and generated enough murk for the band to construct standard-issue MTV postures, cloaked them in diaphanous swirls.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. William Balderston 3d of Rochester have made known the engagement of their daughter, Mary McKinney Balderston, to Richard Andrew Somerby, a son of Mrs. Peter L. Wastrom of Stamford, Conn., and Richard A. Somerby of Hartsdale, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: A man who likes making a public nuisance of himself and harassing corporate officials. A woman whose idea of a family is four perfect loons. A performer who dresses up in fishnet stockings and plastic hoop earrings, singing about his enthusiasm for illicit drugs. A loner who used to get some of his best ideas thanks to huge amounts of coffee and sugar, and who for a long while lived in a mostly unfurnished place, avoiding visitors because, as he later said, he was doing things he didn't want people to see.

LEAD: With her heart aching from a painful breakup, Mary Meyer placed an advertisement in a singles' column: ''Female wanting to meet a man who would like to marry. Celibate before marriage only.'' More than 100 men responded. Most of them thought it was splendid for a woman to be chaste. But none were thrilled with the notion for themselves.

LEAD: There we were, lined up at the entrance of the church, 10 of us clad in flowing pink taffeta with matching pink pumps and tiny strands of pearls. I wasn't sure whether we resembled overgrown sugarplum faires or bridesmaids, until small bouquets of white roses and baby's breath were thrust in our hands.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Werber of Great Neck, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Susan Lynn Werber, to Dr. Andrew Scott Rokito, a son of Dr. Evelyn Wolf Rokito and Dr. Michael Rokito of Roslyn, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: Television viewers may soon wonder if their favorite kitten has returned home. By spring, MTM Entertainment, whose meowing logo became synonymous with quality programming in the 1970's through the mid-80's, will, after a fallow period, have new shows on each of the big three commercial networks.

LEAD: IN one of those strange quirks of history, El Salvador has suddenly become one of the hottest political topics in Connecticut. Newspapers that normally eschew foreign affairs are discussing it and Panama regularly. Politicians whose eyes otherwise glaze over at anything more global than state patronage can't stop talking about it.

LEAD: Jennifer Anne Leahy, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. Vincent Francis Leahy of Newton, Mass., and Ronald Joseph Kim, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Hyung Kim of Glens Falls, N.Y., plan to be married in April.

LEAD: Composition, like conducting, has historically been a man's field, but when Ellen Taaffe Zwilich's Symphony No. 1 won the Pulitzer Prize for music in 1983, a woman had finally acquired a credential that could not be ignored. Today, Ms. Zwilich is awash in prestigious performances and commissions - including pieces for four of the Big Five orchestras in the next few years.

LEAD: While American politicians lecture the world on fair trade, our dumping laws are an inquisitorial nightmare for foreign companies, making a mockery of due process and justice at every turn. In the last 17 years, Congress and the Commerce Department have repeatedly expanded the definition of dumping.

LEAD: It now appears that in the far-reaching work that established him as the father of modern astronomy, Johannes Kepler was not above taking short cuts. In a recent issue of The Journal of the History of Astronomy, William A. Donahue said that when Kepler presented his theory nearly 400 years ago that planets moved in elliptical rather than circular orbits, he falsely claimed that he had confirmed his insight through independent calculations.

LEAD: JACKSON POLLOCK An American Saga. By Steven Naifeh and Gregory White Smith. Illustrated. 934 pp. New York: Clarkson N. Potter. $29.95. JACKSON POLLOCK By Ellen G. Landau. Illustrated. 283 pp. New York: Harry N. Abrams. $75.

LEAD: In ''Wonder Waltz,'' one of 15 surreal musical fragments composed by Elliot Goldenthal for the soundtrack of the movie ''Drugstore Cowboy'' (RCA Novus 3077-2; all three formats), a synthesizer, bells and delicately layered percussion combine to suggest a broken-down merry-go-round playing woozily in an underwater carnival.
LEAD: Shoppers in the ''Beograd Woman'' department store will find that the mention of certain brand names can make the staff snap as though a curse had just been directed at them.

LEAD: Jane Goldblatt's letter of Dec. 24 is timely in that it addresses an issue that Federal courts have recently decided. The issue concerns the education of all children, regardless of the extent of their handicaps.

LEAD: The article by Nancy Ross (''Men, Women and the Revolution,'' Opinion page, Dec. 17), which included her observation that all four physicians attending the birth of her son were female, sent me down memory lane.

LEAD: LIKE most siblings their age, Christopher and David Ferrer, 10 and 12, spend a fair amount of time squabbling, wrestling and competing - especially when playing a computer game they received for Christmas called, rather ominously, ''Marble Madness.''

LEAD: EVERYBODY has heard the stories, and almost every frequent flier can tell them in the first person: a flight delayed, a connection missed, a plane overbooked or a suitcase lost, and sometimes a confrontation with airline agents over compensation for the inconvenience.

LEAD: The engagement of Melanie Cohen to Lawrence T. Greenberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Greenberg of Scarsdale, N.Y., has been made known by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence S. Cohen of New Haven. An August wedding is planned.
LEAD: FOR many commuters constant travel means tedium and exhaustion. But for Patty Cassidy of Greenwich, a long train ride led to a new business.
LEAD: A PARASITIC mite that preys on honeybees has invaded hives in four towns in the state, forcing the authorities to destroy the colonies in 11 hives.

Simmons Jr. of Hilton Head, S.C., and Mrs. Edwin Thorne of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Norman Reginald Prouty Jr., a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Prouty of Katonah, N.Y. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New

LEAD: THE Herculean labor involved in building the Shoreham nuclear-power plant may have been largely a waste, but a group of energy experts in Midland, Mich., hopes to convince Long Islanders not to overlook the value of an indestructible component: the land on which the plant sits.

LEAD: CANADIANS have for decades been accustomed to sleeping in Holiday Inns, eating Kentucky Fried Chicken and getting their Fords fixed at Midas, and many of them have come to resent the widespread presence of these and other American companies.

LEAD: DURING his secret visit to Beijing last month, President Bush's national security adviser toasted Chinese leaders with sympathetic words. ''In both our societies there are voices of those who seek to redirect or frustrate our cooperation,'' he said. ''We must take bold measures to overcome these negative forces.
LEAD: Time is running out for Yasir Arafat and the Palestine Liberation Organization to grab the best political bargain they ever have been offered or are likely to get.

LEAD: Most college students hate institutional food, and Clark University students are no exception. But the university and its food service contractor, Daka, are putting their money where the students' mouths are.

LEAD: The political galleries are full of people asking will he or won't he run for mayor here. But the Rev. Jesse Jackson, as he so often does, is playing a more elaborate political game, one in which his potential candidacy for office provides both a platform and his strongest bargaining chip.

LEAD: THE DAME IN THE KIMONO Hollywood, Censorship, and the Production Code From the 1920s to the 1960s. By Leonard J. Leff and Jerold L. Simmons. Illustrated. 350 pp. New York: Grove Weidenfeld. $22.50.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Leo S. Ullman of Sands Point, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Susan Katharine Ullman to Arik Mark Levinson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen R. Levinson of San Francisco. A May wedding is planned.
LEAD: East Germany has bugged telephone conversations of West German Government officials for years, and evidence indicates it continues to do so, a news magazine reported today.

LEAD: THE REVOLUTION DAY PARADE IN THE western Siberian city of Tyumen has dwindled in recent years from a two-hour spectacle to a perfunctory 45-minute exercise, reflecting the collapse of the Communist faith. Last Nov. 7 the Tyumen city fathers, desperate to boost their ratings, agreed to permit a small show of dissent.
LEAD: The unrest in the Soviet Union has raised the question of whether nuclear arms there could fall into the hands of political extremists, military experts in the United States say.

LEAD: An investigation by Americas Watch, the New York-based human rights group, has concluded that contras were responsible for the deaths of two Roman Catholic nuns whose car was attacked on a remote Nicaraguan highway on Jan. 1.

LEAD: The road to adaptations is paved with good intentions, just as the road leading away is a vale of dashed hopes - the disappointment of readers for whom no cast or single interpretation can match the ideal images in the mind; the disillusionment of authors standing by the wayside clutching checks and crying Foul!

LEAD: For 21 seasons and through several changings of the guard, Syracuse basketball teams had been frustrated by their inability to beat Georgetown on its home court. For an entire week before this afternoon's game between the two Big East Conference powers, Syracuse's upperclassmen recounted stories about the string of failures since 1967-68, when Syracuse defeated Georgetown, 95-78, at McDonough Gymnasium.

LEAD: I read with interest the interview with the Rev. Robert Williams (New Jersey Q & A, ''Answering the Call for a Gay Ministry,'' Dec. 10). And I agree with his premise that the mainstream church has inadequately addressed the needs of the homosexual community. Yet I am compelled - theologically - to take issue with him on three fronts.

LEAD: They have never been considered culinary meccas or odes to the nuances of flavor. Wedding receptions have always been more devoted to decoration than cooking. Ice sculptures, tomato roses, stuffed snow peas and sugar flowers may have become extinct were it not for weddings. In the movie ''True Love,'' a caterer persuades the beleagured young couple to serve sky-blue mashed potatoes to match the bridesmaids' dresses.

LEAD: Tommy Armour 3d, who has led or shared the lead all the way, opened up a three-stroke advantage today in the third round of the Phoenix Open.

LEAD: What's ''American''? Mom? Apple pie? What's truly ''American?'' Not apple pie. Nobody goes into a restaurant anymore and orders apple pie. Anyway, the best apple pie I ever had was in Ulm, Germany.
LEAD: Nearly two million nonworking Americans 50 to 64 years old are ready and able to work, a new survey shows.

LEAD: The Rev. Henry N. Segrest Jr. of Brinkley, Ark., has announced the engagement of his daughter Anne Elizabeth Segrest to Edgar Hassell McCulloch 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. McCulloch Jr. of Ashford, Conn. A March wedding is planned.

''We're taking the rainwater that falls and sending it to Wesleyan University to be analyzed,''

LEAD: Four years ago, Jamil Abdul-Malik, a teacher and self-styled social engineer, approached Yonkers officials for help in building affordable housing on the West Side, where the city's black population is clustered. He received little encouragement.
LEAD: FRANK MANTLIK says he would go to just about any height to spot any bird rarely seen in Connecticut. Mr. Mantlik, a professional wildlife photographer, has been a bird watcher for 20 years.
LEAD: DEVICES AND DESIRES By P. D. James. 433 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

LEAD: On the face of it, ''Romance of the Taj Mahal'' at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art ought to have been an easy, unquestioned and almost ecstatic success with a very large public. For what is the Taj Mahal, if not the building that most people, worldwide, most want to see? Who ever came back from Agra and said, ''Watch out, folks.
LEAD: The serviceable and sometimes ornate uniforms worn by doormen, chefs, chauffeurs and butlers have become coveted fashions in some quarters.
LEAD: OUT-OF-TOWN investors flocking to this city to scoop up real estate at rock-bottom prices have given rise to its newest sport - ''bottom fishing.''

LEAD: GEORGE MARTIN is a bubbling, boisterous bistro that has taken Rockville Centre by storm. Its old-fashioned yet new-fashioned look, spirited young staff and huge portions of well-prepared stick-to-the-ribs food serve as magnets to pull in a crowd.

Sesler of Erie, Pa., has been made known by her mother and stepfather, Mr. and Mrs. Charles T. Maxwell of Bronxville, N.Y., and her father, Peter C. Wiese of New York. A July wedding is planned.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Morton H. Farber of New York have made known February wedding plans for their daughter, Harley Alison Farber, and Robert Martin Raiff, a son of Elizabeth Haron of Greenwich, Conn., and Frederic Raiff of New York.

LEAD: MONDAY: Personal income figures for December will be announced. President Bush is scheduled to submit his 1991 budget to Congress. WEDNESDAY: Leading economic indicators and new housing sales for December will be released. Richard Darman of the Office of Managment and Budget testifies before the Senate Budget Committee.

LEAD: I cannot offhand recall an article in a small magazine making a bigger splash in the literary pool than Tom Wolfe's manifesto, ''Stalking the Billion-Footed Beast,'' in the November 1989 issue of Harper's Magazine. Mr. Wolfe, an old hand at self-publicizing, has been busy widening the ripple effect by lecturing to full houses in places as disparate as Columbia University and the Century Club in New York City; he has appeared on ABC News's ''Nightline'' in his ice-cream suit and high-necked shirt, his demeanor, as always, bland and gentlemanly, to spar tangentially with Margaret

LEAD: THE man who crafted Gov. Jim Florio's new proposal for automobile insurance envisions a year of major changes for New Jersey drivers, a time when insurance costs rise for some people, drop for most others, and in the end, the administration hopes, leaves the state with an insurance system that is fairer and more sensible.

LEAD: In the early 1980's, Paul Brickman made his directorial debut with a buoyant film about a clean-cut Chicago teen-ager who turns over his parents' pristine home to a bevy of call girls. Called ''Risky Business,'' the kinetic comedy ended up a box-office hit.

LEAD: For nearly two weeks now, the Denver Broncos' defensive players have been studying films of the San Francisco 49ers' offense: Joe Montana slinging those quick arrows, Jerry Rice and John Taylor catching them, Roger Craig and Tom Rathman rumbling upfield. But today those films will come to life. Today the Broncos will take their Super Bowl XXIV test.
LEAD: Sunday Silence, who won three of four memorable duels with Easy Goer last year, today was named thoroughbred racing's Horse of the Year for 1989.

LEAD: IN ''The Cocktail Hour,'' in which the making of a martini is mentioned three times within the play's first three minutes or so, a middle-aged publisher (John) visits his well-to-do parents, asking for approval of a play he's written. The play, John announces to his father (Bradley), is about a family that's ''recognizably us.

LEAD: As it happens, the rogue program that Robert Tappan Morris fed into a national computer network in 1988 did not launch missiles, disrupt the stock market or shut down the telephone network. But it did scare the wits out a lot of people who run computer systems. Now some of them would like to see the favor returned by means of a jail sentence for Mr.

LEAD: At the Lincoln Square Synagogue in New York, Sharon R. Brodwin, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gordon Brodwin of Malverne, L.I., was married last evening to Gerald Laderman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Peter Laderman of White Plains. Rabbis Herschel Cohen and Mark L. Winer performed the ceremony.

LEAD: THE county may be a victim of its own success. In the 29 years since the 10.3 miles of the Cross-Westchester Expressway opened, the roadway - I-287 - has been a magnet for business growth in the county. It has also been the scene of horrendous congestion. Now the companies that attracted the traffic in the first place are considering getting involved in transportation management themselves, to help solve the problem.

LEAD: Washington Week is here: President Bush presents his new budget tomorrow; on Tuesday, he reports to Congress on the State of the Union. Yet even with these main events at hand, public debate remains preoccupied by a dazzling, poorly understood preliminary, the Moynihan plan.
LEAD: Federal District Judge George Carter Carr, the chief judge of the Middle District of Florida, died of a brain tumor on Friday. He was 60 years old.

LEAD: Nearly three years ago, Cairy S. Brown, an audit manager at Arthur Andersen & Company, decided she wanted to spend more time with her new baby. The problem: What constitutes part time work for someone who might work a 90-hour week during a client's crunch time?

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Angelo Carlucci of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Bethany Jane Carlucci, to Michael Sanders Astrachan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Boris Astrachan of Hamden, Conn. A July wedding is planned.

LEAD: AS a hopelessly provincial Easterner I had always thought of Astoria as (a) the last name of a well-known New York hotel, (b) the only name of an area of New York City or (c) the title of a half-forgotten travel book by Washington Irving. Recently, however, I visited (d) the real thing - a handsome and historic city situated where the mighty Columbia River meets Oregon's thundering Pacific coast.

LEAD: THE Soviet immigrants from Leningrad had been in Israel only 48 hours, and here in one of the West Bank's largest Jewish settlements their suitcases still sat unpacked in an otherwise empty bedroom. But the couple already spoke with the conviction of hardened Israeli nationalists.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE source of ''My Fair Lady,'' Shaw's ''Pygmalion'' is about a man bettering a woman, burnishing her rough edges, eliminating her telltale accent. Professor Higgins took the rough diamond that was Eliza Doolittle and turned her into a gem - no small feat in Edwardian England, where the quality was as alert to interlopers as are gazelles to the scent of lion.
LEAD: When he was 6 years old, his mother committed suicide. At 18, he wrote a play, called ''Women and Wallace,'' about the calamity and the effect it has had on his life.

LEAD: When the mercantile nations of Europe sent ships around the world in the 15th and 16th centuries, they introduced the notion ofmoney to many people who had relied on barter forthousands of years. Sometimes the results were strange. Among some tribes of western Africa, an object shaped like a Celtic torque or bracelet was held in high esteem.

LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ''Clever'' may be the most feared compliment in rock. A band can labor for a year over a set of songs, agonizing over every syllable and note and reverberation; it can rack its brains over the cover art and lie awake nights remembering whom to thank in the fine print. But let anyone suggest that the results are clever, and the party might be over.

LEAD: A TWO-YEAR-OLD state-financed computer system intended to increase efficiency and standardize procedures in the state's overburdened municipal court system has enabled courts to collect fines and process traffic summonses far more quickly than ever before, court officers and state officials say.

LEAD: Now that the January orgy of bowl and all-star games has almost faded from memory, we spectators can turn to other, more elevating activities, like today's Super Bowl. The players, meanwhile, some 2,000 of them representing more than 30 bowl-qualifying football powers, have returned to their campuses and resumed what the National Collegiate Athletic Association likes to describe as ''normal academic lives.

LEAD: The leaders of the rebellion in Soviet Azerbaijan proposed peace negotiations with the Kremlin today, provided that the central Government first withdraws the troops who seized control of the capital in street battles a week ago, after President Mikhail S. Gorbachev declared emergency rule.

LEAD: Before the game between Connecticut and St. John's tonight, a desperate student circled the brand-new Harry A. Gampel Pavilion and pleaded with passers-by to sell him a ticket. After someone offered him a ticket for $150, he shrugged and walked away. Later, he might have regretted not dipping into his wallet.
LEAD: More than 100 students voluntarily cut short their winter vacations to join a workshop at Swarthmore College last weekend intended to promote tolerance for diversity on and off campus.

LEAD: Tracy Freya Margolin and Dr. Mark Jay Landsman were married last evening at Temple Emanuel in New Hyde Park, L.I., by Rabbi Harold Sapperstein. Mrs. Landsman is a daughter of Linda Margolin of Jericho, L.I., and Eugene Margolin of Great Neck, L.I. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Landsman of North Woodmere, L.I.

LEAD: About half the $36 billion in deficit reduction that President Bush will propose in the budget he sends to Congress on Monday would come out of domestic programs, including some efforts in education, housing, transportation and health.

LEAD: When you spend a lot of money for a car, certain things are to be expected. You get fancy trim, maybe leather. You get performance. And, generally, you get high-tech electronics and mechanical doodads.
LEAD: A picture caption in the [Arts and Leisure] section about actors playing against type misidentified the film in which Cher appeared. It was ''Moonstruck.''
LEAD: HAVING survived the storm on the road, I drove up to our house. Relief! I saw my husband through the kitchen windows cooking dinner by candlelight. Romance!

LEAD: Angered that his troops were not firing on demonstrators, Nicolae Ceausescu threatened on Dec. 17 to execute two of his top ministers, according to testimony read today in the first public trial of members of the ousted government.

LEAD: Near Manhattan's northern boundary, nestled comfortably within an expanse of greenery, sits the Cloisters, John D. Rockefeller Jr.'s homage to the Middle Ages. Like the medieval monastery it resembles, this uptown branch of the Metropolitan Museum has many functions: a landmark to the traveler, a magnet to the aficionado of medieval art, an oasis to the seeker of calm.
LEAD: Buried in the news of the recent default of the Campeau Corporation was a startling bulletin for many shareholders of Fidelity's Puritan Fund.

LEAD: Pumping 12 million barrels a day out of a global total of 63 million, the Soviet Union is the world's largest petroleum producer. It is also No. 1 in natural gas. Should economic and political disarray hinder Soviet energy production, the ripples would reach from Houston to the Persian Gulf.
LEAD: Q. I have dark, wood-paneled walls in my den and would like to lighten the wood. Is it possible to paint over it and retain the look (knots and lines in the wood panels)?

LEAD: The question is not whether betting on the Super Bowl is excessive, but instead, why is betting on the Super Bowl excessive?

LEAD: Reka Feketekuty is one of the best storytellers working today in New York modern dance. She has a knack for subtly suggesting atmosphere, usually dark, and her stories are resonant with extra meanings. But a program presented by Reka and Company Dance Theater on Monday night at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center suggested that she may be better at telling stories than at enunciating great themes.

LEAD: ''PERHAPS one of this year's Winterfest plays will become a classic, playing 400 years from now,'' says this year's promotional brochure for the series now under way at the Yale Repertory Theater in New Haven. ''Perhaps not.''

But in his works that have been heard in New York City - the opera ''Nine Songs,'' which was performed last year, and ''Soundshape,'' which had its premiere on Sunday evening at the Guggenheim

LEAD: I am writing in response to an article, ''Price of Heating Oil Prompts an Outcry'' that appeared Jan. 7 in the Westchester Weekly. Overall the article was even-handed and among other things offered information on fuel co-operatives as an alternative to local fuel marketers. Please allow me to offer some insight as to how a typical co-op works.

LEAD: To the Editor: Your reports on Marienbad and Carlsbad in Czechoslovakia reminded me of my youth. My brother and I spent summer vacations at the home of our grandparents in Marienbad. They had a large house there called Villa Souvenir, which catered to summer guests with room and board and in later years served as a glorified bed and breakfast.

LEAD: ''Being a Scotsman, it goes against the grain to spend $1.50 to buy a $1,'' said Gavin Dobson, president of Murray Johnstone International, a Chicago money manger. He was explaining why he did not buy into the New Germany Fund Inc., which was launched last week. Plenty of other people did buy. The German stock market has fallen 4 percent since it hit a record high on Jan.

LEAD: IT has become commonplace to lament the passing of the day when thinkers like James B. Conant and Lewis Mumford played as influential a role in politics as today's media advisers. Even to those who consider themselves among the last holdouts, the question is no longer whether intellectuals are in hiding, but why.

LEAD: ON a Saturday afternoon last November, Ruth V. Washington, the newly appointed United States Ambassador to the Republic of Gambia, paced the floor of her Hartsdale home and talked with excitement about relocating to the small, African country.

LEAD: The engagement of Hilary duPont Limbocker to Anthony Dick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Mathews Dick Jr. of Washington, has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Derek L. Limbocker of New York. A June wedding is planned.
LEAD: THE NEW POLITICS OF PORNOGRAPHY By Donald Alexander Downs. 266 pp. Illinois: University of Chicago Press. Cloth, $42; Paper, $14.95.

LEAD: A MOTHER'S STORY: The Truth About the Baby M Case, by Mary Beth Whitehead with Loretta Schwartz-Nobel. (St. Martin's, $4.95.) The surrogate mother who decided to keep the baby she was hired to bear tells her side of the story. Last year our reviewer, Josh Greenfield, said this account changed his opinion about the case.

LEAD: YOU don't need spurs, chaps or a 10-gallon hat to eat at Cheyenne Grill, the storefront restaurant on the corner of Main and Elm in Danbury. Just months ago the L-shaped space was home to another restaurant, called Saffron, and the decor remains much the same, with familiar orchid-colored banquettes in the rear and the same pink marbleized tabletops.

LEAD: VIVID memories flashed to the screen of my mind as I laced my skates. I hadn't skated since high school, over 20 years had passed, and here I was, incredulously, tying my old, forgotten skates. I had to laugh at the lunacy; no small child clamored at my side justifying the escapade.
LEAD: Senator Dave Durenberger said Friday that he had repaid the Senate $11,005 in Government money used to rent a condominium in Minneapolis.
LEAD: A grandson and namesake of Secretary of State John Foster Dulles said Friday that he was dismayed by a proposal to rename Washington Dulles International Airport for Dwight D. Eisenhower.

LEAD: To the Editor: In the article on hotel fire safety (Practical Traveler, Nov. 19) Betsy Wade addressed a little-known fact about fire safety. Namely, it doesn't exist in many hotels across the United States.
LEAD: An obituary and its headline last Sunday about a leading member of the Social Democratic Party in West Germany misidentified him in some editions. He was Herbert Wehner.

LEAD: ''I joined because it's the only organization that explores the missing half of sexual liberation - the right to say no.'' - David M. Dismore, a member of the National Chastity Association. [20:4.]

LEAD: Unlike the great industrial wars of America's past, the recent strikes against the Pittston Company and the Nynex Corporation were not over wages or even work conditions, but over health benefits. Such disputes are becoming commonplace. Union officials view health insurance as a basic necessity. As one of the Nynex strikers' picket signs put it, ''Cutting Our Health Benefits Is Sick.

LEAD: A NEW, controversial and high-risk market is evolving in occupied apartments in converted New York City cooperatives, with many of them being offered to investors at deeply discounted prices. The big price breaks are a direct result of the troubles some conversion sponsors are experiencing in meeting maintenance and debt service charges on the apartments they still own in converted buildings.

LEAD: When Clayton Williams, the leading candidate in the campaign for the Texas Republican Party's gubernatorial nomination, suggested converting an environmentally sensitive wilderness area into a prison camp where young drug offenders would learn ''the joys of busting rocks,'' the proposal sparked little dispute because it came in a campaign already marked by oddities.

LEAD: There is no easygoing ''mommy track'' for heads of state. Last week, only a day after Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan gave birth to her second child, a girl, the opposition staged a huge rally in Karachi aimed at pressuring the Bhutto Government while the Prime Minister recovers from the Caesarean birth.

LEAD: UNDER a Congressional order to break even or shut down its debt-plagued express line to Atlantic City, Amtrak officials want to bring New Jersey's casino executives to the bargaining table next month in hopes of finding a way to save the line.

LEAD: For Willa Cather, ''O Pioneers!'' was the novel in which she spoke for the first time in her own voice, free of influence and literary tradition. In it, she said, she had hit ''the home pasture,'' and the book was to set her off on her creative journey. Written in 1913, ''O Pioneers!'' remains one of the enduring works of American literature.

LEAD: Now that it's become chic to not only shop in discount stores but admit it, to carry unprestigious shopping bags, and to own up to such things as eating frozen dinners and preferring inexpensive chocolate, certain other things follow. For instance, little quirks like eating while watching television, managing very well for a week or more without dusting, and virtually living in the bedroom, all of which have been done for years, are now being talked about openly and even proudly.

LEAD: A jockey injured in a four-horse pileup Friday at Beulah Park died today of head injuries.

LEAD: Harassment of Western women traveling in South Asia has turned increasingly violent, marring their vacations and undermining efforts by several countries to cash in on a recent boom in beach vacations, diplomats and tourists say.

LEAD: Representative Augustus F. Hawkins, veteran chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee and the longest-serving black in Congress, said Friday that he would retire at the end of the year. The 82-year-old Democrat has represented the primarily black and Hispanic Watts area of Los Angeles and surrounding Hispanic suburbs since January 1963.

Since then lawsuits and budget constraints have whittled away that harsh policy, and the Government has to find a new strategy for handling a new wave of migrants.
LEAD: One of the oddest political campaigns in recent New Orleans history is ending as it began: quietly, with an uncharacteristic lack of passion.

LEAD: Many of the 1,600 delegates at a Communist Party congress severely criticized their party today and moved toward dissolving it and replacing it with a new left-of-center political grouping.

LEAD: DESPITE New Jersey's reputation for being crowded, in only two of the state's six large industrial cities - the six sisters they're sometimes called - is it possible to take a few steps and stroll out of one city and into another.

LEAD: SAL ALFANO can size up a beard in no time. ''That's a farmer's beard,'' he'll say to a new customer. Or, ''You look like Zeus.''
