LEAD: OLDER than 40 and starting from scratch: I thought I was a unique item, but as soon as I peeked out of my shell I found a sea of women in similar positions.

LEAD: Stacy Beth Bergmann, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Bergmann of Howard Beach, Queens, was married there last evening at the Rockwood Park Jewish Center to Robert Jay Rosen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Rosen of North Hills , L.I. Rabbi Rafael Saffra officiated.

LEAD: The Japanese yen, which has been chronically weak against the dollar, finally found some muscle last week. Betting that the Japanese would raise interest rates after the Parliamentary election on Feb. 18, traders bought yen aggressively last week for the first time in months. By the end of the week, the dollar had fallen to 142.85 yen, down from 146.00.

LEAD: Lewis Mumford, a philosopher, literary critic, historian, city planner, cultural and political commentator, essayist and perspicacious writer on the subject of architecture, died on Friday at his home in Amenia, N.Y. He was 94 years old.

LEAD: THE warm glow of gold and silver handcrafted jewelry is an antidote for midwinter blues as well as an answer for Valentine's Day gift giving. Visitors to the National Invitational Valentine Jewelry Show at the Sheila Nussbaum Gallery will find more than 300 pieces of work from which to choose.
LEAD: MISGUIDED LIVES By Alain Elkann. Translated by William Weaver. 291 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $18.95.

LEAD: It was just one more small step toward their own Super Bowl. The Moscow Bears beat the Russian Braves, 20-0, today before they had to give up the field to a group of 10-year-old soccer players from the Central Army Sports Club.
LEAD: WHITE GIRLS Stories. By Lynn Lauber. 187 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Company. $17.95.

LEAD: The Dec. 31 article ''State Lags in Treating Cocaine Addicts'' gives the impression that Reynolds Hospital (the correct spelling is Runnells Hospital) does not maintain its own drug and alcohol facility.

LEAD: He'd been hoping to have his tangled personal life cleared up before the baseball season, but now it appears that the dispute between the Yankee slugger Dave Winfield and his former common-law wife, Sandra Renfro, is going to drag on a bit longer.

LEAD: A yearlong round of indictments involving bingo operations and official corruption here has put Democrats on the defensive in a legislative election year and presented the generally somnolent state Republican Party with a wake-up call to arms.
LEAD: MEETING over lunch last week, about 100 New Rochelle business and civic leaders talked about how the city could keep its bruising political frays from damaging its prospects for development.

LEAD: EVEN among turn-of-the-century big stores, B. Altman's full-block building at the northeast corner of 34th Street and Fifth Avenue was a particularly imposing palace of consumption. Its move to Fifth Avenue in 1906 also marked a new development in the history of the thoroughfare - a shift from elite, small shops to a mix of both the specialized and the colossal.

LEAD: Frank X. Gargiulo, a former member of the New York City Civil Service Commission, died Thursday of a brain tumor at the St. Rose of Lima Home in Manhattan. He was 60 years old and lived in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn.
LEAD: Those simple symbols called bar codes on the bottom of envelopes can be deciphered by a bright first grader, but finding the rare error is challenging enough to interest adults.

LEAD: The sun came out on Monday morning, Nov. 6, 1989, and so did the reporters and television news crews, for the first day of rehearsal of ''Annie 2: Miss Hannigan's Revenge.'' The $7 million musical continuation of ''Annie,'' which was one of the most successful shows in Broadway history, had been announced with much hoopla in

LEAD: THE innovative Music at Saint James series is held in the lovely village church in North Salem and is devoted - uniquely in the county -to chamber music with pipe organ. It begins its fourth season today at 4 P.M.
LEAD: In a sometimes sloppy, somewhat surreal game that was part slap shot and part slapstick, the Islanders embarrassed the Pittsburgh Penguins, 9-3, this afternoon at Nassau Coliseum.
LEAD: Like Blanche DuBois, the American capital system now finds itself dependent on the kindness - or at least the money - of strangers.

LEAD: UNFINISHED CONVERSATIONS: Mayas and Foreigners Between Two Wars. By Paul Sullivan, (Knopf, $22.95.) In the annals of peasant and Indian uprisings, the Mayan Caste War of 1847 ranks as one of the most prolonged revolts against a postcolonial government. For more than half a century, the oppressed Maya posed a serious threat to Mexican authority in the Yucatan Peninsula.

LEAD: The former Phoenix Cardinals quarterback, Neil Lomax, who retired earlier this month because of degenerative arthritis in his left hip, will undergo a hip transplant in Los Angeles in the next four to six weeks, the team's orthopedic surgeon said. . . . Claude Vilgrain and Jon Morris, who had been assigned to the Devils' Utica farm team, were recalled to the parent club to fill in for three injured forwards.

LEAD: The nameless person attracted scant attention in life, despite his efforts to provoke people in the subway. One night last week he tried again, by spitting on and then punching Rodney Sumter, waiting for a train with his little boy. Enraged, Mr. Sumter fought back; within minutes the deranged, homeless man lay dead.

LEAD: In the last couple of years, the pouf seems to have gone out of the down coat, the overstuffed garment that wreaked winter havoc with coat-checkers and turned a lot of fashionable people into reasonable facsimiles of the Michelin Man. Still very much around, however, is the cloth coat, adaptable as ever to the winds of change.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: C.R. Bard Inc., a leading maker of inflatable catheters used by doctors to unclog arteries, was riding high last year. But then the tips on some of its newest catheters began breaking off inside patients under treatment for heart and vascular disease.

LEAD: KING INDUSTRIES of Norwalk, which has been in the chemical business for 60 years, has a collection of protective suits, fire suppression foam and chemical analysis equipment and a staff of environmental scientists that no fire department could afford to maintain.

LEAD: SIR YEHUDI MENUHIN will conduct the English String Orchestra when it appears at the Palace Theater in Stamford next Sunday in a program that includes Elgar's Serenade in E minor, Benjamin Britten's ''Simple Symphony'' and the Walton Sonata for String Orchestra.

LEAD: Key Matchups Joe Montana vs. Alphonso Carreker and Michael Brooks. The Broncos are unlikely to get to Montana in the pocket because he usually throws the ball so quickly. The Broncos are not that concerned if he scrambles to the left because he seldom throws from there. But they know he is dangerous when he scrambles to the right, so they will work hard to contain him there.

LEAD: I was saddened to see that William Safire has fallen for the simplistic Anglo-Saxon chauvinism of Strunk and White (On Language: ''Word of the Year: Freedom,'' Dec. 31). He writes that ''these Germanic words [like freedom] are punchier than their Romance-language counterparts: rich and hard are more telling than affluent and arduous.
LEAD: Q. I have dark, wood-paneled walls in my den and would like to lighten the wood. Is it possible to paint over it and retain the look (knots and lines in the wood panels)?

LEAD: A TWO-YEAR slump in property values has pushed down home prices in the New York region and mortgage interest rates also have fallen, but the reductions show little sign of attracting the huge numbers of buyers who were locked out of the region's giddy real estate market in the mid-80's.

LEAD: Bernie Nicholls's life is defined more by his MasterCard than any master plan. Nicholls does not have an agent. He retains no financial consultant. By his own frank admission and rough estimation, he has spent as much as $10,000 a month on dress suits.

LEAD: MORE than 600 people have been arrested and face suspension of their drivers licenses under Connecticut's new drunken driving law, and few of those motorists are fighting it, the state Motor Vehicles Department says.

LEAD: NEARLY a month after he took office and nearly three months after he was elected Mayor of New York City, David N. Dinkins has yet to name the heads of about a dozen big municipal agencies that handle problems from jails to garbage. So who's minding the store?

LEAD: Art imitates life in the offices of the National Abortion Rights Action League and the National Right to Life Committee. At Naral, the prints and posters are mainly renderings of women. In the offices of Right to Life, the pictures are of babies. The issue of abortion is framed, quite literally, on the walls of their Washington headquarters: which comes first, the woman or the fetus?

LEAD: Tom Landry, who built the Dallas Cowboys from a National Football League expansion team into a two-time Super Bowl champion, and Franco Harris and Jack Lambert, teammates on the four-time Pittsburgh Steeler champions of the 1970's, were among the seven figures voted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame today.
LEAD: WITH automobile insurance rates high and rising, Connecticut officials last week began a yearlong study to try to find calm solutions in advance of a storm.

LEAD: ''There's no business like show business,'' goes that marvelous Irving Berlin song. As the author of ''Other People's Money,'' a play about business, and as a businessman turned playwright myself, I would have written the lyric differently: ''There's no business in show business'' would have been more like it.

LEAD: Joe Dumars made his first basket of the second half with only 1 minute 40 seconds to play, snapping a tie and lifting the Detroit Pistons to an 85-83 victory tonight over the Minnesota Timberwolves.

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.
LEAD: A panel of Federal judges has refused to let Louisiana resume enforcing an old criminal law against abortion, saying the 1855 statute had been superseded by newer laws.
LEAD: The highest-ranking officer involved in the latest attempt to overthrow President Corazon C. Aquino was arrested today, the Philippine military authorities said.

LEAD: It now seems clear that the main reason that the Soviet military stormed Baku on the morning of Jan. 20 was to prevent the Communist government of the Azerbaijan republic from falling, much as several national Governments in Eastern Europe have fallen in recent months under the pressure of popular uprisings.
LEAD: A TAXICAB here was suddenly halted at an intersection as a parade, with horns blaring, knees pumping and bright parasols undulating, made its Orphic way down St. Charles Street.
LEAD: NOT every 21-year-old college student can say he owns a string of harness horses. But then, not every college student has a mother who operates a chain of Chinese restaurants.

LEAD: Although the year-end holidays are long gone, letters sent to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund last week continued to relate ways in which people were moved by Christmas and the New Year to reach out to others.
LEAD: WHEN Michael Jackson appeared recently at movie theaters, singing and dancing on the screen, delighted audiences cheered.

LEAD: Many credit market analysts say the gloom in the bond markets, prompted by an unexpectedly large increase in long-term interest rates, is not likely to evaporate quickly. As a result, yields could rise further, they said.

LEAD: On the eve of the submission of President Bush's new budget, his budget director, Richard G. Darman, today defended the size of the military budget, the proposed cut in the capital gains tax and the Administration's opposition to a reduction in the Social Security tax.

LEAD: From a compound for lepers to the outer fringes of the encroaching desert, Pope John Paul II journeyed today among West Africa's poor and afflicted, urging them not to yield to ''despair, pessimism or passivity.''
LEAD: More than 1,000 municipal workers and administrators will lose their city-owned cars this year as part of the continuing austerity program called for by Mayor David N. Dinkins.

LEAD: A bit more than 10 years after it brought out the Walkman, the Sony Corporation has provided a glimpse of one of the device's most offbeat descendants: the Data Discman, for people who would rather jog through the park reading encyclopedia entries than listening to Simon and Garfunkel.

LEAD: Elizabeth Leah Marks, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Marks of New York, and Paul Andrew Taylor, a son of Marjorie Taylor of Newton, Mass., and the late Manuel Taylor, were married yesterday. Rabbi Marc Angel officiated at Congregation Shearith Israel in New York.
LEAD: A gay Episcopal priest ordained just last Dec. 16 has been forced to resign as director of a Hoboken ministry to homosexuals because of comments he made questioning celibacy and monogamy.

LEAD: Lloyd Richards, the dean of the Yale School of Drama and artistic director of the Yale Repertory Theater, will leave both posts in June 1991, Yale University's president, Benno C. Schmidt Jr., announced yesterday.

LEAD: Since the 1940's, Roland Petit has amused and amazed audiences by combining the refinement of classical ballet with the extravagance of the Parisian music hall. Some of this French choreographer's productions have been lofty. Others have been saucy. Most have been unpredictable.

LEAD: My political philosophy will outlast Communism, even outlast capitalism. I have come to believe in improvisationism, the politics of dealing dazzlingly with the present.
LEAD: CONTINENTAL AIRLINES abruptly dismissed Ayer as its advertising agency on Friday and said it would put its account into a formal review involving four or five agencies.

LEAD: An avalanche prompted officials to close the Jackson Hole Ski Resort today, but no one was injured, officials said. The resort was closed for the day after the avalanche at 1:10 P.M. in an area called the Headwall, said Mike McCollister, director of operations. About 50 searchers with tracking dogs sifted through the snow for three hours and determined no one had been trapped.

LEAD: Four American psychoanalysts are to teach in the Soviet Union, the first such exchange in at least a decade. Organized by DR. ARNOLD M. ROTHSTEIN, program chairman of the American Psychoanalytic Association, the group will teach classes to 200 Soviet psychiatrists for one week, beginning April 23.
LEAD: A top executive at Apple Computer Inc. has resigned in what could be the start of an overhaul of the company's American sales and marketing organization, industry officials said this weekend.
LEAD: MOST college coaches no doubt would revel in a system wherein, by simply asking a computer, they could find just the scholar-athlete they need.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A long-awaited study of malpractice in New York hospitals, perhaps the most comprehensive ever conducted in the United States, concludes that thousands of hospital deaths and tens of thousands of injuries are tied to negligence each year but that relatively few victims seek recourse in the courts.
LEAD: Manuel Antonio Noriega, the fallen Panamanian leader, was transferred from the Federal courthouse to a Federal prison south of Miami tonight, the warden said.

LEAD: If an opponent opens the bidding, there is an argument for stretching to a borderline game. The declarer will have considerable information about the location of the opposing high cards, and the opponents will have defensive problems: One of them will be very weak, and virtually entryless.

LEAD: A spokesman for Viking Penguin, the publisher of the novel ''The Satanic Verses,'' denied today that it had told Salman Rushdie, the author of the book, that it would not bring out a paperback edition.

LEAD: DDB Needham, a unit of the Omnicom Group, has increased its presence in Canada through the acquisition of Carder Gray Advertising of Toronto, which it will merge with DDB Needham Canada. The new agency, to be called Carder Gray DDB Needham Advertising, will have billings of $85 million, with $55 million of that coming from Carder Gray.
LEAD: * Marine Transport Lines Inc., Secaucus, N.J., a bulk shipping company, announced the resignation of Dirk Langeveld, its executive vice president and chief operating officer.
LEAD: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that the Nicaraguan Government had reversed its position and would allow American Congressmen to observe the February elections.

LEAD: Two young men in Bronco colors - orange-and-blue caps, orange-and-blue sweaters and orange-and-blue-painted faces - sat behind an end zone in the Superdome today, took some photographs and watched the game. And cheered early. Very early.
LEAD: Karsten Manufacturing Corporation, makers of the controversial Ping Eye 2-irons, has dropped a $100 million lawsuit that threatened the future authority of the United States Golf Association.

LEAD: Israeli and East German officials are to begin preliminary talks on Monday aimed at establishing the first diplomatic ties between the two nations, the Foreign Ministry said today. But first the two sides must resolve longstanding disagreements over the Nazi genocide.

LEAD: In a court battle over the future of Peach Lake, two suburban imperatives are colliding in this remote corner of Westchester County: the need for affordable housing and the yearning for open spaces.

LEAD: Vinson Cole's performances in opera and oratorio have been frequent and notable over the last decade. Mr. Cole, a lyric tenor, was a regular at the New York City Opera in the early 1980's, and he joined the Metropolitan Opera roster in 1987. He has made recordings with Herbert von Karajan and Carlo Maria Giulini.

LEAD: Armenian and Azerbaijani partisans began withdrawing from a key battlefront today and agreed to discuss extending the truce between the two competing nationalist groups to other parts of the volatile region, spokesmen reported.

LEAD: Poland's Communist Party, after ruling the country for 45 years, voted to dissolve itself. LEAD: Randon A. Samelson, the chairman of Orange-Co. Inc., said Friday that his company had lowered its stake in the Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation to 5.9 percent from 12.7 percent.

LEAD: Bernard J. Ferguson, a lawyer and former president of the Queens County Bar Association, died on Saturday at Mary Immaculate Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived in Bayside, Queens, and had previously been a resident of Flushing for more than 60 years.

LEAD: Most first-time visitors to this famous vantage point on the Panama Canal, eight miles from the Pacific, come away dazzled by the majesty of the 51.2-mile waterway and the near-miraculous ingenuity and sacrifice that went into its construction more than 75 years ago.

LEAD: The number of working United States oil and gas rigs continued to decline last week, dropping by 27, to a total of 937, Baker Hughes Inc. reported. LEAD: The Stride Rite Corporation announced it had rejected a $900 million takeover bid from a group of investors, declaring the company would best be served by pursuing an independent strategy for growth. Stride Rite, the leading children's shoe maker in the country, received the $32-a-share offer in December from a group led by Walsh, Greenwood & Company, a Greenwich, Conn., investment concern.

LEAD: Much of ''Women and Wallace'' can sound like the intensely earnest confession of an 18-year-old. Why not? It is. Jonathan Marc Sherman was just that age when he wrote the play, which went on to become a 1988 winner in the Young Playwrights Festival in New York. Tonight at 10 on Channel 13, the ''American Playhouse'' series is presenting ''Women and Wallace'' in an adaptation of a version originally done for Playwrights Horizons Off Broadway.

LEAD: Has any film maker ever worked harder to win his audience's affections than Mike Jittlov, the writer, director, co-producer and star of ''The Wizard of Speed and Time''? On the evidence of Mr. Jittlov's world-class home movie, it hardly seems possible that anyone has. Mr. Jittlov, for whom this is clearly a labor of love as well as a Herculean effort, attempts every conceivable trick in the special-effects book in order to wow his viewers, and at times the results are literally dizzying.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Why don't Americans vote? While other parts of the world edge closer to democracy, America's democracy is shrinking. Reflecting a steady decline in participation, barely half the voting-age population took part in the 1988 Presidential election - the worst turnout in 64 years. The uninspiring campaign surely didn't help.

LEAD: Coral S. Potter, an actor with the Jean Cocteau Repertory Theater for 17 years, died of lung cancer on Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 49 years old. Mr. Potter had been a member of the Cocteau's resident acting company since its second season in 1972. His many credits included ''The Golem,'' ''The Duchess of Malfi,'' ''Waiting for Godot,'' ''The Cenci,'' ''Hamlet,'' ''Ghosts,'' ''Twelfth Night,'' ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' ''Rhinoceros'' and ''Volpone.

LEAD: The American Express Company said Monday that its unit for processing information for mutual funds had acquired a mutual-fund transfer agency from the Mellon Bank Corporation. The Boston-based American Express unit, Shareholder Services Group Inc., acquired Mellon Mutal Fund Services Group for an undisclosed price.

LEAD: Though the Juilliard School's series called Focus 1990, the World of Arnold Schoenberg, might appear to be another crash course in 20th-century musical history, its real goals may lie beyond the scope of a thumbnail survey. LEAD: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., which was assembled by a succession of brash, savvy leaders into the nation's second-largest brokerage, began a new era yesterday as a top executive from the American Express Company took the corporate reins.
LEAD: Boys who are wildly aggressive are the focus of an intensive new effort by psychologists to set them straight while they are still young.

LEAD: Trying to chip away at vital prosecution evidence, John Gotti's chief counsel appeared yesterday to concede tacitly that Mr. Gotti was heard on tapes directing affairs for the Gambino organization, reputed to be the largest crime family in the nation.
LEAD: The eight-member crew of a Honduran freighter was detained Tuesday after Federal agents seized 1,100 pounds of cocaine found aboard the ship about 400 miles southwest of Miami, officials said.

LEAD: Mirza Abdul Baqi Beg, a professor of physics at Rockefeller University who helped verify that elementary particles like protons and neutrons are made up of smaller entities known as quarks, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 55 years old.
LEAD: SIR GEORG SOLTI has commissioned four new works for his 22d, and final, season with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, which will also be the orchestra's 100th.

LEAD: An American soldier who fled to East Germany in 1959, fearing that an accident in which he was involved would land him in the stockade, saw his family on Tuesday for the first time in three decades and was then taken away as an Army deserter.

LEAD: Grosvenor Dana, a retired shipping executive, died of injuries sustained last Thursday when he was struck by a hit-and-run driver near his home in Mount Vernon, N.Y. He died on Sunday at Mount Vernon Hospital at the age of 88.
LEAD: A Navajo tribal judge today ordered Peter MacDonald Sr., the suspended Navajo chairman, to face three criminal trials instead of a single trial on 107 criminal counts.

LEAD: After a four-month search, John F. Grundhofer has been named chairman, president and chief executive of the troubled First Bank System Inc. of Minneapolis. Mr. Grundhofer, 51, had been a vice chairman of the Wells Fargo Bank.

LEAD: John Cardinal O'Connor yesterday strongly defended the Bishop who last week said that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was ''in serious risk of going to hell'' for his support of abortion rights. The Bishop's views, the Cardinal said, are consistent with church teaching.

LEAD: PRO BASKETBALL 76ers Capture 9th Straight Charles Barkley had 31 points and 16 rebounds as Philadelphia won its ninth consecutive game, scoring a 112-108 victory over the Pacers on Indiana's home court last night. Reggie Miller led Indiana with 26 points. (AP) Pistons 133, Bullets 109: Mark Aguirre scored 12 of his 25 points in Detroit's runaway second quarter against visiting Washington.
LEAD: At a decidedly capitalist gathering at a resort here in the desert, eight people in the personal computer industry in the Soviet Union met informally this week with their American counterparts.

LEAD: Paul Tagliabue, the commissioner of the National Football League, said yesterday that he would permit Keith Millard of the Minnesota Vikings to play on Sunday in the Pro Bowl in Hawaii, but that he would then meet sometime after the game in his league office with the tackle, who was recently selected as the league's defensive player of 1989.

LEAD: THE acquisition of a 16.53 percent stake in National Intergroup Inc. by a New York investment partnership has again put pressure on the troubled Pittsburgh-based holding company, which has a pharmaceutical distribution business and owns 50 percent of the National Steel Corporation.

LEAD: The British Government said this week that security forces might have engaged in a campaign to discredit the Irish Republican Army in the 1970's. It said it would reopen the case of a former British Army officer who says he was unfairly dismissed for seeking to end his part in the effort.
LEAD: The Alice Paul Centennial Foundation has completed the purchase of Miss Paul's birthplace here, said a spokeswoman for the foundation, Janet Tegley.

LEAD: Burton R. Lifland, the chief judge of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, approved a plan to allow Eastern Airlines to spend $50 million from a special fund to help meet its operating expenses.

LEAD: Cuba accused the United States Coast Guard of firing on a Cuban-chartered freighter off the coast of Mexico today while Washington explained that the attack was intended to disable the Panamanian-registered vessel after it refused to stop for a drug search.

LEAD: The Westchester County Executive said today that layoff notices would go out to 455 county employees starting on Thursday. But county officials said that it was uncertain how many would eventually be forced from their jobs to balance the county's budget, or which programs and services would be cut.
LEAD: Seeking to secure guarantees against collusion in a new labor contract, baseball players yesterday rejected the owners' proposal on collusion and the owners' negotiators withdrew it.

While the Senate is often the forum for fiercely partisan debate, there is something about a birthday that makes even political adversaries wax mellow. Such was the case last Tuesday when Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the 65-year-old Democratic leader, rose to wish a happy birthday to his Republican counterpart, Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, who had just turned 58. Their remarks, unabashedly sentimental, tell something about the two men who come from different political parties but nevertheless have become fast friends. Here are excerpts of their remarks: Senator Byrd:Mr. President, today is an outstanding day in the life of a truly fine and capable U.S. Senator. The majority leader of the Senate today experiences one of those days that he and I - I should only speak for myself - increasing desire not to see come around.

Colleges across the nation are threatened with the loss of millions of dollars in basketball television revenue because of overexposure of the game this season and the resultant large drop in television ratings, according to some college administrators and television executives. The ratings have declined while the rights fees have more than doubled in the last year or two. "I don't know if our conference's TV packager is going to be able to pay," said Frank Broyles, athletic director at Arkansas of the Southwest Conference. "It has us worried."

The Census Bureau said today that there had been a rapid increase in poverty from 1979 to 1982, even if the value of food stamps, public housing, Medicare and Medicaid benefits was counted as income The Government does not include such noncash benefits when it calculates the number of people whose income falls below the poverty level. Reagan Administration officials, including David A. Stockman, Director of the Office of Management and Budget, have often asserted that that practice has the effect of inflating official poverty figures. Congress asked t he bureau to compare poverty figures using both methods of calculation. Counting only cash income, there were 26.1 million poor people in 1979 and 34.4 million in 1982. But if the full market value of noncash benefits had been counted as income, there would have been 15.1 million poor people in 1979 and 22.9 million in 1982, the bureau said.

LEAD: WHEN a circuit breaker governing a household electrical circuit trips or a fuse blows, power to the circuit is immediately shut off to reduce the chance of fire and injury from electric shock. LEAD: WHEN Kenneth Smith was a student at the Cranbrook Academy of Art in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., he discovered several examples of furniture by the Finnish architect Eliel Saarinen in the school's basement.
LEAD: THE 150-year-old weeping Camperdown elm in Prospect Park in Brooklyn stands a mere 12 feet high, but its intricate pattern of branches etches a 25-foot circle.
LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's recognition that pressure is growing for German reunification was seized upon in West Germany today as the lifting of the last major obstacle to unity.
LEAD: David N. Dinkins was Felix G. Rohatyn's second, maybe third, choice last year to be mayor of New York City. Now Mr. Rohatyn pays Mayor Dinkins what appears to be the ultimate compliment.

LEAD: President Bush rightly asks Congress to remove an ignominious blot on the good name and credit of the United States. His new budget seeks full payment of U.S. dues to 51 international organizations, including the United Nations. He also seeks approval of a five-year plan to cover back dues to the U.N.

LEAD: The Northrop Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell two office buildings, one of which houses its corporate headquarters, and another 53-acre site. The price of the sales is more than $250 million.

LEAD: An article yesterday on a children's opera about crack at the Symphony Space in Manhattan referred incorrectly to Lizandra De La Cruz, the student on whose play the show is based. She attends the PACE Academy for Gifted Students at Junior High School 118 in the East Tremont section of the Bronx.

LEAD: The Arts & Entertainment Network seems a bit nervous about ''27 Wagons Full of Cotton,'' the Tennessee Williams play that concludes (tonight at 9) the first batch of monthly one-acters being presented on the new ''American Playwrights Theater.'' Although the first to be produced for the series, this play is the last of four to be shown.

LEAD: A production of the Kurt Weill and Bertolt Brecht choral ballet ''Seven Deadly Sins,'' featuring the soprano Teresa Stratas, has been postponed from its scheduled April opening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

LEAD: Senior Government officials said today that they ''fully expect'' to reach an agreement with the United States this year for the largest withdrawal of American military personnel from South Korea since the end of the Vietnam War.
LEAD: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that profits fell nearly 33 percent in the fourth quarter of 1989 but rose almost 4 percent for the year, a third consecutive record.

LEAD: NL Industries, the Houston-based commodity chemical maker that has been seeking to maximize the value of its investment in the Georgia Gulf Corporation, announced today that it intends to make a $45-a-share cash tender offer for the Atlanta-based chemical company by next Wednesday.

LEAD: The goal of the 1,633 delegates who attended the congress of the Polish Communist Party last weekend was to dissolve the party, shed its Stalinist skin and emerge as a modern social democratic party.

LEAD: This time, Dick Steinberg promises, the Jets are prepared for Plan B since the future of the club is not tied to the 37 men the team had on the list of protected players it submitted yesterday to the National Football League.
LEAD: KPMG Peat Marwick, the world's largest accounting firm, announced yesterday that it had sold its executive search operation to the unit's management.

LEAD: The collapse of the real estate market in Arizona claimed another victim today when Federal regulators seized control of Merabank, the state's largest savings and loan institution, from its parent company, the Pinnacle West Capital Corporation.
LEAD: After five losing sessions, stock prices rose yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 47.30 points, or 1.9 percent higher, to 2,590.54.
LEAD: A group that includes Robert M. Bass, the Texas financier, has offered $270 million to acquire control of The St. Petersburg Times in Florida.

Even Alfredo Kraus, one of the company's principal assets these days, was powerless to raise the performance to a level of passable mediocrity.

LEAD: Nigel Lawson, who resigned abruptly as Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer in October, has been named a director of Barclays Bank P.L.C., the bank said today. Mr. Lawson, 57 years old, will continue as a Conservative Party Member of Parliament and also serve as a part-time adviser to the bank. Barclays declined to disclose how much he would be paid.

LEAD: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico urged the industrialized nations of the West today not to forget Mexico and the rest of Latin America as they move to help the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe.

LEAD: Some are anxious, some can hardly wait, but it seems that everyone here is waiting for the West Germans.

The company also said it expected growth in its second quarter, which ends on March 31, to be comparable to its first, in which its revenues grew 6 percent and its earnings declined 11 percent from the previous year.

LEAD: Gov. William A. O'Neill today ordered a 2 percent budget cut for most state agencies starting April 1, following a State Comptroller's report putting the state's deficit at $90.1 million, up from $65 million just last month.

LEAD: ONE of the most talked-about commercials of recent months is the spot for Honda in which a man visiting an art gallery examines an Accord that is hanging in front of him like a painting - and then, defying gravity, he climbs in and drives the car right off the wall.

LEAD: Eli Lilly & Company said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings grew by double digits over the previous year, helped by higher unit sales in United States and foreign markets. The Upjohn Company, meanwhile, said it had a $118 million loss in the quarter, reflecting the costs of a previously announced restructuring.

LEAD: Airborne Express, which has refrained from active participation in the advertising wars fought by its rivals the United Parcel Service and the Federal Express Corporation, is joining the fray, with Mandelbaum Mooney Ashley as its new marketing partner. The $15 million San Francisco agency would not disclose billings for the account.

LEAD: Allen Barke, former chief executive of the British subsidiary of Ford, died on Monday. He was 86 years old. The cause of his death was not given. Mr. Barke became director of Ford's product division in 1959 when the company's plants were being increasingly hit by wildcat strikes. In 1965 he contracted hepatitis, and soon after his health forced him to resign.

LEAD: With an air of low-budget pomp and protocol, political insurgents from four Soviet republics converged on this Baltic capital today to begin peace talks aimed at resolving the Armenian-Azerbaijani civil conflict.

LEAD: Dennis McIntyre, a playwright whose work examined the ills of American society, died of stomach cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 47 years old. Mr. McIntyre's latest play, ''Established Price,'' was staged at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven last month by Arvin Brown with a cast that included Jason Robards.

LEAD: At Lincoln Center, ARLENE SHULER will be dancing behind the scenes as the new vice president for planning and development. Ms. Shuler, 42, has an impressive record of jobs in the arts, including serving as executive director of Volunteer Lawyers for the Arts. And she was a dancer with the Joffrey Ballet for four years.

LEAD: For the four children still being treated at North Shore University Hospital after surviving the crash of Avianca Flight 52 last week, these are days of confusion and pain, of waiting for broken bones to heal and of trying to understand what happened.

LEAD: After three days of ferocious fighting that left at least 53 people dead and 200 wounded, Lebanon's warring Christian factions said today that they had agreed to a truce in a Christian enclave north of the city.

LEAD: Hoping to encourage the release of Nelson Mandela from a South African prison, the White House announced today that President Bush will invite Mr. Mandela and President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa to pay separate visits to Washington should the anti-apartheid leader be freed.

LEAD: A new 23-story condominium called the Grosvenor House, at 22 West 15th Street between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, may not have all the English embellishments of the London hotel of the same name. But it apparently has enough to help it sell fairly well in a generally slow market. In nine months, well over 50 percent of the units, 77 of 134, have been sold.
LEAD: On the ice, the Minnesota North Stars' power play ranks seventh in a 21-team league. In the front office, their current power play ranks among the most threatening in professional sports.

LEAD: In a surprise move that will reduce its car-making capacity by about 20 percent, the Chrysler Corporation said today that it would permanently close its suburban St. Louis car assembly plant, laying off about 3,700 workers.

LEAD: Henry Baker, a New York real-estate broker for more than 75 years and believed to be the oldest active broker in the field in the United States, died of pneumonia yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 99 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: ''You always have some people who don't want to get with the program,'' Bob Sefchek observed with a shake of his head as he nudged his van through the streets of this neat suburban community, behind a work crew putting recycling baskets on the steps and porches of 1,200 homes.

LEAD: N.B.A. Houston Offense Catches Fire Akeem Olajuwon had 23 points and 7 blocked shots, and Otis Thorpe scored 30 points as the Houston Rockets enjoyed their best offensive output this season, beating the Chicago Bulls at home by 139-112 last night while never trailing. All five Houston starters scored in double figures.

LEAD: Herbert Whyman, a Manhattan lawyer for more than half a century, died of bladder cancer on Wednesday at his home in Roslyn Heights, L.I. He was 76 years old.

LEAD: John J. Phelan Jr.'s tenure at the helm of the New York Stock Exchange coincided with one of the most turbulent periods in the history of the United States stock market. Yet as Wall Street executives assessed his six years as chairman, there was almost universal praise for his leadership and the stature he lent an organization that in many ways came of age on his watch.

LEAD: The painter Bob Thompson died in 1966 at the age of 28, having spent less than a decade getting all he could out of the New York art scene and the great museums of Italy and France, and putting it to immediate use. It's hard to say if he reached absolute maturity as an artist; the exhibition of his work from the early 1960's at the Vanderwoude Tananbaum Gallery is often uneven.

LEAD: Presenting a preliminary New York City budget that would not have struck Edward I. Koch as unfamiliar, the Budget Director for Mayor David N. Dinkins acknowledged yesterday that ''there aren't a whole lot of brand-new, unthought-of solutions.''

LEAD: The indoor track season is half over, and Roger Kingdom has not run a race all winter. Set back by the flu, he has been spending as much time at awards banquets as in training. LEAD: The Advertising column of Business Day on Wednesday, and a correction in this space yesterday referring to it, misstated the measurement by which the 286 computer chip processes data. It does so in bundles of 16 bits, not bytes or characters. A bit is the smallest unit of information; eight bits equal one byte, the minimum necessary in a computer to define a character (like a letter or a number).

LEAD: Only three of the four Zairian stars who founded Les Quatre Etoiles -the singers Wuta Mayi and Nyboma and the guitarist Syran Mbenza -were on hand when the group performed on Friday night at Kilimanjaro; in the seven-man group, an Angolan bassist, Miguel, deputized for Bopol. LEAD: No wedding reception is complete without a cake. Spring and summer weddings are being planned now, and the cake is worth researching. Pastry shops quote prices according to the number of servings and the elaborateness of the decorations. Catering halls and hotels usually charge a flat per-person price for a wedding cake, often including it as part of a package.

LEAD: In a sharp departure from the Bush Administration's cautious statements on China, a confidential State Department report says there were pervasive, severe violations of human rights in Beijing, Tibet and other parts of China last year.

LEAD: With the requisite amount of hype and hoopla, the principals of Mars in New York, the club with the ''Bladerunner'' look at Tenth Avenue and 13th Street, have opened a branch along Bangkok's street of shame, Patpong, and it is the most wholesome establishment in the neighborhood.

LEAD: This year's Focus series at the Juilliard School has been exploring the world of Arnold Schoenberg through his own works and works by composers who influenced him or who were influenced by him. In the fifth installment, on Thursday evening at the Juilliard Theater, the student musicians offered a group of harmonically and dramatically edgy works that Schoenberg composed between 1941 and 1950, as well as gentler scores by Luigi Dallapiccola and Earl Kim.
LEAD: For men, Valentine's Day traditionally brings forth ties, red suspenders or perhaps a silver picture frame.

LEAD: Garth Fagan's ''Easter Freeway Processional'' may well become a modern-dance classic. The dance, created in 1983, offers a clear and vibrant look into Mr. Fagan's unusual choreographic style and uses Philip Glass's music in an equally fresh way. Mysterious emotion bubbles through its fairly formalistic surface.

LEAD: A box on Jan. 21 with an article about Harry J. Gray, head of American Medical International Inc., misidentified a business professor at Emory University who has studied older executives. He is Jeffrey Sonnenfeld.
LEAD: Asserting that Indians are the best guardians of the rain forest, Colombia's Government has recognized Indian land rights to half the Colombian Amazon.

LEAD: There were two Mark Taylors on view Thursday at St. Mark's Church, where Mark Taylor and Friends presented a program of four new and recent dances. One Mr. Taylor was a choreographer who creates dances that lope and canter easily through open space, with a sanitized look that is very far from the irony and ambiguity so fashionable now in dance.

LEAD: An American Airlines 727-200 jetliner with 63 people aboard landed safely at O'Hare International Airport on Friday after the pilot reported steering problems. The flight originated in Omaha. The pilot brought the airliner in with a back-up hydraulic system. No one was hurt.

LEAD: Mephistopheles cavorted on stage Thursday night in a new Hal Prince production of Gounod's ''Faust'' at the Metropolitan Opera. One audience member got into the mood by lacquering her hair into a devil's horn. Up in the boxes, an enormous ruby-and-diamond butterfly that could have flown out of Marguerite's garden was perched on Judy Taubman's shoulder.

LEAD: CHICKEN SOUP SEEMS TO BELONG to New York. It is a curative, a panacea, a culinary medium. Its aroma rushes from the doors of Jewish delis and waves like steamy ribbons behind the bicycles that deliver Chinese food throughout the city. The scent of chicken soup lingers over kitchen stoops in the Italian section of Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, and above the homes of Greek families in Astoria, Queens.

LEAD: WHEN Gov. William A. O'Neill steps up to the podium under the Capitol dome on Wednesday to present his 10th budget to the General Assembly, he will speak in numbers. With a shortfall in the current state budget that is estimated at more than $90 million, the Governor is expected to ask for millions of dollars in spending cuts in dozens of state programs and increases for a rare and scattered few.

LEAD: WHEN a friend presented me with a giant bag of dried porcini mushrooms he had bought at the Rome airport, duty free, I thought it would be years before I got around to finishing them. But soon I found myself using them more and more often, in a variety of different ways. These powerful mushrooms have a strong meaty flavor that is wonderful in sauces, stews and impromptu pasta dishes.

LEAD: While the Frankfurt Bund has been the focus of this year's excitement over investing in the future of Eastern Europe, the Vienna Bourse has quietly crept higher and higher, setting nine new record highs. And this after 1989, a year it outperformed every other major market.

LEAD: In a speech before the South African Parliament on Friday, President F .W . de Klerk announced measures designed to create a climate conducive to negotiating an end to apartheid. They include the legalization of the African National Congress and the release of its imprisoned leader, Nelson Mandela.

Brown of Herndon, Va., and Enrico Marziali of Washington. An April wedding is planned. Miss Crowther, who is employed by the University of Virginia in Charlottesville, Va., graduated from Fluvanna County High School in Palmyra, Va., and the Woodrow Wilson Center in Fishersville, Va.

LEAD: Mel Lewis, the jazz drummer and orchestra leader, died of melanoma Friday evening at Cabrini Hospice in Manhattan. He was 60 years old.

LEAD: There have been more than a dozen books written about Josephine Baker. She herself wrote five autobiographies, a novel and a collection of fairy tales that expressed her vision of universal brotherhood. Since she died in 1975 at the age of 69, at least seven books by other people have been published.

LEAD: Most of the 221 Soviet Jewish immigrants boarding El Al Flight 368 from Budapest to Tel Aviv in the early hours of Wednesday morning said they were fleeing a vicious paradox, the dark side of glasnost.

LEAD: Canadian immigration officials and welfare agencies are struggling to keep up with a surge of Eastern European travelers who are using a refueling stop at the airport in Gander, Newfoundland, to apply for entry to Canada as refugees.

LEAD: May wedding plans for Jacqueline Beth Lippman and Geoffrey Allen Drucker have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lippman of Watchung, N.J. Mr. Drucker is the son of Dr. William D. Drucker of Milwaukee and Mrs. William H. Gindin of Princeton, N.J.

A May wedding is planned. Miss Braun, 24 years old, is a senior account executive at Hill & Knowlton in the public relations firm's New York headquarters.

LEAD: Nearly a decade after President Ronald Reagan dismissed 11,400 striking air-traffic controllers across the nation, the New York metropolitan region is still short of fully trained controllers, although the number of flights they have to guide through the crowded skies has soared 58 percent.

LEAD: LIKE a string of discarded jewel boxes, three exquisite but decaying railroad stations of the old Harlem Branch of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad in the Bronx are approaching the point where restoration may not be possible. Built in 1908 and closed in 1937, they are beautiful even in their disintegration.

Instead of hurtling about inside their office towers and shopping arcades, people careen along the sidewalks in their rush to get somewhere. LEAD: WHEN Big East basketball returned to the University of Connecticut last Saturday after a four-year absence, it was to a brand-new $28.5 million arena and a raucous sellout crowd of 8,241. Scalpers, who finally had a reason to do business in Storrs, were asking $40 for an $8 ticket. Even the Governor was there.
LEAD: It is possible to spend a pleasant afternoon in a quiet seaside village without leaving New York City.

LEAD: For St. John's, a third consecutive Big East Conference loss was now the least of their problems. A 7-point second-half lead that evaporated more because of their own failures than the success of their opponents had become a footnote.

LEAD: If Handel's ''Messiah'' heralded the dawn of oratorio worship in England, and to a great degree in Victorian America, Felix Mendelssohn's ''Elijah'' struck high noon with its premiere at the Birmingham Festival in 1846. Even in these more secular times, ''Elijah'' appeals, because its beauty and dramatic vitality ring true.

LEAD: MY Aunt Dorothy was trying to decide whether to take me on the cruise that stops in Borneo or the one that stops in Kuala Lumpur. I told her that I was concerned about Borneo as it has more than 150 kinds of snakes and our friend Lucille was chased by a mongoose and grabbed by an orangutan the last time she was in Borneo and Lucille said, don't go.
LEAD: St. Nicholas of Tolentine upset Christ the King by 71-63 tonight in the opening game of the inaugural Metro Classic.

LEAD: MURDER is a crime and thou shalt not commit it. Everyone knows that. Everyone who reads a newspaper also knows that people murder other people.

LEAD: Syracuse University trustees last week approved a cost increase of almost 10 percent for next year despite a weeklong student boycott of the university's student center, bookstores and snack bars.

LEAD: An article on page 7 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the monologuist Eric Bogosian misidentifies the theater that first staged his show ''Drinking in America.'' It was American Place Theater.

LEAD: Instead of just single-mindedly fighting the proposed closing of five Bay Area naval bases, local officials here are also considering how to acccomplish the historic task of converting to a peacetime economy with the least immediate pain and the most long-range promise.

LEAD: WALL STREET WOMEN By Anne B. Fisher. 177 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

LEAD: N.H.L. Canadiens 1, Sabres 0: Stephane Richer's 32d goal of the season ended a tie at 15:48 of the second period as the Montreal Canadiens, playing at home, edged the Buffalo Sabres by 1-0 last night. The Montreal goaltender, Patrick Roy, made 30 saves in earning his second shutout of the season.

LEAD: After losing most of the notorious McMartin Preschool child abuse case, the Los Angeles prosecutor Lael Rubin whined that the defendants ''were lucky.'' The jury acquitted Peggy Buckey and her son, Ray, on 52 counts and deadlocked on 13 counts against the son. Ms. Rubin's graceless, unprofessional remark ignored the prosecution's ineptitude, which helped produce an inconclusive 30-month trial after a five-year investigation.
LEAD: A two-day-old baby boy was kidnapped yesterday from a Brooklyn Hospital and a young woman who had been chatting with the mother earlier is being sought, the police said.

LEAD: The Los Angeles Clippers guard Gary Grant will undergo surgery tomorrow to repair a fractured and dislocated left ankle, and will most likely miss the rest of the season. Dr. Tony Daly will place a metal plate and screws in the joint to help it heal.

LEAD: A chemical engineer and a businessman have developed an air-conditioning system that runs on the principle of a gentle spring rain and uses no chlorofluorocarbons. The real trick, however, is that the water-based mists can soak up humidity as well as heat.
LEAD: SWEET TALK By Stephanie Vaughn. 194 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95.

LEAD: THE beginning of love stays in memory, a vivid freeze-frame amid the flux of the past. I fell for Italy one mild November morning, my first in Rome, when the street I was walking down opened suddenly upon the Colosseum. Confronted by the huge presence of a long-familiar icon, I gaped like a Visigoth fresh from the boondocks.
LEAD: No country, especially the U.S., can any longer avoid addressing the issue of German reunification.

LEAD: The composer Ezra Laderman celebrated his 65th birthday in June, but he is still collecting presents. The latest was a concert of his flute music, presented by the New York Flute Club last Sunday at Cami Hall. Mr. Laderman is an amateur flutist and has written a good deal of solo and chamber music for the instrument.

LEAD: EMERGENCY teams in fire departments, hospitals and other agencies spend many hours every year reviewing disaster plans, but when Avianca Flight 52 crashed Jan. 25 in Cove Neck, with 158 passengers and crew members aboard, the same people who had drilled repeatedly and prepared continually for disasters were in disbelief that a catastrophe of that magnitude had actually occurred.

LEAD: Educated as well as entertained by those British-made TV adaptations of English crime and mystery fiction that have become a staple feature of public-broadcasting and cable network programming, most American viewers can now distinguish at a glance their favorite detective heroes. This season alone, we have been matching wits with such distinctive sleuths as Agatha Christie's Hercule Poirot, John Mortimer's Rumpole of the Bailey and Dorothy L.

LEAD: LEADERS of the New York Legislature say they expect no major votes on abortion in this year's session. But somewhat paradoxically, the absence of such votes seems to make the issue loom all the larger in this fall's election.
LEAD: Eager to polish their image for elections this spring, Bulgaria's ruling Communists today chose an advocate of change as the country's new Prime Minister.

LEAD: THREE-LEGGED HORSE. By Ann Hood. (Bantam, Paper, $7.95.) Between the tuna casseroles, the women's magazines of yesteryear served up heart- and hearth-warming fiction. The spirit of that fiction, nicely adapted to the changing social patterns of the 1980's, suffuses ''Three-Legged Horse,'' Ann Hood's third novel, in which Abby Nash comes belatedly of age, shedding her immaturity in the person of her footloose husband, Zach, for whom the summer of 1969 will never end.

LEAD: Ethnic Albanian emigrants from the southern Yugoslav province of Kosovo say that contrary to official reports, the conflict in the area is not religious or ethnic but a struggle for freedom and democracy.

LEAD: The engagement of Katharine Hudson Ross and Charles Lee Johnson has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mrs. Andrew Rockefeller of Greenwich, Conn., and Henry Lawrence Ross of Rancho Mirage, Calif. Mr. Johnson is a son of Robertson Lee Johnson of Portland, Ore., and the late Mrs. Johnson.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Everett H. Erlick of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lorre Bert Erlick, to Anthony Pir Brenner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Brenner of New York. An October wedding is planned.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Q. Our master bedroom has six Thermopane windows. When the temperature outside drops below freezing, condensation forms on the inside of these windows and the water runs onto the sill. This room is the only one exposed to the outside on three sides and the only one with this problem. Our heat is set at 60 degrees during the night.

LEAD: Carol Gilligan's ideas are interesting, but it surprises me that they are considered radical or controversial (''Confident at 11, Confused at 16,'' by Francine Prose, Jan. 7). Is there a woman alive who is not aware of exactly when and how she learned that the rules are different for boys and girls?
LEAD: Darryl Strawberry's turbulent career took a dramatic turn yesterday when the 27-year-old outfielder entered the Smithers Center in Manhattan to treat what the Mets called an alcohol problem.

LEAD: Tables, chairs and lamps are crafted from branches; others are carved out of tree stumps and stone. Sofas, with deeply curved silhouettes and wild-colored fabrics, are often 20 feet long, and their grand presence almost fills a room. This furniture is not meant to shock. It's functional yet intentionally whimsical.

LEAD: In a trial that could help determine the pace of economic development across the West, the Federal Government is battling the Colorado authorities over control of the water from the Rocky Mountains.

LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have ratings. Prices are current. Michael's

LEAD: Any discussion of how to appreciate a 24-hour race (if the word ''appreciate'' can be applied to something that long) must dwell upon a baser instinct: the ability to enjoy watching someone else's car fall to pieces.

LEAD: LIKE all of the land in Westchester, it first belonged to the Indians. Then the pleasant acreage in Purchase was farmed by Quaker families who during the Revolution sheltered wounded from the Battle of White Plains in their nearby meetinghouse.

LEAD: The Knicks proved last night that even when their outside shooting is suspect, the offensive abilities of Patrick Ewing are enough to guide them to victory. They also proved that their mastery over the Pacers is still intact.

LEAD: Queen Elizabeth II brought the curtain down on the 14th Commonwealth Games today and the 11-day, 57-nation event closed in controversy as one of the world's best-known runners, John Walker, made a sad and angry exit in front of his home public.

LEAD: At the end of 1989, as chairman of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee, I issued a report that concluded our top economic policy priority in 1990 should be eliminating the Federal budget deficit. Unfortunately, the budget proposed by President Bush last week breaks no new ground in dealing with the deficit.
LEAD: A surgeon at a hospital here has implanted in a human an experimental device made of a slender, hollow bundle of fibers that works like a lung in supplying oxygen to the body.
LEAD: EXCUSE ME, SIR, would you like to play a game with us?''
LEAD: In the annals of biochemistry it would be hard to find a more enigmatic and intriguing substance than the neurotransmitting chemical called serotonin.

LEAD: Bob Gansler, the coach of the United States national soccer team, made it clear today that he was losing patience with players who have allowed peripheral issues, like contract disputes, to affect their preparation for the World Cup finals four months from now in Italy.

LEAD: Programs like the one by the Downtown Chamber and Opera Players at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday evening - ''Lost and Found: The Musical Legacy of Erwin Schulhoff and Kurt Weill'' - can easily devolve into didacticism, the more so in this case, since both composers had an ideological bent. But there was none of it here: simply a succession of solidly musical works, well and straightforwardly performed.

LEAD: Except for scientific or educational purposes, balloons should be eliminated from use outdoors. Of course there is a sense of excitement (as noted by Erwin Lewis, in his letter to the New Jersey editor on Dec. 17) felt by each of us when they float overhead. However, if only one bird or animal (including human) is injured through strangulation on the things, their use must be stopped.

LEAD: Q. Our master bedroom has six Thermopane windows. When the temperature outside drops below freezing, condensation forms on the inside of these windows and the water runs onto the sill. This room is the only one exposed to the outside on three sides and the only one with this problem. Our heat is set at 60 degrees during the night.
LEAD: A local emergency agency declared a low-level alert at a nuclear plant in central Pennsylvania today after a problem with cooling equipment developed. Officials said no radiation was released.
LEAD: Billy Owens scored 25 points, including 12 in a decisive 10-minute stretch in the first half, as Syracuse beat Florida State by 90-69 today.
LEAD: Your article ''Isolated Business Districts Facing New Economic Pressures'' [Jan. 21] caused me to write about the abuse of what was once so wonderful.
LEAD: An article last Sunday on the right to bear arms misstated the annual number of murders in the United States. In recent years there have been just over 20,000.

LEAD: Even as the Spenglerian twilight descends on Western civilization, it is good to know that youth is already sharpening its musical sensibilities in preparation for a new dawn. You may think this a suspect statement, but evidence to corroborate it does exist. At hand is an article that recently appeared on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times entitled ''We're Talking the Wrong Language to 'TV Babies.
